376 </a>

631 <a class="usa-button usa-button--unstyled" href="mailto:?subject=Information from the National Cancer Institute Web Site &body=I found this information on www.cancer.gov and I'd like to share it with you: https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq %0D%0A%0D%0A NCI's Web site, www.cancer.gov, provides accurate, up-to-date, comprehensive cancer information from the U.S. government's principal agency for cancer research. If you have questions or need additional information, we invite you to contact NCI's LiveHelp instant messaging service at https://livehelp.cancer.gov, or call the NCI's Contact Center 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237) (toll-free from the United States).">

745 <div class="resize-content">

746

747 <h1>

748Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer (PDQ®)–Health Professional Version</h1>

749

750 <div id="cgvBody">

751

752 <div class="summary-sections">

753

754 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

755

756 <h6>

757On This Page</h6>

758

759 <ul>

760

761 <li>

762<a href="#_4">

763General Information About Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</a>

764</li>

765

766 <li>

767<a href="#_116">

768Subsequent Neoplasms</a>

769</li>

770

771 <li>

772<a href="#_1360">

773Late Effects of the Cardiovascular System</a>

774</li>

775

776 <li>

777<a href="#_9">

778Late Effects of the Central Nervous System</a>

779</li>

780

781 <li>

782<a href="#_30">

783Late Effects of the Digestive System</a>

784</li>

785

786 <li>

787<a href="#_66">

788Late Effects of the Endocrine System</a>

789</li>

794</li>

795

799</li>

834

835

836 <div class="accordion">

837

838

839

840 <section id="_4">

841

842 <h2>

843General Information About Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer</h2>

844

845 <div id="_section_4" class="pdq-sections">

846<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

847<h6>

848In This Section</h6>

849<ul>

850<li>

851<a href="#_990_toc">

852Prevalence of Late Effects in Childhood Cancer Survivors</a>

853</li>

854<li>

855<a href="#_121_toc">

856Mortality<ul>

857<li>

858<a href="#_2000_toc">

859Survivors of adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancers</a>

860</li>

861</ul>

862</a>

863</li>

864<li>

865<a href="#_280_toc">

866Monitoring for Late Effects</a>

867</li>

868<li>

869<a href="#_123_toc">

870Resources to Support Survivor Care<ul>

871<li>

872<a href="#_1040_toc">

873Risk-based screening</a>

874</li>

875<li>

876<a href="#_1091_toc">

877Access to risk-based survivor care</a>

878</li>

879</ul>

880</a>

881</li>

882<li>

883<a href="#_287_toc">

884Transition to Survivor Care<ul>

885<li>

886<a href="#_950_toc">

887Long-term follow-up programs</a>

888</li>

889<li>

890<a href="#_952_toc">

891COG long-term follow-up guidelines for childhood and AYA cancer survivors</a>

892</li>

893</ul>

894</a>

895</li>

896</ul>

897</nav>

898<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

899<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-pdq">

900Go to Patient Version</a>

901</div>

902<p id="_279" tabindex="-1">

903During the past five decades, dramatic progress has been made in the development of curative therapies for pediatric malignancies. More than 80% of children with cancer who have access to contemporary therapies are expected to survive into adulthood.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9041</a>

905] The therapies responsible for this survival can also produce adverse, long-term, health-related outcomes, referred to as <strong>

906late effects</strong>

907, which appear months to years after completion of cancer treatment. </p>

908<p id="_1079" tabindex="-1">

909Many approaches have been used to study the very long-term morbidity associated with childhood cancer and its contribution to early mortality. These initiatives have used a spectrum of resources, including data from the following: </p>

910<div class="pdq-content-list">

911<ul id="_1080">

912<li>

913Population-based registries.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9142</a>

915,<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9163</a>

917]</li>

918<li>

919Self-reported outcomes (provided through large-scale cohort studies).[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

9204</a>

921,<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

9225</a>

923]</li>

924<li>

925Medical assessments.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9266</a>

927-<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9288</a>

929]</li>

930</ul>

931</div>

932<p id="_1081" tabindex="-1">

933High-quality data is needed to establish the occurrence of and risk profiles for late cancer treatment&#8211;related toxicity. The highest quality data typically comes from studies that report outcomes in survivors who have undergone medical assessments that provide well-characterized clinical statuses, treatment exposures, and specific late effects. Regardless of study methodology, it is important to consider selection and participation bias of the cohort studies in the context of the findings. </p>

934<section id="_990">

935<h3 id="_990_toc">

936Prevalence of Late Effects in Childhood Cancer Survivors</h3>

937<p id="_991" tabindex="-1">

938Late effects are common in adults who have survived childhood cancer. Their prevalence increases as time from cancer diagnosis elapses. Multi-institutional and population-based studies have shown excess risk of hospital-related morbidity among childhood and young adult cancer survivors compared with age- and sex-matched controls, with some evidence that this risk is disproportionately high among survivors of racial and ethnic minority populations.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9393</a>

940,<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

9419</a>

942-<a href="#cit/section_1.13">

94313</a>

944]</p>

945<p id="_1345" tabindex="-1">

946Among adults who were treated for cancer during childhood, late effects contribute to a high burden of morbidity. Research has shown the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

9474</a>

948,<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9496</a>

950,<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

9517</a>

952,<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

95314</a>

954-<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

95517</a>

956]</p>

957<div class="pdq-content-list">

958<ul id="_1346">

959<li>

96060% to more than 90% of survivors develop one or more chronic health conditions.</li>

961<li>

96220% to 80% of survivors experience severe or life-threatening complications during adulthood.</li>

963</ul>

964</div>

965<p id="_1836" tabindex="-1">

966The St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study aimed to describe the cumulative burden of cancer therapy using the cumulative burden metric, which incorporates multiple health conditions and recurrent events into a single metric that takes into account competing risks. By age 50 years, survivors in this cohort experienced an average of 17.1 chronic health conditions, 4.7 of which were severe/disabling, life threatening, or fatal.[<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

96716</a>

968] This finding contrasts with the cumulative burden in matched community controls, who experienced 9.2 chronic health conditions, 2.3 of which were severe/disabling, life threatening, or fatal (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1838">

969Figure 1</a>

970).[<a href="#cit/section_1.16">

97116</a>

972]</p>

973<p id="_1837" tabindex="-1">

974<figure id="figure_1838" class="image-center">

975<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/791436.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

976Enlarge</a>

977<img id="_1838" alt="Charts showing distribution of cumulative burden by age among childhood cancer survivors of specific pediatric cancer subtypes and community controls participating in St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study." title="Charts showing distribution of cumulative burden by age among childhood cancer survivors of specific pediatric cancer subtypes and community controls participating in St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/791436-750.jpg">

978<figcaption class="caption-container">

979Figure 1. Figure shows distribution of cumulative burden by age among childhood cancer survivors of specific pediatric cancer subtypes and community controls participating in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study. The cumulative burden at age 30 years and rate of cumulative burden growth is variable across cancer subtypes and organ systems. Reprinted from <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-lancet" title="https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-lancet">

980The Lancet</a>

981, Volume 390, Issue 10112, Bhakta N, Liu Q, Ness KK, Baassiri M, Eissa H, Yeo F, Chemaitilly W, Ehrhardt MJ, Bass J, Bishop MW, Shelton K, Lu L, Huang S, Li Z, Caron E, Lanctot J, Howell C, Folse T, Joshi V, Green DM, Mulrooney DA, Armstrong GT, Krull KR, Brinkman TM, Khan RB, Srivastava DK, Hudson MM, Yasui Y, Robison LL, The cumulative burden of surviving childhood cancer: an initial report from the St Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE), Pages 2569&#8211;2582, Copyright (2017), with permission from Elsevier.</figcaption>

982</figure>

983</p>

984<p id="_2791" tabindex="-1">

985St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study investigators compared the cumulative burden of chronic health conditions among 4,612 adolescent and young adult survivors at the ages of 18 years (the time of transition from pediatric to adult health care systems) and 26 years (the time of transition from family to individual health insurance plans) with that of 625 controls.[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

98618</a>

987]</p>

988<div class="pdq-content-list">

989<ul id="_2792">

990<li>

991Survivors at the age of 18 years experienced an average of 22.3 disabling conditions per 100 individuals versus 3.5 in controls, and 128.7 lower-severity conditions (at risk of progressing to higher-grade disabling conditions) versus 12.4 in controls. </li>

992<li>

993Survivors at the age of 26 years experienced an average of 40.3 disabling conditions per 100 individuals versus 5.7 in controls, and 240.5 lower-severity conditions versus 51.3 in controls.</li>

994<li>

995The cumulative burden of disabling, disease-specific conditions at the ages of 18 and 26 years was most notable for survivors of bone tumors (musculoskeletal: 99.9 and 121.70, respectively), soft tissue sarcomas (musculoskeletal: 49.5 and 54.1, respectively), and central nervous system (CNS) tumors (neurological: 24.7 and 36.8, respectively).</li>

996<li>

997The cumulative burden of lower-severity conditions (potentially amenable to intervention) at the ages of 18 and 26 years was most notable for neurological conditions across most cancer subgroups, with the highest cumulative burden in CNS tumor survivors (95.2 and 162.3, respectively).</li>

998<li>

999These findings highlight the importance of optimizing access to health care and health insurance as survivors age and can no longer participate in pediatric health care systems.</li>

1000</ul>

1001</div>

1002<p id="_1347" tabindex="-1">

1003The variability in prevalence is related to differences in the following:</p>

1004<div class="pdq-content-list">

1005<ul id="_1348">

1006<li>

1007Age and follow-up time of the cohorts studied.</li>

1008<li>

1009Methods and consistency of assessment (e.g., self-reported vs. risk-based medical evaluations).</li>

1010<li>

1011Treatment intensity and treatment era.</li>

1012</ul>

1013</div>

1014<p id="_1349" tabindex="-1">

1015<a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/ccss" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/ccss">

1016Childhood Cancer Survivor Study</a>

1017 (CCSS) investigators demonstrated that the elevated risk of morbidity and mortality among aging survivors in the cohort increases beyond the fourth decade of life. By age 50 years, the cumulative incidence of a self-reported severe, disabling, life-threatening, or fatal health condition was 53.6% among survivors, compared with 19.8% among a sibling control group. Among survivors who reached age 35 years without a previous severe, disabling, life-threatening, or fatal health condition, 25.9% experienced a new grade 3 to grade 5 health condition within 10 years, compared with 6.0% of healthy siblings (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1617">

1018Figure 2</a>

1019).[<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

10204</a>

1021] </p>

1022<p id="_1736" tabindex="-1">

1023The presence of serious, disabling, and life-threatening chronic health conditions adversely affects the health status of aging survivors. The greatest impact is on functional impairment and activity limitations. Predictably, chronic health conditions have been reported to contribute to a higher prevalence of emotional distress symptoms in adult survivors than in population controls.[<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

102419</a>

1025] Female survivors demonstrate a steeper trajectory of age-dependent decline in health status than do male survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

102620</a>

1027] The even-higher prevalence of late effects among cohorts evaluated by clinical assessments is related to the subclinical and undiagnosed conditions detected by screening and surveillance measures.[<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

10287</a>

1029]</p>

1030<p id="_1617" tabindex="-1">

1031<figure id="figure_1618" class="image-center">

1032<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/788250.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1033Enlarge</a>

1034<img id="_1618" alt="Charts showing the cumulative incidence of chronic health conditions by age among survivors and siblings." title="Charts showing the cumulative incidence of chronic health conditions by age among survivors and siblings." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/788250-750.jpg">

1035<figcaption class="caption-container">

1036Figure 2. Cumulative incidence of chronic health conditions for (A) grades 3 to 5 chronic health conditions, (B) multiple grade 3 to 5 conditions in survivors, (C) multiple grade 3 to 5 conditions in siblings, (D) conditioned based on no previous grade 3 to 5 conditions among survivors by ages 25, 35, or 45, and (E) conditioned based on no previous grade 3 to 5 conditions among siblings by ages 25, 35, or 45. Armstrong GT, Kawashima T, Leisenring W, et al: Aging and Risk of Severe, Disabling, Life-Threatening, and Fatal Events in the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. Journal of Clinical Oncology (<a href="https://ascopubs.org/journal/jco" title="https://ascopubs.org/journal/jco">

1037https://ascopubs.org/journal/jco</a>

1038), Volume 32 (Issue 12), 2014: Pages 1218-1227. Reprinted with permission. Copyright &#169; 2014 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. and American Society of Clinical Oncology. All rights reserved.</figcaption>

1039</figure>

1040</p>

1041<p id="_1583" tabindex="-1">

1042CCSS investigators also evaluated the impact of race and ethnicity on late outcomes. The study compared late mortality, subsequent neoplasms, and chronic health conditions in Hispanic (n = 750) and non-Hispanic Black (n = 694) participants with those in non-Hispanic White participants (n = 12,397).[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

104321</a>

1044] The following results were observed:</p>

1045<div class="pdq-content-list">

1046<ul id="_1737">

1047<li>

1048Cancer treatment did not account for disparities in mortality, chronic health conditions, or subsequent neoplasms observed among the groups.</li>

1049<li>

1050Differences in socioeconomic status and cardiovascular risk factors affected risk. All-cause mortality was higher among non-Hispanic Black participants than among other groups, but this difference disappeared after adjustment for socioeconomic status.</li>

1051<li>

1052Risk of developing diabetes was elevated among racial and ethnic minority groups even after adjustment for socioeconomic and obesity status.</li>

1053<li>

1054Non-Hispanic Black patients had a higher likelihood of reporting cardiac conditions, but this risk diminished after adjusting for cardiovascular risk factors.</li>

1055<li>

1056Nonmelanoma skin cancer was not reported by non-Hispanic Black participants, a finding that has been replicated by other studies.[<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

105722</a>

1058] Hispanic participants had a lower risk of nonmelanoma skin cancer than non-Hispanic White participants.</li>

1059</ul>

1060</div>

1061<p id="_1085" tabindex="-1">

1062Recognition of late effects, concurrent with advances in cancer biology, radiological sciences, and supportive care, has resulted in a change in the prevalence and spectrum of treatment effects. In an effort to reduce and prevent late effects, contemporary therapy for most pediatric malignancies has evolved to a risk-adapted approach that is assigned on the basis of a variety of clinical, biological, and sometimes genetic factors. </p>

1063<p id="_3038" tabindex="-1">

1064The CCSS reported that with decreased cumulative dose and frequency of therapeutic radiation from 1970 to 1999, survivors have experienced a significant decrease in risk of subsequent neoplasms.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

106523</a>

1066] </p>

1067<div class="pdq-content-list">

1068<ul id="_3039">

1069<li>

1070With the exception of survivors requiring intensive multimodality therapy for refractory/relapsed malignancies, life-threatening treatment effects are relatively uncommon after contemporary therapy in early follow-up (up to 10 years after diagnosis). </li>

1071<li>

1072However, survivors still frequently experience life-altering morbidity related to effects of cancer treatment on endocrine, reproductive, musculoskeletal, and neurological function.</li>

1073</ul>

1074</div>

1075<p id="_2070" tabindex="-1">

1076A CCSS investigation examined temporal patterns in the cumulative incidence of severe to fatal chronic health conditions among survivors treated from 1970 to 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

107724</a>

1078] </p>

1079<div class="pdq-content-list">

1080<ul id="_3040">

1081<li>

1082The 20-year cumulative incidence of at least one grade 3 to 5 chronic condition decreased significantly, from 33.2% for survivors diagnosed between 1970 and 1979, to 29.3% for those diagnosed between 1980 and 1989, to 27.5% for those diagnosed between 1990 and 1999, compared with a 4.6% incidence in a sibling cohort.</li>

1083<li>

1084 The overall decrease in incidence of chronic conditions across the three treatment decades was, in part, because of a substantial reduction of endocrinopathies, subsequent malignant neoplasms (SMNs), musculoskeletal conditions, and gastrointestinal conditions, whereas the cumulative incidence of hearing loss increased during this time.</li>

1085<li>

1086 Declines in morbidity were not uniform across the diagnosis groups or condition types because of differences in treatment and survival patterns over time. For more information, see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2123">

1087Figure 3</a>

1088.</li>

1089<li>

1090 Despite declines in chronic health conditions over time, self-reported health status has not improved in more recent treatment eras. This finding may be because of the survival of children with higher-risk disease who would have previously died of cancer, or an enhanced awareness of and surveillance for late effects among more recently treated survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

109125</a>

1092]</li>

1093</ul>

1094</div>

1095<p id="_2122" tabindex="-1">

1096<figure id="figure_2123" class="image-center-full">

1097<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/797854.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1098Enlarge</a>

1099<img id="_2123" alt="Graphs showing the cumulative incidence of grade 3&#8211;5 chronic health conditions in 5-year survivors of childhood cancer by diagnosis decade and siblings." title="Graphs showing the cumulative incidence of grade 3&#8211;5 chronic health conditions in 5-year survivors of childhood cancer by diagnosis decade and siblings." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/797854-750.jpg">

1100<figcaption class="caption-container">

1101Figure 3. Cumulative incidence of grade 3&#8211;5 chronic health conditions in 5-year survivors of childhood cancer by diagnosis decade and siblings. (A) Cumulative incidence of a first grade 3&#8211;5 condition. (B) Cumulative incidence of two or more grade 3&#8211;5 conditions. The shaded area represents the 95% confidence interval (CI). The number of participants at risk (number censored) at each 5-year interval post-diagnosis is listed below the x-axis. The number censored does not include those who experienced a competing risk event (death from a cause other than a grade 5 chronic condition). Reprinted from <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-lancet-oncology" title="https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-lancet-oncology">

1102The Lancet Oncology</a>

1103, Volume 19, Issue 12, Todd M Gibson, Sogol Mostoufi-Moab, Kayla L Stratton, Wendy M Leisenring, Dana Barnea, Eric J Chow, Sarah S Donaldson, Rebecca M Howell, Melissa M Hudson, Anita Mahajan, Paul C Nathan, Kirsten K Ness, Charles A Sklar, Emily S Tonorezos, Christopher B Weldon, Elizabeth M Wells, Yutaka Yasui, Gregory T Armstrong, Leslie L Robinson, Kevin C Oeffinger, Temporal patterns in the risk of chronic health conditions in survivors of childhood cancer diagnosed 1970&#8211;99: a report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study cohort. Pages 1590-1601, Copyright (2018), with permission from Elsevier.</figcaption>

1104</figure>

1105</p>

1106</section>

1107<section id="_121">

1108<h3 id="_121_toc">

1109Mortality</h3>

1110<p id="_122" tabindex="-1">

1111Late effects also contribute to an excess risk of premature death among long-term survivors of childhood cancer, as observed in the following studies:</p>

1112<div class="pdq-content-list">

1113<ul id="_1738">

1114<li>

1115Several studies of large cohorts of survivors have reported early mortality among individuals treated for childhood cancer, compared with age- and sex-matched general population controls. Relapsed/refractory primary cancer remains the most frequent cause of death, followed by excess cause-specific mortality from subsequent primary cancers, and cardiac and pulmonary toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

111626</a>

1117-<a href="#cit/section_1.31">

111831</a>

1119]</li>

1120<li>

1121A CCSS study evaluated specific health-related causes of late mortality and excess deaths, compared with the general U.S. population to identify targets to reduce future risk.[<a href="#cit/section_1.31">

112231</a>

1123]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1124<ul id="_3041">

1125<li>

1126 At a median follow-up of 29 years from diagnosis, the 40-year cumulative all-cause mortality rate was 23.3%, with 51.2% of deaths attributed to health-related causes.</li>

1127<li>

1128Survivors who were 40 or more years from diagnosis experienced 131 excess health-related deaths per 10,000 person-years (95% confidence interval [CI], 111&#8211;163). Excess deaths were most commonly related to cancer (absolute excess risk per 10,000 person-years, 54; 95% CI, 41&#8211;68), heart disease (27; 18&#8211;38), and cerebrovascular disease (10; 5&#8211;17).</li>

1129<li>

1130Healthy lifestyle (assessed by smoking status, alcohol consumption, physical activity, body mass index, and absence of hypertension and diabetes) were each associated with a 20% to 30% reduction in health-related mortality, independent of other factors.</li>

1131</ul>

1132</div>

1133</li>

1134<li>

1135An analysis of the CCSS and Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program data evaluated conditional survival. The study demonstrated a subsequent 5-year survival rate of 92% or higher among most diagnoses at 5 years, 10 years, 15 years, and 20 years. Among those who had survived at least 5 years from diagnosis, the probability of all-cause mortality in the next 10 years was 8.8% in the CCSS and 10.6% in the SEER study, with neoplasms accounting for cause of death in approximately 75% of survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

113632</a>

1137]</li>

1138</ul>

1139</div>

1140<p id="_1086" tabindex="-1">

1141Despite high premature morbidity rates, overall mortality has decreased over time.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

114226</a>

1143,<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

114428</a>

1145,<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

114629</a>

1147,<a href="#cit/section_1.33">

114833</a>

1149,<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

115034</a>

1151] </p>

1152<p id="_2499" tabindex="-1">

1153CCSS investigators evaluated all-cause and health-related late mortality (including late effects of cancer therapy), SMNs, chronic health conditions, and neurocognitive outcomes among 6,148 survivors of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (median age, 27.9 years; range, 5.9&#8211;61.9 years) diagnosed between 1970 and 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

115435</a>

1155]</p>

1156<div class="pdq-content-list">

1157<ul id="_2500">

1158<li>

1159Overall, the 20-year all-cause late mortality rate was 6.6%.</li>

1160<li>

1161Compared with participants who were treated in the 1970s, patients who were treated with risk-stratified regimens in the 1990s experienced lower health-related late mortality (rate ratio: 1990s standard risk, 0.2; 1990s high risk, 0.3), which was comparable to the U.S. population (standardized mortality ratio [SMR]: 1990s standard risk, 1.3; 1990s high risk, 1.7). </li>

1162</ul>

1163</div>

1164<p id="_2969" tabindex="-1">

1165The risk of late mortality and serious chronic health conditions have decreased over time among survivors of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). CCSS investigators evaluated the long-term morbidity, mortality, and health status of more than 800 5-year survivors of childhood AML based on treatment and treatment era. Survivors were compared by treatment group (hematopoietic stem cell transplantation [HSCT]); chemotherapy with cranial radiation [CRT]; chemotherapy only) and decade of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.36">

116636</a>

1167]</p>

1168<div class="pdq-content-list">

1169<ul id="_2970">

1170<li>

1171Among 856 survivors, the 20-year late mortality cumulative incidence was highest after HSCT (13.9%; chemotherapy with CRT, 7.6%; chemotherapy only, 5.1%). </li>

1172<li>

1173Mortality cumulative incidence decreased for survivors of HSCT diagnosed in the 1990s (8.5%) compared with the 1970s (38.9%), as did standardized mortality rates. </li>

1174<li>

1175Self-reported health status was good to excellent for 88.2% of childhood AML survivors, regardless of treatment. </li>

1176<li>

1177Most survivors did not experience any grade 3 to 5 chronic health conditions after 20 years (HSCT, 45.8%; chemotherapy with CRT, 23.7%; chemotherapy only, 27.0%).</li>

1178<li>

1179 A temporal reduction in chronic health conditions cumulative incidence was seen after HSCT (1970s, 76.1%; 1990s, 38.3%; <em>

1180P</em>

1181 = .02), mirroring a reduction in total-body irradiation use.</li>

1182</ul>

1183</div>

1184<p id="_2930" tabindex="-1">

1185Population-based data from a state cancer registry was used to evaluate differences in survival and long-term outcomes by race and ethnicity among 4,222 children diagnosed with cancer between 1987 and 2012.[<a href="#cit/section_1.12">

118612</a>

1187]</p>

1188<div class="pdq-content-list">

1189<ul id="_2931">

1190<li>

1191Compared with non-Hispanic White children, hospitalization was 70% (hazard ratio [HR], 1.7) more common 5 or more years after diagnosis for American Indian and Alaskan Native children and 50% (HR, 1.5) more common for Black children.</li>

1192<li>

1193Among survivors at 5 or more years from diagnosis, 2.3-fold to 3.6-fold statistically significant relative increases were observed for hospitalizations for specific conditions for American Indian and Alaskan Native children (HR, 2.3 for infection-related conditions; HR, 3.0 for hematologic-related conditions; HR, 2.6 for digestive-related conditions). The greatest increases were noted for mental health&#8211;related conditions (HR, 3.6), a pattern also noted for Black children (HR, 2.5).</li>

1194</ul>

1195</div>

1196<p id="_3026" tabindex="-1">

1197A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study explored associations between modifiable chronic health conditions and late mortality within the context of social determinants of health.[<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

119837</a>

1199]</p>

1200<div class="pdq-content-list">

1201<ul id="_3027">

1202<li>

1203Among 9,440 5-year childhood cancer survivors included in the analysis (median age at last follow-up, 27.5 years; median follow-up, 18.8 years), all-cause mortality (SMR, 7.6; 95% CI, 7.2&#8211;8.1) and health-related late mortality (SMR, 7.6; 95% CI, 7.0&#8211;8.2) was significantly higher than expected for U.S. mortality rates.</li>

1204<li>

1205Among 3,407 adult St. Jude Lifetime Cohort participants who completed an on-campus assessment (median age at assessment, 35.4 years; median follow-up, 27.3 years), significant increases in late all-cause and health-related deaths were associated with the number of modifiable chronic health conditions, living in a U.S. census block associated with a high area deprivation index, and frailty.</li>

1206<li>

1207Specific associations for excess health-related mortality included: one grade 2 modifiable chronic health condition (rate ratio [RR], 2.2; 95% CI, 1.1&#8211;4.4), two grade 2 modifiable chronic health conditions (RR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;5.2), three grade 2 modifiable chronic health conditions (RR, 4.0; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;8.4), area deprivation index in 51st to 80th percentile (RR, 9.2; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;69.7), area deprivation index in 81st to 100th percentile (RR, 16.2; 95% CI, 2.1&#8211;123.7), and frailty (RR, 2.3; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;4.1).</li>

1208</ul>

1209</div>

1210<section id="_2000">

1211<h4 id="_2000_toc">

1212Survivors of adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancers</h4>

1213<p id="_2001" tabindex="-1">

1214Little information is available on late mortality among survivors of AYA cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

121538</a>

1216-<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

121740</a>

1218]</p>

1219<div class="pdq-content-list">

1220<ul id="_2762">

1221<li>

1222Using SEER data, conditional relative survival up to 25 years after diagnosis was studied in a cohort of AYA patients (N = 205,954) diagnosed with a first malignant cancer (thyroid, melanoma, testicular, breast, lymphoma, leukemia, and CNS tumors).[<a href="#cit/section_1.38">

122338</a>

1224] <div class="pdq-content-list">

1225<ul id="_2402">

1226<li>

1227For all cancer types combined, among individuals who survived up to 5 years, the subsequent 5-year relative survival rate exceeded 95% by 7 years after diagnosis.</li>

1228<li>

1229Most AYA cancer patients who survived at least 7 years after diagnosis experienced little difference in survival compared with the general population.</li>

1230<li>

1231 For specific cancer types, including CNS tumors, female breast cancer, Hodgkin lymphoma, and leukemia, evidence of excess mortality risk persisted, or re-emerged, more than 10 years after a cancer diagnosis.</li>

1232<li>

1233 Conditional relative survival was lowest for AYA patients with CNS tumors, although patients aged 15 to 29 years demonstrated a higher survival rate than did patients aged 30 to 39 years at the time of diagnosis of their CNS tumors.</li>

1234</ul>

1235</div>

1236</li>

1237<li>

1238 A separate analysis of 5-year survivors of AYA cancer (aged 15&#8211;39 years at diagnosis), also using SEER data (N = 282,969), demonstrated the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.39">

123939</a>

1240]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1241<ul id="_2461">

1242<li>

1243The 10-year all-cause mortality rate decreased from 8.3% for those diagnosed between 1975 and 1984 to 5.4% for those diagnosed between 2005 and 2011. </li>

1244<li>

1245The decrease in mortality primarily resulted from fewer deaths from the initial cancer.</li>

1246</ul>

1247</div>

1248</li>

1249<li>

1250CCSS investigators compared chronic health conditions and all-cause and cause-specific mortality among 5,804 survivors of early-AYA cancer survivors (cancer diagnosis, age 15&#8211;20 years; median age, 42 years) and 5,804 childhood cancer survivors (cancer diagnosis, age &lt;15 years; median age, 34 years) matched on primary cancer diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

125140</a>

1252]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1253<ul id="_2403">

1254<li>

1255The SMR was 5.9 (95% CI, 5.5&#8211;6.2) for early-AYA survivors and 6.2 (95% CI, 5.8&#8211;6.6) for younger childhood cancer survivors, compared with the general population.</li>

1256<li>

1257Early-AYA survivors had lower SMRs for death from health-related causes than did childhood cancer survivors (SMR, 4.8 [95% CI, 4.4&#8211;5.1] vs. 6.8 [95% CI, 6.2&#8211;7.4]), which was primarily evident more than 20 years after cancer diagnosis. </li>

1258<li>

1259Early-AYA and childhood cancer survivors were at greater risk of developing severe and disabling, life-threatening, or fatal (grades 3&#8211;5) health conditions than were siblings of the same age (HR, 4.2 [95% CI, 3.7&#8211;4.8] for early-AYA and 5.6 [95% CI, 4.9&#8211;6.3] for childhood cancer survivors), although the risk was lower for early-AYA survivors than for childhood cancer survivors.</li>

1260</ul>

1261</div>

1262</li>

1263<li>

1264In a retrospective, population-based cohort study from Kaiser Permanente, cause-specific mortality in 2-year survivors (N = 10,574) of AYA cancers (patients aged 13&#8211;39 years who were diagnosed between 1990 and 2012) was examined and compared with individuals without cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

126541</a>

1266]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1267<ul id="_2411">

1268<li>

1269 AYA cancer survivors were at a 10.4-fold increased risk of death compared with the matched noncancer cohort, and this risk remained elevated at more than 20 years after diagnosis (incidence rate ratio [IRR], 2.9).</li>

1270<li>

1271Beginning at 15 years after diagnosis, the incidence of second cancer&#8211;related mortality exceeded the rate of recurrence-related mortality.</li>

1272<li>

1273Mortality risk of suicide was doubled in AYA cancer survivors compared with the noncancer cohort.</li>

1274</ul>

1275</div>

1276</li>

1277<li>

1278Chronic comorbidities were investigated in a retrospective, population-based cohort study of 6,778 2-year AYA cancer survivors diagnosed and monitored at Kaiser Permanente.[<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

127942</a>

1280]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1281<ul id="_2471">

1282<li>

1283Approximately 17% of the survivors developed more than one comorbidity. The most common comorbidities were dyslipidemia (22 per 1,000 person-years), hypertension (16 per 1,000 person-years), diabetes (10 per 1,000 person-years), thyroid disorders (9 per 1,000 person-years), and severe depression or anxiety (8 per 1,000 person-years).</li>

1284<li>

1285IRRs were higher in survivors than in controls without a history of cancer for avascular necrosis (IRR, 8.25), followed by osteoporosis (IRR, 5.75), joint replacement (IRR, 3.89), stroke (IRR, 3.19), premature ovarian failure (IRR, 2.87), and cardiomyopathy or heart failure (IRR, 2.64).</li>

1286<li>

1287For survivors of AYA cancer, the prevalence of multiple comorbidities approached 40% at 10 years after index date (a 2-year time point from diagnosis), compared with 20% for those without cancer (<em>

1288P</em>

1289 &lt; .001).</li>

1290</ul>

1291</div>

1292</li>

1293</ul>

1294</div>

1295</section>

1296</section>

1297<section id="_280">

1298<h3 id="_280_toc">

1299Monitoring for Late Effects</h3>

1300<p id="_281" tabindex="-1">

1301Recognition of both acute and late modality&#8211;specific toxicity has motivated investigations evaluating the pathophysiology and prognostic factors for cancer treatment&#8211;related effects. Consequently, the results of late effects research have played an important role in the following areas:</p>

1302<div class="pdq-content-list">

1303<ul id="_1002">

1304<li>

1305Changing pediatric cancer therapeutic approaches to reduce treatment-related mortality among survivors treated in more recent eras.[<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

130643</a>

1307] </li>

1308<li>

1309The development of risk counseling and health screening recommendations for long-term survivors by identifying the clinical and treatment characteristics of those at highest risk of therapy-related complications.[<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

131044</a>

1311]</li>

1312</ul>

1313</div>

1314<p id="_1039" tabindex="-1">

1315The common late effects of pediatric cancer encompass several broad domains, including the following: </p>

1316<div class="pdq-content-list">

1317<ul id="_992">

1318<li>

1319Growth and development.</li>

1320<li>

1321Organ function.</li>

1322<li>

1323Reproductive capacity and health of offspring.</li>

1324<li>

1325Secondary carcinogenesis. </li>

1326<li>

1327Psychosocial sequelae related to the primary cancer, its treatment, or maladjustment associated with the cancer experience.</li>

1328</ul>

1329</div>

1330<p id="_282" tabindex="-1">

1331Late sequelae of therapy for childhood cancer can be anticipated based on therapeutic exposures, but the magnitude of risk and the manifestations in an individual patient are influenced by numerous factors. Multiple factors should be considered in the risk assessment for a given late effect (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2723">

1332Figure 4</a>

1333).[<a href="#cit/section_1.45">

133445</a>

1335]</p>

1336<p id="_3056" tabindex="-1">

1337<strong>

1338Cancer-related factors:</strong>

1339</p>

1340<div class="pdq-content-list">

1341<ul id="_283">

1342<li>

1343Organs or tissues affected by the cancer.</li>

1344<li>

1345Direct tissue effects.</li>

1346<li>

1347Cancer-induced organ dysfunction or other tissue effects.</li>

1348</ul>

1349</div>

1350<p id="_3057" tabindex="-1">

1351<strong>

1352Treatment-related factors:</strong>

1353</p>

1354<div class="pdq-content-list">

1355<ul id="_284">

1356<li>

1357Radiation therapy: Total dose, fraction size, organ or tissue volume exposed.</li>

1358<li>

1359Chemotherapy: Agent type, dose-intensity, cumulative dose, schedule.</li>

1360<li>

1361Surgery: Technique, site, consequential organ dysfunction.</li>

1362<li>

1363HSCT.</li>

1364<li>

1365Combined-modality effects (therapeutic interactions).</li>

1366<li>

1367Blood product transfusion.</li>

1368<li>

1369Chronic graft-versus-host disease.</li>

1370</ul>

1371</div>

1372<p id="_3058" tabindex="-1">

1373<strong>

1374Host-related factors:</strong>

1375</p>

1376<div class="pdq-content-list">

1377<ul id="_285">

1378<li>

1379Sex.</li>

1380<li>

1381Genetic predisposition.</li>

1382<li>

1383Premorbid, comorbid, posttreatment health states and exposures.</li>

1384<li>

1385Developmental status (age).</li>

1386<li>

1387Time from diagnosis/therapy.</li>

1388<li>

1389Inherent tissue sensitivities and capacity for normal tissue repair.</li>

1390<li>

1391Hormonal milieu.</li>

1392<li>

1393Socioeconomic status.</li>

1394<li>

1395Health habits.</li>

1396</ul>

1397</div>

1398<p id="_2722" tabindex="-1">

1399<figure id="figure_2723" class="image-center-full">

1400<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/803054.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1401Enlarge</a>

1402<img id="_2723" alt="Chart showing factors influencing morbidity and mortality in the childhood cancer survivor." title="Chart showing factors influencing morbidity and mortality in the childhood cancer survivor." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/803054-750.jpg">

1403<figcaption class="caption-container">

1404Figure 4. Factors influencing morbidity and mortality of the childhood cancer survivor. Each arrow indicates a different factor affecting morbidity and mortality that exerts its effect along a continuum of care. Note that all effectors can begin exerting influence on morbidity during the period of cancer-directed therapy. Factors are separated into those that cannot be modified (red), those for which future interventions are plausible (yellow), and those for which there are known targets for interventions or areas in which therapy and surveillance have already been modified (blue). Reprinted from <a href="https://acsjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/15424863" title="https://acsjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/15424863">

1405CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians</a>

1406, Volume 68, Issue 2, Dixon SB, Bjornard KL, Alberts NM, et al., Factors influencing risk-based care of the childhood cancer survivor in the 21st century, Pages 133&#8211;152, Copyright &#169; 2018 American Cancer Society, with permission from John Wiley and Sons.</figcaption>

1407</figure>

1408</p>

1409</section>

1410<section id="_123">

1411<h3 id="_123_toc">

1412Resources to Support Survivor Care</h3>

1413<section id="_1040">

1414<h4 id="_1040_toc">

1415Risk-based screening</h4>

1416<p id="_124" tabindex="-1">

1417The need for long-term follow-up of childhood cancer survivors is supported by the American Society of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology, the International Society of Pediatric Oncology, the American Academy of Pediatrics, the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG), and the Institute of Medicine. A risk-based medical follow-up is recommended, which includes a systematic plan for lifelong screening, surveillance, and prevention that incorporates risk estimates based on the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.45">

141845</a>

1419]</p>

1420<div class="pdq-content-list">

1421<ul id="_1003">

1422<li>

1423Previous cancer.</li>

1424<li>

1425Cancer therapy.</li>

1426<li>

1427Genetic predisposition.</li>

1428<li>

1429Lifestyle behaviors.</li>

1430<li>

1431Comorbid conditions.</li>

1432<li>

1433Sex.</li>

1434</ul>

1435</div>

1436<p id="_1087" tabindex="-1">

1437Part of long-term follow-up also focuses on appropriate screening of educational and vocational progress. Specific treatments for childhood cancer, especially those that directly impact nervous system structures, may result in sensory, motor, and neurocognitive deficits that may have adverse effects on functional status, educational attainment, and future vocational opportunities. In support of this, a CCSS investigation observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.46">

143846</a>

1439]</p>

1440<div class="pdq-content-list">

1441<ul id="_1088">

1442<li>

1443Treatment with cranial radiation doses of 25 Gy or higher was associated with higher odds of unemployment (health related: odds ratio [OR], 3.47; 95% CI, 2.54&#8211;4.74; seeking work: OR, 1.77; 95% CI, 1.15&#8211;2.71).</li>

1444<li>

1445Unemployed survivors reported higher levels of poor physical functioning than employed survivors, had lower education and income, and were more likely to be publicly insured than unemployed siblings. </li>

1446</ul>

1447</div>

1448<p id="_1089" tabindex="-1">

1449These data emphasize the importance of facilitating survivor access to individualized education services, which has been demonstrated to have a positive impact on education achievement.[<a href="#cit/section_1.47">

145047</a>

1451] These services may in turn enhance vocational opportunities.</p>

1452<p id="_126" tabindex="-1">

1453In addition to risk-based screening for medical late effects, the impact of health behaviors on cancer-related health risks is also emphasized. Health-promoting behaviors are stressed for survivors of childhood cancer. Educational efforts focused on healthy lifestyle behaviors include the following: </p>

1454<div class="pdq-content-list">

1455<ul id="_993">

1456<li>

1457Abstinence from smoking, excess alcohol use, and illicit drug use to reduce the risk of organ toxicity and, potentially, subsequent neoplasms.</li>

1458<li>

1459Healthy dietary practices and active lifestyle to reduce treatment-related metabolic and cardiovascular complications. </li>

1460<li>

1461Regular physical activity to reduce neurocognitive problems and enhance psychological outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

146248</a>

1463,<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

146449</a>

1465]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1466<ul id="_3042">

1467<li>

1468 Survivors who engaged in consistent physical activity over time had fewer neurocognitive problems, including difficulties with task efficiency, emotional regulation, organization, and memory. They also experienced larger neurocognitive improvements, compared with those who had inconsistent activity levels.[<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

146948</a>

1470]</li>

1471<li>

1472Vigorous exercise in survivors has been associated with a lower prevalence of depression and somatization, as well as less impairment in physical functioning, general health and vitality, emotional role limitations, and mental health quality-of-life domains.[<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

147349</a>

1474]</li>

1475</ul>

1476</div>

1477</li>

1478</ul>

1479</div>

1480<p id="_994" tabindex="-1">

1481Proactively addressing unhealthy and risky behaviors is pertinent because several research investigations confirm that long-term survivors use tobacco and alcohol and have inactive lifestyles despite their increased risk of cardiac, pulmonary, and metabolic late effects.[<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

148250</a>

1483-<a href="#cit/section_1.52">

148452</a>

1485]</p>

1486</section>

1487<section id="_1091">

1488<h4 id="_1091_toc">

1489Access to risk-based survivor care</h4>

1490<p id="_1287" tabindex="-1">

1491Most childhood cancer survivors do not receive recommended risk-based care. The CCSS observed the following:</p>

1492<div class="pdq-content-list">

1493<ul id="_1288">

1494<li>

149592.8% of survivors reported receiving some form of medical care in the previous year.[<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

149653</a>

1497]</li>

1498<li>

1499Nearly 40% reported receiving care that focused on their previous cancer (survivor-focused care).[<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

150053</a>

1501]</li>

1502<li>

1503Surveillance for new cases of cancer was very low in survivors at the highest risk of colon, breast, or skin cancer, suggesting that survivors and their physicians need education about the risk of subsequent neoplasms and recommended surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

150454</a>

1505]</li>

1506<li>

1507Sociodemographic factors have been linked to declining rates of follow-up care over time from diagnosis. CCSS participants who were male, had a household income of less than $20,000 per year, and had lower educational attainment (high school education or less) were more likely to report no care at their most recent follow-up survey. This trend is concerning because the prevalence of chronic health conditions increases with longer elapsed time from cancer diagnosis in adults treated for cancer during childhood.[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

150855</a>

1509]</li>

1510<li>

1511A study that included 975 adult survivors of childhood cancer identified factors associated with attending the recommended risk-based, cancer-related medical visits. The relative risk of having a cancer-related visit was higher among survivors who:[<a href="#cit/section_1.56">

151256</a>

1513]<div class="pdq-content-list">

1514<ul id="_2183">

1515<li>

1516Assigned a greater importance to these visits.</li>

1517<li>

1518Perceived a greater susceptibility to health problems.</li>

1519<li>

1520Had experienced a cancer-related chronic health problem that was moderate to life-threatening.</li>

1521<li>

1522Were seeing a primary care provider for a cancer-related problem.</li>

1523<li>

1524Had received a cancer treatment care plan.</li>

1525<li>

1526Expressed greater confidence in physicians&#8217; abilities to address questions and concerns.</li>

1527</ul>

1528</div>

1529</li>

1530</ul>

1531</div>

1532<p id="_947" tabindex="-1">

1533Access to health insurance appears to play an important role in risk-based survivor care.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

153457</a>

1535,<a href="#cit/section_1.58">

153658</a>

1537] Lack of access to health insurance affects the following:</p>

1538<div class="pdq-content-list">

1539<ul id="_948">

1540<li>

1541<strong>

1542Cancer-related visits.</strong>

1543 In the CCSS, uninsured survivors were less likely than those privately insured to report a cancer-related visit (adjusted relative risk, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.75&#8211;0.91) or a cancer center visit (adjusted relative risk, 0.83; 95% CI, 0.71&#8211;0.98). Uninsured survivors had lower levels of utilization in all measures of care than privately insured survivors. In contrast, publicly insured survivors were more likely to report a cancer-related visit (adjusted relative risk, 1.22; 95% CI, 1.11&#8211;1.35) or a cancer center visit (adjusted relative risk, 1.41; 95% CI, 1.18&#8211;1.70) than were privately insured survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

154457</a>

1545]</li>

1546<li>

1547<strong>

1548Health care outcomes. </strong>

1549In a study comparing health care outcomes for long-term AYA cancer survivors with young adults who have no cancer history, the proportion of uninsured survivors did not differ between the two groups.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

155059</a>

1551] </li>

1552<li>

1553<strong>

1554Financial burden.</strong>

1555 Subgroups of adult survivors of childhood cancer may be at additional risk of health care barriers due to financial hardship. Younger survivors (aged 20&#8211;29 years), females, non-White survivors, and survivors reporting poorer health faced more cost barriers, which may inhibit the early detection of late effects.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

155659</a>

1557] Survivors are more likely than their siblings to forego needed medical care related to financial challenges.[<a href="#cit/section_1.60">

155860</a>

1559]</li>

1560</ul>

1561</div>

1562<p id="_949" tabindex="-1">

1563Overall, lack of health insurance&#8212;related to health issues, unemployment, and other societal factors&#8212;remains a significant concern for survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.61">

156461</a>

1565,<a href="#cit/section_1.62">

156662</a>

1567] Legislation, including the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA),[<a href="#cit/section_1.63">

156863</a>

1569,<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

157064</a>

1571] has improved access and retention of health insurance among survivors, although the quality and limitations associated with these policies have not been well studied.</p>

1572</section>

1573</section>

1574<section id="_287">

1575<h3 id="_287_toc">

1576Transition to Survivor Care</h3>

1577<section id="_950">

1578<h4 id="_950_toc">

1579Long-term follow-up programs</h4>

1580<p id="_288" tabindex="-1">

1581Transition of care from the pediatric to adult health care setting is necessary for most childhood cancer survivors in the United States. </p>

1582<p id="_1004" tabindex="-1">

1583When available, multidisciplinary long-term follow-up programs in the pediatric cancer center work collaboratively with community physicians to provide care for childhood cancer survivors. This type of shared care has been proposed as the optimal model to facilitate coordination between the cancer center oncology team and community physician groups providing survivor care.[<a href="#cit/section_1.65">

158465</a>

1585]</p>

1586<p id="_951" tabindex="-1">

1587An essential service of long-term follow-up programs is the organization of an individualized survivorship care plan that includes the following:</p>

1588<div class="pdq-content-list">

1589<ul id="_995">

1590<li>

1591Details about therapeutic interventions undertaken for childhood cancer and their potential health risks (e.g., chemotherapy type and cumulative dose, radiation treatment fields and dose, surgical procedures, blood product transfusions, and HSCT).</li>

1592<li>

1593Personalized health screening recommendations.</li>

1594<li>

1595Information about lifestyle factors that modify risks. </li>

1596</ul>

1597</div>

1598<p id="_2031" tabindex="-1">

1599A CCSS investigation that evaluated perceptions of future health and cancer risk highlighted the importance of continuing education of survivors during long-term follow-up evaluations. A substantial subgroup of adult survivors reported a lack of concern about future health (24%) and subsequent cancer risks (35%), even after exposure to treatments associated with increased risks. These findings present concerns that survivors may be less likely to engage in beneficial screenings and risk-reduction activities.[<a href="#cit/section_1.66">

160066</a>

1601]</p>

1602<p id="_2412" tabindex="-1">

1603The CCSS evaluated the surveillance and screening practices of 11,337 childhood cancer survivors. They found that fewer than half of high-risk survivors at increased risk of developing SMNs or cardiac dysfunction received the recommended surveillance, which likely exposes them to preventable morbidity and mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

160454</a>

1605]</p>

1606<div class="pdq-content-list">

1607<ul id="_2413">

1608<li>

160927% of survivors and 20% of primary care providers (PCP) had a survivorship care plan. Survivors treated after 1990 were more likely to have a survivorship care plan.</li>

1610<li>

1611Survivorship care plan possession by high-risk survivors was associated with increased adherence to COG-recommended breast (22% vs. 8%), skin (35% vs. 23%), and cardiac (67% vs. 33%) surveillance. PCP survivorship care plan possession was associated with increased adherence to skin surveillance (40% vs. 23%).</li>

1612<li>

1613Among high-risk survivors, adherence increased for colorectal (14% to 41%, <em>

1614P</em>

1615 &lt; .001) and cardiac (22% to 38%, <em>

1616P</em>

1617 &lt; .001) surveillance and decreased for breast surveillance (38% to 13%, <em>

1618P</em>

1619 &lt; .001) between 2007 and 2016.</li>

1620<li>

1621For average-risk survivors, better adherence to American Cancer Society recommendations for breast (57%), cervical (84%), and colorectal (69%) screening was observed than with COG recommendations. PCP survivorship care plan possession was associated with increased adherence to breast and colorectal screening. Survivors were less adherent to breast screening than the general population and less adherent to cervical screening than siblings.</li>

1622</ul>

1623</div>

1624<p id="_996" tabindex="-1">

1625For survivors who have not been provided with this information, the COG offers a template that can be used by survivors to organize a personal treatment summary. For more information, see the COG <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/pdf/COG_LTFU_Guidelines_AppendixI_v4.pdf" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/pdf/COG_LTFU_Guidelines_AppendixI_v4.pdf">

1626Survivorship Guidelines, Appendix 1</a>

1627.</p>

1628</section>

1629<section id="_952">

1630<h4 id="_952_toc">

1631COG long-term follow-up guidelines for childhood and AYA cancer survivors</h4>

1632<p id="_289" tabindex="-1">

1633To facilitate survivor and provider access to succinct information to guide risk-based care, COG investigators have organized a compendium of exposure- and risk-based health surveillance recommendations, with the goal of standardizing the care of childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.67">

163467</a>

1635] </p>

1636<p id="_953" tabindex="-1">

1637The compendium of resources includes the following:</p>

1638<div class="pdq-content-list">

1639<ul id="_954">

1640<li>

1641<strong>

1642Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines.</strong>

1643 COG <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

1644Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

1645 are appropriate for asymptomatic survivors presenting for routine exposure-based medical evaluation 2 or more years after completion of therapy.</li>

1646<li>

1647<strong>

1648Health Links.</strong>

1649 Patient education materials called <strong>

1650Health Links</strong>

1651 provide detailed information on guideline-specific topics to enhance health maintenance and promotion among this population of cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_1.68">

165268</a>

1653]</li>

1654</ul>

1655</div>

1656<p id="_955" tabindex="-1">

1657Information concerning late effects is summarized in tables throughout this summary.</p>

1658<p id="_922" tabindex="-1">

1659Several groups have undertaken research to evaluate the yield from risk-based screening as recommended by the COG and other pediatric oncology cooperative groups.[<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

16607</a>

1661,<a href="#cit/section_1.69">

166269</a>

1663,<a href="#cit/section_1.70">

166470</a>

1665] Pertinent considerations in interpreting the results of these studies include the following: </p>

1666<div class="pdq-content-list">

1667<ul id="_997">

1668<li>

1669Variability in the cohort&#8217;s age at treatment.</li>

1670<li>

1671Age at screening.</li>

1672<li>

1673Time from cancer treatment.</li>

1674<li>

1675Participation bias. </li>

1676</ul>

1677</div>

1678<p id="_998" tabindex="-1">

1679Collectively, these studies demonstrate that screening identifies a substantial proportion of individuals with previously unrecognized, treatment-related health complications of varying degrees of severity. Study results have also identified low-yield evaluations that have encouraged revisions of screening recommendations. Ongoing research is evaluating the cost effectiveness of screening in the context of consideration of benefits, risks, and harms.</p>

1680</section>

1681</section>

1682<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1732</li>

1733<li id="section_1.13">

1735[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1736</li>

1737<li id="section_1.14">

1738Berbis J, Michel G, Chastagner P, et al.: A French cohort of childhood leukemia survivors: impact of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation on health status and quality of life. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 19 (7): 1065-72, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23618717&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23618717&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1739[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1740</li>

1741<li id="section_1.15">

1742Phillips SM, Padgett LS, Leisenring WM, et al.: Survivors of childhood cancer in the United States: prevalence and burden of morbidity. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev 24 (4): 653-63, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25834148&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25834148&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1743[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1744</li>

1745<li id="section_1.16">

1746Bhakta N, Liu Q, Ness KK, et al.: The cumulative burden of surviving childhood cancer: an initial report from the St Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE). Lancet 390 (10112): 2569-2582, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28890157&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28890157&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1747[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1748</li>

1910Casillas J, Castellino SM, Hudson MM, et al.: Impact of insurance type on survivor-focused and general preventive health care utilization in adult survivors of childhood cancer: the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS). Cancer 117 (9): 1966-75, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21509774&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21509774&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1911[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1912</li>

1913<li id="section_1.58">

1914Keegan TH, Tao L, DeRouen MC, et al.: Medical care in adolescents and young adult cancer survivors: what are the biggest access-related barriers? J Cancer Surviv 8 (2): 282-92, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24408440&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24408440&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1915[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1916</li>

1917<li id="section_1.59">

1918Kirchhoff AC, Lyles CR, Fluchel M, et al.: Limitations in health care access and utilization among long-term survivors of adolescent and young adult cancer. Cancer 118 (23): 5964-72, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23007632&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23007632&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1919[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1920</li>

1921<li id="section_1.60">

1922Nathan PC, Huang IC, Chen Y, et al.: Financial Hardship in Adult Survivors of Childhood Cancer in the Era After Implementation of the Affordable Care Act: A Report From the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. J Clin Oncol 41 (5): 1000-1010, 2023.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36179267&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=36179267&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1923[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1924</li>

1925<li id="section_1.61">

1926Kirchhoff AC, Kuhlthau K, Pajolek H, et al.: Employer-sponsored health insurance coverage limitations: results from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. Support Care Cancer 21 (2): 377-83, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22717916&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22717916&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1927[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1928</li>

1929<li id="section_1.62">

1930Kuhlthau KA, Nipp RD, Shui A, et al.: Health insurance coverage, care accessibility and affordability for adult survivors of childhood cancer: a cross-sectional study of a nationally representative database. J Cancer Surviv 10 (6): 964-971, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27072683&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27072683&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1931[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1932</li>

1933<li id="section_1.63">

1934Park ER, Kirchhoff AC, Zallen JP, et al.: Childhood Cancer Survivor Study participants' perceptions and knowledge of health insurance coverage: implications for the Affordable Care Act. J Cancer Surviv 6 (3): 251-9, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22592507&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22592507&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1935[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1936</li>

1937<li id="section_1.64">

1938Warner EL, Park ER, Stroup A, et al.: Childhood cancer survivors' familiarity with and opinions of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. J Oncol Pract 9 (5): 246-50, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23943900&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23943900&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1939[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1940</li>

1941<li id="section_1.65">

1942Jacobs LA, Shulman LN: Follow-up care of cancer survivors: challenges and solutions. Lancet Oncol 18 (1): e19-e29, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28049574&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28049574&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1943[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1944</li>

1945<li id="section_1.66">

1946Gibson TM, Li C, Armstrong GT, et al.: Perceptions of future health and cancer risk in adult survivors of childhood cancer: A report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. Cancer 124 (16): 3436-3444, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29938398&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29938398&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1947[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1948</li>

1949<li id="section_1.67">

1950Landier W, Bhatia S, Eshelman DA, et al.: Development of risk-based guidelines for pediatric cancer survivors: the Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines from the Children's Oncology Group Late Effects Committee and Nursing Discipline. J Clin Oncol 22 (24): 4979-90, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15576413&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15576413&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1951[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1952</li>

1953<li id="section_1.68">

1954Eshelman D, Landier W, Sweeney T, et al.: Facilitating care for childhood cancer survivors: integrating children's oncology group long-term follow-up guidelines and health links in clinical practice. J Pediatr Oncol Nurs 21 (5): 271-80, 2004 Sep-Oct.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15381795&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15381795&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1955[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1956</li>

1957<li id="section_1.69">

1958Landier W, Armenian SH, Lee J, et al.: Yield of screening for long-term complications using the children's oncology group long-term follow-up guidelines. J Clin Oncol 30 (35): 4401-8, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23091100&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23091100&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1959[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1960</li>

1961<li id="section_1.70">

1962Wasilewski-Masker K, Mertens AC, Patterson B, et al.: Severity of health conditions identified in a pediatric cancer survivor program. Pediatr Blood Cancer 54 (7): 976-82, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20108334&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20108334&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1963[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1964</li>

1965</ol>

1966</div>

1967

1968 </section>

1969

1970

1971

1972 <section id="_116">

1973

1974 <h2>

1975Subsequent Neoplasms</h2>

1976

1977 <div id="_section_116" class="pdq-sections">

1978<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1979<h6>

1980In This Section</h6>

1981<ul>

1982<li>

1983<a href="#_293_toc">

1984Myelodysplastic Syndrome and Acute Myeloid Leukemia Postcytotoxic Therapy (MDS-pCT and AML-pCT)</a>

1985</li>

1986<li>

1987<a href="#_296_toc">

1988Therapy-Related Solid SNs<ul>

1989<li>

1990<a href="#_3043_toc">

1991Subsequent neoplasms after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</a>

1992</li>

1993<li>

1994<a href="#_1841_toc">

1995Breast cancer</a>

1996</li>

1997<li>

1998<a href="#_1844_toc">

1999Thyroid cancer</a>

2000</li>

2001<li>

2002<a href="#_1846_toc">

2003CNS tumors</a>

2004</li>

2005<li>

2006<a href="#_1848_toc">

2007Bone and soft tissue tumors</a>

2008</li>

2009<li>

2010<a href="#_1850_toc">

2011Skin cancer</a>

2012</li>

2013<li>

2014<a href="#_1852_toc">

2015Lung cancer</a>

2016</li>

2017<li>

2018<a href="#_1854_toc">

2019Gastrointestinal (GI) cancer</a>

2020</li>

2021<li>

2022<a href="#_3030_toc">

2023Oral cancers</a>

2024</li>

2025<li>

2026<a href="#_3044_toc">

2027Urogenital cancers</a>

2028</li>

2029<li>

2030<a href="#_1856_toc">

2031Renal carcinoma</a>

2032</li>

2033</ul>

2034</a>

2035</li>

2036<li>

2037<a href="#_2253_toc">

2038Survival Outcomes After SNs</a>

2039</li>

2040<li>

2041<a href="#_299_toc">

2042Subsequent Neoplasms and Genetic Susceptibility<ul>

2043<li>

2044<a href="#_652_toc">

2045Drug-metabolizing enzymes and DNA repair polymorphisms</a>

2046</li>

2047</ul>

2048</a>

2049</li>

2050<li>

2051<a href="#_305_toc">

2052Screening and Follow-up for Subsequent Neoplasms</a>

2053</li>

2054</ul>

2055</nav>

2056<p id="_290" tabindex="-1">

2057Subsequent neoplasms (SNs) are defined as histologically distinct neoplasms developing at least 2 months after completion of treatment for the primary malignancy. SNs may be benign or malignant. Childhood cancer survivors have increased risks of developing SNs that are multifactorial in etiology and vary according to the following: </p>

2058<div class="pdq-content-list">

2059<ul id="_956">

2060<li>

2061Host factors (e.g., genetics, immune function, hormone status).</li>

2062<li>

2063Primary cancer therapy.</li>

2064<li>

2065Environmental exposures.</li>

2066<li>

2067Lifestyle factors.</li>

2068</ul>

2069</div>

2070<p id="_957" tabindex="-1">

2071SNs are the leading cause of nonrelapse late mortality (standardized mortality ratio, 15.2; 95% confidence interval [CI], 13.9&#8211;16.6).[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

20721</a>

2073] The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) reported the following 30-year cumulative incidence rates:[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

20742</a>

2075] </p>

2076<div class="pdq-content-list">

2077<ul id="_958">

2078<li>

2079All SNs: 20.5% (95% CI, 19.1%&#8211;21.8%).</li>

2080<li>

2081Nonmelanoma skin cancer (NMSC): 9.1% (95% CI, 8.1%&#8211;10.1%).</li>

2082<li>

2083SNs with malignant histologies (excluding NMSC): 7.9% (95% CI, 7.2%&#8211;8.5%).</li>

2084<li>

2085Meningioma: 3.1% (95% CI, 2.5%&#8211;3.8%).</li>

2086</ul>

2087</div>

2088<p id="_959" tabindex="-1">

2089This represents a sixfold increased risk of SNs among cancer survivors, compared with the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

20902</a>

2091] </p>

2092<p id="_960" tabindex="-1">

2093Several studies have described the excess risk of SNs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

20943</a>

2095,<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

20964</a>

2097] </p>

2098<p id="_1839" tabindex="-1">

2099Evidence (excess risk of SNs):</p>

2100<div class="pdq-content-list">

2101<ol id="_1840">

2102<li>

2103A population-based study that leveraged registry data evaluated early second primary tumors occurring within 5 years of a first primary cancer diagnosed before age 15 years (1971&#8211;2010).[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

21045</a>

2105]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2106<ul id="_3028">

2107<li>

2108Early second primary tumors developed in 0.4% of cancer survivors, which is a sevenfold excess risk (standardized incidence ratio [SIR], 7.7; 95% CI, 6.7&#8211;8.9).</li>

2109<li>

2110Excess risk was higher among children diagnosed between 1981 and 1990 (SIR, 9.5; 95% CI, 7.1&#8211;12.5), compared with earlier or later decades (SIR, 6.5&#8211;7.5).</li>

2111<li>

2112Cancer predisposition syndromes were implicated in 21% of children with early second primary tumors and suspected in another 5%.</li>

2113</ul>

2114</div>

2115</li>

2116<li>

2117An international case-control study pooled data for an analysis of meningioma risk after treatment for childhood cancer. The study evaluated the magnitude of radiation dose&#8211;response association, potential modifiers of radiation risks, and the role of chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

21186</a>

2119]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2120<ul id="_2971">

2121<li>

2122Increasing radiation dose was associated with increased risk of meningioma (excess odds ratio [OR]/Gy, 1.44; 95% CI, 0.6&#8211;3.6), without evidence of departure from linearity.</li>

2123<li>

2124Exposure to radiation doses of 24 Gy or higher was associated with more than 30-fold higher odds of developing a meningioma (OR, 33.7; 95% CI, 14.1&#8211;80.3).</li>

2125<li>

2126Patients aged 10 years or older at treatment had a significantly lower radiation dose&#8211;response association compared with those treated before the age of 10 years (excess OR/Gy, 0.57; 95% CI, 0.18&#8211;1.91 vs. 2.20; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;6.31). </li>

2127<li>

2128Treatment with methotrexate was associated with an increased risk of meningioma (OR, 3.43; 95% CI, 1.56&#8211;7.57), but without evidence of a dose-response association or interaction with radiation dose.</li>

2129<li>

2130Meningioma risk associated with radiation exposure remained significantly elevated 30 years after treatment (excess OR/Gy, 3.76; 95% CI, 0.77&#8211;29.15).</li>

2131</ul>

2132</div>

2133</li>

2134<li>

2135A CCSS cohort reported on any new SN (including malignant neoplasms, NMSCs, benign meningiomas, and other benign neoplasms) occurring after age 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

21363</a>

2137] <div class="pdq-content-list">

2138<ul id="_2864">

2139<li>

2140At the age of 55 years, the cumulative incidence of any new SN was 34.6%. The incidence of malignant SNs was 16.3%.</li>

2141<li>

2142Female sex and therapeutic radiation exposure were associated with an increased risk of developing SNs in multivariate analysis.</li>

2143</ul>

2144</div>

2145<p id="_2865" tabindex="-1">

2146Prolonged follow-up has established that multiple SNs are common among aging childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

21477</a>

2148,<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

21498</a>

2150]</p>

2151</li>

2152<li>

2153The CCSS also reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

21544</a>

2155]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2156<ul id="_2870">

2157<li>

2158Individuals treated in more recent treatment eras experienced decreased risk of SNs (including subsequent malignancies, NMSCs, and benign meningiomas) compared with those treated earlier. This lower risk was attributed to decreased exposure to therapeutic radiation.</li>

2159<li>

2160However, individuals treated in the 1990s remain at increased risk of SNs compared with the general population.</li>

2161</ul>

2162</div>

2163</li>

2164<li>

2165CCSS investigators evaluated morbidity and mortality associated with meningioma among 4,221 participants treated with cranial radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

21669</a>

2167]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2168<ul id="_1829">

2169<li>

2170The cumulative incidence of subsequent meningioma by age 40 years was 5.6% in this group of patients, and the incidence was without demonstrable plateau.</li>

2171<li>

2172Risk factors for subsequent meningioma included female sex (hazard ratio [HR], 1.7; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;2.3) and higher cranial radiation dose (HR, 2.6; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;4.2 after 30 Gy or higher).</li>

2173<li>

2174Among survivors reporting meningiomas, the risk of neurological sequelae occurring 5 or more years after primary cancer diagnosis was increased for seizures (HR, 10.0; 95% CI, 7.0&#8211;15.3); auditory-vestibular-visual sensory deficits (HR, 2.3; 95% CI, 1.3&#8211;4.0); focal neurological dysfunction (HR, 4.9; 95% CI, 3.2&#8211;7.5); and severe headaches (HR, 3.2; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;5.4).</li>

2175<li>

2176With a median follow-up of 72 months after meningioma diagnosis, 13% of the patients had died, with six deaths attributed to meningioma.</li>

2177</ul>

2178</div>

2179</li>

2180<li>

2181Dutch Childhood Oncology Group (DCOG)&#8211;LATER investigators evaluated the cumulative meningioma incidence and performed excess relative risk modeling of benign meningiomas in childhood cancer patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

218210</a>

2183]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2184<ul id="_2453">

2185<li>

2186Among 5,843 childhood cancer survivors (median follow-up, 23.3 years; range, 5.0&#8211;52.2 years), 97 patients developed a benign meningioma, including 80 after full-volume cranial radiation and 14 after partial-volume cranial radiation. </li>

2187<li>

2188The 40-year cumulative incidence of meningioma after any cranial radiation was 12.4% (95% CI, 9.8%&#8211;15.2%).</li>

2189<li>

2190Compared with cranial radiation doses of 1 to 19 Gy, no cranial radiation was associated with a low meningioma risk (HR, 0.04; 95% CI, 0.01&#8211;0.15), while increased risks were observed for doses of 20 to 39 Gy (HR, 1.66; 95% CI, 0.83&#8211;3.33) and 40 Gy or higher (HR, 2.81; 95% CI, 1.30&#8211;6.08). </li>

2191<li>

2192Survivors diagnosed before the age of 5 years showed significantly increased risks (HR, 2.38; 95% CI, 1.39&#8211;4.07) compared with patients diagnosed between the ages of 10 and 17 years. </li>

2193<li>

2194Radiation volume was not significantly associated with increased risk (HR for full vs. partial volume, 1.66; 95% CI, 0.86&#8211;3.22) and dose effects did not vary significantly according to exposure age or radiation volume. </li>

2195<li>

2196Treatment with carboplatin was associated with meningioma risk (HR, 3.55; 95% CI, 1.62&#8211;7.78), but a dose-response was not observed, and all nine exposed cases had received high-dose cranial radiation.</li>

2197<li>

2198In a follow-up study from the DCOG-LATER cohort, 90% of survivors with meningioma presented with symptoms rather than through late effects clinic screening, and 32% of survivors presented with synchronous meningiomas.[<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

219911</a>

2200]</li>

2201</ul>

2202</div>

2203</li>

2204<li>

2205CCSS investigators have also evaluated associations between chemotherapy and subsequent malignant neoplasms (SMNs) among nonirradiated, long-term survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

220612</a>

2207]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2208<ul id="_2184">

2209<li>

2210Of 1,498 SMNs in 1,344 survivors, 229 occurred in 206 survivors who were treated with chemotherapy only.</li>

2211<li>

2212The 30-year SMN cumulative incidence was 3.9% for the chemotherapy-only group, 9.0% for the chemotherapy-plus-radiation group, 10.8% for the radiation-only group, and 3.4% for the neither-treatment group.</li>

2213<li>

2214SIRs for SMNs were increased for any SMN (SIR, 2.8), subsequent leukemia/lymphoma (SIR, 1.9), breast cancer (SIR, 4.6), soft tissue sarcoma (SIR, 3.4), thyroid cancer (SIR, 3.8), and melanoma (SIR, 2.3).</li>

2215<li>

2216The SMN rate was significantly associated with exposure to platinum chemotherapy doses higher than 750 mg/m<span class="sup">

22172</span>

2218 (relative rate, 2.7) and alkylating agents (relative rate, 1.2 per 5,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

22192</span>

2220).</li>

2221<li>

2222The breast cancer rate showed a linear dose response (relative rate, 1.3 per 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

22232</span>

2224) with anthracycline exposure.</li>

2225</ul>

2226</div>

2227</li>

2228<li>

2229DCOG-LATER investigators evaluated the contribution of chemotherapy to solid cancer risk in a large cohort of childhood cancer survivors diagnosed between 1963 and 2001 (median follow-up, 20.7 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

223013</a>

2231]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2232<ul id="_1806">

2233<li>

2234The 25-year cumulative SN incidence was 3.9% and did not change across decades.</li>

2235<li>

2236Survivors treated with doxorubicin exhibited a dose-dependent increased risk of all solid cancers and breast cancer.
