This relationship was stronger in survivors with Li-Fraumeni syndrome&#8211;associated childhood cancers (leukemia, central nervous system [CNS], and sarcomas other than Ewing) than in survivors of other cancers.</li>

2237<li>

2238Among female survivors who did not receive chest radiation or total-body irradiation (TBI) and developed breast cancer (n = 31), HRs for doxorubicin dose tertiles were 1.3 (95% CI, 0.3&#8211;6.1), 5.6 (95% CI, 1.9&#8211;16.2), and 9.9 (95% CI, 4.2&#8211;23.8).</li>

2239<li>

2240A dose-response relationship was confirmed with cyclophosphamide and subsequent sarcoma, particularly bone sarcoma. The HR for subsequent sarcoma was 3.1 (95% CI, 1.5&#8211;6.0) for survivors who received cyclophosphamide at a dose greater than 9,400 mg/m<span class="sup">

22412</span>

2242 and 2.6 (95% CI, 1.3&#8211;5.2) for those who received ifosfamide.</li>

2243</ul>

2244</div>

2245</li>

2246<li>

2247St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study investigators assessed the contribution of pathogenic and likely pathogenic mutations in cancer predisposition genes to SN risk in childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

224814</a>

2249]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2250<ul id="_2034">

2251<li>

2252Of 3,006 study participants evaluated by whole-genome sequencing (30-fold), 1,120 SNs were diagnosed among 439 survivors (14.6%), and 175 pathogenic or likely pathogenic mutations were identified in 5.8% of survivors. The prevalence of a pathogenic or likely pathogenic mutation among nonirradiated survivors with SNs was much higher, at 18%.</li>

2253<li>

2254Mutations were associated with significantly increased rates of breast cancer (relative risk [RR], 13.9) and sarcoma (RR, 10.6) among irradiated survivors and with developing any SN (RR, 4.7), breast cancer (RR, 7.7), nonmelanoma skin cancer (RR, 11), and two or more histologically distinct SNs (RR, 18.6).</li>

2255<li>

2256Mutation carriers did not have an increased rate of meningioma or thyroid cancer.</li>

2257</ul>

2258</div>

2259</li>

2260<li>

2261A CCSS study evaluated the occurrence of cancer types in which human papillomavirus (HPV) is an established etiologic risk factor. The study included 24,363 childhood cancer survivors who were a median of 21 years from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

226215</a>

2263]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2264<ul id="_2921">

2265<li>

2266The 30-year cumulative incidence of an HPV-associated cancer was 0.3% (95% CI, 0.2%&#8211;0.4%), reflecting an almost threefold excess risk (SIR, 2.86; 95% CI, 2.05&#8211;4.00) to that of the general population.</li>

2267<li>

2268Male and female cancer survivors had an elevated risk of HPV-associated oropharyngeal (SIR in males, 4.06; SIR in females, 8.44) and anorectal (SIR in males, 13.56; SIR in females, 9.16) SMNs. However, females were not at increased risk of cervical or vulvar cancers, compared with the general population.</li>

2269<li>

2270Independent risk factors for HPV-associated cancers identified by multivariable modeling included male sex (vs. females: relative SIR, 1.99; 95% CI, 1.00&#8211;3.94); head, neck, and pelvic radiation therapy doses higher than 30 Gy (vs. none: relative SIR, 2.35; 95% CI, 1.11&#8211;4.97); and cisplatin-equivalent doses higher than 400 mg/m<span class="sup">

22712</span>

2272 (vs. none: relative SIR, 4.51; 95% CI, 1.78&#8211;11.43).</li>

2273</ul>

2274</div>

2275</li>

2276</ol>

2277</div>

2278<p id="_961" tabindex="-1">

2279The incidence and type of SNs depend on the following:</p>

2280<div class="pdq-content-list">

2281<ul id="_962">

2282<li>

2283Primary cancer diagnosis.</li>

2284<li>

2285Type of therapy received.</li>

2286<li>

2287Presence of genetic conditions. </li>

2288</ul>

2289</div>

2290<p id="_963" tabindex="-1">

2291Unique associations with specific therapeutic exposures have resulted in the classification of SNs into the following two distinct groups:</p>

2292<div class="pdq-content-list">

2293<ul id="_291">

2294<li>

2295Myelodysplastic syndrome postcytotoxic therapy (MDS-pCT) and acute myeloid leukemia postcytotoxic therapy (AML-pCT) (previously termed t-MDS and t-AML).</li>

2296<li>

2297Therapy-related solid SNs.</li>

2298</ul>

2299</div>

2300<section id="_293">

2301<h3 id="_293_toc">

2302Myelodysplastic Syndrome and Acute Myeloid Leukemia Postcytotoxic Therapy (MDS-pCT and AML-pCT)</h3>

2303<p id="_2472" tabindex="-1">

2304Subsequent primary leukemias have been reported in survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma, leukemia, sarcoma, CNS tumors, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, neuroblastoma, and Wilms tumor. In a cohort of nearly 70,000 5-year childhood cancer survivors, survivors had a fourfold increased risk (SIR, 3.7) of developing a leukemia, with an absolute excess risk of 7.5. Specifically, a sixfold relative risk of developing a myeloid leukemia (SIR, 5.8) was reported.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

230516</a>

2306]</p>

2307<div class="pdq-content-list">

2308<ul id="_2473">

2309<li>

2310The risk remained significantly elevated beyond 20 years from the first primary malignancy (SIR, 2.4).</li>

2311<li>

2312Hodgkin lymphoma survivors had the greatest excess risk of developing a subsequent leukemia (SIR, 7.9) and specifically a myeloid leukemia (SIR, 12.1), with the largest excess risk seen before 20 years of follow-up. </li>

2313</ul>

2314</div>

2315<p id="_2882" tabindex="-1">

2316A pooled analysis examined all published studies with detailed treatment data for children with cancer diagnosed between 1930 and 2000. Treatment data included estimated radiation doses to the active bone marrow and doses of specific chemotherapy agents. In this report, 147 cases of second primary leukemia (69% of cases were AML) were matched to 522 controls.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

231717</a>

2318]</p>

2319<div class="pdq-content-list">

2320<ul id="_2883">

2321<li>

2322After controlling for other therapies, topoisomerase II inhibitor therapy was associated with an increased risk of second AML (no radiation and &gt;2,500 mg/m<span class="sup">

23232</span>

2324 vs. none: OR, 14.3; 95% CI, 2.7&#8211;75.1). </li>

2325<li>

2326Radiation dose to the active bone marrow was also associated with an increased risk of second AML among patients who did not receive chemotherapy (&gt;0&#8211;12 Gy: OR, 4.9; 95% CI, 0.95&#8211;25.6) but not among those who received chemotherapy.</li>

2327<li>

2328Second primary leukemias were most likely to occur in the first decade after cancer treatment. </li>

2329</ul>

2330</div>

2331<p id="_999" tabindex="-1">

2332Characteristics of MDS-pCT and AML-pCT include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

233318</a>

2334,<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

233519</a>

2336] </p>

2337<div class="pdq-content-list">

2338<ul id="_1005">

2339<li>

2340A short latency (&lt;10 years from primary cancer diagnosis). The risk of MDS-pCT or AML-pCT plateaus after 10 to 15 years. Although the risk of subsequent leukemia remains significantly elevated beyond 15 years from primary diagnosis (SIR, 3.5; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;6.0), these events are relatively rare, with an absolute excess risk of 0.02 cases per 1,000 person-years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

234119</a>

2342]</li>

2343<li>

2344 An association with alkylating agents and/or topoisomerase II inhibitors.</li>

2345</ul>

2346</div>

2347<p id="_964" tabindex="-1">

2348Based on the updated definitions from the World Health Organization, MDS-pCT and AML-pCT are clonal disorders, which arise in patients previously exposed to cytotoxic therapy, either chemotherapy or large-field radiation therapy, for an unrelated neoplasm.[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

234920</a>

2350] The following two types of MDS-pCT and AML-pCT are the most frequently observed among survivors:</p>

2351<div class="pdq-content-list">

2352<ul id="_295">

2353<li>

2354<strong>

2355Alkylating agent&#8211;related type:</strong>

2356 Alkylating agents associated with MDS-pCT and AML-pCT include cyclophosphamide, ifosfamide, mechlorethamine, melphalan, busulfan, nitrosoureas, chlorambucil, and dacarbazine.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

235721</a>

2358] <p id="_1000" tabindex="-1">

2359The risk of alkylating agent&#8211;related MDS or AML is dose dependent, with a latency of 3 to 5 years after exposure; it is associated with abnormalities involving chromosomes 5 (-5/del(5q)) and 7 (-7/del(7q)).[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

236021</a>

2361]</p>

2362</li>

2363<li>

2364<strong>

2365Topoisomerase II inhibitor&#8211;related type:</strong>

2366 Topoisomerase II inhibitor agents include etoposide, teniposide, and anthracycline-related drugs.<p id="_1001" tabindex="-1">

2367Most of the translocations observed in patients exposed to topoisomerase II inhibitors disrupt a breakpoint cluster region between exons 5 and 11 of the band 11q23 and fuse <em class="gene-name">

2368KMT2A</em>

2369 with a partner gene.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

237021</a>

2371] Topoisomerase II inhibitor&#8211;related AML presents as overt leukemia after a latency of 6 months to 3 years and is associated with balanced translocations involving chromosome bands 11q23 or 21q22.[<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

237222</a>

2373]</p>

2374</li>

2375</ul>

2376</div>

2377<p id="_2470" tabindex="-1">

2378For more information, see the <a href="/types/leukemia/hp/child-aml-treatment-pdq#_607">

2379Therapy-Related AML and Therapy-Related Myelodysplastic Syndromes</a>

2380 section in Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment.</p>

2381</section>

2382<section id="_296">

2383<h3 id="_296_toc">

2384Therapy-Related Solid SNs</h3>

2385<p id="_297" tabindex="-1">

2386Therapy-related solid SNs represent 80% of all SNs, demonstrate a strong relationship with radiation exposure, and are characterized by a latency that exceeds 10 years. The risk of solid SNs continues to increase with longer follow-up. The risk of solid SNs is highest when the following occur:[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

23874</a>

2388,<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

238913</a>

2390]</p>

2391<div class="pdq-content-list">

2392<ul id="_1006">

2393<li>

2394Younger age at time of radiation exposure.</li>

2395<li>

2396High total dose of radiation.</li>

2397<li>

2398Longer period of follow-up after radiation exposure. </li>

2399</ul>

2400</div>

2401<p id="_1007" tabindex="-1">

2402The histological subtypes of solid SNs encompass a neoplastic spectrum ranging from benign and low-grade malignant lesions (e.g., NMSC, meningiomas) to high-grade malignancies (e.g., breast cancers, glioblastomas) (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2719">

2403Figure 5</a>

2404).[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

24054</a>

2406,<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

240713</a>

2408,<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

240923</a>

2410,<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

241124</a>

2412]</p>

2413<figure id="figure_2719" class="image-center">

2414<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/803047.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2415Enlarge</a>

2416<img id="_2719" alt="Graph showing fitted radiation dose (Gy) response by type of second cancer: sarcoma, skin cancer (BCC), meningioma, salivary gland cancer, glioma, breast cancer, and thyroid cancer." title="Graph showing fitted radiation dose (Gy) response by type of second cancer: sarcoma, skin cancer (BCC), meningioma, salivary gland cancer, glioma, breast cancer, and thyroid cancer." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/803047-750.jpg">

2417<figcaption class="caption-container">

2418Figure 5. Fitted radiation dose-response by type of second cancer, based on previously published studies of second sarcoma, skin, meningioma, salivary gland, glioma, breast, and thyroid gland. The order of second cancers from top to bottom in the graph is the same as in the key to the right of the panel. Reprinted from <a href="https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/international-journal-of-radiation-oncology-biology-physics" title="https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/international-journal-of-radiation-oncology-biology-physics">

2419International Journal of Radiation Oncology*Biology*Physics</a>

2420, Volume 94, Issue 4, Inskip PD, Sigurdson AJ, Veiga L, et al., Radiation-Related New Primary Solid Cancers in the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study: Comparative Radiation Dose Response and Modification of Treatment Effects, Pages 800&#8211;807, Copyright &#169; 2016, with permission from Elsevier.</figcaption>

2421</figure>

2422<p id="_965" tabindex="-1">

2423Solid SNs in childhood cancer survivors most commonly involve the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

24244</a>

2425,<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

242613</a>

2427,<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

242823</a>

2429,<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

243025</a>

2431-<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

243228</a>

2433] </p>

2434<div class="pdq-content-list">

2435<ul id="_966">

2436<li>

2437<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1841">

2438Breast</a>

2439.</li>

2440<li>

2441<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1844">

2442Thyroid</a>

2443.</li>

2444<li>

2445<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1846">

2446CNS</a>

2447.</li>

2448<li>

2449<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1848">

2450Bone and soft tissue</a>

2451. </li>

2452<li>

2453<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1850">

2454Skin</a>

2455.</li>

2456</ul>

2457</div>

2458<p id="_1008" tabindex="-1">

2459With longer follow-up of adult survivors of childhood cancer cohorts, epithelial neoplasms have been observed in the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

246013</a>

2461,<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

246229</a>

2463]</p>

2464<div class="pdq-content-list">

2465<ul id="_1009">

2466<li>

2467<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1852">

2468Lung</a>

2469.</li>

2470<li>

2471<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1854">

2472Gastrointestinal tract</a>

2473.</li>

2474<li>

2475<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_3030">

2476Oral cavity</a>

2477.</li>

2478<li>

2479<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_3044">

2480Genitourinary system</a>

2481.</li>

2482<li>

2483<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1856">

2484Kidney</a>

2485.</li>

2486</ul>

2487</div>

2488<p id="_967" tabindex="-1">

2489Benign and low-grade SNs, including NMSCs and meningiomas, have also been observed with increasing prevalence in survivors who were treated with radiation therapy for childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

24904</a>

2491,<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

249210</a>

2493,<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

249430</a>

2495]</p>

2496<section id="_3043">

2497<h4 id="_3043_toc">

2498Subsequent neoplasms after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</h4>

2499<p id="_465" tabindex="-1">

2500Recipients of HSCT are treated with high-dose chemotherapy and, often, TBI, which makes their risk of SNs unique from that of the general oncology population. </p>

2501<div class="pdq-content-list">

2502<ul id="_2985">

2503<li>

2504Among 4,318 first-time allogeneic HSCT recipients treated for AML and chronic myeloid leukemia between 1986 and 2005, and conditioned with high-dose busulfan and cyclophosphamide (Bu-Cy), 66 solid cancers were reported at a median of 6 years post-HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

250531</a>

2506]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2507<ul id="_2426">

2508<li>

2509The cumulative incidence of new solid cancers was 0.9% at 5 years and 2.4% at 10 years and appears to be similar, regardless of exposure to radiation. </li>

2510<li>

2511Bu-Cy conditioning without TBI was associated with higher risks of solid SNs than in the general population. </li>

2512<li>

2513Chronic graft-versus-host disease increased the risk of SNs, especially those involving the oral cavity.</li>

2514</ul>

2515</div>

2516</li>

2517<li>

2518A study of 4,905 1-year survivors of allogeneic HSCT who underwent transplant between 1969 and 2014 for malignant or nonmalignant diseases, and were followed for a median 12.5 years, demonstrated a strong effect of TBI dose and dose fractionation on risk of SNs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

251932</a>

2520]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2521<ul id="_2990">

2522<li>

2523The 20-year cumulative incidence of SN after HSCT for individuals treated at younger than 20 years was 8.1%.</li>

2524<li>

2525SN risk was highest in survivors exposed to high-dose, single-fraction TBI (6&#8211;12 Gy) or very high-dose fractionated TBI (14.4&#8211;17.5 Gy).</li>

2526<li>

2527With low-dose TBI (2&#8211;4.5 Gy), the SN risk was comparable to the risk with chemotherapy alone, although it was still twofold higher than in the general population.</li>

2528<li>

2529Among individuals treated at younger than 20 years, the number of SNs was 12.5-fold higher than expected in the general population, and the excess absolute risk was 10.6 per 1,000 person-years. Survivors treated with HSCT at this young age were more likely to develop SNs than were survivors who were treated after age 50 years (HR, 2.3).</li>

2530</ul>

2531</div>

2532</li>

2533</ul>

2534</div>

2535<p id="_968" tabindex="-1">

2536Some well-established solid SNs are described in the following sections.</p>

2537</section>

2538<section id="_1841">

2539<h4 id="_1841_toc">

2540Breast cancer</h4>

2541<p id="_2417" tabindex="-1">

2542Female survivors of childhood, adolescent, and young adult cancer treated with radiation therapy to fields including the chest are at increased risk of developing breast cancer. </p>

2543<div class="pdq-content-list">

2544<ul id="_2427">

2545<li>

2546The cumulative breast cancer incidence ranges from 8% to 20% by age 40 to 45 years among childhood cancer survivors and is as high as 35% by age 50 years in Hodgkin lymphoma survivors, comparable to that observed among <em class="gene-name">

2547BRCA</em>

2548 gene mutation carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

254918</a>

2550,<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

255133</a>

2552-<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

255336</a>

2554] </li>

2555<li>

2556Radiation dose and volume of breast exposed are important factors affecting risk. Specific chemotherapeutic agents, particularly alkylating agents and anthracyclines, may affect risk as well.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

255733</a>

2558,<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

255935</a>

2560,<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

256137</a>

2562]</li>

2563</ul>

2564</div>

2565<p id="_2246" tabindex="-1">

2566Evidence (excess risk of breast cancer):</p>

2567<div class="pdq-content-list">

2568<ol id="_2247">

2569<li>

2570Breast cancer is the most common therapy-related solid SN after a previous diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

257118</a>

2572,<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

257334</a>

2574] The following has been observed in female survivors of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma:<div class="pdq-content-list">

2575<ul id="_2248">

2576<li>

2577Excess risk of breast cancer has been reported in survivors treated with high-dose, extended-volume radiation at age 30 years or younger.[<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

257838</a>

2579] </li>

2580<li>

2581Data indicate that females treated with low-dose, involved-field radiation also exhibit excess breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

258239</a>

2583]</li>

2584<li>

2585Patients who received limited volume supradiaphragmatic radiation therapy (excluding the axillae) had a significantly lower risk of subsequent breast cancers than patients who received full mantle-field radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

258637</a>

2587]</li>

2588<li>

2589For patients treated with radiation therapy to the chest before age 16 years, the cumulative incidence of breast cancer approaches 20% by age 45 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

259018</a>

2591]</li>

2592<li>

2593The latency period after chest irradiation ranges from 8 to 10 years, and the risk of subsequent breast cancer increases in a linear fashion with radiation dose (<em>

2594P</em>

2595 for trend &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

259640</a>

2597]</li>

2598<li>

2599Treatment with higher cumulative doses of alkylating agents and ovarian radiation of 5 Gy or higher (exposures predisposing to premature menopause) have been correlated with reductions in breast cancer risk, underscoring the potential contribution of hormonal stimulation on breast carcinogenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

260037</a>

2601,<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

260241</a>

2603,<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

260442</a>

2605]</li>

2606<li>

2607The observed number of invasive breast cancer cases among young (aged &lt;30 years) survivors, compared with what is expected in the general population, has decreased over recent treatment eras (1970s SIR, 55.0 vs. 1990s SIR, 14.3).[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

260836</a>

2609]</li>

2610</ul>

2611</div>

2612</li>

2613<li>

2614The St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE) assessed subsequent breast cancer risk among 1,467 female cancer survivors and evaluated risk associated with anthracycline exposure. The study also evaluated whether surveillance imaging affects breast cancer outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

261525</a>

2616]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2617<ul id="_2146">

2618<li>

2619In women who received neither chest radiation nor anthracyclines, the cumulative incidence of breast cancer was 2% at age 35 years and 15% at age 50 years. For women who were treated with 250 mg/m<span class="sup">

26202</span>

2621 or higher of anthracyclines, the rates were 7% at age 35 years and 46% at age 50 years.</li>

2622<li>

2623Anthracycline doses of 250 mg/m<span class="sup">

26242</span>

2625 or higher remained significantly associated with increased risk of breast cancer in models, excluding survivors with cancer predisposition gene mutations, chest radiation of 10 Gy or higher, or both.</li>

2626<li>

2627Breast cancers detected by imaging and/or prophylactic mastectomy were more likely to be <em>

2628in situ</em>

2629 carcinomas, be smaller masses, have no lymph node involvement, and be treated without chemotherapy, compared with breast cancers detected by physical findings.</li>

2630<li>

2631Dual imaging with mammography and breast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in this cohort was a sensitive and specific approach to identify breast cancers that require less aggressive therapy than breast cancers detected by physical findings.</li>

2632</ul>

2633</div>

2634</li>

2635<li>

2636The risk of breast cancer was also increased in the following studies that used lower radiation doses to treat cancer that metastasized to the chest/lung (e.g., Wilms tumor, sarcoma) and exposed the breast tissue:<div class="pdq-content-list">

2637<ol id="_2300" class="lower-alpha">

2638<li>

2639In 116 children in the CCSS cohort treated with 2 Gy to 20 Gy to the lungs (median, 14 Gy), the SIR for breast cancer was 43.6 (95% CI, 27.1&#8211;70.1).[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

264035</a>

2641]</li>

2642<li>

2643A report of 2,492 female participants in the National Wilms Tumor Studies 1 through 4 (1969&#8211;1995) addressed the excess risk of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

264443</a>

2645]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2646<ul id="_1859">

2647<li>

2648Sixteen of 369 women who received chest irradiation for metastatic Wilms tumor developed invasive breast cancer (cumulative risk at age 40 years, 14.8% [95% CI, 8.7%&#8211;24.5%]). The SIR of 27.6 (95% CI, 16.1&#8211;44.2) was based on 5,010 person-years of follow-up.</li>

2649<li>

2650Of the 369 patients, radiation doses to the chest were less than 12 Gy in 4%, 12 Gy in 64%, 13 Gy to 15 Gy in 19%, and more than 15 Gy in 13% of patients.</li>

2651<li>

2652For all patients who developed breast cancer (with or without chest irradiation), the median age at first breast cancer diagnosis was 34.3 years (range, 15.5&#8211;48.4) and the median time from Wilms tumor diagnosis was 27.1 years (range, 7.9&#8211;35.7).</li>

2653</ul>

2654</div>

2655</li>

2656</ol>

2657</div>

2658</li>

2659<li>

2660The risk of developing breast cancer after radiation therapy and chemotherapy with anthracyclines was evaluated in the CCSS. In a nested-case control study of 271 childhood cancer survivors (diagnosed between 1970&#8211;1986) who were subsequently diagnosed with breast cancer, the combination of anthracyclines and radiation therapy to the breast was associated with increased risks of breast cancer consistent with an additive interaction.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

266133</a>

2662]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2663<ul id="_2299">

2664<li>

2665For the study group, the median age of first cancer diagnosis was 15 years and the median age at breast cancer diagnosis was 39 years.</li>

2666<li>

2667The OR for breast cancer increased with increasing radiation dose to the breast (OR per 10 Gy, 3.9; 95% CI, 2.5&#8211;6.5) and was similar for estrogen receptor&#8211;positive and estrogen receptor&#8211;negative cancers.</li>

2668<li>

2669The OR per 10 Gy to the breast was higher for women who received ovarian doses less than 1 Gy (OR, 6.8; 95% CI, 3.9&#8211;12.5) than for women who received ovarian doses greater than or equal to 15 Gy (OR, 1.4; 95% CI, 1.0&#8211;6.4).</li>

2670<li>

2671The OR for breast cancer increased with cumulative anthracycline dose (OR per 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

26722</span>

2673, 1.23; 95% CI, 1.09&#8211;1.39; <em>

2674P</em>

2675 &lt; .01 for trend).</li>

2676<li>

2677There was an additive interaction between radiation therapy and anthracycline treatment. The OR was 19.1 (95% CI, 7.6&#8211;48.0) for the combined association of anthracycline therapy and breast radiation dose of 10 Gy or more (compared with 0 to less than 1 Gy) versus 9.6 (95% CI, 4.4&#8211;20.7) without anthracycline therapy.</li>

2678</ul>

2679</div>

2680</li>

2681<li>

2682Childhood cancer survivors not exposed to chest radiation also have an increased risk of breast cancer at a young age.<div class="pdq-content-list">

2683<ol id="_2447" class="lower-alpha">

2684<li>

2685A CCSS investigation examined the breast cancer risk of 3,768 female participants who did not receive chest radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

268644</a>

2687] <div class="pdq-content-list">

2688<ul id="_2418">

2689<li>

2690A fourfold excess risk (SIR, 4.0; 95% CI, 3.0&#8211;5.3) of breast cancer was observed compared with rates in the general population.</li>

2691<li>

2692Breast cancer risk was highest among survivors of sarcoma (SIR, 5.3; 95% CI, 3.6&#8211;7.8) and leukemia (SIR, 4.1; 95% CI, 2.4&#8211;6.9), for whom the cumulative incidence of breast cancer was estimated to be 5.8% and 6.3%, respectively, by age 45 years.</li>

2693<li>

2694Treatment with alkylating agents and anthracyclines increased the risk of breast cancer in a dose-dependent manner.</li>

2695</ul>

2696</div>

2697</li>

2698<li>

2699CCSS investigators also examined SN risk among 7,448 participants who were treated with chemotherapy only.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

270012</a>

2701]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2702<ul id="_2419">

2703<li>

2704Breast cancer incidence was 4.6-fold greater than what would be expected in the general population (SIR, 4.6; 95% CI, 3.5&#8211;6.0).</li>

2705<li>

2706A linear dose response was demonstrated between anthracyclines and breast cancer rate (RR, 1.3/100 mg/m<span class="sup">

27072</span>

2708; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;1.6).</li>

2709</ul>

2710</div>

2711</li>

2712</ol>

2713</div>

2714</li>

2715<li>

2716DCOG-LATER investigators evaluated the contribution of chemotherapy to solid cancer risk in a large cohort of childhood cancer survivors diagnosed between 1963 and 2001.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

271713</a>

2718]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2719<ul id="_1862">

2720<li>

2721 Survivors treated with doxorubicin exhibited a dose-dependent increased risk of breast cancer (HR, 3.1; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;6.5 among survivors treated with anthracycline doses of 250 mg/m<span class="sup">

27222</span>

2723 or higher).</li>

2724<li>

2725The doxorubicin&#8211;breast cancer dose response was stronger for survivors of Li-Fraumeni&#8211;associated cancers (leukemia, CNS, and sarcomas other than Ewing) than for survivors of other cancers.</li>

2726</ul>

2727</div>

2728</li>

2729<li>

2730A Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Program&#8211;based study evaluated trends in surgical management and the 5- and 10-year cumulative incidence of contralateral breast cancer among women who were treated with radiation therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma before age 30 years and diagnosed with a subsequent breast cancer between 1990 and 2016.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

273145</a>

2732]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2733<ul id="_3049">

2734<li>

2735Overall, 263 (89.2%) women presented with unilateral breast cancer, 50 of whom (19.0%) underwent breast-conserving surgery and 213 of whom (81.0%) underwent mastectomy (40.5% bilateral).</li>

2736<li>

2737The 5-year incidence of contralateral breast cancer in women who underwent unilateral surgery was 9.4% (95% CI, 5.6%&#8211;15.4%), increasing to 20.2% (95% CI, 13.7%&#8211;29.2%) at 10 years and 29.9% (95% CI, 20.8%&#8211;41.9%) at 15 years. This finding underscores the importance of ongoing breast cancer surveillance and consideration of prophylactic mastectomy.</li>

2738</ul>

2739</div>

2740</li>

2741</ol>

2742</div>

2743<p id="_2863" tabindex="-1">

2744Breast cancer risk varies among childhood cancer survivors who are treated with chest radiation therapy, and the risk is based on multiple clinical factors. The first personalized breast cancer risk prediction model was developed and validated using multinational cohorts of female 5-year cancer survivors who were diagnosed at younger than 21 years and treated with chest irradiation (n = 2,147). The model includes current age, chest radiation field, whether chest radiation was delivered within 1 year of menarche, anthracycline exposure, age of menopause, and history of a first-degree relative with breast cancer. The model is available as an <a href="https://ccss.stjude.org/tools-documents/calculators-other-tools/breast-cancer-probability-calculator.html" title="https://ccss.stjude.org/tools-documents/calculators-other-tools/breast-cancer-probability-calculator.html">

2745online risk calculator</a>

2746.[<a href="#cit/section_2.46">

274746</a>

2748]</p>

2749<section id="_2250">

2750<h5 id="_2250_toc">

2751Subsequent versus de novo breast cancer</h5>

2752<p id="_2251" tabindex="-1">

2753Several studies have investigated the clinical characteristics of subsequent breast cancers arising in women treated with radiation therapy for childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

275447</a>

2755-<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

275651</a>

2757]</p>

2758<div class="pdq-content-list">

2759<ul id="_2252">

2760<li>

2761In one population-based study, radiation-induced breast cancer was noted to have more adverse clinicopathological features, as evidenced by a twofold increased risk of estrogen receptor&#8211;negative, progesterone receptor&#8211;negative breast cancer observed among 15-year Hodgkin lymphoma survivors, compared with women who had sporadic breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.47">

276247</a>

2763]</li>

2764<li>

2765Other studies have observed a higher proportion of more histologically aggressive subtypes (e.g., triple-negative breast cancer) than age-matched sporadic invasive cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.48">

276648</a>

2767,<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

276849</a>

2769]</li>

2770<li>

2771 These findings are in contrast to other smaller, hospital-based, case-control studies of breast cancer among Hodgkin lymphoma survivors that have not identified a significant variation in hormone receptor status when compared with primary breast cancer controls. Previous studies have also not demonstrated a significant difference in overall risk of high-grade versus low-grade tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

277250</a>

2773,<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

277451</a>

2775]</li>

2776<li>

2777A study using SEER Program data evaluated the clinicopathological features of 321 breast cancers diagnosed in 257 women (median age, 22 years; range, 18&#8211;26 years at Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosis) who were previously treated with radiation for Hodgkin lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

277852</a>

2779]<div class="pdq-content-list">

2780<ul id="_2929">

2781<li>

2782Women who developed breast cancer after radiation for Hodgkin lymphoma were younger than women diagnosed with breast cancer without a prior malignancy (43 vs. 60 years) and were less likely to present with ductal carcinoma <em>

2783in situ</em>

2784 (0.4% vs. 14.9%).</li>

2785<li>

2786Radiation was not associated with poorer biological features, compared with breast cancers diagnosed in similarly aged women with no prior malignancy. However, higher proportions of upper outer quadrant and smaller tumors (&#8804;2 cm) were found.</li>

2787<li>

2788Most tumors in survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma were hormone sensitive (nearly two-thirds were estrogen receptor&#8211;positive/HER2-negative). This finding suggests that endocrine prevention may be an option for this high-risk population.</li>

2789</ul>

2790</div>

2791</li>

2792</ul>

2793</div>

2794</section>

2795<section id="_2255">

2796<h5 id="_2255_toc">

2797Mortality after subsequent breast cancer</h5>

2798<p id="_2256" tabindex="-1">

2799In a study of female participants in the CCSS who were subsequently diagnosed with breast cancer (n = 274) and matched to a control group of women (n = 1,095) with de novo breast cancer, the following was observed:[<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

280053</a>

2801] </p>

2802<div class="pdq-content-list">

2803<ul id="_2428">

2804<li>

2805Survivors of childhood cancer were found to have elevated mortality rates (HR, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;3.0), even after adjusting for breast cancer treatment.</li>

2806<li>

2807Survivors were five times more likely to die from other health-related causes, including other SMNs and cardiovascular or pulmonary disease (HR, 5.5; 95% CI, 3.4&#8211;9.0).</li>

2808<li>

2809 The cumulative incidence of a second asynchronous breast cancer was elevated significantly compared with controls (at 5 years, 8.0% among childhood cancer survivors vs. 2.7% among controls; <em>

2810P</em>

2811 &lt; .001).</li>

2812</ul>

2813</div>

2814<p id="_2257" tabindex="-1">

2815Although current evidence does not show a survival benefit from the initiation of breast cancer surveillance in women treated with radiation therapy to the chest for childhood cancer, interventions to promote detection of small and early-stage tumors may improve prognosis. Those with more limited treatment options because of previous exposure to radiation or anthracyclines may especially benefit.</p>

2816<p id="_2429" tabindex="-1">

2817In support of surveillance, SJLIFE investigators observed that breast cancers detected by imaging and/or prophylactic mastectomy were more likely to be <em>

2818in situ</em>

2819 carcinomas, be smaller masses (3.3 cm mean tumor size detected by physical examination vs. 1.1 cm detected by imaging), have no lymph node involvement, and be treated without chemotherapy, compared with breast cancers detected by physical findings.[<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

282025</a>

2821]</p>

2822<p id="_2474" tabindex="-1">

2823Investigators used data from the CCSS and two Cancer Intervention and Surveillance Modeling Network breast cancer simulation models to estimate the clinical benefits, harms, and cost-effectiveness of breast cancer screening among childhood cancer survivors who were previously treated with chest radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.54">

282454</a>

2825]</p>

2826<div class="pdq-content-list">

2827<ul id="_2475">

2828<li>

2829Screening with mammography and MRI, as recommended in COG Long-Term Follow-Up guidelines, is projected to avert half of the expected breast cancer deaths among high-risk survivors.</li>

2830<li>

2831On an annual schedule, a survivor will have an average of 4 to 5 false-positive screening results and 1 to 2 benign biopsy results over the course of their lifetime.</li>

2832<li>

2833Because of the large survival benefits, the harm-benefit tradeoffs for survivors were found to be appropriate, resulting in more favorable harm-benefit ratios.</li>

2834</ul>

2835</div>

2836<p id="_2972" tabindex="-1">

2837Another CCSS investigation quantified the association between temporal changes in cancer treatment over three decades and subsequent breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

283836</a>

2839]</p>

2840<div class="pdq-content-list">

2841<ul id="_2973">

2842<li>

2843The cumulative incidence of breast cancer was 8.1% (95% CI, 7.3%&#8211;9.0%) by age 45 years among 11,550 female survivors (median age, 34.2 years), representing a more than sixfold excess risk (SIR, 6.6; 95% CI, 6.1&#8211;7.2), compared with age-, sex-, and calendar year&#8211;matched controls.</li>

2844<li>

2845Concurrent with changes in therapy by decade, including reduced rates of chest and pelvic radiation therapy and increased rates of anthracycline chemotherapy exposure, and adjusting for age and age at diagnosis, the invasive breast cancer rate decreased 18% for every 5 years of primary cancer diagnosis era (rate ratio, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.74&#8211;0.90). This finding was largely associated with the reduced rate of chest radiation therapy. </li>

2846</ul>

2847</div>

2848</section>

2849</section>

2850<section id="_1844">

2851<h4 id="_1844_toc">

2852Thyroid cancer</h4>

2853<p id="_1845" tabindex="-1">

2854Thyroid cancer is observed after the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

285512</a>

2856,<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

285724</a>

2858,<a href="#cit/section_2.55">

285955</a>

2860,<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

286156</a>

2862]</p>

2863<div class="pdq-content-list">

2864<ul id="_1011" class="list-dash">

2865<li>

2866Neck radiation therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), and brain tumors.</li>

2867<li>

2868Iodine I 131-metaiodobenzylguanidine (131I-MIBG) treatment for neuroblastoma.</li>

2869<li>

2870TBI for HSCT. </li>

2871<li>

2872Chemotherapy only, without therapeutic radiation.</li>

2873</ul>

2874</div>

2875<p id="_1012" tabindex="-1">

2876The 25-year cumulative incidence of thyroid cancer among survivors of childhood cancer is 0.5%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

287713</a>

2878] The risk of thyroid cancer among childhood cancer survivors is more than tenfold higher than that of the general population (SIR, 10.5; 95% CI, 9.1&#8211;12).[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

28794</a>

2880] Significant modifiers of the radiation-related risk of thyroid cancer include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

288128</a>

2882,<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

288357</a>

2884]</p>

2885<div class="pdq-content-list">

2886<ul id="_1013" class="list-dash">

2887<li>

2888Female sex.</li>

2889<li>

2890Younger age at exposure.</li>

2891<li>

2892Longer time since exposure.</li>

2893<li>

2894Radiation dose. A linear dose-response relationship between radiation exposure and thyroid cancer is observed up to 10 Gy, with a leveling off between 10 Gy and 30 Gy, and a decline in the OR at higher doses, especially in children younger than 10 years at treatment, suggesting a cell killing effect of the target cells at higher doses.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

289524</a>

2896,<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

289728</a>

2898,<a href="#cit/section_2.58">

289958</a>

2900]</li>

2901</ul>

2902</div>

2903<p id="_2988" tabindex="-1">

2904In a Dutch case-control study, childhood cancer survivors with subsequent thyroid cancer were more likely to present with smaller tumors and bilateral tumors than the general population. Treatment outcomes were similar between subsequent and sporadic thyroid cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

290559</a>

2906]</p>

2907<p id="_1610" tabindex="-1">

2908For information about detecting thyroid nodules and thyroid cancer, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_807">

2909Thyroid nodules</a>

2910 section.</p>

2911</section>

2912<section id="_1846">

2913<h4 id="_1846_toc">

2914CNS tumors</h4>

2915<p id="_2430" tabindex="-1">

2916Subsequent CNS tumors represent a spectrum of histological subtypes, from high-grade gliomas to benign meningiomas. The CCSS has reported briefer latency for gliomas than for meningiomas.[<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

291760</a>

2918] Accurate assessment of the prevalence of low-grade and benign lesions is challenging because of the variable opinions and practices related to neuroimaging versus symptom surveillance in long-term survivors treated with cranial irradiation. Therefore, the prevalence of these tumors is likely higher than proven.</p>

2919<p id="_1847" tabindex="-1">

2920Brain tumors develop after cranial irradiation for histologically distinct brain tumors or for management of disease among ALL or non-Hodgkin lymphoma patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.61">

292161</a>

2922] SIRs reported for subsequent CNS neoplasms after treatment for childhood cancer range from 8.1 to 52.3 across studies.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

292324</a>

2924]</p>

2925<p id="_973" tabindex="-1">

2926The risk of subsequent brain tumors demonstrates a linear

2927relationship with radiation dose.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

292826</a>

2929,<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

293060</a>

2931]</p>

2932<div class="pdq-content-list">

2933<ul id="_1014" class="list-dash">

2934<li>

2935The risk of meningioma after radiation increases with radiation dose,[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

29369</a>

2937] and in some studies is further potentiated with increased exposure to intrathecal methotrexate.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

293826</a>

2939] However, this finding has not been consistently replicated.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

294010</a>

2941]</li>

2942<li>

2943Cavernomas have also been reported with considerable frequency after CNS irradiation but have been speculated to result from angiogenic processes as opposed to true tumorigenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.62">

294462</a>

2945-<a href="#cit/section_2.64">

294664</a>

2947]</li>

2948</ul>

2949</div>

2950<p id="_2890" tabindex="-1">

2951The Dutch Long-Term Effects after Childhood Cancer (LATER) investigators have described the clinical characteristics of childhood cancer survivors who developed histologically confirmed meningiomas.[<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

295211</a>

2953]</p>

2954<div class="pdq-content-list">

2955<ul id="_2891">

2956<li>

2957In 6,015 childhood cancer survivors from the LATER cohort, 1,551 of whom had prior cranial radiation therapy, 93 survivors developed meningiomas. </li>

2958<li>

2959Of these patients, 89 (95.7%) were treated with prior cranial radiation therapy. The median age at diagnosis was 31.8 years (range, 13.2&#8211;50.5 years). </li>

2960<li>

2961Thirty of the survivors presented with synchronous meningiomas, and 84 survivors presented with symptoms. Only 16% of the meningiomas were detected in late effects clinics.</li>

2962<li>

2963All survivors underwent surgery, and one-third (n = 31) of them also received radiation therapy. Twelve survivors had three or more surgeries for growth of residual tumor, recurrences, and new meningiomas. Although the extent of surgical resection was not described, the indications for radiation therapy during follow-up after surgical resection included residual tumor, recurrences, location, or new meningioma. During follow-up, 38 survivors (40.9%) developed new meningiomas, 22 (23.7%) had recurrences, and at least 4 died because of the meningioma.</li>

2964</ul>

2965</div>

2966<p id="_974" tabindex="-1">

2967Neurological sequelae associated with meningiomas can include seizures, auditory-vestibular-visual deficits, focal neurological dysfunction, and severe headaches.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

29689</a>

2969] Despite the well-established increased risk of subsequent CNS neoplasms among childhood cancer survivors treated with cranial irradiation and the growing recognition of associated morbidity, the current literature is insufficient to evaluate the potential harms and benefits of routine screening for these lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

297065</a>

2971] The decision to initiate surveillance should be shared by the cancer survivor and health care provider after carefully considering the potential harms and benefits of surveillance for CNS neoplasms, such as meningioma.</p>

2972<p id="_2964" tabindex="-1">

2973Proton radiation therapy for pediatric medulloblastoma is associated with low rates of brain stem injury and secondary malignancies. The long-term effects were reported in 178 pediatric patients with medulloblastoma who were treated with surgery, proton radiation therapy, and chemotherapy between 2002 and 2016 (median follow-up, 9.3 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

297466</a>

2975]</p>

2976<div class="pdq-content-list">

2977<ul id="_2965">

2978<li>

2979At 10 years, eight patients (4.5%) developed a secondary tumor (benign or malignant), with median follow up of 9.1 years. Three patients (1.7%) developed a secondary malignancy.</li>

2980<li>

2981In-field second malignancies were glioblastoma (n = 2), meningioma (n = 2), and high-grade glioma (n = 1). The other malignancies were one each of ovarian fibroma, plexiform fibromyxoma of the esophagus, and papillary thyroid carcinoma.</li>

2982<li>

2983Four patients developed brain stem injury at a median of 4.2 years. The 5-year cumulative incidence of brain stem injury was 1.1%, and the 10-year cumulative incidence was 1.9%.</li>

2984</ul>

2985</div>

2986</section>

2987<section id="_1848">

2988<h4 id="_1848_toc">

2989Bone and soft tissue tumors</h4>

2990<p id="_2004" tabindex="-1">

2991 Survivors of hereditary retinoblastoma, Ewing sarcoma, and other malignant bone tumors are at a particularly increased risk of developing subsequent bone and soft tissue tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

299267</a>

2993-<a href="#cit/section_2.71">

299471</a>

2995] </p>

2996<div class="pdq-content-list">

2997<ul id="_2431">

2998<li>

2999Radiation therapy is associated with a linear dose-response

3000relationship.[<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

300172</a>

3002] </li>

3003<li>

3004After adjustment for radiation therapy, treatment with alkylating agents [<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

300513</a>

3006] and anthracyclines [<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

300773</a>

3008] have both been linked to sarcoma, with the risk increasing with cumulative drug exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

300973</a>

3010]</li>

3011<li>

3012 Soft tissue sarcomas can be of various histological subtypes, including nonrhabdomyosarcoma soft tissue sarcomas, rhabdomyosarcoma, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, Ewing/primitive neuroectodermal tumors, and other rare tumor types.</li>

3013</ul>

3014</div>

3015<p id="_2258" tabindex="-1">

3016Evidence (excess risk of bone and soft tissue tumors):</p>

3017<div class="pdq-content-list">

3018<ol id="_2259">

3019<li>

3020A population-based study of 69,460 5-year survivors of cancer diagnosed before age 20 years observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

302168</a>

3022,<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

302369</a>

3024]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3025<ul id="_2260">

3026<li>

3027 The risk of subsequent primary bone cancer was 22-fold greater than that of the general population, with an estimated 45-year cumulative incidence of 0.6%, compared with an expected rate of 0.03% in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

302868</a>

3029]</li>

3030<li>

3031 The observed excess numbers of subsequent primary bone cancer declined with both age and years from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

303268</a>

3033]</li>

3034<li>

3035The risk of subsequent soft tissue sarcoma was almost 16-fold higher than the general population, with an estimated 45-year cumulative incidence of 1.4%, compared with an expected rate of 0.1%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

303669</a>

3037]</li>

3038<li>

3039 The median time from diagnosis to occurrence of a soft tissue sarcoma was 19 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

304069</a>

3041]</li>

3042<li>

3043The most commonly observed soft tissue sarcomas were leiomyosarcoma, fibromatous neoplasms, and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

304469</a>

3045]</li>

3046<li>

3047 The SIR for subsequent fibromatous primary sarcomas decreased with increasing years from diagnosis and attained age, whereas the SIR for leiomyosarcoma and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors remained consistently high across all years from diagnosis and at all attained ages.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

304869</a>

3049]</li>

3050<li>

3051The absolute excess risks of all sarcoma subtypes were generally low, except for leiomyosarcoma that followed a retinoblastoma diagnosis (absolute excess risks, 52.7 per 10,000 person-years among survivors 45 years or more from diagnosis).[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

305269</a>

3053]</li>

3054<li>

3055 The risk of developing a leiomyosarcoma was 30-fold higher among survivors of childhood cancer, compared with an excess risk of 0.7 for the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

305669</a>

3057] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3058<ul id="_2261" class="list-dash">

3059<li>

3060Retinoblastoma survivors were at the highest risk (SIR, 342.9), followed by Wilms tumor survivors (SIR, 74.2). </li>

3061<li>

306290% of leiomyosarcomas observed after a Wilms tumor diagnosis developed within the irradiated tissue.</li>

3063</ul>

3064</div>

3065</li>

3066</ul>

3067</div>

3068</li>

3069<li>

3070In a CCSS cohort, an increased risk of subsequent bone or soft tissue sarcoma was associated with radiation therapy, a primary diagnosis of sarcoma, a history of other SNs, and treatment with higher doses of anthracyclines or alkylating agents.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

307127</a>

3072] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3073<ul id="_2432">

3074<li>

3075The 30-year cumulative incidence of subsequent sarcoma in CCSS participants was 1.08% for survivors who received radiation therapy and 0.5% for survivors who did not receive radiation therapy.</li>

3076</ul>

3077</div>

3078</li>

3079<li>

3080Dose-risk modeling was used to study the risk of bone sarcoma in a retrospective cohort of 4,171 survivors of a childhood solid cancer treated between 1942 and 1986 (median follow-up, 26 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

308172</a>

3082]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3083<ul id="_1864">

3084<li>

3085Results demonstrated that the risk of bone sarcoma increased slightly up to a cumulative organ-absorbed radiation dose of 15 Gy (HR, 8.2; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;42.9) and then rapidly increased for higher radiation doses (HR for 30 Gy or more, 117.9; 95% CI, 36.5&#8211;380.6), compared with patients not treated with radiation therapy.</li>

3086<li>

3087The excess RR per Gy in this model was 1.77 (95% CI, 0.62&#8211;5.94).</li>

3088</ul>

3089</div>

3090</li>

3091<li>

3092 In survivors of bilateral retinoblastoma, the most commonly observed malignant SN is sarcoma, specifically osteosarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.74">

309374</a>

3094-<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

309576</a>

3096] The contribution of chemotherapy to solid malignancy carcinogenesis was highlighted in a long-term follow-up study of 906 5-year hereditary retinoblastoma survivors who were diagnosed between 1914 and 1996 and observed through 2009.[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

309767</a>

3098]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3099<ul id="_1865">

3100<li>

3101 Treatment with alkylating agents significantly increased risk of subsequent bone tumors (HR, 1.60; 95% CI, 1.03&#8211;2.49) and leiomyosarcoma (HR, 2.67; 95% CI, 1.22&#8211;5.85) among members of the cohort.</li>

3102<li>

3103Leiomyosarcoma occurrence was more common after treatment with alkylating agent chemotherapy and radiation therapy compared with radiation therapy alone (5.8% vs. 1.6% at age 40 years; <em>

3104P</em>

3105 = .01).</li>

3106</ul>

3107</div>

3108</li>

3109<li>

3110The CCSS reported the following on 105 cases and 422 matched controls in a nested case-control study of 14,372 childhood cancer survivors:[<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

311173</a>

3112]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3113<ul id="_2262">

3114<li>

3115Soft tissue sarcomas occurred at a median of 11.8 years (range, 5.3&#8211;31.3 years) from original diagnoses. </li>

3116<li>

3117Any exposure to radiation was associated with increased risk of soft tissue sarcoma (OR, 4.1; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;9.5), which demonstrated a linear dose-response relationship.</li>

3118<li>

3119Anthracycline exposure was associated with soft tissue sarcoma risk (OR, 3.5; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;7.7), independent of radiation dose.</li>

3120</ul>

3121</div>

3122</li>

3123<li>

3124In a cohort of 952 irradiated survivors of hereditary retinoblastoma diagnosed between 1914 and 2006, CCSS investigators observed that elevated bone and soft tissue sarcoma risks differed by age, location, and sex.[<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

312576</a>

3126]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3127<ul id="_2185">

3128<li>

3129Head and neck bone and soft tissue sarcomas were diagnosed beginning in early childhood and continued well into adulthood (60-year cumulative incidence of 6.8% and 9.3%, respectively). </li>

3130<li>

3131Body and extremity bone sarcoma incidence flattened after adolescence (60-year cumulative incidence, 3.5%).</li>

3132<li>

3133Body and extremity soft tissue sarcoma incidence was rare until age 30 years, when incidence rose steeply (60-year cumulative incidence, 6.6%) particularly for females (60-year cumulative incidence, 9.4%).</li>

3134</ul>

3135</div>

3136</li>

3137<li>

3138In a retrospective study of 160 patients with hereditary retinoblastoma who received radiation therapy, no correlation was identified between age (before or after 12 months) at which external-beam radiation therapy was given and development of subsequent malignancy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

313970</a>

3140] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3141<ul id="_2433">

3142<li>

3143Patients with and without subsequent malignancies did not differ by <em class="gene-name">

3144RB1</em>

3145 mutation type. Also, there was no association with mutation type and location of SMN, or SMN type and age at diagnosis. </li>

3146<li>

3147The study showed that patients who have a low penetrance mutation and receive external-beam radiation therapy remain at risk of SMNs and should be cautiously monitored.</li>

3148</ul>

3149</div>

3150</li>

3151</ol>

3152</div>

3153</section>

3154<section id="_1850">

3155<h4 id="_1850_toc">

3156Skin cancer</h4>

3157<p id="_1851" tabindex="-1">

3158<strong>

3159Nonmelanoma skin cancers</strong>

3160 (NMSCs) are one of the most common SNs among childhood cancer survivors and show a strong association with radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

31614</a>

3162,<a href="#cit/section_2.77">

316377</a>

3164] Adherence to sun protection behaviors can reduce exposure to UV radiation that may exacerbate risk. </p>

3165<p id="_2991" tabindex="-1">

3166The CCSS performed a randomized, controlled, comparative effectiveness trial to test methods to improve early detection of skin cancer among survivors of childhood cancer at high risk after radiation therapy exposure. Participants were randomly assigned to the experimental arm, which included print materials in combination with mHealth strategies (text messages and use of the Advancing Survivors&#8217; Knowledge website), or the control arm. Screening rates improved by 1.5-fold in the experimental arm. Rates of physician skin examination increased from baseline to 12 months, and rates of self-examination increased from baseline to 18 months in all three intervention groups. However, the increase in rates did not differ between the intervention groups.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

316778</a>

3168]</p>

3169<p id="_2263" tabindex="-1">

3170Evidence (excess risk of NMSCs):</p>

3171<div class="pdq-content-list">

3172<ol id="_2264">

3173<li>

3174Compared with participants who did not receive radiation therapy, CCSS participants treated with radiation therapy had a 6.3-fold increased risk of NMSCs (95% CI, 3.5&#8211;11.3).[<a href="#cit/section_2.79">

317579</a>

3176]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3177<ul id="_2265">

3178<li>

317990% of tumors occurred within the radiation field.</li>

3180<li>

3181A CCSS case-control study of the same cohort reported on subsequent basal cell carcinomas (BCCs). Children who received 35 Gy or more to the skin site had an almost 40-fold excess risk of developing BCCs (OR, 39.8; 95% CI, 8.6&#8211;185), compared with those who did not receive radiation therapy. Results were consistent with a linear dose-response relationship, with an excess OR per Gy of 1.09 (95% CI, 0.49&#8211;2.64). </li>

3182</ul>

3183</div>

3184</li>

3185<li>

3186In 5,843 childhood cancer survivors in the DCOG-LATER cohort, investigators found that childhood cancer survivors had a 30-fold increased risk of developing BCCs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

318730</a>

3188]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3189<ul id="_2266">

3190<li>

3191After a first BCC diagnosis, 46.7% of patients developed additional BCCs. </li>

3192<li>

3193BCC risk was associated with any radiation therapy to the relevant radiation field (site of BCC) (HR, 14.32) and with estimated percentage of exposed skin surface area (26%&#8211;75%: HR, 1.99; 76%&#8211;100%: HR, 2.16 vs. 1%&#8211;25% exposed; <em>

3194P</em>

3195<sub>

3196trend</sub>

3197 among exposed = .002). </li>

3198<li>

3199BCC risk was not associated with prescribed radiation dose and likelihood of sun-exposed skin area. </li>

3200<li>

3201Of all chemotherapy groups examined, only vinca alkaloids increased the BCC risk (HR, 1.54).</li>

3202</ul>

3203</div>

3204</li>

3205<li>

3206The occurrence of an NMSC as the first SN has been reported to identify a population at high risk of a future invasive malignant SN.[<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

32077</a>

3208] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3209<ul id="_2448">

3210<li>

3211CCSS investigators observed a cumulative incidence of a malignant neoplasm of 20.3% (95% CI, 13.0%&#8211;27.6%) at 15 years among radiation-exposed survivors who developed an NMSC as a first SN, compared with 10.7% (95% CI, 7.2%&#8211;14.2%) among survivors whose first SN was an invasive malignancy.</li>

3212</ul>

3213</div>

3214</li>

3215</ol>

3216</div>

3217<p id="_728" tabindex="-1">

3218<strong>

3219Malignant melanoma</strong>

3220 has also been reported as an SN in childhood cancer survivor cohorts, although at a much lower incidence than NMSCs.</p>

3221<p id="_981" tabindex="-1">

3222Risk factors for malignant melanoma identified among these studies include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

322380</a>

3224]</p>

3225<div class="pdq-content-list">

3226<ul id="_982" class="list-dash">

3227<li>

3228Radiation therapy.</li>

3229<li>

3230Combination of alkylating agents and antimitotic drugs. </li>

3231</ul>

3232</div>

3233<p id="_2267" tabindex="-1">

3234Evidence (excess risk of melanoma):</p>

3235<div class="pdq-content-list">

3236<ol id="_2268">

3237<li>

3238 A systematic review that included data from 19 original studies (total N = 151,575 survivors; median follow-up of 13 years) observed an incidence of 10.8 cases of malignant melanoma per 100,000 childhood cancer survivors per year.[<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

323980</a>

3240]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3241<ul id="_2269">

3242<li>

3243Melanomas most frequently developed in survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma, hereditary retinoblastoma, soft tissue sarcoma, and gonadal tumors. However, the relatively small number of survivors represented in the relevant studies preclude assessment of melanoma risk among other types of childhood cancer.</li>

3244</ul>

3245</div>

3246</li>

3247<li>

3248CCSS investigators observed an approximate 2.5-fold increased risk (SIR, 2.42; 95% CI, 1.77&#8211;3.23) of melanoma among members of their cohort (median time to development, 21 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

324981</a>

3250]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3251<ul id="_2270">

3252<li>

3253 The cumulative incidence of first subsequent melanoma at 35 years from initial cancer diagnosis was 0.55% (95% CI, 0.37%&#8211;0.73%), and the absolute excess risk was 0.10 per 1,000 person-years (95% CI, 0.05&#8211;0.15).</li>

3254<li>

3255 Family history of cancer, demographic characteristics, or treatment-related factors did not predict risk of melanoma.</li>

3256</ul>

3257</div>

3258</li>

3259</ol>

3260</div>

3261<section id="_2896">

3262<h5 id="_2896_toc">

3263Skin cancer risk after retinoblastoma</h5>

3264<p id="_2897" tabindex="-1">

3265The incidence of melanoma and NMSC was evaluated in a cohort of 1,851 long-term, White survivors of retinoblastoma (1,020 hereditary and 831 nonhereditary) who were diagnosed from 1914 to 2006 and monitored through 2016.[<a href="#cit/section_2.82">

326682</a>

3267]</p>

3268<div class="pdq-content-list">

3269<ul id="_2898">

3270<li>

3271Of all patients, 33 hereditary and 7 nonhereditary survivors developed melanoma, and 26 hereditary and 9 nonhereditary survivors developed NMSC. The median age of skin cancer development was about 20 years younger for hereditary survivors than nonhereditary survivors. </li>

3272<li>

3273Most NMSCs were on the head/neck, whereas melanomas were more broadly distributed, with patterns similar to melanoma-prone families.</li>

3274<li>

3275At 50 years after retinoblastoma diagnosis, in hereditary survivors, the cumulative incidence of melanoma was 4.5% and the cumulative incidence of NMSC was 3.7%. In nonhereditary survivors, the cumulative incidence of melanoma was 0.7% and the cumulative incidence of NMSC was 1.5%.</li>

3276</ul>

3277</div>

3278</section>

3279</section>

3280<section id="_1852">

3281<h4 id="_1852_toc">

3282Lung cancer</h4>

3283<p id="_1853" tabindex="-1">

3284Among childhood cancer survivor cohorts, lung cancer represents a relatively uncommon SN. There is a long latent period between the childhood cancer diagnosis and the development of a lung SN.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

328513</a>

3286,<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

328783</a>

3288]</p>

3289<p id="_2271" tabindex="-1">

3290Evidence (excess risk of lung cancer):</p>

3291<div class="pdq-content-list">

3292<ol id="_2272">

3293<li>

3294The 30-year cumulative incidence of lung cancer among CCSS participants was 0.16% (95% CI, 0.09%&#8211;0.23%), representing a SIR of 4.0 (95% CI, 2.9&#8211;5.4).[<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

329583</a>

3296]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3297<ul id="_2974">

3298<li>

3299Lung cancer risk demonstrated a dose-related association with chest radiation dose: 10 to 30 Gy (HR, 3.4; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;11.0), more than 30 to 40 Gy (HR, 4.6; 95% CI, 1.5&#8211;14.3), and more than 40 Gy (HR, 9.1; 95% CI, 3.1&#8211;27.0).</li>

3300<li>

3301Cumulative incidence of lung SMNs was higher among current or past smokers, compared with those who had never smoked.</li>

3302<li>

3303The SIR for lung cancer was highest among survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma (SIR, 9.3; 95% CI, 6.2&#8211;13.4) and bone cancer (SIR, 4.4; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;9.1).</li>

3304</ul>

3305</div>

3306</li>

3307<li>

3308The 25-year cumulative incidence of lung cancer among the DCOG-LATER cohort was 0.1% (95% CI, 0.0%&#8211;0.3%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

330913</a>

3310]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3311<ul id="_2449">

3312<li>

3313Incidence was approximately fourfold higher than what would be expected in the general population (SIR, 4.3; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;8.5).</li>

3314</ul>

3315</div>

3316</li>

3317<li>

3318Lung cancer has been reported after chest irradiation for Hodgkin lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

331984</a>

3320]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3321<ul id="_2450">

3322<li>

3323The risk increases in association with longer elapsed time from

3324diagnosis.</li>

3325</ul>

3326</div>

3327</li>

3328<li>

3329Smoking has been linked with the occurrence of lung cancer that develops after radiation therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.84">

333084</a>

3331]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3332<ul id="_2451">

3333<li>

3334The increase in risk of lung cancer with increasing radiation dose is greater among patients who smoke after exposure to radiation than among those who refrain from smoking (<em>

3335P</em>

3336 = .04).</li>

3337</ul>

3338</div>

3339</li>

3340</ol>

3341</div>

3342</section>

3343<section id="_1854">

3344<h4 id="_1854_toc">

3345Gastrointestinal (GI) cancer</h4>

3346<p id="_1855" tabindex="-1">

3347There is substantial evidence that childhood cancer survivors develop GI malignancies more frequently and at a younger age than the general population. This evidence supports the need for early initiation of colorectal carcinoma surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

334818</a>

3349,<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

335085</a>

3351-<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

335287</a>

3353]</p>

3354<p id="_2273" tabindex="-1">

3355Evidence (excess risk of GI cancer):</p>

3356<div class="pdq-content-list">

3357<ol id="_1868">

3358<li>

3359In a French and British cohort-nested, case-control study of childhood solid tumor survivors diagnosed before age 17 years, the risk of developing a digestive organ SN varied with therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

336085</a>

3361]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3362<ul id="_1020">

3363<li>

3364The risk of GI cancer was 9.7-fold higher than in population controls. </li>

3365<li>

3366The SNs most often involved the colon/rectum (42%), liver (24%), and stomach (19%).</li>

3367<li>

3368A strong radiation dose-response relationship was observed, with an OR of 5.2 (95% CI, 1.7&#8211;16.0) for local radiation doses between 10 Gy to 29 Gy and 9.6 (95% CI, 2.6&#8211;35.2) for doses of 30 Gy and above, compared with survivors who had not received radiation therapy.</li>

3369<li>

3370Chemotherapy alone and combined-modality therapy were associated with a significantly increased risk of developing a GI SN (SIR, 9.1; 95% CI, 2.3&#8211;23.6; SIR 29.0; 95% CI, 20.5&#8211;39.8, respectively).</li>

3371</ul>

3372</div>

3373</li>

3374<li>

3375CCSS investigators reported a 4.6-fold higher risk of GI SNs among their study participants than in the general population (95% CI, 3.4&#8211;6.1).[<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

337686</a>

3377]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3378<ul id="_1021">

3379<li>

3380The SNs most often involved the colon (39%), rectum/anus (16%), liver (18%), and stomach (13%).</li>

3381<li>

3382The SIR for colorectal cancer was 4.2 (CI, 2.8&#8211;6.3).</li>

3383<li>

3384The most prevalent GI SN histology was adenocarcinoma (56%).</li>

3385<li>

3386The highest risk of GI SNs was associated with abdominal irradiation (SIR, 11.2; CI, 7.6&#8211;16.4), but survivors not exposed to radiation also had a significantly increased risk (SIR, 2.4; CI, 1.4&#8211;3.9).</li>

3387<li>

3388High-dose procarbazine (RR, 3.2; CI, 1.1&#8211;9.4) and platinum drugs (RR, 7.6; CI, 2.3&#8211;25.5) independently increased the risk of GI SNs. </li>

3389</ul>

3390</div>

3391</li>

3392<li>

3393St. Jude Children's Research Hospital investigators observed that the SIR for subsequent colorectal carcinoma was 10.9 (95% CI, 6.6&#8211;17.0) compared with U.S. population controls. Investigators also observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

339487</a>

3395]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3396<ul id="_1022">

3397<li>

3398Incidence of a subsequent colorectal carcinoma increased steeply with advancing attained age, with a 40-year cumulative incidence of 1.4% &#177; 0.53% among the entire cohort (N = 13,048) and 2.3% &#177; 0.83% for 5-year survivors. </li>

3399<li>

3400Colorectal carcinoma risk increased by 70% with each 10 Gy increase in radiation dose. Increasing radiation volume also increased the risk.</li>

3401<li>

3402Treatment with alkylating agent chemotherapy was also associated with an 8.8-fold excess risk of subsequent colorectal carcinoma. </li>

3403</ul>

3404</div>

3405</li>

3406<li>

3407A multi-institutional prospective study observed that potentially precancerous neoplastic polyps were found in 27.8% of childhood cancer survivors who received radiation to the abdomen/pelvis at least 10 years earlier and who had colonoscopic screening between age 35 and 49 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

340888</a>

3409] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3410<ul id="_2037">

3411<li>

3412This polyp prevalence is at least as high as that previously reported for the average-risk population older than 50 years and is similar to the 24% incidence rate for patients with hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer. Polyp prevalence rates in the general population for people aged 35 to 49 years are unclear.</li>

3413</ul>

3414</div>

3415</li>

3416<li>

3417A DCOG-LATER record linkage study evaluated the risk of histologically confirmed colorectal adenomas among 5,843 5-year childhood cancer survivors followed for a median of 24.9 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.89">

341889</a>

3419]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3420<ul id="_2038">

3421<li>

3422The cumulative incidence of colorectal adenoma by age 45 years was 3.6% among survivors who received abdominal pelvic radiation versus 2.0% for survivors who did not receive abdominal pelvic radiation, versus 1.0% among siblings.</li>

3423<li>

3424Factors associated with adenoma risk were abdominal pelvic radiation (HR, 2.1), TBI (HR, 10.6), cisplatin (HR, 2.1 for &lt;480 mg/m<span class="sup">

34252</span>

3426; HR, 3.8 for &#8805;480 mg/m<span class="sup">

34272</span>

3428), diagnosis of hepatoblastoma (HR, 27.1), and family history of early-onset colorectal cancer (HR, 20.5).</li>

3429<li>

3430Procarbazine exposure was also associated with an increased risk among survivors not exposed to abdominal pelvic radiation or TBI (HR, 2.7).</li>

3431</ul>

3432</div>

3433</li>

3434<li>

3435The PanCare Childhood and Adolescent Cancer Survivor Care and Follow-Up Studies (PanCareSurFup) consortium reported on digestive cancers in a cohort of 69,460 5-year childhood cancer survivors in Europe.[<a href="#cit/section_2.90">

343690</a>

3437]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3438<ul id="_2989">

3439<li>

3440Survivors of Wilms tumor (SIR, 12.1; 95% CI, 9.6&#8211;15.1) and Hodgkin lymphoma (SIR, 7.3; 95% CI, 5.9&#8211;9.0) were at the highest risk for GI SMNs.</li>

3441<li>

3442By age 55 years, 2.3% of survivors of Wilms tumor and Hodgkin lymphoma developed a secondary colorectal cancer, a rate that is comparable to that of the general population with two or more first-degree relatives affected by GI cancer.</li>

3443</ul>

3444</div>

3445</li>

3446<li>

3447A nested case-control study examined the rate of colorectal cancer according to large bowel radiation therapy dose and procarbazine dose among 5-year Hodgkin lymphoma survivors who were diagnosed between age 15 and 50 years (only 27% of cases were 15 to 24 years old) at five hospital centers in the Netherlands (diagnosed between 1964 to 2000; median follow-up, 26 years).[<a href="#cit/section_2.91">

344891</a>

3449]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3450<ul id="_3029">

3451<li>

3452The median interval between Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosis and subsequent colorectal cancer was 25.7 years (range, 18.2&#8211;31.6 years).</li>

3453<li>

3454Treatment with subdiaphragmatic radiation therapy (RR, 2.4; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;4.1) and more than 8.4 g/m<span class="sup">

34552</span>

3456 of procarbazine (RR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.3&#8211;5.0) were associated with increased rates of colorectal cancer on univariable analysis.</li>

3457<li>

3458Colorectal cancer rate increased linearly with mean radiation therapy dose to the whole large bowel and dose to the affected bowel segment. The dose response became steeper with higher doses of procarbazine and increased 1.2-fold (95% CI, 1.1&#8211;1.3) for each 1 g/m<span class="sup">

34592</span>

3460 increase in procarbazine.</li>

3461</ul>

3462</div>

3463</li>

3464</ol>

3465</div>

3466</section>

3467<section id="_3030">

3468<h4 id="_3030_toc">

3469Oral cancers</h4>

3470<p id="_3031" tabindex="-1">

3471The PanCareSurFup consortium reported on risks of oral second primary neoplasms (validated through pathology reports) in a cohort of 69,460 5-year childhood cancer survivors in Europe.[<a href="#cit/section_2.92">

347292</a>

3473]</p>

3474<div class="pdq-content-list">

3475<ul id="_3032">

3476<li>

3477Oral second primary neoplasms (n = 145; 64 salivary gland, 38 tongue, 20 pharynx, 2 lip, and 21 other) developed in 143 survivors at a median age of 32 years. This represents a fivefold excess risk compared with that expected in the general population.</li>

3478<li>

3479Childhood cancer diagnostic groups at greatest risk for an oral second primary neoplasm included leukemia (SIR, 19.2; 95% CI, 14.6&#8211;25.2), bone sarcoma (SIR, 6.4; 95% CI, 3.7&#8211;11.0), Hodgkin lymphoma (SIR, 6.2; 95% CI, 3.9&#8211;9.9), and soft tissue sarcoma (SIR, 5.0; 95% CI, 3.0&#8211;8.5).</li>

3480<li>

3481Observed specific treatment associations with oral second primary neoplasms included radiation therapy and salivary gland neoplasms (SIR, 33; 95% CI, 25.3&#8211;44.5) and chemotherapy (any exposure) and tongue neoplasms (SIR, 15.9; 95% CI, 10.6&#8211;23.7).</li>

3482<li>

3483Data were not available to assess the contributions of health behaviors (smoking, alcohol intake) and HPV infection status to the development of oral second primary neoplasms.</li>

3484</ul>

3485</div>

3486</section>

3487<section id="_3044">

3488<h4 id="_3044_toc">

3489Urogenital cancers</h4>

3490<p id="_3045" tabindex="-1">

3491Development of subsequent primary urogenital cancers in childhood and adolescent cancer survivors is rare. </p>

3492<p id="_3046" tabindex="-1">

3493Using SEER data of 43,991 patients (aged &lt;20 years) diagnosed with a first primary cancer from 1975 to 2016, the risk of urinary system cancer was higher for both females (SIR, 5.18; 95% CI, 3.65&#8211;7.14) and males (SIR, 2.80; 95% CI, 1.94&#8211;3.92), compared with the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.93">

349493</a>

3495]</p>

3496<div class="pdq-content-list">

3497<ul id="_3047">

3498<li>

3499Females were more likely than males to develop a subsequent urinary system cancer (SIR, 1.86; 95% CI, 1.13&#8211;3.03) and kidney cancer (SIR, 1.97; 95% CI, 1.11&#8211;3.53).</li>

3500<li>

3501Females with any first cancer had higher risks than the general population for developing cancers of the corpus uteri (SIR, 2.32; 95% CI, 1.49&#8211;3.45) and vulva (SIR, 4.27; 95% CI, 1.38&#8211;9.95).</li>

3502</ul>

3503</div>

3504</section>

3505<section id="_1856">

3506<h4 id="_1856_toc">

3507Renal carcinoma</h4>

3508<p id="_1857" tabindex="-1">

3509Consistent with reports among survivors of adult-onset cancer, an increased risk of renal carcinoma has been observed in survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.29">

351029</a>

3511,<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

351294</a>

3513,<a href="#cit/section_2.95">

351495</a>

3515] Underlying genetic predisposition may also play a role in the risk of developing renal carcinomas because rare cases of renal carcinoma have been observed in children with tuberous sclerosis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

351694</a>

3517] Cases of secondary renal carcinoma associated with Xp11.2 translocations and <em class="gene-name">

3518TFE3</em>

3519 gene fusions have also been reported and suggest that cytotoxic chemotherapy may contribute to renal carcinogenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.96">

352096</a>

3521-<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

352298</a>

3523]</p>

3524<p id="_2274" tabindex="-1">

3525Evidence (excess risk of renal carcinoma):</p>

3526<div class="pdq-content-list">

3527<ol id="_2275">

3528<li>

3529CCSS investigators reported a significant excess of subsequent renal carcinoma among 14,358 5-year survivors in the cohort (SIR, 8.0; 95% CI, 5.2&#8211;11.7) compared with the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

353094</a>

3531]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3532<ol id="_2462" class="lower-alpha">

3533<li>

3534 The reported overall absolute excess risk of 8.4 per 10<span class="sup">

35355</span>

3536 person-years indicates that these cases are relatively rare. Highest risk was observed among the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

3537<ul id="_2420">

3538<li>

3539Neuroblastoma survivors (SIR, 85.8; 95% CI, 38.4&#8211;175.2).[<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

354094</a>

3541] Radiation has been hypothesized to predispose children with high-risk neuroblastoma to renal carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.99">

354299</a>

3543] </li>

3544<li>

3545Those treated with renal-directed radiation therapy of 5 Gy or higher (RR, 3.8; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;9.3).[<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

354694</a>

3547]</li>

3548<li>

3549Those treated with platinum-based chemotherapy (RR, 3.5; 95% CI, 1.0&#8211;11.2).[<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

355094</a>

3551]</li>

3552</ul>

3553</div>

3554</li>

3555</ol>

3556</div>

3557</li>

3558</ol>

3559</div>

3560</section>

3561</section>

3562<section id="_2253">

3563<h3 id="_2253_toc">

3564Survival Outcomes After SNs</h3>

3565<p id="_2281" tabindex="-1">

3566Outcome after the diagnosis of an SN is variable, as treatment for some histological subtypes may be compromised if childhood cancer therapy included cumulative doses of agents and modalities at the threshold of tissue tolerance.</p>

3567<p id="_2158" tabindex="-1">

3568Using data from the SEER Program, individuals younger than 60 years with first primary malignancies (n = 1,332,203) were compared with childhood cancer survivors (n = 1,409) who had a second primary malignancy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.100">

3569100</a>

3570] </p>

3571<div class="pdq-content-list">

3572<ul id="_2434">

3573<li>

3574Survivors of childhood cancer diagnosed with a second primary malignancy experienced poorer overall survival than did their peers without a history of cancer (HR, 1.86; 95% Cl, 1.72&#8211;2.02) after the study had accounted for cancer type, age, sex, race, and decade of diagnosis.</li>

3575<li>

3576 A history of childhood cancer was consistently associated with a twofold to threefold increased risk of death for the most diagnosed second primary malignancies, including breast cancer, thyroid cancer, AML, brain cancer, melanoma, bone cancer, and soft tissue sarcoma.</li>

3577</ul>

3578</div>

3579<p id="_2280" tabindex="-1">

3580In a study of female participants in the CCSS who were subsequently diagnosed with breast cancer (n = 274) and matched to a control group of women (n = 1,095) with de novo breast cancer, survivors of childhood cancer were found to have elevated mortality rates (HR, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;3.0) even after adjusting for breast cancer treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

358153</a>

3582] </p>

3583<div class="pdq-content-list">

3584<ul id="_2435">

3585<li>
