3586Survivors were five times more likely to die as a result of other health-related causes, including other SMNs and cardiovascular or pulmonary disease (HR, 5.5; 95% CI, 3.4&#8211;9.0).</li>

3587<li>

3588 The cumulative incidence of a second asynchronous breast cancer was elevated significantly compared with controls (at 5 years, 8.0% among childhood cancer survivors vs. 2.7% among controls; <em>

3589P</em>

3590 &lt; .001).</li>

3591</ul>

3592</div>

3593</section>

3594<section id="_299">

3595<h3 id="_299_toc">

3596Subsequent Neoplasms and Genetic Susceptibility</h3>

3597<p id="_300" tabindex="-1">

3598Literature clearly supports the role of chemotherapy and radiation therapy in the development of SNs. However, interindividual variability exists, suggesting that genetic variation has a role in susceptibility to genotoxic exposures, or that genetic susceptibility syndromes confer an increased risk of cancer, such as Li-Fraumeni syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.101">

3599101</a>

3600,<a href="#cit/section_2.102">

3601102</a>

3602] In a population-based Swiss Childhood Cancer Survivor Study, cancer predisposition syndromes were associated with a high risk of second primary neoplasms before the age of 21 years and represented the most important risk factor (HR, 7.8; 95% CI, 4.8&#8211;12.7) for developing a second primary cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

3603103</a>

3604] </p>

3605<p id="_2277" tabindex="-1">

3606 Previous studies have demonstrated that childhood cancer survivors with a family history of Li-Fraumeni syndrome in particular, or a family history of cancer, carry an increased risk of developing an SN.[<a href="#cit/section_2.104">

3607104</a>

3608,<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

3609105</a>

3610] A prospective registry followed 480 individuals with pathogenic or likely pathogenic germline <em class="gene-name">

3611TP53</em>

3612 variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.106">

3613106</a>

3614] Individuals who developed a first cancer were monitored for the development of a second malignant neoplasm. Among individuals who were younger than 17 years at the time of diagnosis of their first cancer, 50% developed a second cancer within 20 years.</p>

3615<p id="_987" tabindex="-1">

3616The risk of SNs could potentially be modified by mutations in high-penetrance genes that lead to these serious genetic diseases (e.g., Li-Fraumeni syndrome).[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

3617105</a>

3618] However, the attributable risk is expected to be very small because of the extremely low prevalence of mutations in high-penetrance genes. </p>

3619<p id="_2278" tabindex="-1">

3620Likewise, children with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) who develop a primary tumor are at an increased risk of SNs compared with childhood cancer survivors without NF1. Treatment with radiation, but not alkylating agents, increases the risk of SNs in survivors with NF1.[<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

3621107</a>

3622] SNs represent a major contributor to excess mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with NF1.[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

3623108</a>

3624] These survivors developed late-onset (&gt;5 years from diagnosis) SMNs at four times the rate of glioma survivors without NF1 (4.02; range, 2.12&#8211;7.62). The 30-year, all-cause late mortality rate was 46.3% (95% CI, 23.9%&#8211;62.2%) in glioma survivors with NF1, compared with 18% (95% CI, 16.1%&#8211;20.0%) in glioma survivors without NF1. The most common causes of death among survivors with NF1 and glioma were SNs.</p>

3625<p id="_988" tabindex="-1">

3626<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_510">

3627Table 1</a>

3628 summarizes the spectrum of neoplasms, affected genes, and Mendelian mode of inheritance of selected syndromes of inherited cancer predisposition.</p>

3629<table id="_510" class="table-default expandable-container">

3630<caption>

3631Table 1. Selected Syndromes of Inherited Cancer Predisposition<span class="sup">

3632a</span>

3633 </caption>

3637<col width="25.00%">

3638<col width="25.00%">

3900<td>

3901Wilms tumor</td>

3902<td align="Center" scope="col">

3903<em class="gene-name">

3904WT1</em>

3905</td>

3906<td align="Center" scope="col">

3907Dominant</td>

3908</tr>

3909<tr>

3910<td>

3911Xeroderma pigmentosum</td>

3912<td>

3913Leukemia, melanoma </td>

3914<td align="Center" scope="col">

3915<em class="gene-name">

3916XPA, XPB, XPC, XPD, XPE, XPF, XPG, POLH</em>

3917</td>

3918<td align="Center" scope="col">

3919Recessive</td>

3920</tr>

3921</tbody>

3922</table>

3923<p id="_2878" tabindex="-1">

3924The <a href="https://mipogg.com/" title="https://mipogg.com/">

3925McGill Interactive Pediatric OncoGenetic Guidelines (MIPOGG) tool</a>

3926 identifies children with cancer who have an increased likelihood of having a cancer predisposition syndrome. This tool guides clinicians through a series of yes or no questions, and it generates a recommendation for or against genetic evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.110">

3927110</a>

3928,<a href="#cit/section_2.111">

3929111</a>

3930]</p>

3931<div class="pdq-content-list">

3932<ul id="_2879">

3933<li>

3934In a population-based, nested, case-control study, the MIPOGG tool identified survivors who were at increased risk of developing SMNs, after controlling for radiation and chemotherapy exposures (HR, 1.53; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;2.19).</li>

3935<li>

3936 SMN prediction was superior in survivors of CNS and solid tumor neoplasms and in survivors who were not irradiated during treatment of their primary malignancy.</li>

3937<li>

3938Use of the MIPOGG tool in pediatric oncology patients, at diagnosis or in survivorship follow-up, may help prioritize those who should undergo genetic evaluation.</li>

3939</ul>

3940</div>

3941<section id="_652">

3942<h4 id="_652_toc">

3943Drug-metabolizing enzymes and DNA repair polymorphisms</h4>

3944<p id="_653" tabindex="-1">

3945The interindividual variability in risk of SNs is more likely related to common polymorphisms in low-penetrance genes that regulate the availability of active drug metabolites or are responsible for DNA repair. Gene-environment interactions may magnify subtle functional differences resulting from genetic variations. </p>

3946<p id="_2454" tabindex="-1">

3947In related research, SJLIFE investigators evaluated cancer treatments and pathogenic germline mutations in 127 genes from six major DNA repair pathways to identify childhood cancer survivors at an increased risk of SNs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.112">

3948112</a>

3949]</p>

3950<div class="pdq-content-list">

3951<ul id="_2455">

3952<li>

3953Among 4,402 survivors who underwent whole-genome sequencing, 495 (11.2%) developed 1,269 SNs.</li>

3954<li>

3955Among 508 survivors (11.5%), 538 pathogenic germline mutations were identified in 98 DNA repair pathways (e.g., <em class="gene-name">

3956POLG</em>

3957, <em class="gene-name">

3958MUTYH</em>

3959, <em class="gene-name">

3960ERCC2</em>

3961, and <em class="gene-name">

3962BRCA2</em>

3963).<p id="_2730" tabindex="-1">

3964The following three groups were identified to have an elevated risk of SNs:</p>

3965<div class="pdq-content-list">

3966<ul id="_2456">

3967<li>

3968Female survivors with mutations in homologous recombination genes who were treated with high doses (&#8805;20 Gy) of chest radiation (RR, 4.4; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;12.4) or a cumulative dose of anthracyclines in the second or third tertile (RR, 4.4; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;11.4) had a significantly increased risk of breast cancer.</li>

3969<li>

3970Survivors with mutations in homologous recombination genes who received alkylating agent doses in the third tertile had an increased rate of subsequent sarcomas (RR, 14.9; 95% CI, 4.0&#8211;38.0).</li>

3971<li>

3972Survivors with mutations in nucleotide excision repair genes who were treated with neck radiation (&#8805;30 Gy) had an increased risk of subsequent thyroid cancer (RR, 12.9; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;46.6).</li>

3973</ul>

3974</div>

3975</li>

3976</ul>

3977</div>

3978<section id="_654">

3979<h5 id="_654_toc">

3980Drug-metabolizing enzymes</h5>

3981<p id="_655" tabindex="-1">

3982Metabolism of genotoxic agents occurs in two phases. </p>

3983<div class="pdq-content-list">

3984<ol id="_1024">

3985<li>

3986Phase I involves activation of substrates into highly reactive electrophilic intermediates that can damage DNA, a reaction principally performed by the cytochrome p450 (CYP) family of enzymes.</li>

3987<li>

3988Phase II enzymes (conjugation) function to inactivate genotoxic substrates. The phase II proteins comprise the glutathione S-transferase (GST) enzymes, NAD(P)H:quinone oxidoreductase-1 (NQO1) enzyme, and others. </li>

3989</ol>

3990</div>

3991<p id="_1025" tabindex="-1">

3992The balance between the two sets of enzymes is critical to the cellular response to xenobiotics; for example, high activity of a phase I enzyme and low activity of a phase II enzyme can result in DNA damage.</p>

3993</section>

3994<section id="_656">

3995<h5 id="_656_toc">

3996DNA repair polymorphisms</h5>

3997<p id="_657" tabindex="-1">

3998DNA repair mechanisms protect somatic cells from mutations in tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes that can lead to cancer initiation and progression. An individual&#8217;s DNA repair capacity appears to be genetically determined.[<a href="#cit/section_2.113">

3999113</a>

4000] A number of DNA repair genes contain polymorphic variants, resulting in large interindividual variations in DNA repair capacity.[<a href="#cit/section_2.113">

4001113</a>

4002] Evaluation of the contribution of polymorphisms influencing DNA repair to the risk of SN represents an active area of research. </p>

4003</section>

4004</section>

4005</section>

4006<section id="_305">

4007<h3 id="_305_toc">

4008Screening and Follow-up for Subsequent Neoplasms</h3>

4009<p id="_306" tabindex="-1">

4010Vigilant screening is important for childhood cancer survivors at risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.114">

4011114</a>

4012] Because of the relatively small size of the pediatric cancer survivor population and the prevalence and time to onset of therapy-related complications, undertaking clinical studies to assess the impact of screening recommendations on the morbidity and mortality associated with the late effect is not feasible. </p>

4013<p id="_1026" tabindex="-1">

4014Well-conducted studies of large populations of childhood cancer survivors have provided compelling evidence linking specific therapeutic exposures and late effects. This evidence has been used by several national and international cooperative groups (Scottish Collegiate Guidelines Network, Children&#8217;s Cancer and Leukaemia Group, <a href="https://childrensoncologygroup.org/" title="https://childrensoncologygroup.org/">

4015Children's Oncology Group [COG]</a>

4016, DCOG) to develop consensus-based clinical practice guidelines to increase awareness and standardize the immediate care needs of medically vulnerable childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.115">

4017115</a>

4018]</p>

4019<p id="_989" tabindex="-1">

4020All pediatric cancer survivor health screening guidelines employ a hybrid approach that is both evidence-based (using established associations between therapeutic exposures and late effects to identify high-risk categories) and grounded in the collective clinical experience of experts (matching the magnitude of the risk with the intensity of the screening recommendations). The screening recommendations in these guidelines represent a statement of consensus from a panel of experts in the late effects of pediatric cancer treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.114">

4021114</a>

4022,<a href="#cit/section_2.115">

4023115</a>

4024]</p>

4025<p id="_466" tabindex="-1">

4026The COG Guidelines for malignant SNs indicate that certain high-risk populations of childhood cancer survivors merit heightened surveillance because of predisposing host, behavioral, or therapeutic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.114">

4027114</a>

4028]</p>

4029<div class="pdq-content-list">

4030<ul id="_431">

4031<li>

4032<strong>

4033Screening for leukemia:</strong>

4034 MDS-pCT or AML-pCT usually manifests within 10 years after exposure. Recommendations include monitoring with history and physical examination for signs and symptoms of pancytopenia for 10 years after exposure to alkylating agents or topoisomerase II inhibitors. </li>

4035<li>

4036<strong>

4037Screening after radiation exposure:</strong>

4038 Most other SNs are associated with radiation exposure and usually manifest more than 10 years after exposure. Screening recommendations include careful annual physical examination of the skin and exposed (often underlying) tissues in the radiation field. <p id="_1027" tabindex="-1">

4039Specific comments about screening for more common radiation-associated SNs are as follows:</p>

4040<div class="pdq-content-list">

4041<ul id="_508" class="list-dash">

4042<li>

4043<strong>

4044Screening for early-onset skin cancer:</strong>

4045 Annual dermatological exam focusing on skin lesions and pigmented nevi in the radiation field is recommended. Survivors are counseled about the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

4046<ul id="_1028">

4047<li>

4048 Increased risk of skin cancer. </li>

4049<li>

4050Potential exacerbation of risk through tanning.</li>

4051<li>

4052Benefits of adhering to behaviors to protect the skin from excessive UV radiation exposure.</li>

4053</ul>

4054</div>

4055</li>

4056<li>

4057<strong>

4058Screening for early-onset breast cancer:</strong>

4059 Because outcome after breast cancer is directly linked to stage at diagnosis, close surveillance that results in early diagnosis may improve survival.[<a href="#cit/section_2.116">

4060116</a>

4061] Several pediatric cancer groups have endorsed the recommendation for early (before population breast cancer screening) initiation of breast cancer surveillance using mammography, breast MRI, or both imaging modalities in young women who were treated with chest irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.116">

4062116</a>

4063] <p id="_924" tabindex="-1">

4064Mammography, the most widely accepted screening tool for breast cancer in the general population, may not be the ideal screening tool by itself for radiation-related breast cancers occurring in relatively young women with dense breasts. On the basis of research among young women with inherited susceptibility to breast cancer, dual-imaging modalities may enhance early detection related to the higher sensitivity of MRI in detecting lesions in premenopausal dense breasts and the superiority of mammography in identifying ductal carcinoma <em>

4065in situ</em>

4066;[<a href="#cit/section_2.117">

4067117</a>

4068-<a href="#cit/section_2.119">

4069119</a>

4070] therefore, the American Cancer Society recommends including adjunct screening with MRI.[<a href="#cit/section_2.120">

4071120</a>

4072] The high sensitivity and specificity in detecting early-stage lesions with dual-imaging surveillance is offset by a substantial rate of additional investigations attributable to false-positive results.[<a href="#cit/section_2.119">

4073119</a>

4074] </p>

4075<p id="_925" tabindex="-1">

4076Many clinicians are concerned about potential harms related to radiation exposure associated with annual mammography in these young women. In this regard, it is important to consider that the estimated mean breast dose with contemporary standard two-view screening mammograms is about 3.85 mGy to 4.5 mGy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

4077121</a>

4078-<a href="#cit/section_2.123">

4079123</a>

4080] Thus, 15 additional surveillance mammograms from age 25 to 39 years would increase the total radiation exposure in a woman treated with 20 Gy of chest radiation to 20.05775 Gy. The benefits of detection of early breast cancer lesions in high-risk women must be balanced by the risk predisposed by a 0.3% additional radiation exposure. </p>

4081<p id="_926" tabindex="-1">

4082To keep young women engaged in breast health surveillance, the COG Guideline recommends the following for females who received a radiation dose of <strong>

408310 Gy or higher</strong>

4084 to the mantle, mediastinal, whole lung, and axillary fields:</p>

4085<div class="pdq-content-list">

4086<ul id="_1029">

4087<li>

4088Monthly breast self-examination beginning at puberty.</li>

4089<li>

4090Annual clinical breast examinations beginning at puberty until age 25 years.</li>

4091<li>

4092A clinical breast examination every 6 months, with annual mammograms and MRIs beginning 8 years after radiation therapy or at age 25 years (whichever occurs later).</li>

4093</ul>

4094</div>

4095<p id="_927" tabindex="-1">

4096The risk of breast cancer in patients who received <strong>

4097less than 10 Gy</strong>

4098 of radiation with potential impact to the breast is of a lower magnitude compared with those who received 10 Gy or higher. Monitoring of patients treated with less than 10 Gy of radiation with potential impact to the breast is determined on an individual basis after a discussion with the provider regarding the benefits and risk/harms of screening. If a decision is made to screen, the recommendations for women exposed to 10 Gy or higher are used.</p>

4099</li>

4100<li>

4101<strong>

4102Screening for thyroid cancer:</strong>

4103 Surveillance recommendations for thyroid cancer among survivors treated with radiation therapy to the thyroid gland vary a great deal. Consensus recommendations for surveillance were developed by the International Guidelines Harmonization Group (IGHG) with the PanCareSurFup consortium. Ultimately, neither of the two surveillance strategies, thyroid ultrasonography and neck palpation, was demonstrated to be superior. This finding highlights the need for shared decision-making between the medical provider and patient.[<a href="#cit/section_2.124">

4104124</a>

4105]</li>

4106<li>

4107<strong>

4108Screening for subsequent CNS neoplasms:</strong>

4109 The IGHG identified a paucity of high-quality evidence for CNS screening. The group determined there was insufficient evidence to establish whether early CNS neoplasm detection results in reduced morbidity and/or mortality. Therefore, a recommendation was not made for or against MRI surveillance. Shared decision-making between the medical provider and survivor is recommended to formulate a screening plan.[<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

411065</a>

4111]</li>

4112<li>

4113<strong>

4114Screening for early-onset colorectal cancer:</strong>

4115 Screening of those at risk of early-onset colorectal cancer (i.e., radiation doses of 20 Gy or higher to the abdomen, pelvis, or spine) includes colonoscopy every 5 years or multitarget stool DNA test every 3 years beginning at age 30 years or 5 years after radiation therapy (whichever occurs later). For more information, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

4116COG Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

4117.</li>

4118</ul>

4119</div>

4120</li>

4121</ul>

4122</div>

4123</section>
