J Clin Oncol 38 (35): 4194-4207, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33078972&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33078972&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4589[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4590</li>

4591<li id="section_2.117">

4592Kriege M, Brekelmans CT, Boetes C, et al.: Efficacy of MRI and mammography for breast-cancer screening in women with a familial or genetic predisposition. N Engl J Med 351 (5): 427-37, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15282350&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15282350&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4593[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4594</li>

4595<li id="section_2.118">

4596Leach MO, Boggis CR, Dixon AK, et al.: Screening with magnetic resonance imaging and mammography of a UK population at high familial risk of breast cancer: a prospective multicentre cohort study (MARIBS). Lancet 365 (9473): 1769-78, 2005 May 21-27.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15910949&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15910949&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4597[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4598</li>

4599<li id="section_2.119">

4600Tieu MT, Cigsar C, Ahmed S, et al.: Breast cancer detection among young survivors of pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma with screening magnetic resonance imaging. Cancer 120 (16): 2507-13, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24888639&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24888639&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4601[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4602</li>

4603<li id="section_2.120">

4604Saslow D, Boetes C, Burke W, et al.: American Cancer Society guidelines for breast screening with MRI as an adjunct to mammography. CA Cancer J Clin 57 (2): 75-89, 2007 Mar-Apr.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17392385&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17392385&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4605[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4606</li>

4607<li id="section_2.121">

4608Berrington de Gonzalez A, Berg CD, Visvanathan K, et al.: Estimated risk of radiation-induced breast cancer from mammographic screening for young BRCA mutation carriers. J Natl Cancer Inst 101 (3): 205-9, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19176458&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19176458&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4609[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4610</li>

4611<li id="section_2.122">

4612Young KC, Burch A, Oduko JM: Radiation doses received in the UK Breast Screening Programme in 2001 and 2002. Br J Radiol 78 (927): 207-18, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15730985&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15730985&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4613[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4614</li>

4615<li id="section_2.123">

4616Spelic DC: Trends in Mammography Dose and Image Quality 1974-2005. Silver Spring, Md: U.S. Food and Drug Administration, 2006. <a href="http://wayback.archive-it.org/7993/20170112093758/http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/MammographyQualityStandardsActandProgram/FacilityScorecard/ucm113352.htm" title="http://wayback.archive-it.org/7993/20170112093758/http://www.fda.gov/Radiation-EmittingProducts/MammographyQualityStandardsActandProgram/FacilityScorecard/ucm113352.htm">

4617Available online</a>

4618. Last accessed August 21, 2023.</li>

4619<li id="section_2.124">

4620Clement SC, Kremer LCM, Verburg FA, et al.: Balancing the benefits and harms of thyroid cancer surveillance in survivors of Childhood, adolescent and young adult cancer: Recommendations from the international Late Effects of Childhood Cancer Guideline Harmonization Group in collaboration with the PanCareSurFup Consortium. Cancer Treat Rev 63: 28-39, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29202445&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29202445&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4621[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4622</li>

4623</ol>

4624</div>

4625

4626 </section>

4627

4628

4629

4630 <section id="_1360">

4631

4632 <h2>

4633Late Effects of the Cardiovascular System</h2>

4634

4635 <div id="_section_1360" class="pdq-sections">

4636<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

4637<h6>

4638In This Section</h6>

4639<ul>

4640<li>

4641<a href="#_2335_toc">

4642Cardiovascular Outcomes</a>

4643</li>

4644<li>

4645<a href="#_1366_toc">

4646Treatment Risk Factors<ul>

4647<li>

4648<a href="#_1368_toc">

4649Anthracyclines and related agents</a>

4650</li>

4651<li>

4652<a href="#_1376_toc">

4653Radiation therapy</a>

4654</li>

4655<li>

4656<a href="#_1382_toc">

4657Conventional cardiovascular conditions</a>

4658</li>

4659</ul>

4660</a>

4661</li>

4662<li>

4663<a href="#_1384_toc">

4664Other Risk Factors</a>

4665</li>

4666<li>

4667<a href="#_2311_toc">

4668Peripartum Cardiac Dysfunction</a>

4669</li>

4670<li>

4671<a href="#_2161_toc">

4672Heart Transplant After Childhood Cancer</a>

4673</li>

4674<li>

4675<a href="#_1386_toc">

4676Knowledge Deficits</a>

4677</li>

4678<li>

4679<a href="#_1390_toc">

4680Screening, Surveillance, and Counseling<ul>

4681<li>

4682<a href="#_2344_toc">

4683Consensus regarding evidence about screening, surveillance, and counseling</a>

4684</li>

4685</ul>

4686</a>

4687</li>

4688<li>

4689<a href="#_2200_toc">

4690Predicting Cardiovascular Disease Risk<ul>

4691<li>

4692<a href="#_2347_toc">

4693Risk prediction for cardiovascular diseases </a>

4694</li>

4695</ul>

4696</a>

4697</li>

4698</ul>

4699</nav>

4700<p id="_1361" tabindex="-1">

4701Cardiovascular disease, after recurrence of the original cancer and development of second primary cancers, has been reported to be the leading cause of premature mortality among long-term childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

47021</a>

4703-<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

47043</a>

4705] </p>

4706<p id="_1802" tabindex="-1">

4707Evidence (excess risk of premature cardiovascular mortality):</p>

4708<div class="pdq-content-list">

4709<ol id="_1803">

4710<li>

4711In the North American Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS), more than 34,000 5-year survivors of childhood cancer were diagnosed and treated from 1970 to 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

47121</a>

4713]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4714<ul id="_2872">

4715<li>

4716Participants followed for 15 years had a standardized mortality ratio (SMR) of 11.7 (95% confidence interval [CI], 9.4&#8211;14.4) for cardiac mortality.</li>

4717<li>

4718Late cardiac mortality in children who were treated more recently (i.e., in the 1990s) appears to have decreased (e.g., the cumulative incidence was 0.5% in 1970&#8211;1974 vs. 0.1% in 1990&#8211;1994).</li>

4719</ul>

4720</div>

4721</li>

4722<li>

4723In the CCSS, outcomes for patients diagnosed and treated in adolescence and early adulthood (aged &gt;15 to &lt;21 years) were compared with survivors of similar cancers diagnosed in childhood (aged &lt;15 years) and the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

47244</a>

4725]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4726<ul id="_3002">

4727<li>

4728Childhood cancer survivors (n = 5,804) had a greater SMR than early-adolescent and young adult survivors (n = 5,804) for cardiac deaths beginning 20 years after diagnosis (SMR, 5.4; 95% CI, 3.7&#8211;7.8 vs. SMR, 1.8; 95% CI, 0.7&#8211;4.3). </li>

4729<li>

4730When compared with siblings of the same age, survivors of childhood cancer (n = 4,082) had a higher risk of developing grades 3 to 5 chronic cardiac conditions than early adolescents and young adults (n = 4,082) (hazard ratio [HR], 5.6 [4.5&#8211;7.1] vs. 4.3 [3.5&#8211;5.4]).</li>

4731</ul>

4732</div>

4733</li>

4734<li>

4735Cardiac disease becomes increasingly important as survivors of childhood cancer reach mature adulthood. This finding was observed in the population-based British Childhood Cancer Survivor Study, comprised of 34,489 5-year survivors of childhood cancer diagnosed from 1940 to 2006.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

47362</a>

4737,<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

47385</a>

4739]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4740<ul id="_2301">

4741<li>

4742In survivors of childhood cancer aged 60 years and older, circulatory disease overtakes subsequent primary neoplasms as the leading cause of excess mortality (37% of the excess number of deaths observed were caused by circulatory conditions compared with 31% of excess number of deaths caused by subsequent primary neoplasms).[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

47432</a>

4744]</li>

4745<li>

4746The risk of both overall cardiac and cardiomyopathy/heart failure mortality was greatest among those diagnosed between 1980 and 1989. Survivors who were diagnosed from 1980 to 1989 had 28.9 times the excess number of cardiac deaths as did survivors who were diagnosed either before 1970 or from 1990 to the present.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

47475</a>

4748]</li>

4749</ul>

4750</div>

4751</li>

4752</ol>

4753</div>

4754<p id="_1397" tabindex="-1">

4755The specific late effects covered in this section include the following:</p>

4756<div class="pdq-content-list">

4757<ul id="_1362">

4758<li>

4759Cardiomyopathy/heart failure.</li>

4760<li>

4761Ischemic heart disease.</li>

4762<li>

4763Pericardial heart disease.</li>

4764<li>

4765Valve disease.</li>

4766<li>

4767Conduction disorders.</li>

4768<li>

4769Cerebrovascular disease. </li>

4770<li>

4771Venous thromboembolism.</li>

4772</ul>

4773</div>

4774<p id="_1363" tabindex="-1">

4775This section will also briefly discuss the influence of related conditions such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes. However, this section will not provide a detailed review of those conditions as a consequence of childhood cancer treatment. A comprehensive review of long-term cardiovascular toxicity in childhood and young adult survivors of cancer has been published.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

47766</a>

4777]

4778</p>

4779<section id="_2335">

4780<h3 id="_2335_toc">

4781Cardiovascular Outcomes</h3>

4782<div class="pdq-content-list">

4783<ul id="_2336">

4784<li>

4785Numerous studies focus on cardiac events among childhood cancer survivors. Very large cohort studies exist, many with several decades of follow-up, that are either hospital based,[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

47867</a>

4787-<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

47889</a>

4789] clinical trial based,[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

479010</a>

4791,<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

479211</a>

4793] or population based.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

47942</a>

4795,<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

47963</a>

4797,<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

47985</a>

4799]</li>

4800<li>

4801Notably, the average age of these populations is still relatively young (early or mid-adulthood). Consequently, the reported risk of serious cardiovascular outcomes is very high relative to the age-matched general population, whereas the absolute risk often remains low, limiting the power of many studies. </li>

4802<li>

4803Among the large studies featuring thousands of survivors, the main limitation has been inadequate ability to clinically ascertain late cardiovascular complications, with a greater reliance on either administrative records (e.g., death registries) and/or self-report or proxy-report.</li>

4804<li>

4805While each study design has some inherent biases, the overall literature, based on a combination of self-reported outcomes, clinical ascertainment, and administrative data sources, is robust. These studies conclude that certain cancer-related exposures are associated with a significantly greater risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in survivors. </li>

4806<li>

4807Although late effects research often lags behind changes in contemporary therapy, many therapies linked to cardiovascular late effects remain in common use today. However, restricted doses of these therapies are often given to patients with biologically favorable disease presentations. In addition, dexrazoxane cardioprotection is also widely used for patients exposed to these therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

480812</a>

4809-<a href="#cit/section_3.14">

481014</a>

4811] </li>

4812<li>

4813Ongoing research is important to ensure that use of newer targeted agents does not result in unexpected cardiovascular effects.[<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

481415</a>

4815]</li>

4816</ul>

4817</div>

4818</section>

4819<p id="_1625" tabindex="-1">

4820Evidence (selected cohort studies describing cardiovascular outcomes):</p>

4821<div class="pdq-content-list">

4822<ol id="_1626">

4823<li>

4824A case-control study of the PanCareSurFup and ProCardio cohort evaluated treatment-related risk factors for heart failure in survivors of childhood cancer (5 or more years) diagnosed between 1940 and 2009.[<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

482516</a>

4826]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4827<ul id="_2975">

4828<li>

4829The 50-year cumulative incidence of heart failure among the entire cohort was 2% (95% CI, 1.7%&#8211;2.2%).</li>

4830<li>

4831A subcohort study evaluated 500 cases with symptomatic heart failure and 500 controls without heart failure (matched for sex, age, calendar year of first diagnosis, and length of follow-up) for whom detailed treatment exposures were available. The risk of heart failure was increased more than fivefold (odds ratio [OR], 5.5; 95% CI, 2.5&#8211;12.3) among survivors who received a mean heart radiation therapy dose of 5 Gy to 15 Gy or less, compared with those who did not receive heart radiation therapy. The risk increased with a larger volume of radiation exposing the heart. </li>

4832<li>

4833Heart failure risk increased in a linear fashion with higher mean heart radiation therapy doses. </li>

4834<li>

4835Survivors who received a cumulative anthracycline dose of more than 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

48362</span>

4837 had a substantially increased risk of heart failure (OR, 5.8; 95% CI, 2.9&#8211;11.3 for 100 to &lt;250 mg/m<span class="sup">

48382</span>

4839 and OR, 21.2; 95% CI, 11.4&#8211;39.2 for &gt;250 mg/m<span class="sup">

48402</span>

4841).</li>

4842<li>

4843An anthracycline dose of less than 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

48442</span>

4845 was not a significant risk factor for heart failure. </li>

4846</ul>

4847</div>

4848</li>

4849<li>

4850CCSS investigators reported on major cardiac events among participants diagnosed with childhood cancer between 1970 and 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

485117</a>

4852]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4853<ul id="_2302">

4854<li>

4855In this update, the 20-year cumulative incidence of heart failure and coronary artery disease for patients treated in the 1990s declined over the decades to 0.54% and 0.19%, respectively, but was significant only for coronary artery disease.</li>

4856<li>

4857The risk of coronary artery disease was significantly decreased from the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s (0.38%, 0.24%, and 0.19%, respectively; HR, 0.65) and was attributed to historical reductions in exposure to cardiac radiation, particularly among survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma.</li>

4858<li>

4859For patients treated in the 1990s, the 20-year cumulative incidence was 0.05% for valvular disease, 0.03% for pericardial disease, and 0.13% for arrhythmias. These numbers did not change over the eras (1970&#8211;1990).</li>

4860</ul>

4861</div>

4862</li>

4863<li>

4864In the CCSS, data from 24,214 5-year survivors diagnosed between 1970 and 1999 were used to assess the impacts of radiation therapy dose and exposed cardiac volume, select chemotherapeutic agents, and age at exposure on the risk of late-onset cardiac disease (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2410">

4865Figure 6</a>

4866).[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

486718</a>

4868]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4869<ul id="_2081">

4870<li>

4871The cumulative incidence of cardiac disease (any cardiac disease, coronary artery disease, and heart failure) 30 years from diagnosis was 4.8%. Male survivors were more likely to develop coronary artery disease and less likely to develop heart failure than were female survivors. Non-Hispanic Black survivors were more likely to develop any cardiac disease than were non-Hispanic White survivors.</li>

4872<li>

4873Low-to-moderate radiation therapy doses (5.0&#8211;19.9 Gy) to large cardiac volumes (&gt;50% of the heart) were associated with a 1.6-fold increased risk of cardiac disease compared with survivors who did not have any cardiac radiation therapy exposure.</li>

4874<li>

4875High doses (&gt;20 Gy) to small cardiac volumes (0.1%&#8211;29.9%) were associated with an elevated rate of cardiac disease compared with unexposed survivors.</li>

4876<li>

4877A dose-response relationship was observed between anthracycline exposure and heart failure, with younger children (&lt;13 years) at the greatest risk of heart failure after comparable dosing.</li>

4878</ul>

4879</div>

4880<figure id="figure_2410" class="image-center-full">

4881<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/801168.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

4882Enlarge</a>

4883<img id="_2410" alt="Chart showing therapy-related cardiac risk in childhood cancer survivors." title="Chart showing therapy-related cardiac risk in childhood cancer survivors." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/801168-750.jpg">

4884<figcaption class="caption-container">

4885Figure 6. Cumulative incidence of therapy-related cardiac risk in childhood cancer survivors, based on (A-C) mean heart dose, (D-F) volume of heart (%) receiving radiotherapy (RT) greater than or equal to 20 Gy, and (G-I) volume of heart (%) receiving RT greater than or equal to 5 Gy when maximum heart dose is less than 20 Gy. (J-L) Cumulative anthracycline dose. (*) 0% maximum radiation dose to the heart = 0.1 to 19.9 Gy. (&#8224;) 0% maximum radiation dose to the heart = 0.1 to 4.9 Gy. Bates JE, Howell RM, Liu Q, et al: Therapy-Related Cardiac Risk in Childhood Cancer Survivors: An Analysis of the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. Journal of Clinical Oncology (<a href="https://ascopubs.org/journal/jco" title="https://ascopubs.org/journal/jco">

4886https://ascopubs.org/journal/jco</a>

4887), Volume 37 (Issue 13), 2019: Pages 1090-1101. Reprinted with permission. Copyright &#169; 2019 Wolters Kluwer Health, Inc. and American Society of Clinical Oncology. All rights reserved.</figcaption>

4888</figure>

4889</li>

4890<li>

4891A cross-sectional CCSS study included 571 adult-aged survivors of childhood cancer (median age, 37.7 years; 28.5 years from cancer diagnosis). The study compared rates of underdiagnosis and undertreatment of modifiable risk factors among survivors and respondents to the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHNES).[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

489219</a>

4893]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4894<ul id="_2966">

4895<li>

4896Rates of cardiovascular disease risk factor underdiagnosis were similar (27.1% of survivors vs. 26.1% of participants from the NHNES; <em>

4897P</em>

4898 = .73). However, survivors were more likely to be undertreated (21.0% versus 13.9%, <em>

4899P</em>

4900 = .007; OR, 1.8; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;2.7).</li>

4901<li>

4902Hypertension (18.9%) and dyslipidemia (16.3%) represented the most underdiagnosed and undertreated risk factors.</li>

4903<li>

4904Men and survivors who were overweight or had obesity were more likely to be underdiagnosed and undertreated.</li>

4905<li>

4906These adult-aged childhood cancer survivors were nearly twice as likely to be undertreated for these conditions.</li>

4907</ul>

4908</div>

4909</li>

4910<li>

4911A Dutch CCSS-LATER study evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for hypertension in childhood cancer survivors (median age, 32.5 years; median follow-up, 25.5 years) who were treated with potentially nephrotoxic therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

491220</a>

4913]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4914<ul id="_2976">

4915<li>

4916Survivors (16.3%) and controls (18.2%) had comparable rates of hypertension. Undiagnosed hypertension was prevalent in 12% of survivors and 17.8% of controls.</li>

4917<li>

4918Treatment factors associated with risk of hypertension included abdominal radiation therapy of more than 20 Gy and total-body irradiation (TBI).</li>

4919<li>

4920Among childhood cancer survivors, glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m<span class="sup">

49212</span>

4922 was significantly associated with hypertension (OR, 3.4; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;8.5).</li>

4923</ul>

4924</div>

4925</li>

4926<li>

4927The CCSS demonstrated that the cumulative incidence of serious cardiac events (myocardial infarction, congestive heart failure, pericardial disease, and valvular abnormalities) in childhood cancer survivors continues to increase beyond age 45 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

49287</a>

4929]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4930<ul id="_1630">

4931<li>

4932 The risk of these events was potentiated (i.e., beyond what would be expected by an additive model) by the presence of concurrent, but potentially modifiable, conditions such as obesity, dyslipidemia, diabetes, and, particularly, hypertension.</li>

4933<li>

4934Hypertension was independently associated with all serious cardiac outcomes (rate ratios, 6-fold to 19-fold), even after adjustment for anthracycline use and chest irradiation.</li>

4935</ul>

4936</div>

4937</li>

4938<li>

4939Of 670 survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma who were treated at St. Jude Children&#8217;s Research Hospital (SJCRH) and survived 10 or more years, 348 patients were clinically assessed in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study.[<a href="#cit/section_3.21">

494021</a>

4941] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4942<ul id="_1631">

4943<li>

4944Overall, survivors had a higher cumulative burden (a novel measurement of disease burden that incorporates multiple health conditions and recurrent events into a single metric) than community controls, with the total grade 3 to 5 cumulative burden among survivors at age 30 years being comparable with that of community controls at 50 years. </li>

4945<li>

4946At age 50 years, the cumulative incidence of those survivors experiencing at least one grade 3 to grade 5 cardiovascular condition was 45.5% (95% CI, 36.6%&#8211;54.3%), compared with 15.7% (95% CI, 7.0%&#8211;24.4%) in community controls.</li>

4947<li>

4948Myocardial infarction and structural heart defects were the major contributors to the excess grade 3 to grade 5 cumulative burden in survivors, whereas there was no notable difference in survivors and community controls at age 50 years for grades 3 to 5 cumulative burden of dyslipidemia and essential hypertension.</li>

4949</ul>

4950</div>

4951</li>

4952<li>

4953Another St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study compared the prevalence of major and minor electrocardiography (ECG) abnormalities among 2,715 participants and 268 community controls.[<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

495422</a>

4955]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4956<ul id="_1830">

4957<li>

4958 Major ECG abnormalities were significantly more prevalent in survivors (10.7%) than in controls (4.9%). The most common abnormalities included isolated ST-T wave abnormalities (7.2%), evidence of myocardial infarction (3.7%), and left ventricular hypertrophy with strain pattern (2.8%).</li>

4959<li>

4960Treatment exposures predicting increased risk of major abnormalities were anthracycline doses of 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

49612</span>

4962 or greater (OR, 1.7; 95% CI, 1.1&#8211;2.5) and cardiac radiation (OR, 2.1; 95% CI, 1.5&#8211;2.9 [0.01&#8211;19.99 Gy]; OR, 2.6; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;3.9 [20&#8211;29.99 Gy]; OR, 10.5; 95% CI, 6.5&#8211;16.9 [&#8805;30 Gy]).</li>

4963<li>

4964Major ECG abnormalities were predictive of all-cause mortality (HR, 4.0; 95% CI, 2.1&#8211;7.8).</li>

4965</ul>

4966</div>

4967</li>

4968<li>

4969In the Teenage and Young Adult Cancer Survivor Study, cardiac mortality was investigated in more than 200,000 5-year survivors of adolescent and young adult cancer (aged 15&#8211;39 years).[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

49703</a>

4971]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4972<ul id="_1834">

4973<li>

4974 Age at diagnosis and type of cancer were identified as being important in determining risk of cardiac mortality.</li>

4975<li>

4976The SMRs for all cardiac disease combined was greatest for individuals diagnosed at age 15 to 19 years (4.2), decreasing to 1.2 for individuals aged 35 to 39 years (2-sided <em>

4977P</em>

4978 for trend &lt; .0001). This age effect was most apparent for survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma, who were also found to be at greatest risk overall.</li>

4979<li>

4980Limitations of this study included lack of detailed information on exposures to radiation therapy (doses, fields), exposures to chemotherapy (primarily anthracycline dose), and cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., smoking, obesity, hypertension, diabetes, family history).</li>

4981</ul>

4982</div>

4983</li>

4984<li>

4985Dutch investigators evaluated the risk of heart failure, temporal changes by treatment periods, and the risk factors for heart failure in 6,165 childhood cancer survivors (median age, 27.3 years; median follow-up, 19.8 years) diagnosed between 1963 and 2002.[<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

498623</a>

4987]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4988<ul id="_2404">

4989<li>

4990The cumulative incidence of developing a heart failure 40 years after a childhood cancer diagnosis was 4.4% (3.4%&#8211;5.5%) among cohort members. </li>

4991<li>

4992The 20-year cumulative incidence of grade 3 or higher heart failure was greater among survivors treated in the more recent treatment periods (for survivors diagnosed between 1990 and 2001, 1.5%; between 1980 and 1989, 1.6%; and between 1970 and 1979, 0.5%) than in survivors treated earlier; however, mortality caused by heart failure decreased in the patients who were treated in the more recent periods. </li>

4993<li>

4994Multivariable analysis demonstrated that patients who received higher doses of mitoxantrone or cyclophosphamide had an increased risk of heart failure compared with survivors who were exposed to lower doses.</li>

4995</ul>

4996</div>

4997</li>

4998</ol>

4999</div>

5000<section id="_1366">

5001<h3 id="_1366_toc">

5002Treatment Risk Factors</h3>

5003<p id="_1367" tabindex="-1">

5004Chemotherapy (in particular, anthracyclines and anthraquinones) along with radiation therapy both independently and in combination, increase the risk of cardiovascular disease in survivors of childhood cancer and are considered to be the most important risk factors contributing to premature cardiovascular disease in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

50053</a>

5006,<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

50079</a>

5008,<a href="#cit/section_3.16">

500916</a>

5010,<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

501124</a>

5012] </p>

5013<section id="_1368">

5014<h4 id="_1368_toc">

5015Anthracyclines and related agents</h4>

5016<p id="_1369" tabindex="-1">

5017Anthracyclines (e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin, idarubicin, and epirubicin) and anthraquinones (e.g., mitoxantrone) are known to directly injure cardiomyocytes through inhibition of topoisomerase 2-beta in cardiomyocytes and formation of reactive oxygen species, resulting in activation of cell-death pathways and inhibition of mitochondrial apoptosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

501825</a>

5019,<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

502026</a>

5021] The downstream results of cell death are changes in heart structure, including wall thinning, which leads to ventricular overload and pathological remodeling that, over time, leads to dysfunction and eventual clinical heart failure.[<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

502227</a>

5023,<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

502428</a>

5025] </p>

5026<p id="_1370" tabindex="-1">

5027Risk factors for anthracycline-related cardiomyopathy include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

502818</a>

5029,<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

503029</a>

5031]</p>

5032<div class="pdq-content-list">

5033<ul id="_1371">

5034<li>

5035Cumulative dose, particularly greater than 250 to 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

50362</span>

5037.</li>

5038<li>

5039Younger age at time of exposure, particularly children younger than 5 years.</li>

5040<li>

5041Increased time from exposure.</li>

5042<li>

5043While there is no definitive safe lower dose threshold, doses in excess of 250 to 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

50442</span>

5045 have been associated with a substantially increased risk of cardiomyopathy, with cumulative incidences exceeding 5% after 20 years of follow-up, and in some subgroups, reaching or exceeding 10% cumulative incidence by age 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

504617</a>

5047,<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

504818</a>

5049,<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

505028</a>

5051]</li>

5052<li>

5053 Concurrent chest or heart radiation therapy also further increases risk of cardiomyopathy,[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

50549</a>

5055,<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

505624</a>

5057,<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

505830</a>

5059] as does the presence of other cardiometabolic traits such as hypertension.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

50607</a>

5061,<a href="#cit/section_3.31">

506231</a>

5063] </li>

5064<li>

5065While development of clinical heart failure can occur within a few years after anthracycline exposure, in most survivors&#8212;even those who received very high doses&#8212;clinical manifestations may not occur for decades.</li>

5066</ul>

5067</div>

5068<section id="_1425">

5069<h5 id="_1425_toc">

5070Anthracycline dose equivalency</h5>

5071<p id="_1373" tabindex="-1">

5072Traditionally, anthracycline dose equivalence has largely been based on acute hematologic toxicity equivalence rather than late cardiac toxicity.</p>

5073<div class="pdq-content-list">

5074<ul id="_2763">

5075<li>

5076Analyses that pooled data from more than 28,000 long-term childhood cancer survivors monitored through age 40 years (resulting in 399 cardiomyopathy cases) have challenged previous assumptions that consider daunorubicin equivalent or nearly equivalent to doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

507732</a>

5078,<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

507933</a>

5080]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5081<ul id="_2304">

5082<li>

5083These investigations found that daunorubicin may be significantly less cardiotoxic than doxorubicin (equivalence ratio, 0.5; 95% CI, 0.4&#8211;0.7).[<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

508432</a>

5085]</li>

5086<li>

5087Compared with doxorubicin, mitoxantrone may be significantly more cardiotoxic than previously thought (equivalence ratio, 10.5; 95% CI, 6.2&#8211;19.1), while epirubicin appeared to be doxorubicin isoequivalent (equivalence ratio, 0.8; 95% CI, 0.3&#8211;1.4).[<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

508833</a>

5089]</li>

5090<li>

5091 Data were too sparse to compare idarubicin with doxorubicin.</li>

5092</ul>

5093</div>

5094</li>

5095</ul>

5096</div>

5097</section>

5098<section id="_1426">

5099<h5 id="_1426_toc">

5100Anthracycline cardioprotection</h5>

5101<p id="_1374" tabindex="-1">

5102Cardioprotective strategies that have been explored include the following:</p>

5103<div class="pdq-content-list">

5104<ul id="_2764">

5105<li>

5106<strong>

5107New, less cardiotoxic agents and liposomal formulations.</strong>

5108 In general, data on whether liposomal formulations of anthracyclines reduce cardiac toxicity in children are limited.[<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

510934</a>

5110,<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

511135</a>

5112]</li>

5113<li>

5114<strong>

5115Prolonged infusion time.</strong>

5116 Prolonged infusion time has been associated with reduced heart failure in adult patients, but not in children.[<a href="#cit/section_3.36">

511736</a>

5118,<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

511937</a>

5120]</li>

5121<li>

5122<strong>

5123Concurrent administration of cardioprotectants.</strong>

5124 A variety of agents have been tested as cardioprotectants (amifostine, acetylcysteine, calcium channel blockers, carvedilol, coenzyme Q10, and L-carnitine), but none were beneficial and are not considered standard of care.[<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

512538</a>

5126,<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

512739</a>

5128]</li>

5129<li>

5130<strong>

5131Dexrazoxane.</strong>

5132 There are more data for dexrazoxane as a cardioprotectant, but mainly in adult patients with cancer. In particular, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved dexrazoxane for women with metastatic breast cancer who have received 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

51332</span>

5134 of anthracyclines and who may benefit from further anthracycline-based therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

513538</a>

5136]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5137<ul id="_2307">

5138<li>

5139 Pediatric data show that dexrazoxane may ameliorate some markers of early cardiac toxicity for up to 5 years after therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

514040</a>

5141-<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

514243</a>

5143] </li>

5144<li>

5145Dexrazoxane may be associated with an increased risk of acute toxicities in some regimens.[<a href="#cit/section_3.44">

514644</a>

5147] </li>

5148<li>

5149A long-term study assessed outcomes of newly diagnosed children with cancer who were treated with dexrazoxane-containing regimens in randomized clinical trials (cumulative prescribed doxorubicin dose, 100&#8211;360 mg/m<span class="sup">

51502</span>

5151; median follow-up, 18.6 years). Dexrazoxane was not associated with cancer relapse (HR, 0.84; 95% CI, 0.63&#8211;1.13), second cancers (HR, 1.19; 95% CI, 0.62&#8211;2.30), all-cause mortality (HR, 1.07; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;1.47), or cardiovascular mortality (HR, 1.45; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;5.16).[<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

515245</a>

5153]</li>

5154<li>

5155Another study evaluated long-term cardiac outcomes of 195 children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia or Hodgkin lymphoma who received doxorubicin with or without dexrazoxane in four randomized trials and patients with osteosarcoma who all received doxorubicin with dexrazoxane in a nonrandomized trial.[<a href="#cit/section_3.46">

515646</a>

5157]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5158<ul id="_2994">

5159<li>

5160At 18.1 years since cancer diagnosis (51% dexrazoxane exposed; cumulative doxorubicin dose, 297 mg/m<span class="sup">

51612</span>

5162), dexrazoxane administration was associated with superior left ventricular fractional shortening (absolute difference, 1.4%; 95% CI, 0.3&#8211;2.5) and ejection fraction (absolute difference, 1.6%; 95% CI, 0.0&#8211;3.2) and lower myocardial stress per B-type natriuretic peptide (-6.7 pg/mL; 95% CI, -10.6 to -2.8). </li>

5163<li>

5164Dexrazoxane use was associated with a reduced risk of lower left ventricular function (30% fractional shortening or 50% ejection fraction; OR, 0.24; 95% CI, 0.07&#8211;0.81), which was primarily observed in those treated with cumulative doxorubicin doses of 250 mg/m<span class="sup">

51652</span>

5166 or higher.</li>

5167</ul>

5168</div>

5169</li>

5170</ul>

5171</div>

5172</li>

5173</ul>

5174</div>

5175</section>

5176</section>

5177<section id="_1376">

5178<h4 id="_1376_toc">

5179Radiation therapy</h4>

5180<p id="_1634" tabindex="-1">

5181While anthracyclines directly damage cardiomyocytes, radiation therapy primarily affects the fine vasculature of affected organs.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

51826</a>

5183]</p>

5184<section id="_1635">

5185<h5 id="_1635_toc">

5186Cardiovascular disease</h5>

5187<p id="_1636" tabindex="-1">

5188Late effects of radiation therapy to the heart specifically include the following:</p>

5189<div class="pdq-content-list">

5190<ul id="_1637">

5191<li>

5192Delayed pericarditis, which can present abruptly or as a chronic pericardial effusion. </li>

5193<li>

5194Pancarditis that includes pericardial and myocardial fibrosis, with or without endocardial fibroelastosis. </li>

5195<li>

5196Cardiomyopathy (in the absence of significant pericardial disease), which can occur even without anthracycline exposure.</li>

5197<li>

5198Ischemic heart disease.</li>

5199<li>

5200Functional valve injury, often aortic.</li>

5201<li>

5202Conduction defects.</li>

5203</ul>

5204</div>

5205<p id="_1638" tabindex="-1">

5206These cardiac late effects are related to the following: </p>

5207<div class="pdq-content-list">

5208<ul id="_1639">

5209<li>

5210Individual radiation fraction size.</li>

5211<li>

5212Volume of the heart that is exposed to radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

521318</a>

5214,<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

521547</a>

5216] </li>

5217<li>

5218Total radiation dose.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5219<ul id="_2309">

5220<li>

5221Various studies have demonstrated a substantially increased risk of these outcomes with higher radiation doses, particularly doses to the heart exceeding 35 Gy (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2410">

5222Figure 6</a>

5223).[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

52249</a>

5225,<a href="#cit/section_3.11">

522611</a>

5227,<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

522817</a>

5229,<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

523018</a>

5231,<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

523224</a>

5233]</li>

5234<li>

5235At higher radiation doses, rates of heart failure, pericardial disease, and valvular disease have been reported to exceed 10% after 20 to 30 years. Although some studies suggest that doses less than 5 Gy may be associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, the relative risk is small (i.e., 2.5) and the 95% CI is large (i.e., 0.2&#8211;41.5); moreover, the dosimetric analyses are generally estimations of incidental cardiac exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

52369</a>

5237,<a href="#cit/section_3.17">

523817</a>

5239,<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

524024</a>

5241]</li>

5242<li>

5243 Low to moderate doses of radiation therapy (5.0&#8211;19.9 Gy) to large cardiac volumes (&gt;50% of the heart) are associated with an increased rate of cardiac disease (i.e., 1.6-fold) compared with survivors who did not have any cardiac radiation therapy exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

524418</a>

5245]</li>

5246<li>

5247 High doses of radiation (&gt;20 Gy) to small cardiac volumes (0.1%&#8211;29.9%) are associated with an elevated rate of cardiac disease (relative rate, 2.4).[<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

524818</a>

5249,<a href="#cit/section_3.48">

525048</a>

5251]</li>

5252<li>

5253Additional confirmatory data are needed for an accurate assessment of risk at very low cardiac doses.</li>

5254<li>

5255Similar to anthracyclines, manifestation of these late effects may take years, if not decades, to present. </li>

5256</ul>

5257</div>

5258</li>

5259</ul>

5260</div>

5261<p id="_1640" tabindex="-1">

5262Patients who were exposed to both radiation therapy affecting the cardiovascular system and cardiotoxic chemotherapy agents are at even greater risk of late cardiovascular outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

52639</a>

5264,<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

526518</a>

5266]</p>

5267</section>

5268<section id="_1641">

5269<h5 id="_1641_toc">

5270Cerebrovascular disease</h5>

5271<p id="_1642" tabindex="-1">

5272Cerebrovascular disease after radiation therapy exposure is another potential late effect observed in survivors. </p>

5273<div class="pdq-content-list">

5274<ul id="_2310">

5275<li>

5276Radiation-induced vascular damage is a complex process that involves both arterial and capillary damage, with veins being less sensitive. </li>

5277<li>

5278The spectrum of abnormalities includes lacunar lesions, vascular malformations, telangiectasias, intracranial hemorrhage, moyamoya, microbleeds, and cavernomas, each with potential symptomatic consequences.[<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

527949</a>

5280,<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

528150</a>

5282]</li>

5283<li>

5284While brain tumor survivors have traditionally had the greatest risk, other survivors exposed to cranial irradiation (&#8805;18 Gy) and neck irradiation (&#8805;40 Gy), such as leukemia and lymphoma survivors, have also been reported to be at increased risk.[<a href="#cit/section_3.51">

528551</a>

5286-<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

528754</a>

5288]</li>

5289<li>

5290In a Pediatric Normal Tissue Effects in the Clinic (PENTEC) analysis, risk of cerebrovascular toxicity and future risk of stroke were analyzed and modeled (COX proportional hazards and baseline cumulative incidences of stroke in nonradiation therapy exposed, age-matched cancer patients and the general population).[<a href="#cit/section_3.55">

529155</a>

5292]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5293<ul id="_3003">

5294<li>

5295Of 3,898 pediatric patients analyzed in five reports, 101 experienced at least one cerebrovascular toxicity (e.g., transient ischemic attack [TIA], stroke, moyamoya, or arteriopathy).</li>

5296<li>

5297The risk of any cerebrovascular toxicity was 0.2% at 30 Gy, 1.3% at 45 Gy, and 4.4% at 54 Gy (D<sub>

529850</sub>

5299, 75.6 Gy; 68.4&#8211;89.4 Gy). </li>

5300<li>

5301At an attained age of 35 years, the predicted stroke incidence at d doses was 0.9% to 1.3% at 30 Gy, 1.8% to 2.7% at 45 Gy, and 2.8% to 4.1% at 54 Gy (population baseline risk, 0.2%&#8211;0.3%). </li>

5302<li>

5303At an attained age of 45 years, the predicted stroke incidence was 2.1% to 4.2% at 30 Gy, 4.5% to 8.6% at 45 Gy, and 6.7% to 13.0% at 54 Gy (population baseline risk, 0.5%&#8211;1.0%). </li>

5304<li>

5305Thus, the risk of future cerebrovascular toxicity continues to rise as follow-up duration increases. Additionally, because the stroke hazard was based on prescribed tumor bed dose rather than circle-of-Willis dose, the reported stroke risk was likely underestimated.</li>

5306</ul>

5307</div>

5308</li>

5309<li>

5310In lymphoma survivors who received only chest and/or neck radiation therapy, cerebrovascular disease is thought to be caused by large-vessel atherosclerosis and cardiac embolism.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

531152</a>

5312]</li>

5313<li>

5314The risk increases with cumulative dose received. One study (N = 325) reported that the stroke hazard increased by 5% (HR, 1.05; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.09; <em>

5315P</em>

5316 = .02), with each 1 Gy increase in the radiation dose, leading to a cumulative incidence of 2% for the first stroke after 5 years and 4% after 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

531756</a>

5318]</li>

5319<li>

5320 Survivors who experienced a stroke were at much greater risk of recurrent strokes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

532157</a>

5322]</li>

5323</ul>

5324</div>

5325<p id="_1644" tabindex="-1">

5326Evidence (selected studies describing prevalence of and risk factors for cerebrovascular accident [CVA]/vascular disease):</p>

5327<div class="pdq-content-list">

5328<ol id="_1645">

5329<li>

5330The population-based British Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (n = 13,457) used Hospital Episode Statistics data for England to assess the risk of cerebrovascular-related hospitalizations (e.g., nontraumatic intracranial hemorrhage, cerebral infarction, or cerebral artery occlusion), particularly in patients older than 50 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

533154</a>

5332]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5333<ul id="_3004">

5334<li>

5335They found that 2.3% of the survivors had been hospitalized at least once for cerebrovascular disease, with a fourfold risk compared with the expected rate. </li>

5336<li>

5337Survivors of central nervous system (CNS) tumors or leukemia who received cranial irradiation were at greatest risk of cerebrovascular disease (CNS tumor standardized hospitalization ratio [SHR], 15.6; 95% CI, 14.0&#8211;17.4 and leukemia SHR, 5.4; 95% CI, 4.5&#8211;6.4).</li>

5338<li>

5339Beyond age 60 years, on average, 3.1% of CNS tumor survivors treated with cranial irradiation were hospitalized annually for cerebrovascular disease. By age 65 years, as many as 26% of these patients will have been hospitalized for a cerebrovascular event. </li>

5340</ul>

5341</div>

5342</li>

5343<li>

5344CCSS investigators observed that 295 of 13,060 participants (35% treated with cranial radiation therapy) reported having a stroke (6.3%; 95% CI, 5.1%&#8211;7.5%) by age 50 years (median follow-up, 19 years). For survivors considered to be high risk, the cumulative incidence of cerebrovascular disease up to age 50 was 19.9%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

534558</a>

5346]</li>

5347<li>

5348A retrospective study of 3,172 5-year survivors of childhood cancer monitored for a mean time of 26 years was formed from the Euro2K cohort, which included eight centers in France and the United Kingdom. Radiation doses to the circle of Willis were estimated for each of the 2,202 children who received radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.59">

534959</a>

5350]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5351<ul id="_1805">

5352<li>

5353Patients who received radiation therapy had an 8.5-fold increased risk (95% CI, 6.3&#8211;11.0) of stroke in contrast to a nonelevated risk for patients who did not receive radiation therapy.</li>

5354<li>

5355The relative risk was 15.7 (95% CI, 4.9&#8211;50.2) for doses of 40 Gy or higher.</li>

5356<li>

5357At age 45 years, the cumulative incidence was 11.3% (95% CI, 7.1%&#8211;17.7%) in patients who received 10 Gy or higher to the circle of Willis, compared with 1% in the general population.</li>

5358</ul>

5359</div>

5360</li>

5361<li>

5362Investigators from the Teenage and Young Adult Cancer Survivor Study (N = 178,962) evaluated the risk of hospitalization for a cerebrovascular event among 5-year survivors of cancer diagnosed between age 15 and 39 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

536360</a>

5364]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5365<ul id="_1835">

5366<li>

5367The investigators found that survivors of adolescent and young adult cancers had a 40% increased risk of hospitalization for cerebrovascular event compared with the general population.</li>

5368<li>

5369Survivors of CNS tumors (SHR, 4.6), head and neck tumors (SHR, 2.6), and leukemia (SHR, 2.5) had the highest risk of hospitalization for a cerebrovascular complication.</li>

5370<li>

5371Males had significantly higher absolute excess risks than did females, especially among head and neck tumor survivors. By age 60 years, 9% of CNS tumor survivors, 6% of head and neck tumor survivors, and 5% of leukemia survivors had been hospitalized for a cerebrovascular event.</li>

5372<li>

5373The risk of hospitalization for a cerebral infarction was particularly increased among survivors of a CNS tumor older than 60 years, whereas this risk was increased across all ages in survivors of head and neck tumors.</li>

5374</ul>

5375</div>

5376</li>

5377<li>

5378CCSS investigators evaluated the rates and predictors of recurrent stroke among participants who reported a first stroke.[<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

537957</a>

5380]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5381<ul id="_1649">

5382<li>

5383 Among responding participants (329 of 443), 271 confirmed a first stroke (at median age, 19 years) and 70 reported a second stroke (at median age, 32 years).</li>

5384<li>

5385Independent predictors of recurrent stroke included treatment with a cranial radiation therapy dose of 50 Gy or higher (vs. no cranial radiation therapy), history of hypertension, and age 40 years or older at first stroke (vs. age 0&#8211;17 years).</li>

5386<li>

5387The 10-year cumulative incidence of late recurrent stroke was 21% overall and 33% for those treated with 50 Gy or higher of cranial radiation therapy.</li>

5388<li>

5389A follow-up study of 224 CCSS participants who experienced stroke demonstrated an increased risk of all-cause and health-related mortality and a negative impact on social attainment, neurocognitive function, emotional distress, and other health-related quality-of-life measures.[<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

539061</a>

5391]</li>

5392</ul>

5393</div>

5394</li>

5395<li>

5396A multicenter retrospective Dutch study evaluated 5-year survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma diagnosed before age 51 years (25% pediatric-aged patients) who were followed for a median of 18 years. Among 2,201 survivors, 96 developed cerebrovascular disease (CVA and TIA).[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

539752</a>

5398]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5399<ul id="_1646">

5400<li>

5401 Most ischemic events were from large-artery atherosclerosis (36%) or cardiac embolism (24%).</li>

5402<li>

5403The cumulative incidence of ischemic CVA or TIA 30 years after lymphoma treatment was 7%.</li>

5404<li>

5405The overall standardized incidence ratio (SIR) was 2.2 for CVA and 3.1 for TIA. However, SIR estimates appeared to be greater among childhood cancer survivors, with SIRs of 3.8 for CVA and 7.6 for TIA.</li>

5406<li>

5407Irradiation to the neck and mediastinum was an independent risk factor for ischemic cerebrovascular disease (HR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.1&#8211;5.6) versus no radiation therapy. Treatment with chemotherapy was not associated with increased risk.</li>

5408<li>

5409Hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia were associated with the occurrence of ischemic cerebrovascular disease.</li>

5410</ul>

5411</div>

5412</li>

5413</ol>

5414</div>

5415</section>

5416<section id="_2071">

5417<h5 id="_2071_toc">

5418 Venous thromboembolism</h5>

5419<p id="_2072" tabindex="-1">

5420Children with cancer have an excess risk of venous thromboembolism within the first 5 years after diagnosis. However, the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism among childhood cancer survivors has not been well studied.[<a href="#cit/section_3.62">

542162</a>

5422]</p>

5423<p id="_2198" tabindex="-1">

5424 CCSS investigators evaluated self-reported late-onset (5 or more years after cancer diagnosis) venous thromboembolism among cohort members (median follow-up, 21.3 years).[<a href="#cit/section_3.63">

542563</a>

5426] </p>

5427<div class="pdq-content-list">

5428<ul id="_2199">

5429<li>

5430The 35-year cumulative incidence of venous thromboembolism among survivors was 4.9%. This risk was twofold higher when compared with a sibling cohort (rate ratio, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;2.8). </li>

5431<li>

5432Risk factors for venous thromboembolism among survivors included female sex, treatment with cisplatin or asparaginase, being affected by obesity or underweight, and recurrent primary or subsequent cancer. </li>

5433<li>

5434 The risk of late venous thromboembolism was higher among survivors of lower-extremity osteosarcoma treated with limb-sparing surgery compared with patients treated with amputation, possibly resulting from alterations in peripheral vascular anatomy and homeostasis. </li>

5435<li>

5436Venous thromboembolism was associated with an almost-twofold increased risk of late mortality (RR, 1.9; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;2.3).</li>

5437</ul>

5438</div>

5439</section>

5440</section>

5441<section id="_1382">

5442<h4 id="_1382_toc">

5443Conventional cardiovascular conditions</h4>

5444<div class="pdq-content-list">

5445<ul id="_2338">

5446<li>

5447Various cancer treatment exposures may also directly or indirectly influence the development of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia.</li>

5448<li>

5449 These conditions remain important among cancer survivors, as they do in the general population, in that they are independent risk factors in the development of cardiomyopathy, ischemic heart disease, and cerebrovascular disease.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

54507</a>

5451,<a href="#cit/section_3.64">

545264</a>

5453-<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

545467</a>

5455]</li>

5456<li>

5457Childhood cancer survivors should be closely monitored for the development of these cardiovascular conditions because they represent potentially modifiable targets for intervention.</li>

5458<li>

5459Related conditions such as obesity and various endocrinopathies (e.g., hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, growth hormone deficiency) that may be more common among subsets of childhood cancer survivors also need to be monitored. If these conditions are untreated/uncontrolled, they may be associated with a metabolic profile that increases cardiovascular risk.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

54608</a>

5461] For more information, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2347">

5462Risk prediction for cardiovascular diseases</a>

5463 section.</li>

5464</ul>

5465</div>

5466</section>

5467</section>

5468<section id="_1384">

5469<h3 id="_1384_toc">

5470Other Risk Factors</h3>

5471<div class="pdq-content-list">

5472<ul id="_2765">

5473<li>

5474<strong>

5475Sex.</strong>

5476 Some, but not all, studies suggest that female sex may be associated with a greater risk of anthracycline-related cardiomyopathy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

54776</a>

5478]</li>

5479<li>

5480<strong>

5481Genetics.</strong>

5482 There is emerging evidence that genetic factors, such as single nucleotide polymorphisms in genes regulating drug metabolism and distribution, could explain the heterogeneity in susceptibility to anthracycline-mediated cardiac injury.[<a href="#cit/section_3.68">

548368</a>

5484-<a href="#cit/section_3.76">

548576</a>

5486] However, these genetic findings still require additional validation before integration into any clinical screening algorithm.[<a href="#cit/section_3.76">

548776</a>

5488]</li>

5489</ul>

5490</div>

5491</section>

5492<section id="_2311">

5493<h3 id="_2311_toc">

5494Peripartum Cardiac Dysfunction</h3>

5495<p id="_2312" tabindex="-1">

5496Long-term survivors of childhood, adolescent, and young adult malignancies with past exposure to potentially cardiotoxic treatments are at risk of peripartum cardiac dysfunction.</p>

5497<p id="_2371" tabindex="-1">

5498 In the general population, peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a rare condition characterized by heart failure during pregnancy (usually the last trimester or &lt;5 months postpartum). The estimated incidence in the general population is 1 case per 3,000 live births.[<a href="#cit/section_3.77">

549977</a>

5500]</p>

5501<p id="_2313" tabindex="-1">

5502There are limited data available about the prevalence in survivors of pediatric, adolescent, and young adult malignancies who have received cardiotoxic therapies.</p>

5503<div class="pdq-content-list">

5504<ul id="_2314">

5505<li>

5506In a retrospective series from SJCRH, 3 cases of peripartum cardiac dysfunction occurred in 1,554 completed pregnancies, which was an incidence of 0.2%; 27% of the 847 long-term survivors had not been exposed to cardiotoxic therapies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

550778</a>

5508]</li>

5509<li>

5510In a series of 64 women who had all received cardiotoxic therapy (44% received chest radiation therapy plus anthracyclines, 14% received chest radiation therapy, 42% received anthracycline alone), 5 women (7.8%) had peripartum cardiac events (3 symptomatic, 2 subclinical). Of the 110 live births, 2 involved PPCM, representing a 55-fold increased risk over the general population. Risk factors were younger age at cancer diagnosis and higher anthracycline dose. Postpartum cardiac function failed to return to baseline in four women (80%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

551179</a>

5512]</li>

5513<li>

5514A single-center study estimated the risk of developing congestive heart failure (CHF) during pregnancy as 1 out of 3 female cancer survivors with a history of cardiotoxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

551580</a>

5516] Seventy-eight consecutive female cancer survivors previously exposed to potentially cardiotoxic treatments (chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy to the thorax as children, adolescents or young adults) who had 94 pregnancies were retrospectively identified through high-risk clinics between 2005 and 2015. <div class="pdq-content-list">

5517<ul id="_3005">

5518<li>

5519A total of 55 women received anthracyclines (range, 90&#8211;500 mg/m<span class="sup">

55202</span>

5521), while 23 received nonanthracycline chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy only. Of the 13 women with prior cardiotoxicity, 8 had reduced left ventricular ejection fraction at the first antenatal visit. CHF occurred in five pregnancies (4 women; 5.3%). </li>

5522<li>

5523The incidence of CHF was 31% for women with a history of cardiotoxicity and 0% for women without a history of cardiotoxicity. When comparing clinical characteristics between women with and without CHF, there was no difference in age of cancer diagnosis, cancer type, or exposure to anthracyclines. </li>

5524<li>

5525Risk factors for developing CHF were history of cardiotoxicity before pregnancy, left ventricular systolic dysfunction at first antenatal visit, or receiving cardiac medications.</li>

5526</ul>

5527</div>

5528</li>

5529</ul>

5530</div>

5531<p id="_2405" tabindex="-1">

5532Based on available evidence about peripartum cardiomyopathy, the International Guideline Harmonization Group assessed that cardiomyopathy surveillance is reasonable before pregnancy or in the first trimester for female survivors of childhood, adolescent, and young adult cancer who are at moderate and high risk because they were treated with anthracyclines or chest radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

553329</a>

5534]</p>

5535</section>

5536<section id="_2161">

5537<h3 id="_2161_toc">

5538Heart Transplant After Childhood Cancer</h3>

5539<p id="_2340" tabindex="-1">

5540Data about the prevalence and outcomes of survivors with heart failure requiring heart transplant are limited. </p>

5541<div class="pdq-content-list">

5542<ul id="_2341">

5543<li>

5544In a study of solid organ transplants in 13,318 survivors in the CCSS, 62 survivors had end-stage heart failure that warranted heart transplants, 37 of whom received a heart transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

554581</a>

5546]</li>

5547<li>

5548 At 35 years after cancer diagnosis, the cumulative incidence of heart transplant was 0.30%, and the cumulative incidence of being placed on the waiting list or receiving a heart was 0.49%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

554981</a>

5550]</li>

5551<li>

5552 The 5-year survival rate from heart transplant was 80.6%, which is similar to the outcome in the general population of the same age range.[<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

555381</a>

5554]</li>

5555</ul>

5556</div>

5557</section>

5558<section id="_1386">

5559<h3 id="_1386_toc">

5560Knowledge Deficits</h3>

5561<p id="_1387" tabindex="-1">

5562While much knowledge has been gained over the past 20 years in better understanding the long-term burden and risk factors for cardiovascular disease among childhood cancer survivors, many areas of inquiry remain, and include the following:</p>

5563<div class="pdq-content-list">

5564<ul id="_1388">

5565<li>

5566Radiation may have both direct and indirect effects on vascular endothelium, contributing to vascular damage beyond the primary radiation field.[<a href="#cit/section_3.82">

556782</a>

5568]</li>

5569<li>

5570The long-term effects of lower radiation doses, particularly in the setting of advanced technology that allows tumor targeting from multiple directions and reduces exposure to surrounding normal tissues, remain to be determined.[<a href="#cit/section_3.83">

557183</a>

5572]</li>

5573<li>

5574The long-term effects of many newer anticancer agents that are based on molecular targets remain unclear, although some of them are known to have shorter-term cardiac toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_3.15">

557515</a>

5576]</li>

5577<li>

5578The efficacy of cardioprotective strategies, including the use of alternative anthracycline formulations that appear promising in adults, requires further study in children.[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

557939</a>

5580]</li>

5581</ul>

5582</div>

5583</section>

5584<section id="_1390">

5585<h3 id="_1390_toc">

5586Screening, Surveillance, and Counseling</h3>

5587<p id="_2342" tabindex="-1">

5588 The International Guideline Harmonization Group has worked collaboratively to harmonize evidence-based cardiac surveillance recommendations and have identified knowledge deficits to help guide future studies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

558929</a>

5590,<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

559167</a>

5592] Risk groups defined by cumulative exposures of anthracycline and chest-directed radiation therapy as well as cardiomyopathy surveillance recommendations are summarized in <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_3024">

5593Table 2</a>

5594.</p>

5595<section id="_2344">

5596<h4 id="_2344_toc">

5597Consensus regarding evidence about screening, surveillance, and counseling</h4>

5598<div class="pdq-content-list">

5599<ul id="_2345">

5600<li>

5601There is no clear evidence (at least through age 50 years or 30&#8211;40 years posttreatment) that a plateau in risk occurs after a certain time among survivors exposed to cancer treatments associated with cardiovascular late effects.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

560284</a>

5603,<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

560485</a>

5605] Thus, life-long surveillance is recommended by one group, even if the cost-effectiveness of certain screening strategies remains unclear.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

560629</a>

5607,<a href="#cit/section_3.86">

560886</a>

5609-<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

561088</a>

5611]<table id="_3024" class="table-default expandable-container">

5612<caption>

5613Table 2. Risk Groups and Cardiomyopathy Surveillance Recommendations for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancer<span class="sup">

5614a</span>

5615</caption>

5616<colgroup>

5617<col width="16.66%">

5618<col width="16.66%">

5619<col width="16.66%">

5620<col width="16.66%">

5621<col width="16.66%">

5622<col width="16.66%">

5623</colgroup>

5624<THead>

5625<tr>

5626<th>

5627Risk Group</th>

5628<th>

5629Anthracycline (mg/m<span class="sup">

56302</span>

5631)</th>

5632<th>

5633Chest-Directed Radiation Therapy (Gy)</th>

5634<th>

5635Anthracycline (mg/m<span class="sup">

56362</span>

5637) + Chest-Directed Radiation Therapy (Gy)</th>

5638<th>

5639Is Screening Recommended?</th>

5640<th>

5641At What Interval?</th>

5642</tr>

5643</THead>

5644<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5645<tr>

5646<td colspan="6">

5647NA = not applicable.</td>

5648</tr>

5649<tr>

5650<td colspan="6">

5651<span class="sup">

5652a</span>

5653Adapted from Ehrhardt et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

565429</a>

5655]</td>

5656</tr>

5657</TFoot>

5658<tbody>

5659<tr>

5660<td>

5661High risk</td>

5662<td>

5663&#8805;250</td>

5664<td>

5665&#8805;30</td>

5666<td>

5667&#8805;100 and &#8805;15</td>

5668<td>

5669Yes</td>

5670<td>

56712 years</td>

5672</tr>

5673<tr>

5674<td>

5675Moderate risk</td>

5676<td>

5677100 to &lt;250</td>

5678<td>

567915 to &lt;30</td>

5680<td>

5681NA</td>

5682<td>

5683Maybe</td>

5684<td>

56855 years</td>

5686</tr>

5687<tr>

5688<td>

5689Low risk</td>

5690<td>

5691&gt;0 to &lt;100</td>

5692<td>

5693&gt;0 to &lt;15</td>

5694<td>

5695NA</td>

5696<td>

5697No</td>

5698<td>

5699No screening</td>

5700</tr>

5701</tbody>

5702</table>

5703</li>

5704<li>

5705A growing body of literature is beginning to establish the yield from these screening studies, which will help inform future guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

57068</a>

5707,<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

570889</a>

5709-<a href="#cit/section_3.91">

571091</a>

5711] In these studies, for example, among adult-aged survivors of childhood cancer, evidence for cardiomyopathy on the basis of echocardiographic changes was found in approximately 6% of at-risk survivors. Overall, in a cohort of more than 1,000 survivors (median age, 32 years), nearly 60% of screened at-risk survivors had some clinically ascertained cardiac abnormality identified.[<a href="#cit/section_3.8">

57128</a>

5713]</li>

5714<li>

5715Given the growing evidence that conventional cardiovascular conditions such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes substantially increase the risk of more serious cardiovascular disease among survivors, clinicians should carefully consider baseline and follow-up screening and treatment of these comorbid conditions that impact cardiovascular health (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1419">

5716Table 3</a>

5717).[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

57187</a>

5719,<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

572052</a>

5721,<a href="#cit/section_3.64">

572264</a>

5723,<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

572492</a>

5725]</li>

5726<li>

5727There is also emerging evidence that adoption of healthier lifestyle factors may decrease future cardiovascular morbidity in at-risk survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

572893</a>

5729,<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

573094</a>

5731] Thus, similar to the general population, survivors should be counseled about maintaining a healthy weight, participating in regular physical activity, adhering to a heart-healthy diet, and abstaining from smoking.</li>

5732<li>

5733 The COG has organized handouts on cardiovascular disease and related topics, including lifestyle choices, written for a lay audience to facilitate counseling and education of survivors. For more information, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

5734COG Survivorship Guidelines</a>

5735.</li>

5736</ul>

5737</div>

5738</section>

5739</section>

5740<section id="_2200">

5741<h3 id="_2200_toc">

5742Predicting Cardiovascular Disease Risk</h3>

5743<div class="pdq-content-list">

5744<ul id="_2346">

5745<li>

5746Attempts to develop more individualized risk prediction for cardiovascular disease may help refine surveillance and counseling in the future. </li>

5747<li>

5748Several groups have collaborated to develop and validate individualized risk calculators for heart failure, ischemic heart disease, and stroke through age 50 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

574930</a>

5750,<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

575158</a>

5752,<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

575392</a>

5754]</li>

5755<li>

5756Updated models based only on CCSS data have incorporated hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes status across time to further refine prediction.[<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

575792</a>

5758]</li>

5759<li>

5760 An online risk calculator incorporating these models is available on the <a href="https://ccss.stjude.org/cvcalc" title="https://ccss.stjude.org/cvcalc">

5761CCSS website</a>

5762.</li>

5763</ul>

5764</div>

5765<section id="_2347">

5766<h4 id="_2347_toc">

5767Risk prediction for cardiovascular diseases </h4>

5768<div class="pdq-content-list">

5769<ul id="_2767">

5770<li>

5771Using data from four large, well-annotated childhood cancer survivor cohorts (CCSS, National Wilms Tumor Study Group, the Netherlands, and SJCRH), a heart failure risk calculator based on readily available demographic and treatment characteristics has been created and validated. This calculator may provide more individualized clinical heart failure risk estimation for 5-year survivors of childhood cancer who have recently completed therapy, through age 40 years. Because of the young age of participants at the time of baseline prediction (5-year survival), this estimator is limited in that information on conventional cardiovascular conditions such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, or diabetes could not be incorporated.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

577230</a>

5773]</li>

5774<li>

5775In another collaborative study, data from the CCSS, Netherlands, and SJCRH were used to develop risk-prediction models for ischemic heart disease and stroke among 5-year survivors of childhood cancer through age 50 years. Risk scores derived from a standard prediction model that included sex, chemotherapy exposure, and radiation therapy exposure identified statistically distinct low-risk, moderate-risk, and high-risk groups. The cumulative incidences at age 50 years among CCSS low-risk groups were less than 5%, compared with approximately 20% for high-risk groups and only 1% for siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

577658</a>

5777]</li>

5778<li>

5779Traditional cardiovascular risk factors remain important for predicting risk of cardiovascular disease among adult-aged survivors of childhood cancer. This finding was demonstrated by a CCSS investigation that constructed prediction models accounting for cardiotoxic cancer treatment exposures, combined with information on traditional cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes. Risk scores based on demographic, cancer treatment, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and diabetes information showed good performance (area under the receiver operating characteristic curve and concordance statistics &#8805;0.70) for predicting cardiovascular events in the models applied to the discovery and replication cohorts. The most influential exposures were anthracycline chemotherapy, radiation therapy, diabetes, and hypertension.[<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

578092</a>

5781]</li>

5782</ul>

5783</div>

5784<table id="_1419" class="table-default expandable-container">

5785<caption>

5786Table 3. Cardiovascular Late Effects<span class="sup">

5787a,b</span>

5788</caption>

5789<colgroup>

5790<col width="33.33%">

5791<col width="33.33%">

5792<col width="33.33%">

5793</colgroup>

5794<THead>

5795<tr>

5796<th>

5797Predisposing Therapy </th>

5798<th>

5799Potential Cardiovascular Effects</th>

5800<th>

5801Health Screening</th>

5802</tr>

5803</THead>

5804<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5805<tr>

5806<td colspan="3">

5807<span class="sup">

5808a</span>

5809The Children's Oncology Group (COG) guidelines also cover other conditions that may influence cardiovascular risk, such as obesity and diabetes mellitus/impaired glucose metabolism.</td>

5810</tr>

5811<tr>

5812<td colspan="3">

5813<span class="sup">

5814b</span>

5815Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

5816Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

5817.</td>

5818</tr>

5819</TFoot>

5820<tbody>

5821<tr>

5822<td rowspan="3">

5823Any anthracycline and/or any radiation exposing the heart</td>

5824<td rowspan="3">

5825Cardiac toxicity (arrhythmia, cardiomyopathy/heart failure, pericardial disease, valve disease, ischemic heart disease)</td>

5826<td>

5827Yearly medical history and physical examination</td>

5828</tr>

5829<tr>

5830<td>

5831Electrocardiography at entry into long-term follow-up</td>

5832</tr>

5833<tr>

5834<td>

5835Echocardiography at entry into long-term follow-up, periodically repeat based on previous exposures and other risk factors</td>

5836</tr>

5837<tr>

5838<td>

5839Radiation exposing the neck and base of skull (especially &#8805;40 Gy)</td>

5840<td>

5841Carotid and/or subclavian artery disease</td>

5842<td>

5843Yearly medical history and physical examination; consider Doppler ultrasonography 10 years after exposure</td>

5844</tr>

5845<tr>

5846<td>

5847Radiation exposing the brain/cranium (especially &#8805;18 Gy)</td>

5848<td>

5849Cerebrovascular disease (cavernomas, moyamoya, occlusive cerebral vasculopathy, stroke)</td>

5850<td>

5851Yearly medical history and physical examination</td>

5852</tr>

5853<tr>

5854<td>

5855Radiation exposing the abdomen</td>

5856<td>

5857Diabetes</td>

5858<td>

5859Diabetes screening every 2 years</td>

5860</tr>

5861<tr>

5862<td>

5863Total-body irradiation (usually &lt;14 Gy)</td>

5864<td>

5865Dyslipidemia; diabetes</td>

5866<td>

5867Fasting lipid profile and diabetes screening every 2 years</td>

5868</tr>

5869<tr>

5870<td>

5871Heavy metals (carboplatin, cisplatin), and ifosfamide exposure; radiation exposing the kidneys; hematopoietic cell transplantation; nephrectomy</td>

5872<td>

5873Hypertension (from renal toxicity)</td>

5874<td>

5875Yearly blood pressure test; renal function laboratory studies at entry into long-term follow-up and repeat as clinically indicated</td>

5876</tr>

5877</tbody>

5878</table>

5879</section>

5880</section>

5881<h6 do-not-show="toc">

5882References</h6>

5898[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

J Clin Oncol 28 (8): 1308-15, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20142603&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20142603&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6218[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6219</li>

6220<li id="section_3.85">

6221Armstrong GT, Kawashima T, Leisenring W, et al.: Aging and risk of severe, disabling, life-threatening, and fatal events in the childhood cancer survivor study. J Clin Oncol 32 (12): 1218-27, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24638000&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24638000&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6222[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6223</li>

6224<li id="section_3.86">

6225Chen AB, Punglia RS, Kuntz KM, et al.: Cost effectiveness and screening interval of lipid screening in Hodgkin's lymphoma survivors. J Clin Oncol 27 (32): 5383-9, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19752333&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19752333&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6226[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6227</li>

6228<li id="section_3.87">

6229Wong FL, Bhatia S, Landier W, et al.: Cost-effectiveness of the children's oncology group long-term follow-up screening guidelines for childhood cancer survivors at risk for treatment-related heart failure. Ann Intern Med 160 (10): 672-83, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24842414&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24842414&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6230[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6231</li>

6232<li id="section_3.88">

6233Yeh JM, Nohria A, Diller L: Routine echocardiography screening for asymptomatic left ventricular dysfunction in childhood cancer survivors: a model-based estimation of the clinical and economic effects. Ann Intern Med 160 (10): 661-71, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24842413&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24842413&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6234[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6235</li>

6236<li id="section_3.89">

6237Landier W, Armenian SH, Lee J, et al.: Yield of screening for long-term complications using the children's oncology group long-term follow-up guidelines. J Clin Oncol 30 (35): 4401-8, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23091100&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23091100&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6238[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6239</li>

6240<li id="section_3.90">

6241Ramjaun A, AlDuhaiby E, Ahmed S, et al.: Echocardiographic Detection of Cardiac Dysfunction in Childhood Cancer Survivors: How Long Is Screening Required? Pediatr Blood Cancer 62 (12): 2197-203, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26146944&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26146944&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6242[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6243</li>

6244<li id="section_3.91">

6245Spewak MB, Williamson RS, Mertens AC, et al.: Yield of screening echocardiograms during pediatric follow-up in survivors treated with anthracyclines and cardiotoxic radiation. Pediatr Blood Cancer 64 (6): , 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27966803&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27966803&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6246[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6247</li>

6248<li id="section_3.92">

6249Chen Y, Chow EJ, Oeffinger KC, et al.: Traditional Cardiovascular Risk Factors and Individual Prediction of Cardiovascular Events in Childhood Cancer Survivors. J Natl Cancer Inst 112 (3): 256-265, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31161223&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31161223&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6250[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6251</li>

6252<li id="section_3.93">

6253Scott JM, Li N, Liu Q, et al.: Association of Exercise With Mortality in Adult Survivors of Childhood Cancer. JAMA Oncol 4 (10): 1352-1358, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29862412&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29862412&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6254[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6255</li>

6256<li id="section_3.94">

6257Schindera C, Z&#252;rcher SJ, Jung R, et al.: Physical fitness and modifiable cardiovascular disease risk factors in survivors of childhood cancer: A report from the SURfit study. Cancer 127 (10): 1690-1698, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33405260&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33405260&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6258[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6259</li>

6260</ol>

6261</div>

6262

6263 </section>

6264

6265

6266

6267 <section id="_9">

6268

6269 <h2>

6270Late Effects of the Central Nervous System</h2>

6271

6272 <div id="_section_9" class="pdq-sections">

6273<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6274<h6>

6275In This Section</h6>

6276<ul>

6277<li>

6278<a href="#_10_toc">

6279Neurocognitive<ul>

6280<li>

6281<a href="#_576_toc">

6282Neurocognitive outcomes in brain tumor survivors</a>

6283</li>

6284<li>

6285<a href="#_579_toc">

6286Neurocognitive outcomes in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) survivors</a>

6287</li>

6288<li>

6289<a href="#_585_toc">

6290Other cancers</a>

6291</li>

6292<li>

6293<a href="#_587_toc">

6294Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</a>

6295</li>

6296</ul>

6297</a>

6298</li>

6299<li>

6300<a href="#_426_toc">

6301Neurological Sequelae<ul>

6302<li>

6303<a href="#_2502_toc">

6304Seizures</a>

6305</li>

6306<li>

6307<a href="#_2506_toc">

6308Leukoencephalopathy</a>

6309</li>

6310<li>

6311<a href="#_2509_toc">

6312Peripheral neuropathy</a>

6313</li>

6314<li>

6315<a href="#_2516_toc">

6316Stroke</a>

6317</li>
