6318<li>

6319<a href="#_2519_toc">

6320Hypersomnia (daytime sleepiness) or narcolepsy</a>

6321</li>

6322<li>

6323<a href="#_2524_toc">

6324Other neurological sequelae</a>

6325</li>

6326</ul>

6327</a>

6328</li>

6329<li>

6330<a href="#_16_toc">

6331Psychosocial<ul>

6332<li>

6333<a href="#_2537_toc">

6334Achievement of social milestones</a>

6335</li>

6336<li>

6337<a href="#_2539_toc">

6338Psychological distress and suicidality </a>

6339</li>

6340<li>

6341<a href="#_2995_toc">

6342Major psychiatric disorders</a>

6343</li>

6344<li>

6345<a href="#_645_toc">

6346PTSD after childhood cancer</a>

6347</li>

6348<li>

6349<a href="#_648_toc">

6350Psychosocial outcomes among childhood, adolescent, and young adult cancer survivors</a>

6351</li>

6352</ul>

6353</a>

6354</li>

6355</ul>

6356</nav>

6357<section id="_10">

6358<h3 id="_10_toc">

6359Neurocognitive</h3>

6360<p id="_575" tabindex="-1">

6361Neurocognitive late effects are commonly observed after treatment of malignancies that require central nervous system (CNS)&#8211;directed therapies. While considerable evidence has been published about this outcome, its quality is often limited by small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, cross-sectional versus longitudinal evaluations, and variable time of assessment from treatment exposures. CNS-directed therapies include the following:</p>

6362<div class="pdq-content-list">

6363<ul id="_1044">

6364<li>

6365Cranial radiation therapy.</li>

6366<li>

6367Systemic therapy with high-dose methotrexate or cytarabine.</li>

6368<li>

6369Intrathecal chemotherapy. </li>

6370</ul>

6371</div>

6372<p id="_1045" tabindex="-1">

6373Children with brain tumors or acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) are most likely to be affected. Risk factors for the development of neurocognitive late effects include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

63741</a>

6375-<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

63765</a>

6377]</p>

6378<div class="pdq-content-list">

6379<ul id="_1046">

6380<li>

6381Female sex.</li>

6382<li>

6383Younger age at the time of treatment.</li>

6384<li>

6385Tumor location.</li>

6386<li>

6387Treatment with cranial radiation therapy and/or chemotherapeutic agents (systemic or intrathecal).</li>

6388<li>

6389Higher cranial radiation dose.</li>

6390<li>

6391Time since treatment.</li>

6392</ul>

6393</div>

6394<p id="_1030" tabindex="-1">

6395Cognitive phenotypes observed in childhood survivors of ALL and CNS tumors may differ from traditional developmental disorders. For example, the phenotype of attention problems in ALL and brain tumor survivors appears to differ from developmental attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in that few survivors demonstrate significant hyperactivity/impulsivity, but instead have associated difficulties with processing speed and executive function.[<a href="#cit/section_4.6">

63966</a>

6397,<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

63987</a>

6399]</p>

6400<p id="_1993" tabindex="-1">

6401In addition to the direct effects of neurotoxic therapies like cranial radiation, Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) investigators observed that chronic health conditions resulting from non-neurotoxic treatment exposures (e.g., thoracic radiation) can adversely impact neurocognitive function presumably mediated by chronic cardiopulmonary and endocrine dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

64028</a>

6403] In addition, some sequelae of neurotoxic therapy (e.g., severe hearing loss) have been associated with neurocognitive deficits independent of the neurotoxic treatment received.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

64049</a>

6405]</p>

6406<p id="_2423" tabindex="-1">

6407A related investigation from the CCSS evaluated longitudinal associations between physical activity and neurocognitive problems in adult survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

640810</a>

6409]</p>

6410<div class="pdq-content-list">

6411<ul id="_2424">

6412<li>

6413Survivors were less likely than their siblings to report consistent physical activity (28.1% vs. 33.6%).</li>

6414<li>

6415Survivors who reported more consistent physical activity had fewer neurocognitive problems and larger improvements in cognitive concerns years after treatment. </li>

6416<li>

6417Body mass index (BMI) and severe chronic health conditions partially mediated the physical activity&#8211;neurocognitive associations, but the mediation effects were small. </li>

6418</ul>

6419</div>

6420<section id="_576">

6421<h4 id="_576_toc">

6422Neurocognitive outcomes in brain tumor survivors</h4>

6423<p id="_577" tabindex="-1">

6424Long-term cognitive effects caused by illness and associated treatments are well-established morbidities in survivors of childhood and adolescent brain tumors. Risk factors for adverse neurocognitive effects in this group include the following: </p>

6425<div class="pdq-content-list">

6426<ul id="_1047">

6427<li>

6428Cranial radiation therapy. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6429<ul id="_2477" class="list-dash">

6430<li>

6431Cranial radiation therapy has been associated with the highest risk of long-term cognitive morbidity, particularly in younger children.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

643211</a>

6433] </li>

6434<li>

6435 There is an established dose-response relationship, with patients who receive higher-dose cranial radiation therapy consistently performing more poorly on intellectual measures.[<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

643612</a>

6437]</li>

6438<li>

6439Radiation dose to specific regions of the brain, including the temporal lobes and hippocampi, have been shown to significantly impact longitudinal intelligence quotient (IQ) scores and academic achievement scores among children treated with craniospinal irradiation for medulloblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

644013</a>

6441]</li>

6442</ul>

6443</div>

6444</li>

6445<li>

6446Tumor site.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

644711</a>

6448,<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

644914</a>

6450]</li>

6451<li>

6452Shunted hydrocephalus.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

645311</a>

6454,<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

645515</a>

6456,<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

645716</a>

6458]</li>

6459<li>

6460Postsurgical cerebellar mutism.[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

646117</a>

6462]</li>

6463<li>

6464Auditory difficulties, including sensorineural hearing loss.[<a href="#cit/section_4.9">

64659</a>

6466,<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

646715</a>

6468,<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

646918</a>

6470]</li>

6471<li>

6472History of stroke.[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

647319</a>

6474]</li>

6475<li>

6476Seizures.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

647714</a>

6478,<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

647920</a>

6480]</li>

6481<li>

6482Socioeconomic status (SES).[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

648321</a>

6484]</li>

6485</ul>

6486</div>

6487<p id="_844" tabindex="-1">

6488The negative impact of radiation treatment has been characterized by changes in IQ scores, which have been noted to drop about 2 to 5 years after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

648922</a>

6490-<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

649124</a>

6492]</p>

6493<div class="pdq-content-list">

6494<ul id="_2478">

6495<li>

6496The decline continues 5 to 10 years afterward, although less is known about potential stabilization or further decline of IQ scores several decades after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

649722</a>

6498-<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

649924</a>

6500] </li>

6501<li>

6502 The decline in IQ scores over time typically reflects the child&#8217;s failure to acquire new abilities or information at a rate similar to that of his or her peers, rather than a progressive loss of skills and knowledge.[<a href="#cit/section_4.12">

650312</a>

6504]</li>

6505<li>

6506Affected children also may experience deficits in other cognitive areas, including academic domains (reading and math) and problems with attention, processing speed, memory, and visual or perceptual motor skills.[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

650723</a>

6508,<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

650925</a>

6510,<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

651126</a>

6512]</li>

6513<li>

6514Changes in cognitive functioning may be partially explained by radiation-induced reduction of normal-appearing white matter volume or integrity of white matter pathways, as evaluated through magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).[<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

651527</a>

6516,<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

651728</a>

6518]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6519<ul id="_2479" class="list-dash">

6520<li>

6521Reduced white matter integrity has been directly linked to slowed cognitive processing speed in survivors of brain tumors,[<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

652229</a>

6523] while greater white matter volume has been associated with better working memory, particularly in females.[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

652428</a>

6525] </li>

6526<li>

6527Data emerging from contemporary protocols show that using lower doses of cranial radiation and more targeted treatment volumes appears to reduce the severity of neurocognitive effects of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

652814</a>

6529,<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

653016</a>

6531,<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

653230</a>

6533]</li>

6534</ul>

6535</div>

6536</li>

6537</ul>

6538</div>

6539<p id="_1742" tabindex="-1">

6540Evidence (predictors of cognitive decline among survivors of CNS tumors):</p>

6541<p id="_847" tabindex="-1">

6542Longitudinal cohort studies have provided insight into the trajectory and predictors of cognitive decline among survivors of CNS tumors.</p>

6543<div class="pdq-content-list">

6544<ol id="_1743">

6545<li>

6546A multisite, prospective, longitudinal trial evaluated predictors of cognitive performance among 139 infants with brain tumors who were treated with chemotherapy, with or without focal proton or photon radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

654731</a>

6548]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6549<ul id="_2837">

6550<li>

6551IQ, parent-reported working memory, and parent-reported adaptive functioning were worse than normative expectations at baseline, with younger age and lower socioeconomic status representing predictive factors.</li>

6552<li>

6553IQ remained stable over time, whereas parent-reported attention and executive dysfunction increased.</li>

6554<li>

6555Cognitive outcomes did not differ by treatment exposure (chemotherapy only vs. chemotherapy with radiation therapy).</li>

6556<li>

6557Changes in cognitive function were associated with supratentorial tumor location and cerebrospinal fluid diversion.</li>

6558</ul>

6559</div>

6560</li>

6561<li>

6562St. Jude Children&#8217;s Research Hospital (SJCRH) studied 78 children younger than 20 years (mean, 9.7 years) diagnosed with a low-grade glioma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

656332</a>

6564]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6565<ul id="_1744">

6566<li>

6567Cognitive decline after 54 Gy of conformal cranial radiation therapy was noted (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1519">

6568Figure 7</a>

6569).</li>

6570<li>

6571Age at time of cranial irradiation was more important than was cranial radiation dose in predicting cognitive decline, with children younger than 5 years estimated to experience the greatest cognitive decline.<p id="_1519" tabindex="-1">

6572<figure id="figure_709" class="image-center">

6573<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/727433.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

6574Enlarge</a>

6575<img id="_709" alt="Graph shows modeled IQ scores after conformal radiation therapy, by age measured in years, and time measured in months, after the start of CRT for pediatric low-grade glioma." title="Graph shows modeled IQ scores after conformal radiation therapy, by age measured in years, and time measured in months, after the start of CRT for pediatric low-grade glioma." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/727433-750.jpg">

6576<figcaption class="caption-container">

6577Figure 7. Modeled intelligence quotient (IQ) scores after conformal radiation therapy (CRT) by age for pediatric low-grade glioma. Age is measured in years, and time is measured in months after the start of CRT. Thomas E. Merchant, Heather M. Conklin, Shengjie Wu, Robert H. Lustig, and Xiaoping Xiong, Late Effects of Conformal Radiation Therapy for Pediatric

6578Patients With Low-Grade Glioma: Prospective Evaluation

6579of Cognitive, Endocrine, and Hearing Deficits, Journal of Clinical Oncology, volume 27, issue 22, pages 3691-3697. Reprinted with permission. &#169; (2009) American Society of Clinical Oncology. All rights reserved.</figcaption>

6580</figure>

6581</p>

6582</li>

6583</ul>

6584</div>

6585</li>

6586<li>

6587In a study of 51 children with low-grade gliomas and low-grade glioneural tumors diagnosed within the first year of life, the following was reported:[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

658833</a>

6589]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6590<ul id="_2480">

6591<li>

6592Mean IQ score was 75.5; 75% of the children had IQ scores lower than 85.</li>

6593<li>

6594Predictors of low IQ included a supratentorial location of the primary tumor and treatment with more chemotherapy regimens but not radiation use.</li>

6595<li>

6596 The child&#8217;s ability to complete age-appropriate tasks was as affected as IQ scores.</li>

6597</ul>

6598</div>

6599</li>

6600<li>

6601A study of 126 medulloblastoma survivors treated with 23.4 Gy or 36 Gy to 39.6 Gy of craniospinal radiation (with a conformal boost dose of 55.8 Gy to the primary tumor bed) assessed processing speed, attention, and memory performance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

660234</a>

6603] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6604<ul id="_1745">

6605<li>

6606Processing speed scores declined significantly over time, while less decline was observed in attention and memory performance. Higher doses of radiation and younger age at diagnosis predicted slower processing speed over time.</li>

6607<li>

6608Studies of working memory and academic achievement in patients enrolled on the same medulloblastoma trial (SJCRH <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00085202">

6609SJMB03 [NCT00085202]</a>

6610) indicated that performance was largely within the age-expected range up to 5 years postdiagnosis,[<a href="#cit/section_4.35">

661135</a>

6612,<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

661336</a>

6614] although in both studies, posterior fossa syndrome, higher cranial radiation dose, and younger age at diagnosis predicted worse performance over time.</li>

6615<li>

6616Serious hearing loss was associated with intellectual and academic decline over time.[<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

661736</a>

6618]</li>

6619</ul>

6620</div>

6621</li>

6622<li>

6623A prospective study compared 36 pediatric patients with medulloblastoma who experienced posterior fossa syndrome with 36 patients with medulloblastoma who did not experience posterior fossa syndrome but were matched on treatment and age at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

662437</a>

6625]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6626<ul id="_2073">

6627<li>

6628 The posterior fossa syndrome group demonstrated lower mean scores at 1, 3, and 5 years postdiagnosis on general intellectual ability, processing speed, working memory, and spatial relations compared with the non&#8211;posterior fossa syndrome group.</li>

6629<li>

6630The group who experienced posterior fossa syndrome showed little recovery over time and further decline over time in some domains (attention and working memory), compared with the non&#8211;posterior fossa syndrome group.</li>

6631</ul>

6632</div>

6633</li>

6634<li>

6635Canadian investigators evaluated the impact of radiation (dose and boost volume) and neurological complications on patterns of intellectual functioning in a cohort of 113 medulloblastoma survivors (mean age at diagnosis, 7.5 years; mean time from diagnosis to last assessment, 6 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.38">

663638</a>

6637]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6638<ul id="_1746">

6639<li>

6640Survivors treated with reduced-dose craniospinal radiation therapy plus tumor bed boost showed stable intellectual functioning.</li>

6641<li>

6642Neurological complications, such as hydrocephalus requiring cerebrospinal fluid diversion and mutism, and treatment with higher doses and larger boost volumes of radiation resulted in intellectual declines with distinctive trajectories.</li>

6643</ul>

6644</div>

6645</li>

6646<li>

6647Studies are beginning to examine cognitive outcomes in histologically distinct subtypes of brain tumors.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6648<ul id="_2481">

6649<li>

6650 Data from a sample of 121 medulloblastoma patients demonstrated variation in cognitive outcomes by four distinct molecular subgroups and differences in patterns of change over time.[<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

665139</a>

6652]</li>

6653<li>

6654 Future research is required to establish if neurocognitive outcomes vary across biologically distinct subtypes of childhood brain tumors.</li>

6655</ul>

6656</div>

6657</li>

6658<li>

6659SES has been shown to predict long-term cognitive outcomes in brain tumor survivors. In a prospective, longitudinal, phase II study of 248 children who were treated with conformal radiation therapy (54&#8211;59.4 Gy) for ependymoma, low-grade glioma, or craniopharyngioma, patients were monitored serially with cognitive assessment for 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

666021</a>

6661]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6662<ul id="_2880">

6663<li>

6664 At preradiation therapy baseline, significant associations were seen between SES and IQ, reading and math scores, sustained attention, and adaptive function. Higher SES was associated with better performance (<em>

6665P</em>

6666 &lt; .005).</li>

6667<li>

6668 SES predicted change over time in IQ and reading and math scores. Higher SES was associated with less decline (<em>

6669P</em>

6670 &lt; .001).</li>

6671<li>

6672 These results suggest that higher SES is a protective factor for cognitive late effects.</li>

6673</ul>

6674</div>

6675</li>

6676</ol>

6677</div>

6678<p id="_2482" tabindex="-1">

6679Evidence (predictors of cognitive decline among long-term survivors of CNS tumors):</p>

6680<p id="_1032" tabindex="-1">

6681Although adverse neurocognitive outcomes observed 5 to 10 years after treatment are presumed to be pervasive, and potentially worsen over time, few empirical data are available regarding the neurocognitive functioning in very long-term survivors of CNS tumors. </p>

6682<div class="pdq-content-list">

6683<ol id="_2483">

6684<li>

6685A longitudinal study evaluated the relationship of hippocampal dose and short-term memory decline in 80 children and adolescents with low-grade gliomas (median age, 9.5 years at treatment) who received 54 Gy of radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.40">

668640</a>

6687]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6688<ul id="_2795">

6689<li>

6690 At a median neurocognitive follow-up of 9.8 years, higher hippocampal dose (volume receiving 40 Gy) was associated with a greater decline in delayed recall.</li>

6691</ul>

6692</div>

6693</li>

6694<li>

6695Among adult survivors participating in the CCSS, CNS tumor survivors (n = 802) self-reported significantly more problems with attention/processing speed, memory, emotional control, and organization than did survivors of non-CNS malignancies (n = 5,937) and sibling controls (n = 382).[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

66963</a>

6697]</li>

6698<li>

6699Another CCSS study evaluating patterns of late mortality and morbidity in 2,821 adult survivors of CNS tumors reported impairment on measures of attention/processing speed (42.9%&#8211;73.3%) and memory (14.3%&#8211;37.4%), with differences observed by diagnosis and cranial radiation dose.[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

670041</a>

6701]</li>

6702<li>

6703A study of 224 adult survivors of pediatric brain tumors participating in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study revealed that 20% to 30% of the survivors demonstrated severe neurocognitive impairment (defined as at least two standard deviations below normative mean) on clinical assessments of intelligence, memory, and executive function (e.g., planning, organization, and flexibility).[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

670414</a>

6705]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6706<ul id="_2484">

6707<li>

6708 Among adults in the general population, the expected impairment rate at this threshold is 2%.</li>

6709<li>

6710 Survivors who received whole-brain cranial irradiation were 1.5 to 3 times more likely to have severe neurocognitive impairment than were survivors who did not receive any cranial irradiation.</li>

6711<li>

6712 Hydrocephalus with shunt placement and seizures were also associated with increased risk of impairment.</li>

6713</ul>

6714</div>

6715</li>

6716<li>

6717In the CCSS, investigators compared long-term neuropsychological and socioeconomic status outcomes of 181 adult survivors of pediatric low-grade gliomas with the outcomes of an age-matched and sex-matched sibling comparison group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.42">

671842</a>

6719]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6720<ul id="_2485">

6721<li>

6722 Survivors who were treated with surgery and radiation therapy (median age at diagnosis, 7 years; median age at assessment, 41 years) scored lower on estimated IQ than did survivors who were treated with surgery only, who scored lower than siblings (surgery and radiation therapy, 93.9; surgery only, 101.2; siblings, 108.5; all <em>

6723P</em>

6724 values &lt; .0001).</li>

6725<li>

6726 Younger age at diagnosis was predictive of low scores for all neuropsychological outcomes except for attention/processing speed.</li>

6727<li>

6728 Survivors who were treated with surgery and radiation therapy had more-than-twofold&#8211;lower occupation scores, income, and education than did survivors who were treated with surgery only.</li>

6729</ul>

6730</div>

6731</li>

6732<li>

6733In a retrospective review of 528 brain tumor survivors diagnosed between 2000 and 2015, the prevalence of a clinical diagnosis of ADHD was 13.1%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

673443</a>

6735]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6736<ul id="_2486">

6737<li>

6738Of the survivors, 12.1% used medications for ADHD, and 19.9% of survivors had symptoms of ADHD without a clinical diagnosis.</li>

6739<li>

6740ADHD diagnosis was associated with younger age at tumor diagnosis and supratentorial tumor location, but not with sex, tumor type, or treatment type.</li>

6741</ul>

6742</div>

6743</li>

6744</ol>

6745</div>

6746<p id="_1033" tabindex="-1">

6747The neurocognitive consequences of CNS disease and treatment may have a considerable impact on functional outcomes for brain tumor survivors. </p>

6748<div class="pdq-content-list">

6749<ul id="_1049">

6750<li>

6751In childhood and adolescence, neurocognitive deficits have been associated with poor social adjustment, including problems with peer relations, social withdrawal, and reduced social skills.[<a href="#cit/section_4.44">

675244</a>

6753,<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

675445</a>

6755]</li>

6756<li>

6757CNS tumor survivors are more likely to need special education services than are survivors of other malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

675846</a>

6759]</li>

6760<li>

6761Adult CNS tumor survivors are less likely to live independently, marry, and graduate from college than are survivors of other malignancies and siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_4.46">

676246</a>

6763-<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

676448</a>

6765]</li>

6766</ul>

6767</div>

6768<section id="_2192">

6769<h5 id="_2192_toc">

6770Cognitive outcomes after proton radiation therapy</h5>

6771<p id="_2193" tabindex="-1">

6772Data are emerging regarding cognitive outcomes after proton radiation to the CNS;[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

677349</a>

6774-<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

677553</a>

6776] however, these studies have been limited by retrospective analysis of cognitive outcomes among relatively small clinically heterogenous pediatric brain tumor cohorts and the use of historically treated photon patients or population standards as comparison groups.</p>

6777<div class="pdq-content-list">

6778<ul id="_2194">

6779<li>

6780 In studies largely describing IQ changes during early follow-up (&lt;5 years from radiation), results demonstrate lack of difference in slopes of IQ change among photon-treated and proton-treated patients [<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

678149</a>

6782] and significant declines in cognitive processing speed among patients treated with proton radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

678350</a>

6784] </li>

6785<li>

6786One study compared the intellectual trajectories between pediatric patients with medulloblastoma who were treated with proton and photon radiation therapy (4.3-year mean follow-up after median 23.4-Gy craniospinal irradiation dose). Notably, boost dose and margins were significantly different between the two groups.[<a href="#cit/section_4.52">

678752</a>

6788]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6789<ul id="_2195">

6790<li>

6791Children treated with proton radiation therapy exhibited superior long-term outcomes in global IQ, perceptual reasoning, and working memory compared with children who were treated with photon radiation therapy.</li>

6792<li>

6793The photon radiation therapy group exhibited a significant decline in global IQ, working memory, and processing speed. </li>

6794<li>

6795The proton radiation therapy group exhibited stable scores over time in all domains, except for processing speed.</li>

6796</ul>

6797</div>

6798</li>

6799</ul>

6800</div>

6801<p id="_2196" tabindex="-1">

6802Considering the relatively brief follow-up time from radiation, longitudinal follow-up is important to determine whether proton radiation provides a clinically meaningful benefit in sparing cognitive function compared with photon radiation. In addition, more targeted radiation treatment volumes with photons may diminish potential differences.</p>

6803</section>

6804</section>

6805<section id="_579">

6806<h4 id="_579_toc">

6807Neurocognitive outcomes in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) survivors</h4>

6808<p id="_2487" tabindex="-1">

6809To minimize the risk of late cognitive sequelae, contemporary therapy for ALL uses a risk-stratified approach that reserves cranial irradiation for children who are considered at high risk of CNS relapse.</p>

6810<p id="_581" tabindex="-1">

6811Although low-risk, standard-risk, and most high-risk patients are treated with chemotherapy-only protocols, early reports of neurocognitive late effects for ALL patients were based on heterogeneously treated groups of survivors who received combinations (simultaneously or sequentially) of intrathecal chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and high-dose chemotherapy, making it difficult to differentiate the impact of the individual treatment components. However, outcome data are increasingly available regarding the risk of neurocognitive late effects in survivors of childhood ALL treated with chemotherapy only.</p>

6812<section id="_631">

6813<h5 id="_631_toc">

6814ALL and cranial radiation</h5>

6815<p id="_1747" tabindex="-1">

6816In survivors of ALL, cranial radiation therapy may result in clinical and radiographic neurological late sequelae, including the following:</p>

6817<div class="pdq-content-list">

6818<ul id="_1748">

6819<li>

6820<strong>

6821Clinical leukoencephalopathy.</strong>

6822 Clinical leukoencephalopathy characterized by spasticity, ataxia, dysarthria, dysphagia, hemiparesis, and seizures is uncommon after contemporary ALL therapy. In contrast, neuroimaging frequently demonstrates white matter abnormalities among survivors treated with cranial irradiation and/or high-dose methotrexate. <div class="pdq-content-list">

6823<ul id="_2488" class="list-dash">

6824<li>

6825Radiographic leukoencephalopathy has been reported in up to 80% of children on some treatment regimens.</li>

6826<li>

6827 Higher doses and more courses of intravenous methotrexate have been reported to increase risk of leukoencephalopathy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

682854</a>

6829]</li>

6830<li>

6831 In many patients, white matter anomalies are transient and decrease in prevalence, extent, and intensity with longer elapsed time from completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

683254</a>

6833]</li>

6834<li>

6835 Leukoencephalopathy results in smaller white matter volumes that have been correlated with cognitive deficits.[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

683654</a>

6837] </li>

6838<li>

6839Although these abnormalities are mild among the irradiated patients (overall IQ fall of approximately 10 points), those who have received higher doses at a young age may have significant learning difficulties.[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

684055</a>

6841,<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

684256</a>

6843]</li>

6844</ul>

6845</div>

6846</li>

6847<li>

6848<strong>

6849Neuropsychological deficits.</strong>

6850 Deficits in neuropsychological functions such as visual-motor integration, processing speed, attention, and short-term memory are reported in children treated with 18 Gy to 24 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

685155</a>

6852,<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

685357</a>

6854,<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

685558</a>

6856]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6857<ul id="_2489" class="list-dash">

6858<li>

6859 Females and children treated at a younger age are more vulnerable to the adverse impact of cranial radiation on the developing brain.[<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

686059</a>

6861]</li>

6862<li>

6863 The decline in intellectual functioning appears to be progressive, showing more impairment of cognitive function with increasing time since radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

686459</a>

6865,<a href="#cit/section_4.60">

686660</a>

6867]</li>

6868<li>

6869 Limited studies suggest that long-term survivors of childhood ALL treated with cranial irradiation are at risk of progressive decline consistent with early-onset mild cognitive impairment; this risk is most prominent among those treated with cranial radiation doses of 24 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

687061</a>

6871,<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

687262</a>

6873]</li>

6874</ul>

6875</div>

6876</li>

6877</ul>

6878</div>

6879</section>

6880<section id="_633">

6881<h5 id="_633_toc">

6882ALL and chemotherapy-only CNS therapy</h5>

6883<p id="_1034" tabindex="-1">

6884Because of its penetrance into the CNS, systemic methotrexate has been used in a variety of low-dose and high-dose regimens for leukemia CNS prophylaxis.</p>

6885<div class="pdq-content-list">

6886<ul id="_2490">

6887<li>

6888 Systemic methotrexate in high doses with or without radiation therapy can lead to an infrequent but well-described leukoencephalopathy, which has been linked to neurocognitive impairment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

688954</a>

6890]</li>

6891<li>

6892 When neurocognitive outcomes after radiation therapy and chemotherapy-only regimens are directly compared, the evidence suggests a better outcome for those treated with chemotherapy alone, although some studies show no significant difference.[<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

689363</a>

6894,<a href="#cit/section_4.64">

689564</a>

6896]</li>

6897<li>

6898 In a longitudinal analysis of 210 childhood ALL survivors, the development of acute leukoencephalopathy during chemotherapy-only CNS therapy predicted higher risks of developing long-term neurobehavioral problems (e.g., deficits in organization and task initiation [components of executive function]) and reduced white matter integrity in frontal brain regions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.65">

689965</a>

6900]</li>

6901<li>

6902Compared with cranial irradiation, chemotherapy-only CNS-directed treatment produces neurocognitive deficits involving processes of attention, speed of information processing, memory, verbal comprehension, visual-spatial skills, visual-motor functioning, and executive functioning; global intellectual function is typically preserved.[<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

690357</a>

6904,<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

690563</a>

6906,<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

690766</a>

6908-<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

690968</a>

6910]</li>

6911<li>

6912 Few longitudinal studies evaluating long-term neurocognitive outcome report adequate data for a decline in global IQ after treatment with chemotherapy alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

691366</a>

6914]</li>

6915<li>

6916 The academic achievement of ALL survivors in the long term seems to be generally average for reading and spelling, with deficits mainly affecting arithmetic performance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

691763</a>

6918,<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

691969</a>

6920]</li>

6921<li>

6922 Risk factors for poor neurocognitive outcome after chemotherapy-only CNS-directed treatment are younger age and female sex.[<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

692368</a>

6924,<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

692570</a>

6926]</li>

6927<li>

6928Reduced cognitive status has been observed in association with reduced integrity in neuroanatomical regions essential in memory formation (e.g., reduced hippocampal volume with increased activation and thinner parietal cortices).[<a href="#cit/section_4.65">

692965</a>

6930]</li>

6931<li>

6932The long-term impact of these prevalent neurocognitive and neuroimaging abnormalities on functional status in aging adults treated for childhood ALL, particularly those treated with contemporary approaches using chemotherapy alone, remains an active area of research.</li>

6933</ul>

6934</div>

6935<p id="_1749" tabindex="-1">

6936Evidence (neurocognitive functioning in large pediatric cancer survivor cohorts):</p>

6937<div class="pdq-content-list">

6938<ol id="_1750">

6939<li>

6940CCSS investigators identified sex-specific associations between treatment and chronic health conditions with neurocognitive impairment among 1,207 survivors of ALL (mean age, 30.6 years) who were treated with chemotherapy only.[<a href="#cit/section_4.71">

694171</a>

6942]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6943<ul id="_2782">

6944<li>

6945Both male and female survivors reported increased prevalence of impaired task efficiency (attention and processing speed; adjusted odds ratio [OR], 1.89 for males; OR, 1.50 for females) and impaired memory (OR, 1.89 for males; OR, 1.96 for females) compared with 2,273 same-sex siblings.</li>

6946<li>

6947Among male survivors, impaired task efficiency was associated with grades 2 to 4 neurological conditions (OR, 4.33) and pulmonary conditions (OR, 4.99). Impaired memory was associated with increased cumulative dose of intrathecal methotrexate (OR, 1.68) and exposure to dexamethasone (OR, 2.44). </li>

6948<li>

6949In female survivors, grades 2 to 4 endocrine conditions were associated with higher risk of impaired task efficiency (OR, 2.19) and memory (OR, 2.26).</li>

6950</ul>

6951</div>

6952</li>

6953<li>

6954The CCSS examined parent-reported cognitive, behavior, and learning problems from 1,560 adolescent survivors of childhood ALL who were treated with chemotherapy alone between 1970 and 1999.[<a href="#cit/section_4.72">

695572</a>

6956]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6957<ul id="_1995">

6958<li>

6959Survivors treated with cranial irradiation had significantly higher frequency of problems in anxiety-depression, inattention-hyperactivity, and social withdrawal than did patients who were not treated with cranial irradiation.</li>

6960<li>

6961Compared with siblings, survivors treated with chemotherapy only were more likely to demonstrate headstrong behavior (19% of survivors vs. 14% of siblings, <em>

6962P</em>

6963 = .010), inattention-hyperactivity (19% vs. 14%, <em>

6964P</em>

6965 &lt; .0001), social withdrawal (18% vs. 12%, <em>

6966P</em>

6967 = .002), and had higher rates of learning problems (28% vs. 14%, <em>

6968P</em>

6969 &lt; .0001).</li>

6970<li>

6971In multivariable models among survivors, increased cumulative dose of intravenous methotrexate (i.e., &gt;4.3 g/m<span class="sup">

69722</span>

6973) conferred increased risk of inattention-hyperactivity (relative risk [RR], 1.53).</li>

6974<li>

6975Adolescent survivors with cognitive or behavior problems and those with learning problems were less likely to graduate from college as young adults than adolescent survivors without cognitive or behavior problems.</li>

6976<li>

6977Inattention and hyperactivity problems were associated with the highest risk of special education placement during adolescence. Participation in special education during adolescence did not improve adult educational attainment.</li>

6978</ul>

6979</div>

6980</li>

6981<li>

6982The SJCRH <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00549848">

6983TOTAL XVI (NCT00549848)</a>

6984 trial evaluated whether a higher dose of pegaspargase and early intensification of triple intrathecal therapy (ITT; methotrexate, hydrocortisone, and cytarabine) would improve systemic and CNS control in children with newly diagnosed ALL. Intensified ITT was defined as more than 21 cumulative doses for patients with low-risk ALL (70 of 194) and more than 27 doses for those with standard- and high-risk ALL (81 of 206). Neurocognitive testing was completed at the end of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.73">

698573</a>

6986]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6987<ul id="_2983">

6988<li>

6989The overall group had below age-based norms on measures of global intelligence (<em>

6990P</em>

6991 &lt; .0001), attention (<em>

6992P</em>

6993 = .0051), working memory (<em>

6994P</em>

6995 = .0001), processing speed (<em>

6996P</em>

6997 = .0002), fine motor speed (<em>

6998P</em>

6999 = .0001), and math skills (<em>

7000P</em>

7001 = .0087). Caregiver ratings of patient functioning showed elevated risks of problems in attention (<em>

7002P</em>

7003 = .0173), executive function (<em>

7004P</em>

7005 = .0001), and adaptive skills (<em>

7006P</em>

7007 = .0001).</li>

7008<li>

7009In the low-risk group, there were no significant differences between patients treated with and without intensified ITT. </li>

7010<li>

7011Patients with standard- and high-risk ALL who were treated with intensified ITT had poorer working memory (<em>

7012P</em>

7013 = .0328) and fine motor speed (<em>

7014P</em>

7015 = .0403), and elevated ratings of inattention (<em>

7016P</em>

7017 = .0189) and executive dysfunction (<em>

7018P</em>

7019 = .0245). Females in this risk group treated with intensified ITT had lower working memory scores.</li>

7020</ul>

7021</div>

7022</li>

7023<li>

7024In the SJCRH <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00137111">

7025Total XV (NCT00137111)</a>

7026 trial, which omitted prophylactic cranial irradiation, comprehensive cognitive testing of 243 participants at week 120 revealed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

702774</a>

7028]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7029<ul id="_1751">

7030<li>

7031A higher risk of below-average performance on a measure of sustained attention but not on measures of intellectual functioning, academic skills, or memory.</li>

7032<li>

7033The risk of cognitive deficits correlated with treatment intensity but not with age at diagnosis or sex.</li>

7034<li>

7035Prolonged follow-up (average, 7.7 years from diagnosis) of this cohort demonstrated that intelligence was within normal limits compared with population expectations, but measures of executive function, processing speed, and memory were less than population means. </li>

7036<li>

7037 Higher plasma methotrexate was associated with executive dysfunction, thicker cerebral cortex, and higher activity in frontal brain regions on functional MRI.</li>

7038</ul>

7039</div>

7040</li>

7041<li>

7042In a large prospective study of neurocognitive outcomes in children with newly diagnosed ALL, 555 children were randomly assigned to receive CNS-directed therapy according to risk group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

704375</a>

7044]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7045<ol id="_1804" class="lower-alpha">

7046<li>

7047The low-risk group was randomly assigned to receive either intrathecal methotrexate or high-dose methotrexate.</li>

7048<li>

7049The high-risk group was randomly assigned to receive either high-dose methotrexate or 24 Gy of cranial radiation therapy.</li>

7050</ol>

7051</div>

7052<div class="pdq-content-list">

7053<ul id="_1752">

7054<li>

7055A significant reduction in IQ scores (4&#8211;7 points) was observed in all patient groups when compared with controls, regardless of the CNS treatment delivered.</li>

7056<li>

7057Children younger than 5 years at diagnosis were more likely to have IQs below 80 at 3 years posttherapy than were children older than 5 years at diagnosis, irrespective of treatment allocation, suggesting that younger children are more vulnerable to treatment-related neurological toxic effects.</li>

7058</ul>

7059</div>

7060</li>

7061<li>

7062Persistent cognitive deficits and progressive intellectual decline have been observed in cohorts of adults treated for ALL during childhood and associated with reduced educational attainment and unemployment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

706356</a>

7064,<a href="#cit/section_4.59">

706559</a>

7066,<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

706762</a>

7068] The results of a study of more than 500 adult survivors of childhood ALL (average, 26 years postdiagnosis) showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

706956</a>

7070]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7071<ul id="_1753">

7072<li>

7073Survivors demonstrated increased rates of impairment across all neurocognitive domains (ranging from 28.6%&#8211;58.9% for each domain).</li>

7074<li>

7075Rate of severe impairment increased as a function of cranial radiation dose and was common among survivors treated with lower doses of cranial irradiation and chemotherapy only.</li>

7076<li>

7077Impairment in executive function skills increased with time since diagnosis in a cranial radiation dose-dependent manner; impairment in intellect, academics, and memory progressively increased with younger age at treatment in a cranial radiation dose-dependent manner; and neurocognitive impairment was related to functional outcomes as adults, including reduced likelihood of college graduation and full-time employment.</li>

7078<li>

7079Continued monitoring by health professionals is needed to identify neurocognitive problems that may emerge over time.</li>

7080</ul>

7081</div>

7082</li>

7083</ol>

7084</div>

7085</section>

7086<section id="_636">

7087<h5 id="_636_toc">

7088ALL and steroid therapy</h5>

7089<p id="_637" tabindex="-1">

7090The type of steroid used for ALL systemic treatment may affect cognitive functioning.</p>

7091<div class="pdq-content-list">

7092<ul id="_2491">

7093<li>

7094 In a study that involved long-term neurocognitive testing (mean follow-up, 9.8 years) of 92 children with a history of standard-risk ALL who had received either dexamethasone or prednisone during treatment, no meaningful differences in mean neurocognitive and academic performance scores were observed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.76">

709576</a>

7096]</li>

7097<li>

7098 In contrast, in a study of 567 adult survivors of childhood leukemia (mean age, 33 years; mean time since diagnosis, 26 years), the following was reported:[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

709956</a>

7100]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7101<ul id="_2866">

7102<li>

7103Dexamethasone exposure was associated with increased risk of impairment in attention (RR, 2.12; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.11&#8211;4.03) and executive function (RR, 2.42; 95% CI, 1.20&#8211;4.91), independent of methotrexate exposure.</li>

7104<li>

7105 Intrathecal hydrocortisone also increased risk of attention problems (RR, 1.24; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.46).</li>

7106</ul>

7107</div>

7108</li>

7109</ul>

7110</div>

7111</section>

7112</section>

7113<section id="_585">

7114<h4 id="_585_toc">

7115Other cancers</h4>

7116<p id="_586" tabindex="-1">

7117Neurocognitive abnormalities have been reported in other groups of cancer survivors. A study of adult survivors of childhood non-CNS cancers (including ALL, n = 5,937) reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

711858</a>

7119]</p>

7120<div class="pdq-content-list">

7121<ul id="_2492">

7122<li>

712313% to 21% of survivors reported impairment in task efficiency, organization, memory, or emotional regulation. This rate of impairment was approximately 50% higher than that reported in the sibling comparison group.</li>

7124<li>

7125 Factors such as diagnosis before age 6 years, female sex, cranial radiation therapy, and hearing impediment were associated with impairment.</li>

7126</ul>

7127</div>

7128<p id="_2493" tabindex="-1">

7129Emerging data suggest that the development of chronic health conditions in adulthood may contribute to cognitive deficits in long-term survivors of non-CNS cancers.</p>

7130<p id="_2838" tabindex="-1">

7131A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study evaluated whether children who experienced CNS injury were at higher risk of neurocognitive impairment associated with subsequent late-onset chronic health conditions. A total of 2,859 survivors who were aged 18 years or older and at least 10 years from diagnosis completed a neurocognitive battery and clinical examination. Of these patients, 1,598 had received CNS-directed therapy, including cranial radiation, intrathecal methotrexate, or neurosurgery.[<a href="#cit/section_4.77">

713277</a>

7133]</p>

7134<div class="pdq-content-list">

7135<ul id="_2839">

7136<li>

7137CNS-treated survivors performed worse than non&#8211;CNS-treated survivors on all neurocognitive tests, and they were more likely to have global neurocognitive impairment (46.9% vs. 35.3%).</li>

7138<li>

7139A dose-response association was observed between severity/burden score of chronic health conditions and global neurocognitive impairment only among CNS-treated survivors (high OR, 2.24; 95% CI, 1.42&#8211;3.53; very high OR, 4.07; 95% CI, 2.30&#8211;7.17).</li>

7140<li>

7141Cardiovascular and pulmonary conditions were associated with cognitive outcomes (processing speed, executive function, and memory impairment) only in CNS-treated survivors with neurological conditions.</li>

7142</ul>

7143</div>

7144<p id="_1710" tabindex="-1">

7145Neurocognitive abnormalities have been reported for the following cancers:</p>

7146<div class="pdq-content-list">

7147<ul id="_1711">

7148<li>

7149<strong>

7150Acute myeloid leukemia (AML).</strong>

7151 CCSS investigators compared the neurocognitive and psychosocial outcomes of 482 survivors (median age, 30 years) with those of 3,190 sibling controls (median age, 32 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

715278</a>

7153] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7154<ul id="_2768">

7155<li>

7156Compared with siblings, AML survivors were more likely to report impairment in overall emotional (RR, 2.19; 95% CI, 1.51&#8211;3.18), neurocognitive (RR, 2.03; 95% CI, 1.47&#8211;2.79), and physical quality of life (RR, 2.71; 95% CI, 1.61&#8211;4.56) outcomes. </li>

7157<li>

7158Survivors were also at increased risk of psychosocial deficits, including lower educational attainment (RR, 1.15; 95% CI, 1.03&#8211;1.30), unemployment (RR, 1.41; 95% CI, 1.16&#8211;1.71), and lower income (RR, 1.39; 95% CI, 1.17&#8211;1.65).</li>

7159<li>

7160 Outcomes were not statistically different between survivors who were treated with transplant and survivors who were treated with intensive chemotherapy alone.</li>

7161</ul>

7162</div>

7163</li>

7164<li>

7165<strong>

7166Osteosarcoma.</strong>

7167 In a study evaluating neurocognitive function among 80 long-term survivors of osteosarcoma (mean time since diagnosis, 24.7 years), survivors demonstrated lower mean scores in reading skills, attention, memory, and processing speed than did community controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

716879</a>

7169]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7170<ul id="_2494" class="list-dash">

7171<li>

7172 The presence of cardiac, pulmonary, and endocrine conditions were significantly associated with worse performance on measures of memory and processing speed.</li>

7173</ul>

7174</div>

7175</li>

7176<li>

7177<strong>

7178Soft tissue sarcoma.</strong>

7179 St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators evaluated neurocognitive function and health status through objective clinical assessments in 150 survivors of childhood soft tissue sarcoma (median age, 33 years; median time from diagnosis, 24 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

718080</a>

7181]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7182<ul id="_2495" class="list-dash">

7183<li>

7184 Compared with community and population controls, survivors demonstrated lower measures of verbal reasoning, mathematics, and long-term memory.</li>

7185<li>

7186 Cumulative anthracycline exposure (per 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

71872</span>

7188) was found to be associated with poorer verbal reasoning, reading, and patient-reported vitality.</li>

7189<li>

7190 Neurological and neurosensory chronic conditions were associated with poorer mathematics scores and hearing impairment.</li>

7191<li>

7192 Better cognitive performance was associated with higher social attainment.</li>

7193</ul>

7194</div>

7195</li>

7196<li>

7197<strong>

7198Wilms tumor.</strong>

7199 St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study investigators examined the prevalence and predictors of neurocognitive outcomes, social attainment, emotional distress, and health-related quality of life in long-term survivors of pediatric Wilms tumor (n = 158; median time since diagnosis, 29 years; median age, 33 years) and compared the results to community controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

720081</a>

7201]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7202<ul id="_2836">

7203<li>

7204Long-term Wilms tumor survivors demonstrated lower neurocognitive function, including verbal reasoning, academics, attention, memory, and executive function, than did controls.</li>

7205<li>

7206Wilms tumor survivors were less likely to graduate from college (OR, 2.23) and had more moderate-to-severe neurological conditions than did controls (18.4% vs. 8.2%; <em>

7207P</em>

7208 &lt; .001).</li>

7209</ul>

7210</div>

7211</li>

7212<li>

7213<strong>

7214Retinoblastoma.</strong>

7215 Early studies of intellectual functioning in survivors of retinoblastoma suggested above average intelligence among bilateral survivors compared with unaffected siblings and the general population, especially those who were blind as a result of their disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.82">

721682</a>

7217-<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

721884</a>

7219] <p id="_1712" tabindex="-1">

7220Later studies have yielded mixed results, with conflicting findings, in part, resulting from the low test-retest reliability of measures used to assess cognitive outcomes at a very young age, as well as temporal differences in treatment exposures.</p>

7221<div class="pdq-content-list">

7222<ul id="_2496" class="list-dash">

7223<li>

7224Serial assessment of cognitive and adaptive functioning in a group of survivors younger than 6 years revealed declines in developmental functioning over time, with the most pronounced declines observed in patients with 13q deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

722585</a>

7226]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7227<ul id="_2793">

7228<li>

7229Further longitudinal follow-up of this cohort identified improvement in adaptive functioning in all treatment groups and in cognitive function in survivors who were treated with enucleation alone from the age of 5 years to the age of 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

723086</a>

7231]</li>

7232<li>

7233At age 10 years, overall functioning was generally within the average range, although estimated IQ was significantly below the normative mean for children who were treated with enucleation alone.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

723486</a>

7235]</li>

7236</ul>

7237</div>

7238</li>

7239<li>

7240A study of very long-term adult survivors, who were on average 33 years postdiagnosis, demonstrated largely average cognitive functioning across domains of intelligence, memory, attention, and executive function.[<a href="#cit/section_4.87">

724187</a>

7242]</li>

7243</ul>

7244</div>

7245</li>

7246<li>

7247<strong>

7248Lymphoma.</strong>

7249 Survivors of lymphoma have not historically been considered at risk of developing neurocognitive late effects.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7250<ul id="_2497" class="list-dash">

7251<li>

7252 However, one report observed that more than two-thirds of survivors of childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma experienced at least mild neurocognitive impairment, including severe deficits in executive function (13%), attention (9%), and memory (4%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

725388</a>

7254]</li>

7255<li>

7256 Similarly, in a study of 62 adult survivors of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma, survivors demonstrated worse performance on measures of sustained attention, short- and long-term memory, and cognitive fluency when compared with national normative data.[<a href="#cit/section_4.89">

725789</a>

7258] Importantly, measures of cardiac and pulmonary function were also associated with neurocognitive impairment in this group of survivors.</li>

7259</ul>

7260</div>

7261</li>

7262<li>

7263<strong>

7264Neuroblastoma.</strong>

7265 CCSS investigators compared cognitive outcomes among 837 survivors of neuroblastoma (median age, 1 year at diagnosis; median attained age, 25 years) and a sibling cohort (median attained age, 23 years) using the CCSS Neurocognitive Questionnaire.[<a href="#cit/section_4.90">

726690</a>

7267]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7268<ul id="_3065" class="list-dash">

7269<li>

7270Survivors had a 50% higher risk of impairment with attention/processing speed and emotional regulation. </li>

7271<li>

7272The risk of neurocognitive impairments was higher among survivors with chronic health conditions. </li>

7273<li>

7274Survivors were also less likely to attain adult milestones, such as living independently.</li>

7275</ul>

7276</div>

7277</li>

7278</ul>

7279</div>

7280</section>

7281<section id="_587">

7282<h4 id="_587_toc">

7283Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</h4>

7284<p id="_588" tabindex="-1">

7285Cognitive and academic consequences of HSCT in children have also been evaluated and include, but are not limited to, the following: </p>

7286<div class="pdq-content-list">

7287<ul id="_2769">

7288<li>

7289In a report from SJCRH in which 268 patients were treated with HSCT, minimal risk of late cognitive and academic sequelae was observed.[<a href="#cit/section_4.91">

729091</a>

7291]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7292<ul id="_1755">

7293<li>

7294Subgroups of patients were at relatively higher risk, including patients who underwent unrelated donor transplantation, received total-body irradiation, and developed graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).</li>

7295<li>

7296These differences were small relative to differences in premorbid functioning, particularly those associated with socioeconomic status.</li>

7297</ul>

7298</div>

7299</li>

7300<li>

7301In a series of 38 patients who underwent HSCT and received intrathecal chemotherapy, significant declines in visual motor skills and memory scores were noted within the first year posttransplant.[<a href="#cit/section_4.92">

730292</a>

7303]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7304<ul id="_1756">

7305<li>

7306By 3 years posttransplant, there was an improvement in visual motor development scores and memory scores, but new deficits were evident in long-term memory scores.</li>

7307<li>

7308By 5 years posttransplant, there were progressive declines in verbal skills and performance skills, and new deficits were seen in long-term verbal memory scores.</li>

7309<li>

7310The greatest decline in neurocognitive function occurred in patients who received cranial irradiation, either as part of their initial therapy or as part of their HSCT conditioning.</li>

7311</ul>

7312</div>

7313</li>

7314</ul>

7315</div>

7316</section>

7317</section>

7318<section id="_426">

7319<h3 id="_426_toc">

7320Neurological Sequelae</h3>

7321<p id="_509" tabindex="-1">

7322Risk of neurological complications may be predisposed by the following: </p>

7323<div class="pdq-content-list">

7324<ul id="_1074">

7325<li>

7326Tumor location.</li>

7327<li>

7328Neurosurgery.</li>

7329<li>

7330Cranial radiation therapy.</li>

7331<li>

7332Spinal radiation therapy.</li>

7333<li>

7334Specific neurotoxic chemotherapeutic agents. </li>

7335</ul>

7336</div>

7337<p id="_1075" tabindex="-1">

7338In children with CNS tumors, mass effect, tumor infiltration, and increased intracranial pressure may result in motor or sensory deficits, cerebellar dysfunction, and secondary effects such as seizures and cerebrovascular complications.[<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

733993</a>

7340] </p>

7341<p id="_2501" tabindex="-1">

7342Numerous reports describe abnormalities of CNS integrity and function, but such studies are typically limited by small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, cross-sectional ascertainment of outcomes, and variable time of assessment from treatment exposures. In contrast, relatively few studies comprehensively or systematically ascertain outcomes related to peripheral nervous system function.</p>

7343<p id="_2119" tabindex="-1">

7344CNS tumor survivors remain at higher risk of new-onset adverse neurological events across their lifetimes than siblings. No plateau has been reached for new adverse sequelae, even 30 years from diagnosis, according to a longitudinal study of 1,876 5-year survivors of CNS tumors from the CCSS. The median time from diagnosis was 23 years, and the median age of the patients studied was 30.3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

734594</a>

7346]</p>

7347<div class="pdq-content-list">

7348<ul id="_2120">

7349<li>

7350Cranial radiation, stroke, tumor recurrence, and development of meningioma were independently associated with late-onset neurological sequelae (seizures, focal neurological dysfunction, and neurosensory abnormalities).</li>

7351<li>

7352This finding supports the need to monitor these patients carefully with continued neurological follow-up within or in close association with a multidisciplinary cancer survivor clinic.</li>

7353</ul>

7354</div>

7355<p id="_1076" tabindex="-1">

7356Neurological complications that may occur in survivors of childhood cancer include the following:</p>

7357<section id="_2502">

7358<h4 id="_2502_toc">

7359Seizures</h4>

7360<p id="_2698" tabindex="-1">

7361The development of seizures may occur secondary to tumor mass effect within the CNS and/or from neurotoxic CNS-directed therapies.</p>

7362<div class="pdq-content-list">

7363<ul id="_2504">

7364<li>

7365In 1,876 5-year survivors of CNS tumors from the CCSS, the incidence of seizures increased from 27% in survivors 5 years from diagnosis to 41% in survivors 30 years from diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

736694</a>

7367]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7368<ul id="_2505" class="list-dash">

7369<li>

7370 Late-onset seizures were associated with frontal lobe radiation of 50 Gy (hazard ratio [HR], 1.8) and temporal lobe radiation in a dose-dependent fashion (HR, 1.9 for 1&#8211;49 Gy; HR, 2.2 for &gt;50 Gy).</li>

7371<li>

7372 Other risk factors associated with late-onset seizures included recurrence (HR, 2.3), development of meningioma (HR, 2.6), and history of stroke (HR, 2.0).</li>

7373<li>

7374 The risk of seizures was elevated for survivors compared with siblings (HR, 12.7).</li>

7375</ul>

7376</div>

7377</li>

7378<li>

7379Among survivors of childhood leukemia in the CCSS (N = 4,151; 64.5% treated with cranial irradiation), 6.1% reported the development of a seizure disorder, and seizures occurred more than 5 years after diagnosis in 51% of these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

738095</a>

7381]</li>

7382<li>

7383A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study evaluated the impact of seizure-related factors on neurocognitive, health-related quality of life (HRQOL), and social outcomes in 2,022 childhood cancer survivors (median age, 31.5 years; median time from diagnosis, 23.6 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.96">

738496</a>

7385]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7386<ul id="_2922">

7387<li>

7388Seizures were identified in 232 survivors (11.5%; 29.9% of survivors with CNS tumors and 9.0% of survivors without CNS tumors).</li>

7389<li>

7390Among CNS tumor survivors, seizures were associated with poorer (based on expected age-adjusted standard z-scores) executive function and processing speed. Seizure resolution was associated with improved attention and memory.</li>

7391<li>

7392Among non-CNS tumor survivors, seizures were associated with worse function in all cognitive domains compared with survivors without seizures. Seizure severity was associated with worse processing speed, and resolution of seizures was associated with better executive function and attention.</li>

7393<li>

7394Non-CNS survivors with seizures had poorer HRQOL outcomes (physical functioning, physical role limitations, and general health). Seizures in both non-CNS and CNS tumor survivors increased the risk of unemployment and part-time employment.</li>

7395</ul>

7396</div>

7397</li>

7398</ul>

7399</div>

7400</section>

7401<section id="_2506">

7402<h4 id="_2506_toc">

7403Leukoencephalopathy</h4>

7404<div class="pdq-content-list">

7405<ul id="_2527">

7406<li>

7407Clinical or radiographic leukoencephalopathy has been reported after cranial irradiation and high-dose systemic methotrexate administration.[<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

740862</a>

7409,<a href="#cit/section_4.97">

741097</a>

7411]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7412<ul id="_2508" class="list-dash">

7413<li>

7414Younger patients and those treated with cranial radiation doses higher than 24 Gy are more vulnerable to reduced white matter volumes associated with leukoencephalopathy.</li>

7415<li>

7416 White matter changes may be accompanied by other neuroimaging abnormalities, including dystrophic calcifications, cerebral lacunae, and cerebral atrophy.</li>

7417</ul>

7418</div>

7419</li>

7420</ul>

7421</div>

7422</section>

7423<section id="_2509">

7424<h4 id="_2509_toc">

7425Peripheral neuropathy</h4>

7426<p id="_2699" tabindex="-1">

7427Vinca alkaloid agents (vincristine and vinblastine) and cisplatin may cause peripheral neuropathy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

742898</a>

7429-<a href="#cit/section_4.100">

7430100</a>

7431]</p>

7432<div class="pdq-content-list">

7433<ul id="_2511">

7434<li>

7435 Peripheral neuropathy presents during treatment and appears to improve or clinically resolve after completion of therapy;[<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

743698</a>

7437] however, recent studies of long-term survivors suggest that chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy is likely under-ascertained.[<a href="#cit/section_4.101">

7438101</a>

7439]</li>

7440<li>

7441 Higher cumulative doses of vincristine and/or intrathecal methotrexate have been linked to neuromuscular impairments in long-term survivors of childhood ALL, which suggests that persistent effects of these agents may affect functional status in aging survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

744298</a>

7443] </li>

7444<li>

7445St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators observed associations between peripheral neuropathy and impairment in performance measures of movement (mobility and walking endurance) and quality of life (physical functioning, role physical, and general health) among survivors of childhood ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

7446102</a>

7447]</li>

7448<li>

7449 Static-standing balance impairment (a predictor of falling within the next 90 days) was more common in survivors compared with controls but was not associated with peripheral neuropathy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

7450102</a>

7451]</li>

7452<li>

7453Among adult survivors of extracranial solid tumors of childhood (median time from diagnosis, 25 years), standardized assessment of neuromuscular function disclosed motor impairment in association with vincristine exposure and sensory impairment in association with cisplatin exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_4.99">

745499</a>

7455]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7456<ul id="_2529" class="list-dash">

7457<li>

7458 Survivors with sensory impairment demonstrated a higher prevalence of functional performance limitations related to poor endurance and mobility restrictions.</li>

7459</ul>

7460</div>

7461</li>

7462</ul>

7463</div>

7464<p id="_2514" tabindex="-1">

7465These studies underscore the importance of assessment and referral to rehabilitative services to optimize functional outcomes among long-term survivors.</p>

7466</section>

7467<section id="_2516">

7468<h4 id="_2516_toc">

7469Stroke</h4>

7470<div class="pdq-content-list">

7471<ul id="_2530">

7472<li>

7473Childhood CNS tumor survivors have a 43-fold elevated risk of stroke compared with siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

747441</a>

7475,<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

7476103</a>

7477]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7478<ul id="_2518" class="list-dash">

7479<li>

7480 Cranial radiation therapy (dose dependent), baseline atherosclerosis, hypertension, and African American ethnicity are identified risk factors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.104">

7481104</a>

7482-<a href="#cit/section_4.106">

7483106</a>

7484] For information about stroke, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1641">

7485Cerebrovascular disease</a>

7486 section.</li>

7487</ul>

7488</div>

7489</li>

7490<li>

7491A British Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (n = 13,457 survivors) that included 2,885 childhood CNS tumor survivors reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

7492107</a>

7493]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7494<ul id="_2862">

7495<li>

7496CNS tumor survivors who were treated with cranial irradiation had an increased risk of developing cerebrovascular disease between the ages of 50 and 65 years.</li>

7497<li>

7498 Compared with an expected incidence of 4.2%, the cumulative incidence of cerebrovascular disease in survivors was 11.6% by age 40 years, 16% by age 50 years, and 26% by age 65 years.</li>

7499</ul>

7500</div>

7501</li>

7502</ul>

7503</div>

7504</section>

7505<section id="_2519">

7506<h4 id="_2519_toc">

7507Hypersomnia (daytime sleepiness) or narcolepsy</h4>

7508<div class="pdq-content-list">

7509<ul id="_2531">

7510<li>

7511 In a retrospective review of brain tumor patients treated at SJCRH, investigators identified 39 of 2,336 patients who were diagnosed with hypersomnia/narcolepsy, for a prevalence rate of 1,670 cases per 100,000, which is much higher than a prevalence rate of 20 to 50 cases per 100,000 reported in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

7512108</a>

7513]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7514<ul id="_2521" class="list-dash">

7515<li>

7516This may be an underestimate in childhood brain tumor survivors because many patients with mild-to-moderate symptoms, such as fatigue and sleep disturbances, may not be recognized or referred to a sleep specialist.</li>

7517<li>

7518 Hypersomnia/narcolepsy was diagnosed at a median of 6 years (range, 0.4&#8211;13.2 years) from tumor diagnosis and 4.7 years (range, 1.5&#8211;10.4 years) from cranial radiation.</li>

7519<li>

7520 Midline tumor location and antiepilepsy drug use correlated with hypersomnia/narcolepsy, while radiation dose higher than 30 Gy trended toward significance.</li>

7521<li>

7522 Posterior fossa tumor location was associated with a reduced risk of hypersomnia.</li>

7523<li>

7524 Treatment of hypersomnia/narcolepsy should be individualized and pharmacologic intervention with stimulants may be beneficial.</li>

7525</ul>

7526</div>

7527</li>

7528<li>

7529In a baseline evaluation of 82 childhood CNS tumor survivors (median age, 13.8 years) participating in a randomized controlled trial of neurofeedback, 48% of survivors endorsed sleep problems and scored significantly worse than the norm on the Sleep Disturbance Scale for Children in the subscales for initiating and maintaining sleep, excessive somnolence, and total scale.[<a href="#cit/section_4.109">

7530109</a>

7531]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7532<ul id="_2523" class="list-dash">

7533<li>

7534 Emotional problems and/or hyperactivity/inattention were independent potential risk factors for sleep problems. Sleep problems were also associated with worse parent-reported executive functioning.</li>

7535</ul>

7536</div>

7537</li>

7538</ul>

7539</div>

7540</section>

7541<section id="_2524">

7542<h4 id="_2524_toc">

7543Other neurological sequelae</h4>

7544<div class="pdq-content-list">

7545<ul id="_2532">

7546<li>

7547In a report from the CCSS that compared self-reported neurological late effects among 4,151 adult survivors of childhood ALL with siblings, survivors were at elevated risk for late-onset coordination problems, motor problems, seizures, and headaches.[<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

754895</a>

7549]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7550<ul id="_2526" class="list-dash">

7551<li>

7552 The overall cumulative incidence was 44% at 20 years. Serious headaches were most common, with a cumulative incidence of 25.8% at 20 years, followed by focal neurological dysfunction (21.2%) and seizures (7%).</li>

7553<li>

7554 Children who were treated with regimens that included cranial irradiation for ALL and those who suffered relapse were at increased risk for late-onset neurological sequelae.</li>

7555</ul>

7556</div>

7557</li>

7558<li>

7559A cross-sectional study evaluated neurological morbidity and quality of life in 162 survivors of childhood ALL (median age at evaluation, 15.7 years; median time from completion of therapy, 7.4 years) in concert with a clinical neurological exam.[<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

7560110</a>

7561]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7562<ul id="_2533" class="list-dash">

7563<li>

7564Neurological symptoms were present in 83% of survivors, but symptom-related morbidity was low and quality of life was high in most survivors.</li>

7565<li>

7566 The most commonly reported symptoms included neuropathy (63%), headache (46.9%), dizziness (33.3%), and back pain (22.8%).</li>

7567<li>

7568 Female sex, ten doses or more of intrathecal chemotherapy, cranial irradiation, CNS leukemia at diagnosis, and history of ALL relapse were associated with neurological morbidity.</li>

7569</ul>

7570</div>

7571</li>

7572<li>

7573Neuroimaging studies of irradiated and nonirradiated ALL survivors demonstrate a variety of CNS abnormalities, including leukoencephalopathy, cerebral lacunes, cerebral atrophy, and dystrophic calcifications (mineralizing microangiopathy).[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

757454</a>

7575,<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

757662</a>

7577,<a href="#cit/section_4.97">

757897</a>

7579,<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

7580111</a>

7581]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7582<ul id="_2534" class="list-dash">

7583<li>

7584 Among these, abnormalities of cerebral white matter integrity and volume have been correlated with neurocognitive outcomes.</li>

7585</ul>

7586</div>

7587</li>

7588<li>

7589Cavernomas have also been observed in ALL survivors treated with cranial irradiation. They have been speculated to result from angiogenic processes as opposed to tumorigenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.112">

7590112</a>

7591]</li>

7592<li>

7593In a retrospective cross-sectional study, 101 survivors of childhood ALL (mean time since diagnosis, 27.6 years) who were treated with cranial irradiation (63.4% received &#8804;18 Gy) underwent neurocognitive testing and 3T brain MRI.[<a href="#cit/section_4.113">

7594113</a>

7595]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7596<ul id="_2783">

7597<li>

7598Small focal intracerebral hemorrhages that are only visible on exquisitely sensitive MRI sequences were identified and localized using susceptibility weighted imaging.</li>

7599<li>

7600At least one microbleed was present in 85% of survivors, and they occurred more frequently in frontal lobes. </li>

7601<li>

7602A radiation dose of 24 Gy conveyed a fivefold greater risk of having multiple microbleeds when compared with a dose of 18 Gy. </li>

7603<li>

7604No significant difference was found in neurocognitive scores with either the absence or presence of microbleeds or their location.</li>

7605</ul>

7606</div>

7607</li>

7608<li>

7609CCSS investigators evaluated treatment-related neurological sequelae in survivors of childhood CNS tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

761094</a>

7611]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7612<ul id="_2535" class="list-dash">

7613<li>

7614In 1,876 5-year survivors of CNS tumors from the CCSS, the cumulative incidence of headaches increased from 38% at 5 years to 53% at 30 years from diagnosis.</li>

7615<li>

7616Coordination problems increased from 21% at 5 years to 53% at 30 years from diagnosis, and motor impairment increased from 21% to 35% during this same time period.</li>

7617<li>

7618 Increased risk of motor impairment was associated with tumor recurrence (HR, 2.6), development of a meningioma (HR, 2.3), and stroke (HR, 14.9).</li>

7619<li>

7620The cumulative incidence of hearing loss increased from 9% at 5 years to 23% at 30 years, cumulative incidence of tinnitus increased from 8% at 5 years to 21% at 30 years, and cumulative incidence of vertigo increased from 9% at 5 years to 17% at 30 years.</li>

7621<li>

7622 Risks of motor impairment (HR, 7.6) and hearing loss (HR, 18.4) were elevated compared with siblings.</li>

7623</ul>

7624</div>

7625</li>

7626<li>

7627CCSS investigators estimated the prevalence and cumulative incidence of neuromuscular dysfunction (motor or sensory dysfunction) among 25,583 childhood cancer survivors and 5,044 siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_4.114">

7628114</a>

7629]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7630<ul id="_2923">

7631<li>

7632Neuromuscular dysfunction was prevalent in 14.7% of survivors 5 years after diagnosis, compared with 1.5% in siblings (prevalence ratio [PR], 9.9%; 95% CI, 7.9&#8211;12.4).</li>

7633<li>

7634The prevalence of neuromuscular dysfunction was highest in survivors of CNS tumors (PR, 27.6; 95% CI, 22.1&#8211;34.6) and sarcomas (PR, 11.5; 95% CI, 9.1&#8211;14.5).</li>

7635<li>

7636The 20-year cumulative incidence increased to 24.3% in survivors 20 years after diagnosis.</li>

7637<li>

7638Cancer treatments associated with increased prevalence of neuromuscular dysfunction included spinal radiation therapy, increasing doses of cranial radiation therapy, and platinum agents.</li>

7639<li>

7640Neuromuscular dysfunction was associated with downstream adverse outcomes, including concurrent or later obesity (PR, 1.1; 95% CI, 1.1&#8211;1.2), anxiety (PR, 2.5; 95% CI, 2.2&#8211;2.9), depression (PR, 2.1; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;2.3), and lower likelihood of graduating college (PR, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.90&#8211;0.94) and finding employment (PR, 0.8; 95% CI, 0.8&#8211;0.9).</li>

7641</ul>

7642</div>

7643</li>

7644</ul>

7645</div>

7646</section>

7647<p id="_1719" tabindex="-1">

7648<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_429">

7649Table 4</a>

7650 summarizes CNS late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

7651<table id="_429" class="table-default expandable-container">

7652<caption>

7653Table 4. Central Nervous System Late Effects<span class="sup">

7654a</span>

7655</caption>

7656<colgroup>

7657<col width="33.33%">

7658<col width="33.33%">

7659<col width="33.33%">

7660</colgroup>

7661<THead>

7662<tr>

7663<th>

7664Predisposing Therapy</th>

7665<th>

7666Neurological Effects</th>

7667<th>

7668Health Screening</th>

7669</tr>

7670</THead>

7671<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

7672<tr>

7673<td colspan="3">

7674IQ = intelligence quotient; IT = intrathecal; IV = intravenous.</td>

7675</tr>

7676<tr>

7677<td colspan="3">

7678<span class="sup">

7679a</span>

7680Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

7681Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

7682.</td>

7683</tr>

7684</TFoot>

7685<tbody>

7686<tr>

7687<td>

7689<td>

7691<td>

7693</tr>

7694<tr>

7695<td>

7697<td>

7699<td>

7701</tr>

7702<tr>

7705radiation exposing the brain </td>

7708headaches; seizures; sensory deficits</td>

7711</tr>

7715</tr>

7723</td>

7750</tr>

7766</tr>

7776</tr>

7780</td>

7786</td>

7791</td>

7806</tr>

7810cytarabine (high-dose IV or IT);

7811radiation exposing the brain;

7812neurosurgery&#8211;brain </td>

7815learning deficits;

7816diminished IQ;

7817behavioral change

7818</td>

7821</td>
