7826</td>

7827</tr>

7828</tbody>

7829</table>

7830</section>

7831<section id="_16">

7832<h3 id="_16_toc">

7833Psychosocial</h3>

7834<p id="_167" tabindex="-1">

7835Many childhood cancer survivors report reduced quality of life or other adverse psychosocial outcomes. The diagnosis of childhood cancer may also affect psychosocial outcomes and the expected attainment of functional and social independence in adulthood. Several investigations have demonstrated that survivors of pediatric CNS tumors are particularly vulnerable.[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

7836115</a>

7837,<a href="#cit/section_4.116">

7838116</a>

7839]</p>

7840<p id="_2536" tabindex="-1">

7841Evidence for adverse psychosocial adjustment after childhood cancer has been derived from sources, ranging from patient-reported or proxy-reported outcomes to data from population-based registries. The former may be limited by small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, and variable methods and venues (clinical vs. distance-based survey) of assessments. The latter is often not well correlated with clinical and treatment characteristics that permit the identification of survivors at high risk of psychosocial deficits.</p>

7842<section id="_2537">

7843<h4 id="_2537_toc">

7844Achievement of social milestones</h4>

7845<p id="_2538" tabindex="-1">

7846Survivors with neurocognitive deficits are particularly vulnerable to deficits in achievement of expected social outcomes during adulthood.</p>

7847<div class="pdq-content-list">

7848<ul id="_1055">

7849<li>

7850In a population-based study of adult survivors of CNS tumors diagnosed in childhood or adolescence, survivors had significantly poorer self-perception and self-esteem than did individuals in the general population. Female sex, persistent visible physical sequelae, specific tumor type, and treatment with cranial radiation therapy predicted poor self-perception outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.117">

7851117</a>

7852]</li>

7853<li>

7854In a series of CNS malignancy survivors (n = 802) reported from the CCSS, adverse outcome on multiple indicators of successful adult adjustment (educational achievement, income, employment, and marital status) were most prevalent among survivors who reported neurocognitive dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

78553</a>

7856]</li>

7857<li>

7858Collectively, studies evaluating psychosocial outcomes among CNS tumor survivors indicate deficits in social competence that worsen over time.[<a href="#cit/section_4.118">

7859118</a>

7860] This includes problems with peer rejection and isolation in childhood/adolescence, and the inability to develop friendships and romantic relationships as adults.</li>

7861<li>

7862In a CCSS study that evaluated predictors of independent living status across diagnostic groups, adult survivors of childhood cancer with neurocognitive, psychological, or physical late effects were less likely to live independently as adults than were siblings in the comparison group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

786347</a>

7864]</li>

7865<li>

7866In a St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study of 224 survivors of CNS tumors (median current age, 26 years; median time from diagnosis, 18 years), neurocognitive impairment was significantly associated with lower educational attainment, unemployment, and dependent living.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

786714</a>

7868]</li>

7869<li>

7870In a series of 1,560 adolescent survivors of childhood ALL treated with chemotherapy alone, the CCSS identified a significant proportion of survivors who still experienced problems with headstrong behavior, inattention-hyperactivity, and social withdrawal, which were associated with an increased risk of special education placement and predicted reduced adult educational attainment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.72">

787172</a>

7872]</li>

7873<li>

7874In a cross-sectional study of 855 childhood leukemia survivors (mean, 10.2 years from diagnosis) in the Leuc&#233;mie de l&#8217;Enfant et de l&#8217;Adolescent (LEA) cohort, investigators identified independent factors associated with repeating a grade in school, including low parental education and household financial difficulties, emphasizing the importance of considering socioeconomic factors that may affect access to educational support. Survivors who were adolescents (aged 11&#8211;17 years) at diagnosis were also at greater risk than were survivors who were children (aged &lt;11 years) at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

7875119</a>

7876]</li>

7877<li>

7878In a population-based, cross-sectional, survivorship study, 28% of adolescent and young adult survivors of sarcoma (aged 18&#8211;39 years at diagnosis; median time from diagnosis, 6.2 years) experienced impaired social functioning.[<a href="#cit/section_4.120">

7879120</a>

7880] Multivariable analysis identified independent associations with impaired social functioning and unemployment (OR, 3.72; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;10.97) and having to make lifestyle changes because of financial problems caused by an individual's physical condition or medical treatment (OR, 3.39; 95% CI, 1.12&#8211;10.30). In contrast, better social support reduced the risk of impaired social functioning (OR, 0.74; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.96).</li>

7881</ul>

7882</div>

7883</section>

7884<section id="_2539">

7885<h4 id="_2539_toc">

7886Psychological distress and suicidality </h4>

7887<p id="_2540" tabindex="-1">

7888Childhood cancer survivors are also at risk of developing symptoms of psychological distress and suicidality.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

7889121</a>

7890]</p>

7891<div class="pdq-content-list">

7892<ul id="_2541">

7893<li>

7894The St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study was used to compare the risks of suicidal ideation, suicidal behaviors, and mortality in adult survivors of childhood cancer with those of the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

7895122</a>

7896]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7897<ul id="_2873">

7898<li>

7899 Survivors (n = 3,096) reported a similar 12-month prevalence of suicidal ideation compared with the general population (standardized incidence ratio [SIR], 0.68) and a lower prevalence of suicidal behaviors (planning: SIR, 0.17; attempts: SIR, 0.07) and mortality (standardized mortality ratio, 0.60). </li>

7900<li>

7901Among survivors, depression (RR, 12.30), anxiety (RR, 2.19), and financial stress (RR, 1.47) were found to be risk factors associated with suicidal ideation.</li>

7902<li>

7903Survivors who were currently single, widowed, or divorced; who were not working full time; who reported financial stress during the previous year; and who reported sleep disturbances had an approximately 30% to 50% higher prevalence of suicidal ideation.</li>

7904</ul>

7905</div>

7906</li>

7907<li>

7908A CCSS study evaluated the prevalence of recurrent suicidal ideation among 9,128 adult long-term survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.123">

7909123</a>

7910]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7911<ul id="_2867">

7912<li>

7913Survivors were more likely to report late suicidal ideation (OR, 1.9; 95% CI, 1.5&#8211;2.5) and recurrent suicidal ideation (OR, 2.6; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;3.8) compared with siblings. </li>

7914<li>

7915History of seizure was associated with a twofold increased likelihood of suicide ideation in survivors.</li>

7916</ul>

7917</div>

7918</li>

7919<li>

7920A population-based study evaluated suicide among adults treated for cancer before age 25 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

7921124</a>

7922]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7923<ul id="_2868">

7924<li>

7925The absolute risk of suicide was low (24 cases among 3,375 deaths).</li>

7926<li>

7927The HR of suicide was increased among individuals treated for cancer in childhood (0&#8211;14 years; HR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;3.8) and in adolescence and young adulthood (15&#8211;24 years; HR, 2.3; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;4.6).</li>

7928</ul>

7929</div>

7930</li>

7931</ul>

7932</div>

7933<p id="_940" tabindex="-1">

7934The presence of chronic health conditions can also impact aspects of psychological health.</p>

7935<div class="pdq-content-list">

7936<ul id="_2542">

7937<li>

7938 In a study that evaluated psychological outcomes among long-term survivors treated with HSCT, 22% of survivors and 8% of sibling controls reported adverse outcomes. Somatic distress was the most prevalent condition and affected 15% of HSCT survivors, representing a threefold higher risk compared with siblings. HSCT survivors with severe or life-threatening health conditions and active chronic GVHD had a twofold increased risk of somatic distress.[<a href="#cit/section_4.125">

7939125</a>

7940] </li>

7941<li>

7942A report from the CCSS revealed that the presence of chronic pulmonary, endocrine, and cardiac conditions was associated with increased risk of psychological distress symptoms in a sample of 5,021 adult survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

7943126</a>

7944]</li>

7945<li>

7946In a CCSS investigation that evaluated long-term psychological and educational outcomes among survivors of neuroblastoma, survivors demonstrated elevated risks of psychological impairment, which was associated with the use of special education services and lower educational attainment. The presence of two or more chronic health conditions, but not common treatment exposures, predicted psychological impairment. Specifically, pulmonary disease predicted impairment in all five psychological domains, whereas endocrine disease and peripheral neuropathy each predicted impairment in three domains.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

7947127</a>

7948]</li>

7949</ul>

7950</div>

7951<p id="_2543" tabindex="-1">

7952Incorporation of psychological screening into clinical visits for childhood cancer survivors may be valuable; however, limiting such evaluations to those returning to long-term follow-up clinics may result in a biased subsample of survivors with more difficulties, and precise prevalence rates may be difficult to establish.</p>

7953<div class="pdq-content-list">

7954<ul id="_2544">

7955<li>

7956 In a study of 101 adult survivors of childhood cancer, psychological screening was performed during a routine annual evaluation at the survivorship clinic at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute.[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

7957128</a>

7958]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7959<ul id="_2545" class="list-dash">

7960<li>

7961 On the Symptom Checklist 90 Revised, 32 survivors had a positive screen (indicating psychological distress), and 14 survivors reported at least one suicidal symptom.</li>

7962<li>

7963 Risk factors for psychological distress included survivors' dissatisfaction with physical appearance, poor physical health, and treatment with cranial irradiation.</li>

7964<li>

7965This instrument was shown to be feasible for use in the clinic-visit setting because the psychological screening was completed in less than 30 minutes and did not appear to cause distress in the survivors in 80% of cases.</li>

7966</ul>

7967</div>

7968 </li>

7969</ul>

7970</div>

7971<p id="_2546" tabindex="-1">

7972For more information about psychological distress, depression, and cancer patients, see <a href="/about-cancer/coping/feelings/anxiety-distress-hp-pdq">

7973Adjustment to Cancer: Anxiety and Distress</a>

7974 and <a href="/about-cancer/coping/feelings/depression-hp-pdq">

7975Depression</a>

7976.</p>

7977</section>

7978<section id="_2995">

7979<h4 id="_2995_toc">

7980Major psychiatric disorders</h4>

7981<p id="_2996" tabindex="-1">

7982A population-based study from Taiwan compared the prevalence of major psychiatric disorders in 5,121 childhood and adolescent cancer survivors with that of population controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

7983129</a>

7984]</p>

7985<div class="pdq-content-list">

7986<ul id="_2997">

7987<li>

7988Survivors (mean age, 9 years; 60% were 5 or more years from diagnosis) showed increased risks of six major psychiatric disorders compared with controls. These disorders included autism spectrum disorder (HR, 10.42; 95% CI, 4.58&#8211;23.69), ADHD (HR, 6.59; 95% CI, 4.91&#8211;8.86), bipolar disorder (HR, 2.93; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;6.80), major depressive disorder (HR, 1.88; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;2.79), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) (HR, 3.37; 95% CI, 1.33&#8211;8.52), and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (HR, 6.10; 95% CI, 1.46&#8211;25.54). </li>

7989<li>

7990Survivors were younger than controls at the time of diagnosis of ADHD, schizophrenia, major depressive disorder, and OCD. </li>

7991<li>

7992Risks of major psychiatric disorders varied according to specific cancer types. The greatest number of major psychiatric disorders was observed among survivors of brain cancer and lymphatic/hematopoietic tissue cancer. </li>

7993</ul>

7994</div>

7995</section>

7996<section id="_645">

7997<h4 id="_645_toc">

7998PTSD after childhood cancer</h4>

7999<p id="_646" tabindex="-1">

8000Despite the many stresses associated with the diagnosis of cancer and its treatment, studies have generally shown low levels of post-traumatic stress symptoms and PTSD in children with cancer, typically no higher than those in healthy comparison children.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

8001130</a>

8002]</p>

8003<div class="pdq-content-list">

8004<ul id="_1056">

8005<li>

8006The prevalence of PTSD and post-traumatic stress symptoms has been reported in 15% to 20% of young adult survivors of childhood cancer, with estimates varying based on criteria used to define these conditions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

8007131</a>

8008]</li>

8009<li>

8010In a cohort of 5,121 childhood and adolescent cancer survivors (mean age, 9 years), the incidence of PTSD was 0.59%. Compared with controls, survivors showed a 6.10-fold elevated risk of being diagnosed with PTSD. Brain cancer survivors had the highest risk of all cancer diagnoses for PTSD (HR, 18.50; 95% CI, 2.11&#8211;162.64).[<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

8011129</a>

8012]</li>

8013<li>

8014 Patient and parent adaptive style appear to be significant determinants of PTSD in the pediatric oncology setting.[<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

8015132</a>

8016,<a href="#cit/section_4.133">

8017133</a>

8018]</li>

8019<li>

8020Survivors with PTSD reported more psychological problems and negative beliefs about their illness and health status than did those without PTSD.[<a href="#cit/section_4.134">

8021134</a>

8022,<a href="#cit/section_4.135">

8023135</a>

8024]</li>

8025<li>

8026A subset of adult survivors (9%) from the CCSS reported functional impairment and/or clinical distress in addition to the set of symptoms consistent with a full diagnosis of PTSD.[<a href="#cit/section_4.136">

8027136</a>

8028]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8029<ul id="_2547" class="list-dash">

8030<li>

8031 PTSD was significantly more prevalent in survivors than in sibling comparisons.</li>

8032<li>

8033 PTSD was significantly associated with being unmarried, having an annual income of less than $20,000, being unemployed, having a high school education or less, and being older than 30 years.</li>

8034<li>

8035 Survivors who were treated with cranial irradiation before age 4 years were at particularly high risk of developing PTSD.</li>

8036<li>

8037 Intensive cancer-directed therapy was also associated with increased risk of full PTSD.</li>

8038</ul>

8039</div>

8040 </li>

8041<li>

8042Because avoidance of places and persons associated with the cancer is part of PTSD, the syndrome may interfere with obtaining appropriate health care.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

8043137</a>

8044] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8045<ul id="_2548">

8046<li>

8047Those with PTSD perceive greater current threats to their lives or the lives of their children.</li>

8048<li>

8049 Other risk factors for PTSD include poor family functioning, decreased social support, and noncancer stressors.</li>

8050</ul>

8051</div>

8052</li>

8053</ul>

8054</div>

8055</section>

8056<section id="_648">

8057<h4 id="_648_toc">

8058Psychosocial outcomes among childhood, adolescent, and young adult cancer survivors</h4>

8059<p id="_649" tabindex="-1">

8060Most research on late effects after cancer has focused on individuals with a cancer diagnosis during childhood. Little is known about the specific impact of a cancer diagnosis with an onset in adolescence or the impact of childhood cancer on adolescent and young adult (AYA) psychosocial outcomes.</p>

8061<p id="_1758" tabindex="-1">

8062Evidence (psychosocial outcomes in AYA cancer survivors):</p>

8063<div class="pdq-content-list">

8064<ol id="_1759">

8065<li>

8066A population-based study linked individuals with a history of six common cancers diagnosed at age 15 to 21 years to provincial health care data to compare rates of outpatient (family physician and psychiatrist) visits for psychiatric indications and time to severe psychiatric events (emergency room visit, hospitalization, and suicide). The study included 2,208 AYA cancer patients and 10,457 matched controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.138">

8067138</a>

8068]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8069<ul id="_2784">

8070<li>

8071Five-year AYA survivors experienced higher rates of outpatient mental health visits than did controls (671 vs. 506 visits per 1,000 person-years; RR, 1.3), higher risk of a severe psychiatric episode (HR, 1.2), and higher risk of a psychotic disorder&#8211;associated severe event (HR, 2.0).</li>

8072<li>

8073Treatment in an adult center was associated with substantially higher outpatient visit rates compared with treatment in pediatric settings (RR, 1.8).</li>

8074</ul>

8075</div>

8076</li>

8077<li>

8078Adult survivors of cancer diagnosed during adolescence (aged 15&#8211;18 years) (N = 825) were compared with an age-matched sample from the general population and a comparison group of adults without cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.139">

8079139</a>

8080] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8081<ul id="_1760">

8082<li>

8083Female survivors of adolescent cancers achieved fewer developmental milestones related to their psychosexual development, such as having their first boyfriend, or they reached these milestones later.</li>

8084<li>

8085Male survivors were more likely to live with their parents than were same-sex controls.</li>

8086<li>

8087Adolescent cancer survivors were less likely to have ever married or have had children. Survivors were significantly older at their first marriage and at the birth of their first child than were their age-matched samples.</li>

8088<li>

8089Survivors in this cohort were also significantly less satisfied with their general and health-related life than were people in a community-based control group. Impaired general and health-related life satisfaction were associated with somatic late effects, symptoms of depression and anxiety, and lower rates of posttraumatic growth.[<a href="#cit/section_4.140">

8090140</a>

8091]</li>

8092</ul>

8093</div>

8094</li>

8095<li>

8096A survey of 4,054 AYA cancer survivors and 345,592 respondents who had no history of cancer reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.141">

8097141</a>

8098]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8099<ul id="_1761">

8100<li>

8101AYA cancer survivors were more likely to smoke (26% vs. 18%), be affected by obesity (31% vs. 27%), and have chronic conditions such as cardiovascular disease (14% vs. 7%), hypertension (35% vs. 9%), asthma (15% vs. 8%), disability (36% vs. 18%), and poor mental health (20% vs. 10%).</li>

8102<li>

8103They were also less likely to receive medical care because of cost (24% vs. 15%).</li>

8104</ul>

8105</div>

8106</li>

8107<li>

8108The CCSS evaluated outcomes of 2,979 adolescent survivors and 649 siblings of childhood cancer survivors to determine the incidence of difficulty in six behavioral and social domains (depression/anxiety, being headstrong, attention deficit, peer conflict/social withdrawal, antisocial behaviors, and social competence).[<a href="#cit/section_4.142">

8109142</a>

8110]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8111<ul id="_1762">

8112<li>

8113Survivors were 1.5 times (95% CI, 1.1&#8211;2.1) more likely than siblings to have symptoms of depression/anxiety and 1.7 times (95% CI, 1.3&#8211;2.2) more likely than siblings to have antisocial behaviors.</li>

8114<li>

8115Scores in the depression/anxiety, attention deficit, and antisocial domains were significantly elevated in adolescents treated for leukemia or CNS tumors, compared with the scores in siblings.</li>

8116<li>

8117In addition, survivors of neuroblastoma had difficulty in the depression/anxiety and antisocial domains.</li>

8118<li>

8119CNS-directed treatments (cranial radiation therapy and/or intrathecal methotrexate) were specific risk factors for adverse behavioral outcomes.</li>

8120</ul>

8121</div>

8122</li>

8123<li>

8124Another CCSS study evaluated psychological and neurocognitive function in 2,589 long-term cancer survivors who were diagnosed during adolescence and young adulthood.[<a href="#cit/section_4.143">

8125143</a>

8126] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8127<ul id="_1763">

8128<li>

8129Compared with a sibling cohort, survivors diagnosed during adolescence and young adulthood reported higher rates of depression (OR, 1.55; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;2.30) and anxiety (OR, 2.00; 95% CI, 1.17&#8211;3.43) and reported more cognitive problems affecting task efficiency (OR, 1.72; 95% CI, 1.21&#8211;2.43), emotional regulation (OR, 1.74; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;2.40), and memory (OR, 1.44; 95% CI, 1.09&#8211;1.89).</li>

8130<li>

8131Survivors of lymphoma and sarcoma diagnosed during later adolescence were at reduced risk of psychosocial and neurocognitive problems than were those diagnosed before age 11 years. These outcomes did not differ by age at diagnosis among CNS tumor and leukemia survivors.</li>

8132<li>

8133Survivors diagnosed during adolescence and young adulthood were also significantly less likely than sibling controls to have attained a post&#8211;high school education, be working full time, be married, or be living independently; inferior social outcomes were related to neurocognitive symptoms.</li>

8134</ul>

8135</div>

8136</li>

8137<li>

8138A follow-up CCSS study evaluated profiles of symptom comorbidities in 3,993 adolescents (aged 13&#8211;17 years) treated for cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.144">

8139144</a>

8140] Latent profile analysis identified four symptom profiles: <div class="pdq-content-list">

8141<ul id="_1611">

8142<li>

8143No significant symptoms.</li>

8144<li>

8145Elevated internalizing symptoms (anxiety and/or depression, social withdrawal, and attention problems).</li>

8146<li>

8147Elevated externalizing symptoms (headstrong behavior and attention problems).</li>

8148<li>

8149Elevated internalizing and externalizing symptoms. </li>

8150</ul>

8151</div>

8152<p id="_1612" tabindex="-1">

8153Overall results support that behavioral, emotional, and social symptoms frequently co-occur and are associated with treatment exposures (cranial radiation, corticosteroids, and methotrexate) and late effects (obesity, cancer-related pain, and sensory impairments) in adolescent survivors diagnosed between 1970 and 1986.</p>

8154</li>

8155<li>

8156Another CCSS study characterized the prevalence and risk of pain, clinically significant interference in daily activities because of pain, and recurrent pain in 10,012 adult survivors of childhood cancer (median time since diagnosis, 23 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

8157145</a>

8158]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8159<ul id="_2421">

8160<li>

8161A significant minority of survivors endorsed moderate to severe pain (29%), moderate to extreme pain interference (20%), and moderate to severe recurrent pain (9%). </li>

8162<li>

8163Older age at diagnosis and follow-up, female sex, and presence of grades 3 to 4 chronic medical conditions were consistently associated with an increased risk of worse pain outcomes. </li>

8164<li>

8165Minority racial and ethnic groups, diagnosis of CNS tumor, and treatment with platinum-based chemotherapy and cranial radiation were associated with an increased risk of late-occurrence pain and pain interference.</li>

8166<li>

8167Depression and anxiety were associated with increased risk of all pain outcomes, and poor vitality mediated the effects of anxiety on high pain and pain interference.</li>

8168</ul>

8169</div>

8170</li>

8171<li>

8172A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study evaluated the associations between comprehensive medical, neurocognitive, and physical performance assessments and self-reported pain, quality of life, and social functioning in 2,836 survivors (mean age, 32.2 years; mean time since diagnosis, 23.7 years) and 343 noncancer community controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.146">

8173146</a>

8174]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8175<ul id="_2785">

8176<li>

8177Moderate-to-very-severe pain with moderate-to-extreme daily interference was endorsed by 18% of survivors, compared with 8% of controls (<em>

8178P</em>

8179 &lt; .001).</li>

8180<li>

8181Survivors of soft tissue sarcoma (OR, 9.25), non-Hodgkin lymphoma (OR, 4.13), and Ewing sarcoma and/or osteosarcoma (OR, 3.93) had the highest odds of pain with daily interference, compared with controls.</li>

8182<li>

8183In multivariable models that included treatment exposures, histories of amputation (OR, 1.89) and/or limb-sparing surgery (OR, 2.30) were associated with increased odds of pain with daily interference.</li>

8184<li>

8185Pain with daily interference was associated with an increased risk of impaired neurocognition (attention: RR, 1.88; memory: RR, 1.65) and physical functioning (aerobic capacity: RR, 2.29; mobility: RR, 1.71).</li>

8186<li>

8187Pain with daily interference was also associated with an increased risk of impaired social functioning (inability to hold a job and/or attend school: RR, 4.46; assistance with routine and/or personal care needs: RR, 5.64), and health-related quality of life (physical: RR, 6.34; emotional: RR, 2.83).</li>

8188</ul>

8189</div>

8190 </li>

8191<li>

8192A Nordic, register-based cohort study evaluated whether childhood cancer survivors (n = 18,621) were at a higher risk of developing psychiatric disorders later in life than their siblings (n = 24,775) and the general population (n = 88,630).[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

8193147</a>

8194]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8195<ul id="_2899">

8196<li>

8197The cumulative incidence of contact with a psychiatric hospital by age 30 years was 15.9% for childhood cancer survivors, 14.0% for siblings, and 12.7% for matched (by birth year, sex, and country/municipality) population controls. </li>

8198<li>

8199The absolute difference was small, but survivors were still at a higher relative risk of any psychiatric hospital contact than their siblings (1.39) and matched controls (HR, 1.34).</li>

8200</ul>

8201</div>

8202</li>

8203</ol>

8204</div>

8205<p id="_2074" tabindex="-1">

8206Evidence (functional and social independence):</p>

8207<div class="pdq-content-list">

8208<ol id="_2075">

8209<li>

8210In a study of 665 survivors of CNS tumors (54% male; 52% treated with cranial radiation therapy; median age, 15 years; and 12 years from diagnosis), CCSS investigators observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_4.115">

8211115</a>

8212]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8213<ul id="_2076">

8214<li>

8215Almost 50% of survivors experienced social difficulties related to peer relationships that exceeded those of survivors of solid tumors and sibling controls.</li>

8216<li>

8217Cranial radiation exposure predicted impaired social and peer relationships, and cognitive impairment mediated these associations.</li>

8218</ul>

8219</div>

8220</li>

8221<li>

8222A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study investigated functional and social independence in 306 CNS tumor survivors (astrocytoma [n = 130], medulloblastoma [n = 77], ependymoma [n = 36], and other [n = 63]; median age, 25 years; and time since diagnosis, 16.8 years).[<a href="#cit/section_4.116">

8223116</a>

8224]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8225<ul id="_2077">

8226<li>

8227 Only 40% of long-term survivors in the study cohort achieved complete independence as adults.</li>

8228<li>

8229Predictors of nonindependence included treatment with craniospinal irradiation, history of hydrocephalus with shunting, and younger age at diagnosis.</li>

8230<li>

8231Beyond impaired IQ scores, functional limitations in aerobic capacity, flexibility, and adaptive physical function were significantly associated with nonindependence.</li>

8232</ul>

8233</div>

8234</li>

8235</ol>

8236</div>

8237<p id="_1059" tabindex="-1">

8238Social withdrawal in adolescence has been associated with adult obesity and physical inactivity.[<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

8239148</a>

8240] As a result, these psychological problems may increase future risk for chronic health conditions and support the need to routinely screen and treat psychological problems after cancer therapy. </p>

8241<p id="_651" tabindex="-1">

8242Because of the challenges experienced by AYA patients at cancer diagnosis and during long-term follow-up, this group may benefit from access to programs to address the unique psychosocial, educational, and vocational issues that impact their transition to survivorship.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

8243149</a>

8244,<a href="#cit/section_4.150">

8245150</a>

8246]</p>

8247</section>

8248</section>

8249<p id="_435" tabindex="-1">

8250For CNS and psychosocial late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

8251Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

8252.</p>

8338[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8341Mabbott DJ, Spiegler BJ, Greenberg ML, et al.: Serial evaluation of academic and behavioral outcome after treatment with cranial radiation in childhood. 8342[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8343</li>

8344<li id="section_4.23">

8345Bri&#232;re ME, Scott JG, McNall-Knapp RY, et al.: Cognitive outcome in pediatric brain tumor survivors: delayed attention deficit at long-term follow-up. Pediatr Blood Cancer 50 (2): 337-40, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17458873&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17458873&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8346[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8347</li>
