J Clin Oncol 34 (28): 3417-25, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27432919&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27432919&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8830[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8831</li>

8832<li id="section_4.145">

8833Karlson CW, Alberts NM, Liu W, et al.: Longitudinal pain and pain interference in long-term survivors of childhood cancer: A report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. Cancer 126 (12): 2915-2923, 2020.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32227649&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=32227649&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8834[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8835</li>

8836<li id="section_4.146">

8837Tonning Olsson I, Alberts NM, Li C, et al.: Pain and functional outcomes in adult survivors of childhood cancer: A report from the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study. Cancer 127 (10): 1679-1689, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33369896&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33369896&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8838[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8839</li>

8840<li id="section_4.147">

8841Frederiksen LE, Erdmann F, Mader L, et al.: Psychiatric disorders in childhood cancer survivors in Denmark, Finland, and Sweden: a register-based cohort study from the SALiCCS research programme. Lancet Psychiatry 9 (1): 35-45, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34822758&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=34822758&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8842[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8843</li>

8844<li id="section_4.148">

8845Krull KR, Huang S, Gurney JG, et al.: Adolescent behavior and adult health status in childhood cancer survivors. J Cancer Surviv 4 (3): 210-7, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20383785&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20383785&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8846[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8847</li>

8848<li id="section_4.149">

8849Freyer DR: Transition of care for young adult survivors of childhood and adolescent cancer: rationale and approaches. J Clin Oncol 28 (32): 4810-8, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20351333&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20351333&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8850[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8851</li>

8852<li id="section_4.150">

8853Nathan PC, Hayes-Lattin B, Sisler JJ, et al.: Critical issues in transition and survivorship for adolescents and young adults with cancers. Cancer 117 (10 Suppl): 2335-41, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21523755&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21523755&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8854[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8855</li>

8856</ol>

8857</div>

8858

8859 </section>

8860

8861

8862

8863 <section id="_30">

8864

8865 <h2>

8866Late Effects of the Digestive System</h2>

8867

8868 <div id="_section_30" class="pdq-sections">

8869<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8870<h6>

8871In This Section</h6>

8872<ul>

8873<li>

8874<a href="#_31_toc">

8875Dental<ul>

8876<li>

8877<a href="#_1164_toc">

8878Overview</a>

8879</li>

8880<li>

8881<a href="#_1239_toc">

8882 Abnormalities of tooth development</a>

8883</li>

8884<li>

8885<a href="#_1241_toc">

8886Salivary gland dysfunction</a>

8887</li>

8888<li>

8889<a href="#_1244_toc">

8890Abnormalities of craniofacial development</a>

8891</li>

8892<li>

8893<a href="#_2557_toc">

8894Other oral health complications</a>

8895</li>

8896<li>

8897<a href="#_1171_toc">

8898Posttherapy management</a>

8899</li>

8900</ul>

8901</a>

8902</li>

8903<li>

8904<a href="#_38_toc">

8905Digestive Tract <ul>

8906<li>

8907<a href="#_1172_toc">

8908Overview</a>

8909</li>

8910<li>

8911<a href="#_2562_toc">

8912 Impact of cancer histology on GI outcomes</a>

8913</li>

8914<li>

8915<a href="#_1175_toc">

8916GI outcomes from selected cohort studies</a>

8917</li>

8918<li>

8919<a href="#_2565_toc">

8920Radiation-related GI injury</a>

8921</li>

8922</ul>

8923</a>

8924</li>

8925<li>

8926<a href="#_34_toc">

8927Hepatobiliary<ul>

8928<li>

8929<a href="#_1178_toc">

8930Overview</a>

8931</li>

8932<li>

8933<a href="#_1184_toc">

8934Types of hepatobiliary late effects</a>

8935</li>

8936<li>

8937<a href="#_1181_toc">

8938Treatment-related risk factors for hepatobiliary late effects</a>

8939</li>

8940<li>

8941<a href="#_1182_toc">

8942Infectious risk factors for hepatobiliary late effects</a>

8943</li>

8944<li>

8945<a href="#_1204_toc">

8946Posttherapy management</a>

8947</li>

8948</ul>

8949</a>

8950</li>

8951<li>

8952<a href="#_769_toc">

8953Pancreas</a>

8954</li>

8955</ul>

8956</nav>

8957<section id="_31">

8958<h3 id="_31_toc">

8959Dental</h3>

8960<section id="_1164">

8961<h4 id="_1164_toc">

8962Overview</h4>

8963<p id="_32" tabindex="-1">

8964Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and local surgery can cause multiple cosmetic and functional abnormalities of the oral cavity and dentition. The quality of current evidence regarding this outcome is limited by retrospective data collection, small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, and heterogeneity in treatment approach, time since treatment, and method of ascertainment. </p>

8965<p id="_1250" tabindex="-1">

8966Oral and dental complications reported in childhood cancer survivors include the following:</p>

8967<div class="pdq-content-list">

8968<ul id="_1238">

8969<li>

8970<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1239">

8971Abnormalities of tooth development</a>

8972.</li>

8973<li>

8974<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1241">

8975Salivary gland dysfunction</a>

8976.</li>

8977<li>

8978<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1244">

8979 Abnormalities of craniofacial development</a>

8980.</li>

8981</ul>

8982</div>

8983<p id="_1870" tabindex="-1">

8984Osteoradionecrosis and second cancers in the oral cavity also occur.</p>

8985</section>

8986<section id="_1239">

8987<h4 id="_1239_toc">

8988 Abnormalities of tooth development</h4>

8989<p id="_1240" tabindex="-1">

8990 Abnormalities of dental development reported in childhood cancer survivors include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

89911</a>

8992-<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

899312</a>

8994]</p>

8995<div class="pdq-content-list">

8996<ul id="_1871">

8997<li>

8998Absence of tooth development.</li>

8999<li>

9000Microdontia.</li>

9001<li>

9002Enamel hypoplasia.</li>

9003<li>

9004Root malformation.</li>

9005<li>

9006Hypodontia.</li>

9007</ul>

9008</div>

9009<p id="_1872" tabindex="-1">

9010 The prevalence of hypodontia has varied widely in series depending on age at diagnosis, treatment modality, and method of ascertainment.</p>

9011<p id="_1873" tabindex="-1">

9012Cancer treatments that have been associated with dental maldevelopment include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

90133</a>

9014,<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

901510</a>

9016]</p>

9017<div class="pdq-content-list">

9018<ul id="_1874">

9019<li>

9020Head and neck <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2770">

9021radiation therapy</a>

9022.</li>

9023<li>

9024Any <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2772">

9025chemotherapy</a>

9026.</li>

9027<li>

9028<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2773">

9029Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</a>

9030.</li>

9031</ul>

9032</div>

9033<p id="_1875" tabindex="-1">

9034Children younger than 5 years are at greatest risk of dental anomalies, including root agenesis, delayed eruption, enamel defects, and/or excessive caries related to disruption of ameloblast (enamel producing) and odontoblast (dentin producing) activity early in life.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

90353</a>

9036]</p>

9037<p id="_1251" tabindex="-1">

9038Key findings related to cancer treatment effect on tooth development include the following:</p>

9039<section id="_2770">

9040<h5 id="_2770_toc">

9041Radiation therapy</h5>

9042<div class="pdq-content-list">

9043<ul id="_2771">

9044<li>

9045Radiation directed at the oral cavity or surrounding structures increases the risk of dental anomalies because ameloblasts can be permanently damaged by doses as low as 10 Gy; in addition, salivary function is impacted by exposure to major and minor glands.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

90463</a>

9047-<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

90485</a>

9049]</li>

9050<li>

9051 The most significant degree of tooth aplasia or delayed eruption occurs in younger children (aged &lt;4 years) who are exposed to radiation doses of 20 Gy or higher.[<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

905213</a>

9053]</li>

9054<li>

9055Developing teeth may be irradiated when treating head and neck sarcomas, Hodgkin lymphoma, neuroblastoma, central nervous system leukemia, nasopharyngeal cancer, and brain tumors, or during total-body irradiation (TBI) for HSCT.</li>

9056<li>

9057 Doses of 10 Gy to 40 Gy can cause root shortening or abnormal curvature, dwarfism, and hypocalcification.[<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

905814</a>

9059]</li>

9060<li>

9061 Significant dental abnormalities, including mandibular or maxillary hypoplasia, increased caries, hypodontia, microdontia, root stunting, and xerostomia have been reported in more than 85% of survivors of head and neck rhabdomyosarcoma treated with radiation doses higher than 40 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

90624</a>

9063,<a href="#cit/section_5.15">

906415</a>

9065]</li>

9066<li>

9067In the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort, survivors who received radiation therapy that potentially exposed the oral cavity were more likely to report at least one dental health problem (odds ratio [OR], 1.48; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.26&#8211;1.72) and at least one soft tissue abnormality (OR, 1.52; 95% CI, 1.25&#8211;1.84) after controlling for socioeconomic factors, age at last follow-up and diagnosis, other treatment exposures, and access to dental services.[<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

906812</a>

9069]</li>

9070</ul>

9071</div>

9072</section>

9073<section id="_2772">

9074<h5 id="_2772_toc">

9075Chemotherapy</h5>

9076<div class="pdq-content-list">

9077<ul id="_2550">

9078<li>

9079 Chemotherapy, especially exposure to alkylating agents, can affect tooth development.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

90803</a>

9081,<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

90825</a>

9083,<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

90846</a>

9085]</li>

9086<li>

9087 Chemotherapy for the treatment of leukemia or neuroblastoma is associated with shortening and thinning of the premolar roots and enamel abnormalities.[<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

90888</a>

9089,<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

909016</a>

9091-<a href="#cit/section_5.18">

909218</a>

9093]</li>

9094<li>

9095 Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) investigators identified age younger than 5 years and increased exposure to cyclophosphamide as significant risk factors for developmental dental abnormalities in long-term survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

90963</a>

9097]</li>

9098<li>

9099In the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort, survivors who received classic alkylating agents (OR, 1.6; 95% CI, 1.36&#8211;1.88) or anthracycline antibiotics (OR, 1.22; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;1.42) were more likely to report at least one dental health problem after controlling for socioeconomic factors, age at last follow-up and diagnosis, other treatment exposures, and access to dental services.[<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

910012</a>

9101]</li>

9102</ul>

9103</div>

9104</section>

9105<section id="_2773">

9106<h5 id="_2773_toc">

9107HSCT</h5>

9108<div class="pdq-content-list">

9109<ul id="_2551">

9110<li>

9111 HSCT conditioning, especially regimens containing TBI, may result in tooth agenesis and root malformation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

91121</a>

9113,<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

91142</a>

9115]</li>

9116<li>

9117 Younger children who have not developed secondary teeth are most vulnerable.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

91181</a>

9119,<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

91202</a>

9121,<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

91225</a>

9123]</li>

9124<li>

9125 Children who undergo HSCT with TBI may develop short V-shaped roots, microdontia, enamel hypoplasia, and/or premature apical closure.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

91261</a>

9127,<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

91282</a>

9129,<a href="#cit/section_5.7">

91307</a>

9131]</li>

9132<li>

9133Younger age at HSCT is associated with greater severity in dental maldevelopment and deficit in vertical growth of the lower face.[<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

91348</a>

9135]</li>

9136<li>

9137 Dental abnormalities have been reported in patients who underwent HSCT without TBI, particularly in patients younger than 2 years at the time of the transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.18">

913818</a>

9139]</li>

9140</ul>

9141</div>

9142</section>

9143</section>

9144<section id="_1241">

9145<h4 id="_1241_toc">

9146Salivary gland dysfunction</h4>

9147<p id="_1242" tabindex="-1">

9148Xerostomia, the sensation of dry mouth, is a potential side effect after head and neck irradiation or HSCT that can severely impact quality of life.[<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

914919</a>

9150]</p>

9151<div class="pdq-content-list">

9152<ul id="_2552">

9153<li>

9154Complications of reduced salivary secretion include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

915519</a>

9156,<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

915720</a>

9158]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9159<ul id="_1878" class="list-dash">

9160<li>

9161Increased caries.</li>

9162<li>

9163Susceptibility to oral infections.</li>

9164<li>

9165Sleep disturbances.</li>

9166<li>

9167Difficulties with chewing, swallowing, and speaking.</li>

9168</ul>

9169</div>

9170</li>

9171<li>

9172The prevalence of salivary gland dysfunction after cancer treatment varies based on measurement techniques (patient report vs. stimulated or unstimulated salivary secretion rates).[<a href="#cit/section_5.21">

917321</a>

9174]</li>

9175<li>

9176 In general, the prevalence of self-reported persistent posttherapy xerostomia is low among childhood cancer survivors.</li>

9177<li>

9178 In the CCSS, the prevalence of self-reported xerostomia in survivors was 2.8% compared with 0.3% in siblings, with an increased risk in survivors older than 30 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

91793</a>

9180]</li>

9181</ul>

9182</div>

9183<p id="_1992" tabindex="-1">

9184Key findings related to cancer treatment effect on salivary gland function include the following:</p>

9185<section id="_2774">

9186<h5 id="_2774_toc">

9187Radiation therapy</h5>

9188<div class="pdq-content-list">

9189<ul id="_2553">

9190<li>

9191 Salivary gland irradiation incidental to treatment of head and neck malignancies or Hodgkin lymphoma causes a qualitative and quantitative change in salivary flow, which can be reversible after doses of lower than 40 Gy but may be irreversible after higher doses, depending on whether sensitizing chemotherapy is also administered.[<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

919219</a>

9193]</li>

9194<li>

9195In a German study of 114 pediatric patients, the risk of acute and late xerostomia increased with parotid and submandibular gland dose. In general, grade 1 or higher xerostomia was seen in patients who received a maximum dose of higher than 20 Gy to the salivary glands. The odds of both acute and late xerostomia were higher in patients who received concurrent chemotherapy compared with those who received radiation therapy alone, with an OR for acute xerostomia of 3.64 (95% CI, 1.49&#8211;8.89) and for late xerostomia of 5.15 (95% CI, 1.20&#8211;22.15).[<a href="#cit/section_5.22">

919622</a>

9197]</li>

9198<li>

9199The Pediatric Normal Tissue Effects in the Clinic (PENTEC) initiative reported on late effects for childhood cancer survivors who were treated with radiation therapy for head and neck cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.23">

920023</a>

9201] Grades 1 or higher xerostomia were seen in patients who received a maximum dose of more than 20 Gy to the salivary glands. The odds of both acute and chronic xerostomia were greater in patients who had received concurrent chemotherapy and radiation therapy (acute xerostomia OR, 3.64; 95% CI, 1.49&#8211;8.89 and late xerostomia OR, 5.15; 95% CI, 1.20&#8211;22.15), compared with patients who were treated with radiation therapy alone. A mean parotid dose of 35 to 40 Gy was associated with a 32% risk of higher than grade 2 acute xerostomia and a 13% to 32% risk of chronic xerostomia.</li>

9202</ul>

9203</div>

9204</section>

9205<section id="_2775">

9206<h5 id="_2775_toc">

9207HSCT</h5>

9208<div class="pdq-content-list">

9209<ul id="_2776">

9210<li>

9211 HSCT recipients are at increased risk of salivary gland dysfunction related to transplant conditioning or graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).</li>

9212<li>

9213 GVHD can cause hyposalivation and xerostomia with resultant dental disease.</li>

9214<li>

9215 In a study of pediatric HSCT survivors, 60% of those exposed to a conditioning regimen with cyclophosphamide and 10 Gy single-dose TBI had decreased salivary secretion rates, compared with 26% of those who received cyclophosphamide and busulfan.[<a href="#cit/section_5.24">

921624</a>

9217]</li>

9218<li>

9219 In another study, the prevalence of reduced salivary secretion did not differ among long-term survivors on the basis of the conditioning regimen (single-dose TBI, 47%; fractionated TBI, 47%; busulfan, 42%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

922025</a>

9221]</li>

9222</ul>

9223</div>

9224</section>

9225<section id="_2777">

9226<h5 id="_2777_toc">

9227Chemotherapy</h5>

9228<div class="pdq-content-list">

9229<ul id="_2778">

9230<li>

9231 The association of chemotherapy alone with xerostomia remains controversial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

923219</a>

9233] </li>

9234<li>

9235Only one study of pediatric patients demonstrated an excess risk (OR, 12.32; 95% CI, 2.1&#8211;74.4) of decreased stimulated saliva flow rates among patients treated with cyclophosphamide; however, an increase in dental caries was not noted and patient-reported xerostomia was not evaluated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

92366</a>

9237]</li>

9238</ul>

9239</div>

9240</section>

9241</section>

9242<section id="_1244">

9243<h4 id="_1244_toc">

9244Abnormalities of craniofacial development</h4>

9245<div class="pdq-content-list">

9246<ul id="_2556">

9247<li>

9248Craniofacial maldevelopment is a common adverse outcome among children treated with high-dose radiation therapy to the head and neck that frequently occurs in association with other oral cavity sequelae such as dental anomalies, xerostomia, and trismus.[<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

92494</a>

9250,<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

925126</a>

9252]</li>

9253<li>

9254 The extent and severity of musculoskeletal disfigurement is related to age at treatment and radiation therapy volume and dose, with higher risk observed among younger patients and those who received 30 Gy or higher of radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

925526</a>

9256]</li>

9257</ul>

9258</div>

9259</section>

9260<section id="_2557">

9261<h4 id="_2557_toc">

9262Other oral health complications</h4>

9263<div class="pdq-content-list">

9264<ul id="_2558">

9265<li>

9266Osteoradionecrosis of the jaw is a rare complication observed in childhood survivors treated with high-dose craniofacial radiation (&gt;40 Gy), particularly after dental extractions in irradiated mandibles.[<a href="#cit/section_5.27">

926727</a>

9268,<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

926928</a>

9270]</li>

9271<li>

9272 Remediation of cosmetic and functional abnormalities often requires multiple surgical interventions.</li>

9273<li>

9274The impact of infectious complications and alterations in the microflora during and after therapy is not known.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

92755</a>

9276]</li>

9277</ul>

9278</div>

9279</section>

9280<section id="_1171">

9281<h4 id="_1171_toc">

9282Posttherapy management</h4>

9283<div class="pdq-content-list">

9284<ul id="_2559">

9285<li>

9286Some studies suggest that fluoride products or chlorhexidine rinses may be beneficial in patients who have undergone radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

928729</a>

9288]</li>

9289<li>

9290 Dental caries are a problematic consequence of reduced salivary quality and flow. The use of topical fluoride can dramatically reduce the frequency of caries, and saliva substitutes and sialagogues can ameliorate sequelae such as xerostomia.[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

929120</a>

9292]</li>

9293<li>

9294The incidence of dental visits for childhood cancer survivors falls below the American Dental Association's recommendation that all adults visit the dentist annually.[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

929530</a>

9296]</li>

9297<li>

9298 The <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

9299Children&#8217;s Oncology Group Long-term Follow-Up Guidelines</a>

9300 recommend biannual dental cleaning and exams for all survivors of childhood cancer.</li>

9301<li>

9302 These findings give health care providers further impetus to encourage routine dental care and dental hygiene evaluations for survivors of childhood treatment.</li>

9303</ul>

9304</div>

9305<p id="_2560" tabindex="-1">

9306For more information about oral complications in cancer patients, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/mouth-throat/oral-complications-hp-pdq">

9307Oral Complications of Chemotherapy and Head/Neck Radiation</a>

9308.</p>

9309</section>

9310<p id="_1720" tabindex="-1">

9311<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_416">

9312Table 5</a>

9313 summarizes oral and dental late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

9314<table id="_416" class="table-default expandable-container">

9315<caption>

9316Table 5. Oral/Dental Late Effects<span class="sup">

9317a</span>

9318</caption>

9319<colgroup>

9320<col width="33.33%">

9321<col width="33.33%">

9322<col width="33.33%">

9323</colgroup>

9324<THead>

9325<tr>

9326<th>

9327Predisposing Therapy</th>

9328<th>

9329Oral/Dental Effects</th>

9330<th>

9331Health Screening/Interventions</th>

9332</tr>

9333</THead>

9334<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

9335<tr>

9336<td colspan="3">

9337CT = computed tomography; GVHD = graft-versus-host disease; MRI = magnetic resonance imaging.</td>

9338</tr>

9339<tr>

9340<td colspan="3">

9341<span class="sup">

9342a</span>

9343Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

9344Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

9345.</td>

9346</tr>

9347</TFoot>

9348<tbody>

9349<tr>

9350<td rowspan="4">

9351Any chemotherapy;

9352radiation exposing oral cavity </td>

9353<td rowspan="4">

9354Dental developmental abnormalities;

9355tooth/root agenesis;

9356microdontia;

9357root thinning/shortening;

9358enamel dysplasia

9359</td>

9360<td>

9361Dental evaluation and cleaning every 6 months</td>

9362</tr>

9363<tr>

9364<td>

9365Regular dental care including fluoride applications </td>

9366</tr>

9367<tr>

9368<td>

9369Consultation with orthodontist experienced in management of irradiated childhood cancer survivors </td>

9370</tr>

9371<tr>

9372<td>

9373Baseline Panorex x-ray before dental procedures to evaluate root development </td>

9374</tr>

9375<tr>

9376<td rowspan="5">

9377Radiation exposing oral cavity </td>

9378<td rowspan="5">

9379Malocclusion;

9380temporomandibular joint dysfunction

9381</td>

9382<td>

9383Dental evaluation and cleaning every 6 months</td>

9384</tr>

9385<tr>

9386<td>

9387Regular dental care including fluoride applications </td>

9388</tr>

9389<tr>

9390<td>

9391Consultation with orthodontist experienced in management of irradiated childhood cancer survivors </td>

9392</tr>

9393<tr>

9394<td>

9395Baseline Panorex x-ray before dental procedures to evaluate root development </td>

9396</tr>

9397<tr>

9398<td>

9399Referral to otolaryngologist for assistive devices for jaw opening</td>

9400</tr>

9401<tr>

9402<td rowspan="4">

9403Radiation exposing oral cavity;

9404hematopoietic cell transplantation with history of chronic GVHD </td>

9405<td rowspan="4">

9406Xerostomia/salivary gland dysfunction;

9407periodontal disease;

9408dental caries;

9409oral cancer (squamous cell carcinoma)

9410</td>

9411<td>

9412Dental evaluation and cleaning every 6 months</td>

9413</tr>

9414<tr>

9415<td>

9416Supportive care with saliva substitutes, moistening agents, and sialogogues (pilocarpine)</td>

9417</tr>

9418<tr>

9419<td>

9420Regular dental care including fluoride applications</td>

9421</tr>

9422<tr>

9423<td>

9424Referral for biopsy of suspicious lesions</td>

9425</tr>

9426<tr>

9427<td rowspan="5">

9428Radiation exposing oral cavity (&#8805;40 Gy) </td>

9429<td rowspan="5">

9430Osteoradionecrosis</td>

9431<td>

9432History: impaired or delayed healing after dental work</td>

9433</tr>

9434<tr>

9435<td>

9436Exam: persistent jaw pain, swelling or trismus</td>

9437</tr>

9438<tr>

9439<td>

9440 Imaging studies (x-ray, CT scan and/or MRI) may assist in making diagnosis</td>

9441</tr>

9442<tr>

9443<td>

9444Surgical biopsy may be needed to confirm diagnosis</td>

9445</tr>

9446<tr>

9447<td>

9448Consider hyperbaric oxygen treatments</td>

9449</tr>

9450</tbody>

9451</table>

9452</section>

9453<section id="_38">

9454<h3 id="_38_toc">

9455Digestive Tract </h3>

9456<section id="_1172">

9457<h4 id="_1172_toc">

9458Overview</h4>

9459<p id="_1173" tabindex="-1">

9460The gastrointestinal (GI) tract is sensitive to the acute toxicities of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery. These important treatment modalities can also result in some long-term issues in a treatment- and dose-dependent manner.</p>

9461<p id="_2561" tabindex="-1">

9462 Reports published about long-term GI tract outcomes are limited by retrospective data collection, small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, heterogeneity in treatment approach, time since treatment, and method of ascertainment. </p>

9463<p id="_1884" tabindex="-1">

9464Treatment-related late effects include the following:</p>

9465<div class="pdq-content-list">

9466<ul id="_1246">

9467<li>

9468Upper and lower digestive tract late effects associated with dose intensity of chemotherapy and/or abdominal radiation.</li>

9469<li>

9470Adhesions secondary to abdominal surgery predisposing to postoperative bowel obstruction.</li>

9471</ul>

9472</div>

9473<p id="_1885" tabindex="-1">

9474Digestive tract&#8211;related late effects include the following:</p>

9475<div class="pdq-content-list">

9476<ul id="_1194">

9477<li>

9478 Esophageal dysmotility.</li>

9479<li>

9480Esophageal stricture.</li>

9481<li>

9482Gastroesophageal reflux.</li>

9483<li>

9484Gastritis, enteritis, or colitis.</li>

9485<li>

9486GI motility dysfunction (diarrhea, constipation, encopresis, bowel obstruction).</li>

9487<li>

9488Subsequent malignant neoplasms (SMNs).</li>

9489</ul>

9490</div>

9491</section>

9492<section id="_2562">

9493<h4 id="_2562_toc">

9494 Impact of cancer histology on GI outcomes</h4>

9495<p id="_2563" tabindex="-1">

9496The abdomen is a relatively common location for several pediatric malignancies, including rhabdomyosarcoma, Wilms tumor, lymphoma, germ cell tumors, and neuroblastoma. </p>

9497<p id="_2564" tabindex="-1">

9498Intra-abdominal tumors often require multimodal therapy, occasionally necessitating resection of bowel, bowel-injuring chemotherapy, and/or radiation therapy. Thus, these tumors would be expected to be particularly prone to long-term digestive tract issues.</p>

9499</section>

9500<section id="_1175">

9501<h4 id="_1175_toc">

9502GI outcomes from selected cohort studies</h4>

9503<p id="_1247" tabindex="-1">

9504Evidence (GI outcomes from selected cohort studies):</p>

9505<div class="pdq-content-list">

9506<ol id="_1886">

9507<li>

9508Among 5-year childhood cancer survivors participating in the CCSS, the cumulative incidence of self-reported GI conditions was 37.6% at 20 years from cancer diagnosis (25.8% for upper GI complications and 15.5% for lower GI complications), representing an almost twofold excess risk of upper GI complications (relative risk [RR], 1.8; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;2.0) and lower GI complications (RR, 1.9; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;2.2), compared with sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

950931</a>

9510]<p id="_1887" tabindex="-1">

9511 Factors predicting higher risk of specific GI complications include the following:</p>

9512<div class="pdq-content-list">

9513<ul id="_1195">

9514<li>

9515Older age at diagnosis.</li>

9516<li>

9517Intensified therapy (anthracyclines for upper GI complications and alkylating agents for lower GI complications).</li>

9518<li>

9519Abdominal radiation therapy.</li>

9520<li>

9521Abdominal surgery. </li>

9522</ul>

9523</div>

9524</li>

9525<li>

9526A cohort study of children treated for acute myeloid leukemia with chemotherapy alone found that GI disorders were relatively rare and not significantly different from those reported by sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_5.32">

952732</a>

9528]</li>

9529</ol>

9530</div>

9531</section>

9532<section id="_2565">

9533<h4 id="_2565_toc">

9534Radiation-related GI injury</h4>

9535<div class="pdq-content-list">

9536<ul id="_2566">

9537<li>

9538Late radiation injury to the digestive tract is attributable to vascular injury.</li>

9539<li>

9540 Necrosis, ulceration, stenosis, or perforation can occur and are characterized by malabsorption, pain, and recurrent episodes of bowel obstruction, as well as perforation and infection.[<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

954133</a>

9542-<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

954335</a>

9544]</li>

9545<li>

9546In general, fractionated radiation doses of 20 Gy to 30 Gy can be delivered to the small bowel without significant long-term morbidity.[<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

954736</a>

9548] </li>

9549<li>

9550Doses higher than 40 Gy are associated with a greater risk of bowel obstruction or chronic enterocolitis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

955136</a>

9552]</li>

9553<li>

9554 Sensitizing chemotherapeutic agents such as dactinomycin or anthracyclines can increase this risk.</li>

9555</ul>

9556</div>

9557<p id="_2567" tabindex="-1">

9558A limited number of reports describe GI complications in pediatric patients with genitourinary solid tumors treated with radiation therapy:[<a href="#cit/section_5.37">

955937</a>

9560-<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

956139</a>

9562]</p>

9563<div class="pdq-content-list">

9564<ol id="_2568">

9565<li>

9566The CCSS evaluated the long-term morbidity among unilateral, nonsyndromic Wilms tumor survivors (n = 2,008) according to conventional treatment regimens. All patients underwent unilateral nephrectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

956740</a>

9568]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9569<ul id="_2992">

9570<li>

9571 The 35-year cumulative incidence for intestinal obstruction was 8.1% (95% CI, 6.6%&#8211;9.6%). </li>

9572<li>

9573Relative to siblings, survivors treated with vincristine and actinomycin D (VA) demonstrated an elevated risk of intestinal obstruction (RR, 9.4). The risk with VA treatment was lower than for treatment groups who received more intensive therapy (RR range, 15.4&#8211;46.8). </li>

9574<li>

9575The rate of intestinal obstruction was highest among survivors who received more than 20 Gy of whole abdomen or flank radiation therapy.</li>

9576</ul>

9577</div>

9578</li>

9579<li>

9580The CCSS evaluated the incidence and risk of late-occurring intestinal obstruction requiring surgery in 12,316 5-year survivors (2,002 with and 10,314 without abdominopelvic tumors) and 4,023 siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

958141</a>

9582]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9583<ul id="_1891">

9584<li>

9585 The most common diagnoses among survivors with abdominopelvic tumors were Wilms tumors and neuroblastomas but also included soft tissue sarcomas, lymphomas, and bone tumors.</li>

9586<li>

9587 The cumulative incidence of late intestinal obstruction requiring surgery at 35 years was 5.8% among survivors with abdominopelvic tumors, 1.0% among those without abdominopelvic tumors, and 0.3% among siblings.</li>

9588<li>

9589Elevated risk of intestinal obstruction requiring surgery was associated with presence of an abdominopelvic tumor (adjusted rate ratio [ARR], 3.6; <em>

9590P</em>

9591 &lt; .001) and exposure to abdominal or pelvic radiation therapy within 5 years of cancer diagnosis (ARR, 2.4; <em>

9592P</em>

9593 &lt; .001).</li>

9594<li>

9595Among survivors of abdominopelvic tumors, the median time from diagnosis to the first late intestinal obstruction requiring surgery was 12 years (range, 8&#8211;19 years).</li>

9596<li>

9597Lymphoma resulted in the highest cumulative incidence of late-occurring intestinal obstruction that required surgery (7.2% at 35 years after diagnosis).</li>

9598</ul>

9599</div>

9600</li>

9601<li>

9602The CCSS evaluated late-onset anorectal disease in cohort members:[<a href="#cit/section_5.42">

960342</a>

9604]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9605<ul id="_2569">

9606<li>

9607Among survivors, pelvic radiation therapy higher than 30 Gy within 5 years of cancer diagnosis was associated with late-onset anorectal disease (ARR for 30&#8211;49.9 Gy vs. none, 1.6; ARR for &#8805;50 Gy vs. none, 5.4). </li>

9608<li>

9609The most frequent anorectal disease reported was fistula in ano, followed by stricture and anorectal SMN.</li>

9610<li>

9611Late-onset anorectal disease was associated with psychological impairment in all domains, as characterized by increased emotional distress and impaired quality of life.</li>

9612</ul>

9613</div>

9614</li>

9615<li>

9616Reports from the Intergroup Rhabdomyosarcoma Study evaluating GI toxicity in long-term survivors of genitourinary rhabdomyosarcoma infrequently observed abnormalities of the irradiated bowel.[<a href="#cit/section_5.37">

961737</a>

9618-<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

961939</a>

9620]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9621<ul id="_2570">

9622<li>

9623Radiation-related complications occurred in approximately 10% of long-term survivors of paratesticular and bladder/prostate rhabdomyosarcoma and included intraperitoneal adhesions with bowel obstruction, chronic diarrhea, and stricture or enteric fistula formation.</li>

9624</ul>

9625</div>

9626</li>

9627<li>

9628The CCSS evaluated the prevalence of esophageal stricture and identified associated clinical and treatment risk factors among 17,121 5-year childhood cancer survivors and 3,400 siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

962943</a>

9630]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9631<ul id="_2924">

9632<li>

9633The prevalence of esophageal stricture among survivors was 2.0% (95% CI, 1.8%&#8211;2.2%), representing a 7.6-fold increased risk compared with siblings.</li>

9634<li>

9635Factors significantly associated with risk of esophageal stricture included a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, greater chest radiation dose, younger age at cancer diagnosis, platinum chemotherapy exposure, and undergoing a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.</li>

9636</ul>

9637</div>

9638</li>

9639</ol>

9640</div>

9641</section>

9642<p id="_1721" tabindex="-1">

9643<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_417">

9644Table 6</a>

9645 summarizes digestive tract late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

9646<table id="_417" class="table-default expandable-container">

9647<caption>

9648Table 6. Digestive Tract Late Effects<span class="sup">

9649a</span>

9650</caption>

9651<colgroup>

9652<col width="33.33%">

9653<col width="33.33%">

9654<col width="33.33%">

9655</colgroup>

9656<THead>

9657<tr>

9658<th>

9659Predisposing Therapy</th>

9660<th>

9661Gastrointestinal Effects</th>

9662<th>

9663Health Screening/Interventions</th>

9664</tr>

9665</THead>

9666<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

9667<tr>

9668<td colspan="3">

9669GVHD = graft-versus-host disease; KUB = kidneys, ureter, bladder (plain abdominal radiograph).</td>

9670</tr>

9671<tr>

9672<td colspan="3">

9673<span class="sup">

9674a</span>

9675Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

9676Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

9677.</td>

9678</tr>

9679</TFoot>

9680<tbody>

9681<tr>

9682<td rowspan="2">

9683Radiation exposing esophagus;

9684hematopoietic cell transplantation with any history of chronic GVHD </td>

9685<td rowspan="2">

9686Gastroesophageal reflux;

9687esophageal dysmotility;

9688esophageal stricture

9689</td>

9690<td>

9691History: dysphagia, heart burn</td>

9692</tr>

9693<tr>

9694<td>

9695Esophageal dilation, antireflux surgery</td>

9696</tr>

9697<tr>

9698<td rowspan="3">

9699Radiation exposing bowel </td>

9700<td rowspan="3">

9701Chronic enterocolitis;

9702fistula;

9703strictures

9704</td>

9705<td>

9706History: nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea</td>

9707</tr>

9708<tr>

9709<td>

9710Serum protein and albumin levels yearly in patients with chronic diarrhea or fistula</td>

9711</tr>

9712<tr>

9713<td>

9714Surgical and/or gastroenterology consultation for symptomatic patients</td>

9715</tr>

9716<tr>

9717<td rowspan="4">

9718Radiation exposing bowel;

9719laparotomy </td>

9720<td rowspan="4">

9721Bowel obstruction

9722</td>

9723<td>

9724History: abdominal pain, distention, vomiting, constipation</td>

9725</tr>

9726<tr>

9727<td>

9728Exam: tenderness, abdominal guarding, distension (acute episode)</td>

9729</tr>

9730<tr>

9731<td>

9732Obtain KUB in patients with clinical symptoms of obstruction</td>

9733</tr>

9734<tr>

9735<td>

9736Surgical consultation in patients unresponsive to medical management</td>

9737</tr>

9738<tr>

9739<td rowspan="2">

9740Pelvic surgery;

9741cystectomy </td>

9742<td rowspan="2">

9743Fecal incontinence

9744</td>

9745<td>

9746History: chronic constipation, fecal soiling</td>

9747</tr>

9748<tr>

9749<td>

9750Rectal exam</td>

9751</tr>

9752</tbody>

9753</table>

9754</section>

9755<section id="_34">

9756<h3 id="_34_toc">

9757Hepatobiliary</h3>

9758<section id="_1178">

9759<h4 id="_1178_toc">

9760Overview</h4>

9761<p id="_1179" tabindex="-1">

9762Hepatic complications resulting from childhood cancer therapy are observed primarily as acute treatment toxicities.[<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

976344</a>

9764] Because many chemotherapy agents and radiation are hepatotoxic, transient liver function anomalies are common during therapy. Severe acute hepatic complications rarely occur. Survivors of childhood cancer can occasionally exhibit long-standing hepatic injury.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

976545</a>

9766]</p>

9767<p id="_1893" tabindex="-1">

9768 Some general concepts regarding hepatotoxicity related to childhood cancer include the following:</p>

9769<div class="pdq-content-list">

9770<ul id="_1180">

9771<li>

9772The risk of long-term hepatotoxicity is not well defined.</li>

9773<li>

9774Children with primary liver tumors requiring significant liver resection, or even transplant, are at higher risk of liver injury.</li>

9775<li>

9776Children receiving radiation therapy to the liver are at higher risk of liver injury.</li>

9777<li>

9778Children undergoing bone marrow transplant are at higher risk of liver injury.</li>

9779</ul>

9780</div>

9781<p id="_1475" tabindex="-1">

9782Certain factors, including the type of chemotherapy, the dose and extent of radiation exposure, the influence of surgical interventions, and the evolving impact of viral hepatitis and/or other infectious complication, need additional attention in future studies.</p>

9783</section>

9784<section id="_1184">

9785<h4 id="_1184_toc">

9786Types of hepatobiliary late effects</h4>

9787<p id="_1894" tabindex="-1">

9788Asymptomatic elevation of liver enzymes is the most common hepatobiliary complication.</p>

9789<div class="pdq-content-list">

9790<ul id="_1249">

9791<li>

9792<strong>

9793Asymptomatic elevation of liver enzymes.</strong>

9794 Liver injury related to treatment for childhood cancer is often asymptomatic and indolent in course. While elevated serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and gamma glutamyltransferase (GGT) levels can reflect transient acute liver injury during chemotherapy, they are not predictive of late hepatic dysfunction or cirrhosis.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9795<ul id="_2571" class="list-dash">

9796<li>

9797Dutch investigators observed hepatobiliary dysfunction in 8.7% of 1,362 long-term survivors (median follow-up, 12.4 years since diagnosis) evaluated by ALT for hepatocellular injury and GGT for biliary tract injury. Cases with a history of viral hepatitis and a history of veno-occlusive disease were excluded.[<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

979846</a>

9799]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9800<ul id="_2572">

9801<li>

9802 Predictors for elevated ALT and GGT by multivariable analysis included treatment with radiation therapy involving the liver, higher body mass index (BMI), higher alcohol intake, and longer follow-up time; older age at diagnosis was only significantly associated with elevated GGT levels.</li>

9803</ul>

9804</div>

9805</li>

9806<li>

9807A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study evaluated prevalence of and risk factors for elevated ALT among 2,751 adult survivors of childhood cancer (median age, 31.4 years; median elapsed time from diagnosis, 23.2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_5.47">

980847</a>

9809]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9810<ul id="_2573">

9811<li>

9812ALT greater than sex-specific upper limits of normal was prevalent in 41.3% of survivors; however, the prevalence of grade 3 or 4 hepatic injury was infrequent (&lt;1%).</li>

9813<li>

9814Independent risk factors for elevated ALT included non-Hispanic White race and ethnicity, older age at evaluation, being overweight or affected by obesity, presence of metabolic syndrome, current treatment with a statin, hepatitis C infection, previous treatment with busulfan or thioguanine, history of hepatic surgery, and the percentage of liver treated with 10 Gy, 15 Gy, 20 Gy, or higher doses.</li>

9815</ul>

9816</div>

9817</li>

9818</ul>

9819</div>

9820</li>

9821</ul>

9822</div>

9823<p id="_412" tabindex="-1">

9824Less commonly reported hepatobiliary complications include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

982548</a>

9826] </p>

9827<section id="_2574">

9828<h5 id="_2574_toc">

9829Cholelithiasis</h5>

9830<div class="pdq-content-list">

9831<ul id="_2575">

9832<li>

9833In limited studies, an increased risk of cholelithiasis has been linked to ileal conduit, parenteral nutrition, abdominal surgery, abdominal radiation therapy, and HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

983449</a>

9835,<a href="#cit/section_5.50">

983650</a>

9837]</li>

9838<li>

9839The cumulative incidence of late (occurring 5 or more years after cancer diagnosis) cholecystectomy among 25,549 CCSS participants diagnosed between 1970 and 1999 (median follow-up, 21.9 years) was 7.2% compared with 6.6% in a sibling control group (rate ratio, 1.3; 95% CI, 1.1&#8211;1.5).[<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

984051</a>

9841] </li>

9842<li>

9843Independent risk factors for late cholecystectomy include attained age, female sex, increasing BMI, exposure to high-dose (&gt;750 mg/m<span class="sup">

98442</span>

9845) platinum chemotherapy (rate ratio, 2.6; 95% CI, 1.5&#8211;4.5), vinca alkaloid chemotherapy (rate ratio, 1.4; 95% CI, 1.1&#8211;1.8) or TBI (rate ratio, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;2.4).[<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

984651</a>

9847]</li>

9848</ul>

9849</div>

9850</section>

9851<section id="_2576">

9852<h5 id="_2576_toc">

9853Focal nodular hyperplasia</h5>

9854<div class="pdq-content-list">

9855<ul id="_2577">

9856<li>

9857Lesions made up of regenerating liver called focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) have been incidentally noted on screening imaging studies after chemotherapy or HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

985852</a>

9859,<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

986053</a>

9861]</li>

9862<li>

9863FNH is thought to represent iatrogenic benign manifestations of vascular damage and have been associated with veno-occlusive disease, high-dose alkylating agents (e.g., busulfan and melphalan), and liver irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

986452</a>

9865]</li>

9866<li>

9867 The

9868prevalence of FNH is unknown; while noted at less than 1% in some papers,[<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

986953</a>

9870] this is likely an underestimate.</li>

9871<li>

9872 In one study of patients who were followed by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) after transplant to assess liver iron stores, the cumulative incidence was 35% at 150 months posttransplant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

987352</a>

9874]</li>

9875<li>

9876FNH can mimic metastatic or subsequent tumors, but MRI imaging has a characteristic pattern and is generally diagnostic.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

987752</a>

9878]</li>

9879<li>

9880 Biopsy or resection is usually unnecessary unless the lesions grow or patients have worrisome symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

988152</a>

9882]</li>

9883</ul>

9884</div>

9885</section>

9886<section id="_2578">

9887<h5 id="_2578_toc">

9888Nodular regenerative hyperplasia</h5>

9889<div class="pdq-content-list">

9890<ul id="_2579">

9891<li>

9892Nodular

9893regenerative hyperplasia is a rare condition characterized by the development of multiple monoacinar regenerative hepatic nodules and mild fibrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

989448</a>

9895]</li>

9896<li>

9897 The pathogenesis of nodular regenerative hyperplasia is not well established but may represent a nonspecific tissue adaptation to heterogeneous hepatic blood flow.[<a href="#cit/section_5.54">

989854</a>

9899]</li>

9900<li>

9901

9902Nodular

9903regenerative hyperplasia has rarely been observed in survivors of childhood cancer treated with chemotherapy, with or without liver irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.55">

990455</a>

9905,<a href="#cit/section_5.56">

990656</a>

9907]</li>

9908<li>

9909Biopsy may be necessary to distinguish nodular

9910regenerative hyperplasia from a subsequent malignancy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.56">

991156</a>

9912]</li>

9913</ul>

9914</div>

9915</section>

9916<section id="_2580">

9917<h5 id="_2580_toc">

9918Microvesicular fatty change</h5>

9919<div class="pdq-content-list">

9920<ul id="_2581">

9921<li>

9922Histological evidence of fatty infiltration (93%) and siderosis (up to 70%) was observed in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who recently completed intensified therapy. Fibrosis developed in 11% and was associated with higher serum low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol.[<a href="#cit/section_5.57">

992357</a>

9924]</li>

9925<li>

9926Fatty liver with insulin resistance has also been reported to develop more frequently in long-term childhood cancer survivors treated with cranial radiation and TBI therapy with allogeneic stem cell transplantation without overweight or obesity.[<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

992758</a>

9928]</li>

9929<li>

9930 Prospective studies are needed to define whether acute posttherapy fatty liver change contributes to the development of late steatohepatitis or the metabolic syndrome in this population.</li>

9931</ul>

9932</div>

9933</section>

9934<section id="_2582">

9935<h5 id="_2582_toc">

9936Transfusion-related iron overload</h5>

9937<div class="pdq-content-list">

9938<ul id="_2583">

9939<li>

9940Red blood cell transfusion can result in an accumulation of excess iron caused by the disruption of the homeostasis of iron storage and distribution when exogenous iron is loaded into organs.</li>

9941<li>

9942 Transfusional iron overload has been reported in pediatric oncology patients, but its prevalence, organ distribution, and severity remain incompletely characterized.</li>

9943<li>

9944 MRI has emerged as an accurate, noninvasive means for measuring iron in multiple organ systems.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

994559</a>

9946,<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

994760</a>

9948]</li>

9949<li>

9950 In a cross-sectional study of 75 patients (4.4 years of median follow-up time; 4.9 years since last transfusion), MRI iron concentrations were elevated in the liver (49.3%) and pancreas (26.4%), but not in the heart.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

995159</a>

9952]</li>

9953<li>

9954 In a multivariable analysis, cumulative packed red blood cell volume and older age at diagnosis predicted elevated liver iron concentration.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

995559</a>

9956]</li>

9957<li>

9958Receipt of allogeneic transplantation is a significant risk factor for transfusional iron overload.[<a href="#cit/section_5.61">

995961</a>

9960]</li>

9961</ul>

9962</div>

9963</section>

9964</section>

9965<section id="_1181">

9966<h4 id="_1181_toc">

9967Treatment-related risk factors for hepatobiliary late effects</h4>

9968<p id="_848" tabindex="-1">

9969The type and intensity of previous therapy influences risk for late-occurring hepatobiliary effects. In addition to the risk of treatment-related toxicity, recipients of HSCT frequently experience chronic liver dysfunction related to microvascular, immunologic, infectious, metabolic, and other toxic etiologies.</p>

9970<p id="_1901" tabindex="-1">

9971Key findings related to cancer treatment effect on hepatobiliary complications include the following:</p>

9972<section id="_2584">

9973<h5 id="_2584_toc">

9974Chemotherapy</h5>

9975<div class="pdq-content-list">

9976<ul id="_2585">

9977<li>

9978Chemotherapeutic agents with established hepatotoxic potential include antimetabolite agents like 6-mercaptopurine, 6-thioguanine, methotrexate, and rarely, dactinomycin.</li>

9979<li>

9980 Veno-occlusive disease/sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (VOD/SOS) and cholestatic disease have been observed after thiopurine administration, especially 6-thioguanine.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

998162</a>

9982]</li>

9983<li>

9984 Progressive fibrosis and portal hypertension have been reported in a subset of children who developed VOD/SOS after treatment with 6-thioguanine.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

998562</a>

9986]</li>

9987<li>

9988 Acute, dose-related, reversible VOD/SOS has been observed in children treated with dactinomycin for pediatric solid tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

998963</a>

9990,<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

999164</a>

9992]</li>

9993<li>

9994 In the transplant setting, VOD/SOS has also been observed after conditioning regimens that have included cyclophosphamide/TBI, busulfan/cyclophosphamide, and carmustine/cyclophosphamide/etoposide.[<a href="#cit/section_5.65">

999565</a>

9996] High-dose cyclophosphamide, common to all of these regimens, is speculated to be a potential causative factor.</li>

9997</ul>

9998</div>

9999</section>

10000<section id="_2586">

10001<h5 id="_2586_toc">

10002Radiation therapy</h5>

10003<div class="pdq-content-list">

10004<ul id="_2587">

10005<li>

10006 Acute radiation-induced liver disease also causes endothelial cell injury that is characteristic of VOD/SOS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

1000766</a>

10008]</li>

10009<li>

10010 In adults, the whole liver has tolerance up to 30 Gy to 35 Gy with conventional fractionation, the prevalence of radiation-induced liver disease varies from 6% to 66% based on the volume of liver involved and on hepatic reserve.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

1001166</a>

10012,<a href="#cit/section_5.67">

1001367</a>

10014]</li>

10015<li>

10016Radiation hepatopathy after contemporary treatment appears to be uncommon in long-term survivors without predisposing conditions, such as viral hepatitis or iron overload.[<a href="#cit/section_5.68">

1001768</a>

10018]</li>

10019<li>

10020 The risk of injury in children increases with radiation dose, hepatic volume, younger age at treatment, previous partial hepatectomy, and concomitant use of radiomimetic chemotherapy, such as dactinomycin and doxorubicin.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

1002169</a>

10022-<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

1002372</a>

10024]</li>

10025<li>

10026 Survivors who received radiation doses of 40 Gy to at least one-third of the liver volume, doses of 30 Gy or higher to the whole abdomen, or an upper abdominal field involving the entire liver are at highest risk for hepatic dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

1002745</a>

10028]</li>

10029<li>

10030 The dose threshold for irreversible hepatic injury is uncertain but is being examined by the <a href="https://www.pentecradiation.org/" title="https://www.pentecradiation.org/">

10031PENTEC</a>

10032 initiative.</li>

10033</ul>

10034</div>

10035</section>

10036<section id="_2588">

10037<h5 id="_2588_toc">

10038HSCT</h5>

10039<div class="pdq-content-list">

10040<ul id="_2589">

10041<li>

10042Chronic liver dysfunction in patients after HSCT is multifactorial in etiology with the most common etiologies including iron overload, chronic GVHD, and viral hepatitis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

1004373</a>

10044]</li>

10045<li>

10046 Patients with chronic GVHD of the GI tract who exhibit an elevated bilirubin have a worse prognosis and quality of life.[<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

1004774</a>

10048]</li>

10049<li>

10050 While chronic liver dysfunction may be seen in more than one-half of long-term HSCT survivors, and the course of the disease appears to be indolent, continued follow-up is needed to establish its long-term impact on survivor health.[<a href="#cit/section_5.75">

1005175</a>

10052]</li>

10053</ul>

10054</div>

10055</section>

10056</section>

10057<section id="_1182">

10058<h4 id="_1182_toc">

10059Infectious risk factors for hepatobiliary late effects</h4>

10060<p id="_411" tabindex="-1">

10061 Viral hepatitis B and C may complicate the treatment course of childhood cancer and result in chronic hepatic dysfunction.</p>

10062<div class="pdq-content-list">

10063<ul id="_2590">

10064<li>

10065Hepatitis B tends to have a more aggressive acute clinical course and a lower rate of chronic infection.</li>

10066<li>

10067 Hepatitis C is characterized by a mild acute infection and a high rate of chronic infection.</li>

10068<li>

10069 The incidence of transfusion-related hepatitis C in childhood cancer survivors has ranged from 5% to 50% depending on the geographic location of the reporting center.[<a href="#cit/section_5.76">

1007076</a>

10071-<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

1007282</a>

10073] </li>

10074<li>

10075Chronic hepatitis predisposes the childhood cancer survivor to cirrhosis, end-stage liver disease, and hepatocellular carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

1007680</a>

10077,<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

1007881</a>

10079] </li>

10080<li>

10081Concurrent infection with hepatitis B and C in combination or in co-occurrence with other hepatotrophic viruses accelerates the progression of liver disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.77">

1008277</a>

10083,<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

1008479</a>

10085]</li>

10086<li>

10087Because most patients received some type of blood product during childhood cancer treatment and many are unaware of their transfusion history, screening on the basis of date of diagnosis/treatment is recommended unless there is absolute certainty that the patient did not receive any blood or blood products.[<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

1008883</a>

10089]</li>

10090<li>

10091All survivors of childhood cancer who received treatment before 1972 should be screened for hepatitis B, and those who received treatment before 1993 should be screened for hepatitis C and referred for discussion of treatment options if screening results are positive.[<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

1009283</a>

10093]</li>

10094</ul>

10095</div>

10096</section>

10097<section id="_1204">

10098<h4 id="_1204_toc">

10099Posttherapy management</h4>

10100<p id="_415" tabindex="-1">

10101Survivors with liver dysfunction should be counseled regarding risk-reduction methods to prevent hepatic injury.</p>

10102<div class="pdq-content-list">

10103<ul id="_2591">

10104<li>

10105 Standard recommendations include maintenance of a healthy body weight, abstinence from alcohol use, and immunization against hepatitis A and B viruses.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

1010645</a>

10107]</li>

10108<li>

10109 In patients with chronic hepatitis, precautions to reduce viral transmission to household and sexual contacts should also be reviewed.</li>

10110</ul>

10111</div>

10112<p id="_1722" tabindex="-1">

10113<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_418">

10114Table 7</a>

10115 summarizes hepatobiliary late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

10116</section>

10117<table id="_418" class="table-default expandable-container">

10118<caption>

10119Table 7. Hepatobiliary Late Effects<span class="sup">

10120a</span>

10121</caption>

10122<colgroup>

10123<col width="33.33%">

10124<col width="33.33%">

10125<col width="33.33%">

10126</colgroup>

10127<THead>

10128<tr>

10129<th>

10130Predisposing Therapy</th>

10131<th>

10132Hepatic Effects</th>

10133<th>

10134Health Screening/Interventions</th>

10135</tr>

10136</THead>

10137<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

10138<tr>

10139<td colspan="3">

10140ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; HSCT = hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.</td>

10141</tr>

10142<tr>

10143<td colspan="3">

10144<span class="sup">

10145a</span>

10146Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

10147Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

10148.</td>

10149</tr>

10150</TFoot>

10151<tbody>

10152<tr>

10153<td rowspan="2">

10154Methotrexate;

10155mercaptopurine/thioguanine;

10156HSCT</td>

10157<td rowspan="2">

10158Hepatic dysfunction

10159</td>

10160<td>

10161Lab: ALT, AST, bilirubin levels</td>

10162</tr>

10163<tr>

10164<td>

10165Ferritin in those treated with HSCT</td>

10166</tr>

10167<tr>

10168<td rowspan="3">

10169Mercaptopurine/thioguanine;

10170HSCT</td>

10171<td rowspan="3">

10172Veno-occlusive disease/sinusoidal obstructive syndrome

10173</td>

10174<td>

10175Exam: scleral icterus, jaundice, ascites, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly</td>

10176</tr>

10177<tr>

10178<td>

10179Lab: ALT, AST, bilirubin, platelet levels </td>

10180</tr>

10181<tr>

10182<td>

10183Ferritin in those treated with HSCT</td>

10184</tr>

10185<tr>

10186<td rowspan="8">

10187Radiation exposing liver/biliary tract;

10188HSCT</td>

10189<td rowspan="8">

10190Hepatic fibrosis/cirrhosis; focal nodular hyperplasia

10191</td>

10192<td>

10193Exam: jaundice, spider angiomas, palmar erythema, xanthomata, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly</td>

10194</tr>

10195<tr>

10196<td>

10197Lab: ALT, AST, bilirubin levels</td>

10198</tr>

10199<tr>

10200<td>

10201Ferritin in those treated with HSCT</td>

10202</tr>

10203<tr>

10204<td>

10205Prothrombin time for evaluation of hepatic synthetic function in patients with abnormal liver screening tests</td>

10206</tr>

10207<tr>

10208<td>

10209Screen for viral hepatitis in patients with persistently abnormal liver function or any patient transfused before 1993</td>

10210</tr>

10211<tr>

10212<td>

10213Gastroenterology/hepatology

10214consultation in patients with persistent liver dysfunction</td>

10215</tr>

10216<tr>

10217<td>

10218Hepatitis A and B immunizations in patients lacking immunity</td>

10219</tr>

10220<tr>

10221<td>

10222Consider phlebotomy and chelation therapy for iron overload</td>

10223</tr>

10224<tr>

10225<td rowspan="3">

10226Radiation exposing liver/biliary tract </td>

10227<td rowspan="3">

10228Cholelithiasis</td>

10229<td>

10230History: colicky abdominal pain related to fatty food intake, excessive flatulence</td>

10231</tr>

10232<tr>

10233<td>

10234Exam: right upper quadrant or epigastric tenderness (acute episode)</td>

10235</tr>

10236<tr>

10237<td>

10238Consider gallbladder ultrasound in patients with chronic abdominal pain</td>

10239</tr>

10240</tbody>

10241</table>

10242</section>

10243<section id="_769">

10244<h3 id="_769_toc">

10245Pancreas</h3>

10246<p id="_770" tabindex="-1">

10247The pancreas has been thought to be relatively radioresistant because of a paucity of information about late pancreatic-related effects. However, children and young adults treated with TBI or abdominal irradiation are known to have an increased risk of insulin resistance and diabetes mellitus.[<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

1024884</a>

10249-<a href="#cit/section_5.86">

1025086</a>

10251]</p>

10252<p id="_2592" tabindex="-1">

10253 While corticosteroids and asparaginase are associated with acute toxicity to the pancreas, late sequelae in the form of exocrine or endocrine pancreatic function for those who sustain acute injury have not been reported.</p>

10254<p id="_1253" tabindex="-1">

10255Evidence (risk of diabetes mellitus):</p>

10256<div class="pdq-content-list">

10257<ol id="_1904">

10258<li>

10259A retrospective cohort study, based on self-reports of 2,520 5-year survivors of childhood cancer treated in France and the United Kingdom, investigated the relationship between radiation dose to the pancreas and risk of a subsequent diabetes mellitus diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_5.87">

1026087</a>

10261]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10262<ul id="_1905">

10263<li>

10264 Sixty-five cases of diabetes mellitus were validated; the risk increased with radiation therapy to the tail of the pancreas, where the islets of Langerhans are concentrated. Risk increased up to 20 to 29 Gy and then plateaued. The estimated RR at 1 Gy was 1.61.</li>

10265<li>

10266Radiation dose to other parts of the pancreas did not have a significant effect.</li>

10267<li>

10268Compared with patients who did not receive radiation therapy, the RR of diabetes mellitus was 11.5 in patients who received more than 10 Gy to the pancreas.</li>

10269<li>

10270Children younger than 2 years at the time of radiation therapy were more sensitive than were older patients (RR at 1 Gy was 2.1 for the young age group vs. 1.4 for older patients).</li>

10271<li>

10272For the 511 patients who received more than 10 Gy, the cumulative incidence of diabetes mellitus was 16%.</li>

10273</ul>

10274</div>

10275</li>

10276<li>

10277Another study evaluated the risk of diabetes mellitus in 2,264 5-year survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma (42% younger than 25 years at diagnosis) after a median follow-up of 21.5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

1027888</a>

10279]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10280<ul id="_1906">

10281<li>

10282The cumulative incidence of diabetes mellitus was 8.3% (95% CI, 6.9%&#8211;9.8%) for the overall cohort and 14.2% (95% CI, 10.7%&#8211;18.3%) for those treated with more than 36 Gy para-aortic radiation.</li>

10283<li>

10284Survivors treated with more than 36 Gy of radiation to the para-aortic lymph nodes and spleen had a 2.3-fold increased risk of diabetes mellitus compared with those who did not receive radiation therapy.</li>

10285<li>

10286The risk of diabetes mellitus increased with higher doses to the pancreatic tail.</li>

10287</ul>

10288</div>

10289</li>

10290<li>

10291CCSS investigators evaluated the risk of diabetes mellitus among 20,762 5-year childhood cancer survivors and 4,853 siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

1029289</a>

10293]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10294<ul id="_2168">

10295<li>

10296 Survivors exposed to abdominal radiation (n = 4,568) were almost three times more likely to develop diabetes than were siblings and 1.6 times more likely than survivors who were not exposed to abdominal radiation.</li>

10297<li>

10298Among survivors treated with abdominal radiation therapy, multivariable modeling identified independent risk factors for developing diabetes, which included older attained age, higher BMI, and increasing dose to the pancreatic tail. </li>

10299<li>

10300A significant interaction was also identified between younger age (&lt;10 years) at cancer diagnosis and higher mean pancreatic tail dose.</li>

10301</ul>

10302</div>

10303</li>

10304<li>

10305St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for diabetes mellitus among 1,044 adult survivors of childhood ALL (mean age, 34 years) who were clinically assessed more than 10 years after treatment and 368 community controls (mean age, 35 years).[<a href="#cit/section_5.90">

1030690</a>

10307]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10308<ul id="_2186">

10309<li>

10310Type 2 diabetes mellitus was prevalent in 7.5% of survivors and 3.8% of controls.</li>

10311<li>

10312Independent risk factors for developing diabetes among survivors included older age (OR, 1.05 for each additional year), BMI of 30 kg/m<span class="sup">

103132</span>

10314 or higher (OR, 7.4), and history of drug-induced hyperglycemia during therapy (OR, 4.67).</li>

10315</ul>

10316</div>

10317</li>

10318</ol>

10319</div>

10320</section>

10321<p id="_436" tabindex="-1">

10322For digestive system late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

10323Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

10324.</p>

10325<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10346[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10347</li>

10348<li id="section_5.6">

10349Hsieh SG, Hibbert S, Shaw P, et al.: Association of cyclophosphamide use with dental developmental defects and salivary gland dysfunction in recipients of childhood antineoplastic therapy. Cancer 117 (10): 2219-27, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21523736&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21523736&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10350[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10351</li>

10352<li id="section_5.7">

10353Dahll&#246;f G: Oral and dental late effects after pediatric stem cell transplantation. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 14 (1 Suppl 1): 81-3, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18162225&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18162225&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10354[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10355</li>

10356<li id="section_5.8">

10357H&#246;ltt&#228; P, Alaluusua S, Saarinen-Pihkala UM, et al.: Long-term adverse effects on dentition in children with poor-risk neuroblastoma treated with high-dose chemotherapy and autologous stem cell transplantation with or without total body irradiation. Bone Marrow Transplant 29 (2): 121-7, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11850706&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11850706&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10358[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10359</li>
