10695 <section id="_66">

10696

10697 <h2>

10698Late Effects of the Endocrine System</h2>

10699

10700 <div id="_section_66" class="pdq-sections">

10701<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

10702<h6>

10703In This Section</h6>

10704<ul>

10705<li>

10706<a href="#_67_toc">

10707Thyroid Gland<ul>

10708<li>

10709<a href="#_802_toc">

10710Hypothyroidism</a>

10711</li>

10712<li>

10713<a href="#_2323_toc">

10714Hyperthyroidism</a>

10715</li>

10716<li>

10717<a href="#_807_toc">

10718Thyroid nodules</a>

10719</li>

10720<li>

10721<a href="#_2205_toc">

10722Screening for thyroid cancer</a>

10723</li>

10724<li>

10725<a href="#_812_toc">

10726Posttransplant thyroid dysfunction</a>

10727</li>

10728</ul>

10729</a>

10730</li>

10731<li>

10732<a href="#_603_toc">

10733Hypothalamus-Pituitary Axis<ul>

10734<li>

10735<a href="#_1292_toc">

10736Central diabetes insipidus</a>

10737</li>

10738<li>

10739<a href="#_1294_toc">

10740Anterior pituitary hormone deficiency</a>

10741</li>

10742<li>

10743<a href="#_607_toc">

10744Growth hormone deficiency</a>

10745</li>

10746<li>

10747<a href="#_613_toc">

10748Disorders of LH and FSH</a>

10749</li>

10750<li>

10751<a href="#_615_toc">

10752TSH deficiency</a>

10753</li>

10754<li>

10755<a href="#_618_toc">

10756ACTH deficiency</a>

10757</li>

10758<li>

10759<a href="#_620_toc">

10760Hyperprolactinemia</a>

10761</li>

10762</ul>

10763</a>

10764</li>

10765<li>

10766<a href="#_629_toc">

10767Testis and Ovary</a>

10768</li>

10769<li>

10770<a href="#_623_toc">

10771Metabolic Syndrome<ul>

10772<li>

10773<a href="#_2381_toc">

10774 Lifestyle impact on modifiable risk factors</a>

10775</li>

10776<li>

10777<a href="#_1355_toc">

10778Abnormal glucose metabolism</a>

10779</li>

10780</ul>

10781</a>

10782</li>

10783<li>

10784<a href="#_640_toc">

10785Body Composition: Underweight, Overweight, and Obesity<ul>

10786<li>

10787<a href="#_2383_toc">

10788Underweight</a>

10789</li>

10790<li>

10791<a href="#_2385_toc">

10792Overweight/obesity</a>

10793</li>

10794<li>

10795<a href="#_1298_toc">

10796Body composition alterations after childhood ALL</a>

10797</li>

10798<li>

10799<a href="#_1301_toc">

10800Body composition alterations after treatment for CNS tumors</a>

10801</li>

10802<li>

10803<a href="#_1303_toc">

10804Body composition alterations after HSCT</a>

10805</li>

10806<li>

10807<a href="#_2900_toc">

10808Body composition alterations after solid malignancies</a>

10809</li>

10810<li>

10811<a href="#_1305_toc">

10812Body composition and frailty</a>

10813</li>

10814</ul>

10815</a>

10816</li>

10817</ul>

10818</nav>

10819<p id="_1476" tabindex="-1">

10820Endocrine dysfunction is common among survivors of childhood cancer, especially in those who were treated with surgery or radiation therapy that involved hormone-producing organs and those who received alkylating agent chemotherapy.</p>

10821<p id="_1477" tabindex="-1">

10822<figure id="figure_1418" class="image-center">

10823<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/767820.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

10824Enlarge</a>

10825<img id="_1418" alt="Chart showing the prevalence of endocrine disorders at the last follow-up visit by gender." title="Chart showing the prevalence of endocrine disorders at the last follow-up visit by gender." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/767820-750.jpg">

10826<figcaption class="caption-container">

10827Figure 8. Prevalence of endocrine disorders at the last follow-up visit, by sex. Brignardello E, Felicetti F, Castiglione A, et al.: Endocrine health conditions in adult survivors of childhood cancer: the need for specialized adult-focused follow-up clinics. European Journal of Endocrinology 168 (3): 465-472, 2013. Copyright &#169; 2013, European Society of Endocrinology.</figcaption>

10828</figure>

10829</p>

10830<p id="_1478" tabindex="-1">

10831The prevalence of specific endocrine disorders is affected by the following:[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

108321</a>

10833-<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

108344</a>

10835] </p>

10836<div class="pdq-content-list">

10837<ul id="_1652">

10838<li>

10839<strong>

10840Patient factors</strong>

10841 (e.g., age at treatment and sex).</li>

10842<li>

10843<strong>

10844Treatment factors</strong>

10845 (e.g., radiation dose and treatment volume).</li>

10846<li>

10847<strong>

10848Time from radiation exposure</strong>

10849 (typically increases with longer time from radiation exposure [see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1477">

10850Figure 8</a>

10851]).[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

108521</a>

10853]</li>

10854</ul>

10855</div>

10856<p id="_1653" tabindex="-1">

10857Endocrinologic late effects can be broadly categorized as those resulting from hypothalamic-pituitary injury or from peripheral glandular compromise.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

108581</a>

10859-<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

108604</a>

10861] The former are most common after treatment for central nervous system (CNS) tumors. The prevalence of these late effects was 24.8% in a nationwide cohort study of 718 survivors who lived longer than 2 years and all hypothalamic-pituitary axes were affected.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

108623</a>

10863]</p>

10864<p id="_1654" tabindex="-1">

10865The following sections summarize research that characterizes the clinical features of survivors at risk of endocrine dysfunction that impacts pituitary, thyroid, adrenal, and gonadal function.</p>

10866<section id="_67">

10867<h3 id="_67_toc">

10868Thyroid Gland</h3>

10869<div class="pdq-content-list">

10870<ul id="_2348">

10871<li>

10872Thyroid dysfunction is a common delayed effect after radiation therapy exposures to fields that include the thyroid gland. This type of radiation therapy is used in treating Hodgkin lymphoma, brain tumors, head and neck sarcomas, and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).</li>

10873<li>

10874 There is considerable evidence linking radiation exposure to thyroid abnormalities. However, the prevalence of specific conditions varies widely because studies are limited by cohort selection and participation bias, heterogeneity in radiation treatment approach, time since radiation exposure, and method of ascertainment (e.g., self-report vs. clinical or diagnostic imaging assessment).</li>

10875<li>

10876Thyroid abnormalities observed in excess in childhood cancer survivors include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

10877<ul id="_2349">

10878<li>

10879Primary hypothyroidism.</li>

10880<li>

10881Hyperthyroidism.</li>

10882<li>

10883Goiter.</li>

10884<li>

10885Nodules.</li>

10886</ul>

10887</div>

10888</li>

10889</ul>

10890</div>

10891<section id="_802">

10892<h4 id="_802_toc">

10893Hypothyroidism</h4>

10894<section id="_2316">

10895<h5 id="_2316_toc">

10896Risk factors</h5>

10897<p id="_2317" tabindex="-1">

10898<strong>

10899Thyroid radiation therapy.</strong>

10900 An increased risk of hypothyroidism has been reported among childhood cancer survivors treated with head and neck radiation exposing the thyroid gland, especially among survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

109011</a>

10902-<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

109034</a>

10904] </p>

10905<p id="_2318" tabindex="-1">

10906<strong>

10907Iodine I 131-metaiodobenzylguanidine (131I-MIBG).</strong>

10908 </p>

10909<div class="pdq-content-list">

10910<ul id="_3016">

10911<li>

10912<strong>

10913Therapeutic 131I-MIBG.</strong>

10914 Thyroid disorders, including primary hypothyroidism, have been reported in children with neuroblastoma who were treated with 131I-MIBG, despite thyroid protection with potassium iodide, perchlorate, or the combination of potassium iodide, thyroxine (T<sub>

109154</sub>

10916), and a thiamazole. However, these reports feature small numbers of patients who have other treatment-related risk factors for thyroid disorders, which limits the ability to identify an independent effect of 131I-MIBG.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

109175</a>

10918] Thyroid disorders were diagnosed in 81% of survivors 15 years after treatment with 131I-MIBG.[<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

109196</a>

10920]</li>

10921<li>

10922<strong>

10923Diagnostic 131I-MIBG.</strong>

10924 Late-onset thyroid abnormalities have not been reported among childhood cancer survivors who had either 131I-MIBG or 123I-MIBG to monitor disease status.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

109257</a>

10926,<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

109278</a>

10928]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10929<ul id="_3007">

10930<li>

10931A retrospective cohort study (n = 48) assessed the prevalence of thyroid dysfunction in survivors of a neuroblastic tumor who received 123I-MIBG for diagnostic purposes. All patients received thyroid prophylaxis (potassium iodide or combination of potassium iodide, thiamazole, and T<sub>

109324</sub>

10933) during exposure to 123I-MIBG. After a median follow up of 6.6 years, thyroid function was normal in 46 of the 48 survivors. Two survivors had mild thyroid dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

109349</a>

10935]</li>

10936</ul>

10937</div>

10938</li>

10939</ul>

10940</div>

10941<p id="_2981" tabindex="-1">

10942<strong>

10943Thyroidectomy.</strong>

10944 As observed in the general, noncancer population, partial or obviously subtotal surgical resection of the thyroid is a risk factor for subsequent hypothyroidism.[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

1094510</a>

10946-<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

1094712</a>

10948]</p>

10949<p id="_1655" tabindex="-1">

10950Evidence (prevalence of and risk factors for hypothyroidism):</p>

10951<div class="pdq-content-list">

10952<ol id="_1656">

10953<li>

10954The German Group of Paediatric Radiation Oncology reported on 1,086 patients treated at 62 centers, including 404 patients (median age, 10.9 years) who received radiation therapy to the thyroid and/or pituitary gland.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

1095513</a>

10956] Follow-up information was available for 264 patients (60.9%; median follow-up, 40 months), with 60 patients (22.7%) showing pathological values.<div class="pdq-content-list">

10957<ul id="_1657">

10958<li>

10959Compared with patients treated with prophylactic cranial irradiation (median dose, 12 Gy), the hazard ratio (HR) for the development of pathological thyroid blood values was 3.072 (<em>

10960P</em>

10961 = .002) for patients treated with radiation doses of 15 Gy to 25 Gy to the thyroid gland. </li>

10962<li>

10963The HR was 3.769 (<em>

10964P</em>

10965 = .009) for patients treated with more than 25 Gy of radiation to the thyroid gland. The HR was 5.674 (<em>

10966P</em>

10967 &lt; .001) for patients treated with craniospinal irradiation (CSI).</li>

10968<li>

10969The cumulative incidence of thyroid hormone substitution therapy did not differ between defined subgroups.</li>

10970</ul>

10971</div>

10972</li>

10973<li>

10974The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) investigated the prevalence of self-reported hypothyroidism assessed through serial questionnaires in 12,015 survivors. A total of 1,193 cases of hypothyroidism were observed, 777 (65%) of which occurred 5 or more years after a cancer diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

1097514</a>

10976]<div class="pdq-content-list">

10977<ul id="_2322">

10978<li>

10979The prevalence at 5 years after a cancer diagnosis and the incidence through 30 years after a cancer diagnosis was the highest in 5-year survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma (32.3%) and CNS tumors (17.7%).</li>

10980<li>

10981The incidence was significantly associated with radiation dose to the thyroid and pituitary. The combined effects of thyroid and hypothalamic-pituitary doses appear to be less than additive when pituitary doses are greater than 16 Gy.</li>

10982<li>

10983Radiation-related risks were higher in males than females and inversely associated with age at exposure and time since exposure but remained elevated more than 25 years after exposure.</li>

10984<li>

10985Certain types of chemotherapy were significantly associated with the risk: bleomycin (rate ratio, 3.4), and the alkylating agents lomustine (rate ratio, 3.0) and cyclophosphamide (rate ratio, 1.3). The strongest chemotherapy-associated risk occurred among survivors of CNS cancer. A significant dose response for lomustine was observed (<em>

10986P</em>

10987 &lt; .01).</li>

10988</ul>

10989</div>

10990</li>

10991<li>

10992In the CCSS, a cohort of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma survivors treated between 1970 and 1986 were evaluated for thyroid disease by use of a self-report questionnaire.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

1099315</a>

10994] <div class="pdq-content-list">

10995<ul id="_2351">

10996<li>

10997Among 1,791 survivors who were followed for a median of 14 years, 34% reported that they had been diagnosed with at least one thyroid abnormality.</li>

10998<li>

10999For hypothyroidism, there was a clear dose response, with a 20-year risk of:<div class="pdq-content-list">

11000<ul id="_1659">

11001<li>

1100220% for those who received less than 35 Gy of radiation to the thyroid gland.</li>

11003<li>

1100430% for those who received 35 Gy to 44.9 Gy of radiation to the thyroid gland.</li>

11005<li>

1100650% for those who received more than 45 Gy of radiation to the thyroid gland. </li>

11007</ul>

11008</div>

11009</li>

11010<li>

11011Compared with a sibling control group, the relative risk (RR) was 17.1 for hypothyroidism.</li>

11012<li>

11013Elapsed time since diagnosis was a risk factor for hypothyroidism, with the risk increasing in the first 3 to 5 years postdiagnosis.</li>

11014<li>

11015 Females were at increased risk for hypothyroidism.</li>

11016</ul>

11017</div>

11018</li>

11019<li>

11020A follow-up study from the CCSS compared self-reported data from 14,290 survivors with data from 4,031 sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

110212</a>

11022] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11023<ul id="_1660">

11024<li>

11025The RR was 3.8 for hypothyroidism and remained significantly higher in survivors when compared with controls, even in the absence of radiation therapy to the thyroid or pituitary.</li>

11026<li>

11027These results indicate the need for continued and individualized long-term monitoring strategies in childhood cancer survivors.</li>

11028</ul>

11029</div>

11030</li>

11031<li>

11032Continuous improvements in the precision of radiation therapy delivery carry the promise to decrease the radiation therapy dose received by the thyroid in a subset of patients. This was demonstrated in a study of 189 children and young adults (aged &lt;26 years) with brain tumors treated with proton radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

1103316</a>

11034]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11035<ul id="_2201">

11036<li>

11037At a median follow-up of 4.4 years, the cumulative incidence of primary hypothyroidism was 3% after CSI and 1.6% overall, which is substantially lower than previous reports of 56% to 65% incidence after CSI with photons.</li>

11038</ul>

11039</div>

11040</li>

11041<li>

11042Among 118 survivors of medulloblastoma (median follow-up, 5.6 years), the estimated cumulative incidence of hypothyroidism was 35.8% (95% confidence interval [CI], 26.7%&#8211;47.1%) by 5 years after radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

1104317</a>

11044] <div class="pdq-content-list">

11045<ul id="_2967">

11046<li>

11047The median time from the end of radiation therapy to the development of hypothyroidism was 2.1 years (range, 0.1&#8211;7.1 years) after proton radiation therapy and 2.9 years (range, 0.8&#8211;7.2 years) after photon radiation therapy. </li>

11048<li>

11049The rate of hypothyroidism (HR, 2.36; 95% CI, 1.11&#8211;5.02) was higher among patients treated with photon radiation therapy compared with those treated with proton radiation therapy. </li>

11050<li>

11051Differences in hypothyroidism risk by radiation modality were largely attributed to higher rates of primary hypothyroidism after photon radiation therapy (HR, 4.61; 95% CI, 1.20&#8211;17.66).</li>

11052</ul>

11053</div>

11054</li>

11055<li>

11056St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for primary hypothyroidism and its associations with chronic health conditions and quality of life among 2,965 childhood cancer survivors (median age, 30.9 years; median time postdiagnosis, 22.3 years).[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

1105712</a>

11058]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11059<ul id="_2925">

11060<li>

11061Primary hypothyroidism was prevalent in 14.7% of survivors. It was more common in females (odds ratio [OR], 1.06; 95% CI, 1.03&#8211;1.08) and survivors diagnosed older than 15 years (vs. age &lt;5 years). It was less common in non-White survivors (OR, 0.96; 95% CI, 0.93&#8211;0.99).</li>

11062<li>

11063Radiation therapy potentially exposing the thyroid gland was associated with dose-related risk of hypothyroidism.</li>

11064<li>

11065Significant associations with primary hypothyroidism included frailty (OR, 1.54; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;2.26), dyslipidemia (OR, 1.52; 95% CI, 1.14&#8211;2.04), and impaired physical quality of life (OR, 1.66; 95% CI, 1.12&#8211;2.48).</li>

11066</ul>

11067</div>

11068</li>

11069<li>

11070The Pediatric Normal Tissue Effects in the Clinic (PENTEC) research consortium performed a systematic review of radiation-associated primary hypothyroidism in children younger than 21 years between 1970 and 2017.[<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

1107118</a>

11072]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11073<ul id="_2968">

11074<li>

11075At mean doses of 10 Gy, 20 Gy, and 30 Gy, predicted rates of uncompensated (clinical) hypothyroidism were 4%, 7%, and 13%, respectively. The compensated (subclinical) hypothyroidism rates were 12%, 25% and 44%, respectively.</li>

11076<li>

11077Female sex (RR, 1.7; <em>

11078P</em>

11079 &lt; .0001) and age younger than 15 years at the time of radiation therapy (RR, 1.3; <em>

11080P</em>

11081 &lt; .005) were associated with higher risks of hypothyroidism.</li>

11082<li>

11083After a mean thyroid dose of 20 Gy, predicted rates of hypothyroidism were 13% for males younger than 14 years and more than 29% for females older than 15 years at the time of radiation therapy.</li>

11084</ul>

11085</div>

11086<table id="_3025" class="table-default expandable-container">

11087<caption>

11088Table 8. Risks of Hypothyroidism (Compensated or Uncompensated) After Radiation Therapy for Pediatric Malignancies, Grouped by Mean Thyroid Dose, Age, and Sex<span class="sup">

11089a</span>

11092<col width="20.00%">

11097</colgroup>

11148</tr>

1119747%</td>

11198</tr>

11199</tbody>

11200</table>

11201</li>

11202</ol>

11203</div>

11204</section>

11205<section id="_2319">

11206<h5 id="_2319_toc">

11207Clinical presentation</h5>

11208<div class="pdq-content-list">

11209<ul id="_2350">

11210<li>

11211Most children treated with radiation therapy who develop hypothyroidism do so within the first 2 to 5 years posttreatment, but new cases can occur later. </li>

11212<li>

11213Reports of thyroid dysfunction differ depending on the dose of radiation, the length of follow-up, and the biochemical criteria used to make the diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.19">

1121419</a>

11215]</li>

11216<li>

11217 The most frequently reported abnormalities include the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

11218<ul id="_2321">

11219<li>

11220Elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).</li>

11221<li>

11222Depressed T<sub>

112234</sub>

11224.</li>

11225<li>

11226Elevated TSH and depressed T<sub>

112274</sub>

11228.</li>

11229</ul>

11230</div>

11231</li>

11232<li>

11233Central hypothyroidism results from radiation exposure of the hypothalamic pituitary axis; there is typically a low free T<sub>

112344</sub>

11235 in conjunction with low TSH.</li>

11236<li>

11237Compensated hypothyroidism includes an elevated TSH with a normal T<sub>

112384</sub>

11239 and is asymptomatic. The natural history is unclear, but most endocrinologists support treatment. </li>

11240<li>

11241Uncompensated hypothyroidism includes both an elevated TSH and a depressed T<sub>

112424</sub>

11243.</li>

11244<li>

11245Thyroid hormone replacement is beneficial for correction of the metabolic abnormality, and has clinical benefits for cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, and neurocognitive function. </li>

11246</ul>

11247</div>

11248</section>

11249</section>

11250<section id="_2323">

11251<h4 id="_2323_toc">

11252Hyperthyroidism</h4>

11253<p id="_2324" tabindex="-1">

11254While less common than hypothyroidism, childhood cancer survivors also experience an increased risk of hyperthyroidism.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

112552</a>

11256,<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

1125715</a>

11258,<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

1125920</a>

11260,<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

1126121</a>

11262]</p>

11263<p id="_2352" tabindex="-1">

11264Evidence (prevalence of and risk factors for hyperthyroidism):</p>

11265<div class="pdq-content-list">

11266<ol id="_2353">

11267<li>

11268CCSS investigators evaluated the prevalence of thyroid disease among 1,791 childhood Hodgkin lymphoma survivors treated between 1970 and 1986 and followed for a median of 14 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

1126915</a>

11270]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11271<ul id="_2354">

11272<li>

11273Hyperthyroidism was reported by 5% of survivors, which was eightfold greater than the incidence reported by the controls. </li>

11274<li>

11275Radiation dose of 35 Gy or more to the thyroid was the only risk factor identified for hyperthyroidism. </li>

11276</ul>

11277</div>

11278</li>

11279<li>

11280Another CCSS study evaluated the risk of hyperthyroidism in relation to incidental therapeutic radiation dose to the thyroid and pituitary glands.[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

1128120</a>

11282]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11283<ul id="_2355">

11284<li>

11285Hyperthyroidism was self-reported by 179 survivors, with 148 cases diagnosed 5 or more years after cancer diagnosis.</li>

11286<li>

11287The cumulative proportion of survivors with hyperthyroidism by 30 years after cancer diagnosis was 2.5% (95% CI, 2.0%&#8211;2.9%).</li>

11288<li>

11289Thyroid radiation increased the risk of hyperthyroidism with evidence of a linear thyroid radiation dose-response over the dose range of 0 Gy to 63 Gy. </li>

11290<li>

11291Radiation to the pituitary gland and chemotherapy were not significantly associated with hyperthyroidism. </li>

11292<li>

11293Radiation-associated risk of hyperthyroidism remained elevated longer than 25 years after exposure. </li>

11294</ul>

11295</div>

11296</li>

11297</ol>

11298</div>

11299</section>

11300<section id="_807">

11301<h4 id="_807_toc">

11302Thyroid nodules</h4>

11303<p id="_2202" tabindex="-1">

11304The clinical manifestation of thyroid neoplasia among childhood cancer survivors ranges from asymptomatic, small, solitary nodules to large, intrathoracic goiters that compress adjacent structures.</p>

11305<p id="_1277" tabindex="-1">

11306The following factors are linked to an increased risk of thyroid nodule development: </p>

11307<div class="pdq-content-list">

11308<ul id="_2779">

11309<li>

11310<strong>

11311Radiation dose, time from diagnosis, and female sex. </strong>

11312<div class="pdq-content-list">

11313<ul id="_2329">

11314<li>

11315Any radiation field that includes the thyroid is associated with an excess risk of thyroid neoplasms, which may be benign (usually adenomas) or malignant (most often differentiated papillary carcinoma).[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

113162</a>

11317,<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

1131815</a>

11319,<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

1132022</a>

11321-<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

1132225</a>

11323]</li>

11324<li>

11325A CCSS study that included survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma identified time from diagnosis, female sex, and radiation dose of 25 Gy or higher as significant risk factors for thyroid nodule development.[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

1132615</a>

11327]</li>

11328<li>

11329 Based on a cohort of 3,254 2-year childhood cancer survivors treated before 1986 and monitored for 25 years, the risk of thyroid adenoma increased with the size of the radiation dose to the thyroid during childhood cancer treatment and plateaued at doses exceeding 10 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

1133023</a>

11331]</li>

11332<li>

11333 CCSS investigators performed a nested case-control study to evaluate the magnitude of risk for thyroid cancer over the therapeutic radiation dose range of pediatric cancers. The risk of thyroid cancer increased with radiation doses up to 20 Gy to 29 Gy (OR, 9.8; 95% CI, 3.2&#8211;34.8), but declined at doses higher than 30 Gy, consistent with a cell-killing effect.[<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

1133425</a>

11335]</li>

11336</ul>

11337</div>

11338</li>

11339<li>

11340<strong>

11341Age at time of radiation therapy.</strong>

11342<div class="pdq-content-list">

11343<ul id="_2330">

11344<li>

11345 Based on the same cohort of 3,254 2-year childhood cancer survivors, the risk of thyroid adenoma per unit of radiation dose to the thyroid was higher if radiation therapy had been delivered before age 5 years. The risk was also higher in individuals who were younger than 40 years at the time of the study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

1134623</a>

11347] </li>

11348<li>

11349Younger age at time of radiation therapy has also been linked to an excess risk of thyroid carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

1135022</a>

11351-<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

1135225</a>

11353]</li>

11354</ul>

11355</div>

11356</li>

11357<li>

11358<strong>

11359Exposure to 131I-MIBG. </strong>

11360<div class="pdq-content-list">

11361<ul id="_2331">

11362<li>

11363During childhood and adolescence, there is an increased risk of developing thyroid nodules, and potentially thyroid cancer, in patients exposed to 131I-MIBG. </li>

11364<li>

11365Clinicians caring for survivors treated with 131I-MIBG should be aware of the risks of developing thyroid dysfunction, thyroid nodules, and thyroid cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

1136626</a>

11367]</li>

11368</ul>

11369</div>

11370</li>

11371<li>

11372<strong>

11373Chemotherapy.</strong>

11374<div class="pdq-content-list">

11375<ul id="_2332">

11376<li>

11377 An increased risk of thyroid nodules and cancer has also been observed in association with chemotherapy, independent of radiation exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

113782</a>

11379,<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

1138022</a>

11381,<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

1138223</a>

11383]</li>

11384<li>

11385In a pooled study of two cohorts of 16,757 survivors that included 187 patients with secondary thyroid cancer, treatments with alkylating agents, anthracyclines, or bleomycin were associated with a significantly increased risk of thyroid cancer in individuals not exposed to radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.27">

1138627</a>

11387] </li>

11388<li>

11389 In the CCSS, the rate ratio of developing thyroid cancer was 2.5 (<em>

11390P</em>

11391 &lt; .01) in survivors not treated with thyroid radiation when compared with sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

113922</a>

11393] </li>

11394<li>

11395 Areas of active research include defining the precise role of exposure to chemotherapy and developing risk prediction models for thyroid cancer in childhood cancer survivors on the basis of demographic and treatment-related risk factors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

1139628</a>

11397]</li>

11398</ul>

11399</div>

11400</li>

11401</ul>

11402</div>

11403</section>

11404<section id="_2205">

11405<h4 id="_2205_toc">

11406Screening for thyroid cancer</h4>

11407<div class="pdq-content-list">

11408<ul id="_2206">

11409<li>

11410Several studies have demonstrated that ultrasonography is superior to clinical examination for detecting thyroid nodules and thyroid cancers, and they have characterized ultrasonographic features of nodules that are more likely to be malignant.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

1141129</a>

11412-<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

1141331</a>

11414]</li>

11415<li>

11416 Primary screening for thyroid neoplasia (beyond physical examination with thyroid palpation) remains controversial because of the lack of data indicating a survival benefit and quality-of-life benefit associated with early detection and intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

1141732</a>

11418] </li>

11419<li>

11420Because these lesions tend to be indolent, are rarely life-threatening, and may clinically manifest many years after exposure to radiation, there are significant concerns regarding the costs and harms of overscreening.[<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

1142133</a>

11422]</li>

11423<li>

11424Expert panels have refrained from specifically endorsing or discouraging the use of ultrasonography as a screening tool for thyroid cancer and this continues to be an active area of investigation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

1142534</a>

11426]</li>

11427<li>

11428 Following a systematic assessment of the evidence, the International Guideline Harmonization Group concluded that initiation of surveillance and the type of surveillance modality (thyroid palpation vs. ultrasonography) should be determined by shared decision-making between the health care provider and survivor after carefully considering the benefits and harms. A decision aid to facilitate discussion accompanies their recommendations.[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

1142932</a>

11430]</li>

11431</ul>

11432</div>

11433<p id="_811" tabindex="-1">

11434For information about subsequent thyroid cancers, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_116">

11435Subsequent Neoplasms</a>

11436 section.</p>

11437</section>

11438<section id="_812">

11439<h4 id="_812_toc">

11440Posttransplant thyroid dysfunction</h4>

11441<p id="_2334" tabindex="-1">

11442Survivors of pediatric hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) are at increased risk of thyroid dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

1144335</a>

11444,<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

1144536</a>

11446]</p>

11447<div class="pdq-content-list">

11448<ul id="_2207">

11449<li>

11450In a retrospective study of a single pediatric transplantation unit, 244 pediatric patients were observed over a 20-year period. These patients had undergone HSCT for malignant or nonmalignant diseases between 1999 and 2018. Patients were assessed with a minimum of four thyroid function tests and one or more thyroid ultrasounds sequentially after HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

1145136</a>

11452]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11453<ul id="_3008">

11454<li>

11455Thyroid complications were detected in 19.7% of patients. </li>

11456<li>

11457The 15-year cumulative incidence of either autoimmune or nonautoimmune thyroid dysfunctions (34%) did not differ statistically between patients who received total-body irradiation (TBI)&#8211;based regimens and patients who received chemotherapy-based regimens (<em>

11458P</em>

11459 = .23). The cumulative incidence after busulfan-based conditioning was similar to that of TBI (10-year cumulative incidence, 22.2% vs. 25.9%, respectively).</li>

11460<li>

11461The cumulative incidence of nonautoimmune hypothyroidism was statistically higher after busulfan-based conditioning (12.4%) than after other chemotherapy-only&#8211;based conditioning regimens (3.1%; <em>

11462P</em>

11463 = .02, 5-year cumulative incidence).</li>

11464<li>

11465The overall incidence of thyroid nodules was low for the first 5 years after HSCT (1.9%) but increased steeply over time, with a 15-year cumulative incidence as high as 52.1%. Patients who received TBI-based conditioning regimens had a higher 15-year cumulative incidence of nodules (66.8%) than patients who received chemotherapy-only regimens (33.6%; <em>

11466P</em>

11467 = .02).</li>

11468<li>

11469 Age older than 10 years at transplantation showed a protective effect (HR, 0.42).</li>

11470<li>

11471Sonographic follow-up showed a progressive statistically significant reduction in thyroid anteroposterior diameter among patients who received TBI-based conditioning regimens (<em>

11472P</em>

11473 = .005) but not in those who received chemotherapy-only regimens. </li>

11474</ul>

11475</div>

11476</li>

11477<li>

11478In a report from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, the risk of thyroid dysfunction after HSCT was much lower (15%&#8211;16%) after fractionated TBI, as opposed to single-dose TBI (46%&#8211;48%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

1147935</a>

11480]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11481<ul id="_3009">

11482<li>

11483The increased risk of thyroid dysfunction did not differ between children receiving a TBI-based or busulfan-based regimen (<em>

11484P</em>

11485 = .48).</li>

11486<li>

11487Other high-dose therapies have not been studied.</li>

11488</ul>

11489</div>

11490</li>

11491</ul>

11492</div>

11493<p id="_1661" tabindex="-1">

11494<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_615">

11495TSH deficiency</a>

11496 (central hypothyroidism) is discussed with late effects that affect the pituitary gland.</p>

11497</section>

11498<p id="_1723" tabindex="-1">

11499<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_375">

11500Table 9</a>

11501 summarizes thyroid late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

11502<table id="_375" class="table-default expandable-container">

11503<caption>

11505a</span>

11506</caption>

11509<col width="33.33%">

11510<col width="33.33%">

11511</colgroup>

11513<tr>

11514<th>

11515Predisposing Therapy </th>

11516<th>

11517Endocrine/Metabolic Effects</th>

11520</tr>

115264</sub>

11576</tr>

11577</tbody>

11578</table>

11579</section>

11580<section id="_603">

11581<h3 id="_603_toc">

11582Hypothalamus-Pituitary Axis</h3>

11583<p id="_604" tabindex="-1">

11584Survivors of childhood cancer are at risk of developing a spectrum of neuroendocrine abnormalities, primarily because of the effect of radiation therapy on the hypothalamus.</p>

11585<div class="pdq-content-list">

11586<ul id="_2208">

11587<li>

11588There are two categories of childhood cancer survivors who experience hypothalamus-pituitary dysfunction after radiation&#8212;survivors with a CNS tumor and survivors treated for a non-CNS tumor of the head or neck or leukemia and/or individuals with a history of an HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

1158937</a>

11590]</li>

11591<li>

11592In addition, tumor development or surgical resection close to the hypothalamus and/or pituitary gland may induce direct anatomical damage to these structures and result in hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction. </li>

11593<li>

11594Essentially all of the hypothalamic-pituitary axes are at risk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.38">

1159538</a>

11596-<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1159740</a>

11598]</li>

11599</ul>

11600</div>

11601<p id="_1662" tabindex="-1">

11602The quality of the literature regarding pituitary endocrinopathy among childhood cancer survivors is often limited by retrospective data collection, small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, heterogeneity in treatment approach, time since treatment, and method of ascertainment. However, the evidence linking this outcome with radiation therapy, surgery, and tumor infiltration is compelling because affected individuals typically present with metabolic and developmental abnormalities early in follow-up.</p>

11603<p id="_3010" tabindex="-1">

11604The risk of hypothalamus-pituitary dysfunction increases with higher doses of radiation therapy. When the radiation therapy dose exceeds 30 Gy, there is a higher risk of developing hypothalamus-pituitary disorders, including adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) deficiency, luteinizing hormone (LH)/follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) deficiency, and TSH deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

1160537</a>

11606]</p>

11607<section id="_1292">

11608<h4 id="_1292_toc">

11609Central diabetes insipidus</h4>

11610<p id="_1293" tabindex="-1">

11611Central diabetes insipidus may herald the diagnosis of craniopharyngioma, suprasellar germ cell tumor, or Langerhans cell histiocytosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.41">

1161241</a>

11613-<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

1161443</a>

11615]</p>

11616<div class="pdq-content-list">

11617<ul id="_2209">

11618<li>

11619Diabetes insipidus may occur as an isolated pituitary deficiency at presentation of sellar/suprasellar tumors, although additional pituitary hormone deficiencies may develop with tumor progression. </li>

11620<li>

11621More commonly, diabetes insipidus occurs in the context of panhypopituitarism caused by the effects of the tumor on the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, or as a consequence of surgical procedures undertaken for local tumor control. </li>

11622<li>

11623Central diabetes insipidus is unlikely to occur as a late effect from surgical tumor resection past 2 years of follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_6.44">

1162444</a>

11625] Its emergence past that time should prompt assessment for tumor changes or other causes.</li>

11626<li>

11627Central diabetes insipidus has not been reported as a late effect of cranial irradiation in childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

116283</a>

11629]</li>

11630</ul>

11631</div>

11632</section>

11633<section id="_1294">

11634<h4 id="_1294_toc">

11635Anterior pituitary hormone deficiency</h4>

11636<p id="_1295" tabindex="-1">

11637Deficiencies of anterior pituitary hormones and major hypothalamic regulatory factors are common late effects among survivors treated with cranial irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1163840</a>

11639]</p>

11640<p id="_1663" tabindex="-1">

11641Evidence (prevalence of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency):</p>

11642<div class="pdq-content-list">

11643<ol id="_1664">

11644<li>

11645Young patients with brain tumors are particularly vulnerable to hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction. One study included 718 childhood brain tumor survivors who were monitored for a median of 7.9 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.45">

1164645</a>

11647]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11648<ul id="_2884">

11649<li>

11650No differences were observed in the prevalence of hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction among infants (0&#8211;1 years), toddlers (&#8805;1&#8211;3 years), or older age groups at diagnosis, despite the fact that radiation therapy was less frequently used in infants.</li>

11651<li>

11652Radiation exposure (OR, 16.44; 95% CI, 8.93&#8211;30.27), suprasellar tumor location (OR, 44.76; 95% CI, 19.00&#8211;105.49), and younger age (OR, 1.11; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.18) were associated with hypothalamic dysfunction. </li>

11653<li>

11654Infant and toddler brain tumor survivors showed more weight gain (<em>

11655P</em>

11656&#8201;&lt; .0001) and smaller height standard deviation score (SDS) (<em>

11657P</em>

11658&#8201;=&#8201;.001) during follow-up than survivors diagnosed at an older age. </li>

11659<li>

11660Among non-irradiated survivors, those who were infants and toddlers at diagnosis were significantly more frequently diagnosed with TSH, ACTH, and antidiuretic hormone (ADH) deficiency, compared with survivors diagnosed at an older age, presumably caused by systemic therapies or the trauma of neurosurgery.</li>

11661</ul>

11662</div>

11663 </li>

11664<li>

11665A study targeting more refined data on the radiation doses associated with pituitary insufficiency analyzed 102 patients treated for tumors that included radiation therapy exposures (CNS, head and neck, hematologic malignancies) between 2008 and 2019. The median (interquartile range [IQR]) age at radiation therapy was 9.0 years (6.0&#8211;12.0 years), and the median follow-up was 5.7 years (3.5&#8211;9.1 years). Most patients received focal brain radiation therapy (36.3%) or TBI (32.4%). The most frequent diagnoses were ALL (25.5%) and medulloblastoma (17.6%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.46">

1166646</a>

11667]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11668<ul id="_3011">

11669<li>

11670Most patients developed pituitary insufficiency (64 patients; 62.7%). Forty-one percent of patients had one hormone deficiency and 38% had two hormone deficiencies. </li>

11671<li>

11672Growth hormone deficiency (58 patients; 56.9%) and TSH deficiency (32 patients; 31.4%) were most common. </li>

11673<li>

11674Patients who developed pituitary insufficiency had received a higher maximum pituitary dose (median [IQR], 44.0 Gy [20.4&#8211;54.0] vs. 18.2 Gy [14.4&#8211;52.6]; <em>

11675P</em>

11676 = .008). Doses of 40 to 49 Gy or higher than 50 Gy led to a higher cumulative incidence rate than doses lower than 20 Gy (HR, 4.07; <em>

11677P</em>

11678 &lt; .001 and HR, 3.04; <em>

11679P</em>

11680 &lt; .001, respectively). </li>

11681<li>

11682However, even at lower dose bands, levels of pituitary insufficiency were significant. The 5-year cumulative incidence was higher than 30% for growth hormone deficiency with doses lower than 20 Gy and for TSH deficiency with doses of 20 to 29 Gy.</li>

11683</ul>

11684</div>

11685</li>

11686<li>

11687In a single-institution study, 1,713 adult survivors of childhood cancers and brain tumors (median age, 32 years) were monitored for a median follow-up of 25 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

1168839</a>

11689]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11690<ul id="_1665">

11691<li>

11692The prevalence of hypothalamic-pituitary axis disorders was 56.4% in individuals exposed to cranial radiation therapy at doses of 18 Gy or higher.</li>

11693</ul>

11694</div>

11695</li>

11696<li>

11697A study of 3,141 childhood cancer survivors who were systematically evaluated for hypothalamic-pituitary disorders at a median follow-up of 24.1 years reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

1169847</a>

11699]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11700<ol id="_2731" class="lower-alpha">

11701<li>

11702 For patients who were treated with hypothalamic-pituitary radiation therapy (n = 1,089), the following was observed: <div class="pdq-content-list">

11703<ul id="_2732">

11704<li>

11705The estimated prevalence of growth hormone deficiency was 40.2%.</li>

11706<li>

11707The estimated prevalence of TSH deficiency was 11.1%.</li>

11708<li>

11709The estimated prevalence of LH/FSH deficiency was 10.6%.</li>

11710<li>

11711The estimated prevalence of ACTH deficiency was 3.2%.</li>

11712<li>

11713The estimated prevalence of central precocious puberty was 0.9%.</li>

11714</ul>

11715</div>

11716</li>

11717<li>

11718For patients who did not receive hypothalamic-pituitary radiation therapy, the estimated prevalence of growth hormone deficiency was 6.2% and less than 1% for the other hypothalamic-pituitary disorders.</li>

11719<li>

11720Clinical factors independently associated with hypothalamic-pituitary disorders included the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

11721<ul id="_2733">

11722<li>

11723Hypothalamic-pituitary radiation therapy (even at relatively low doses, except for ACTH deficiency which was not observed until &gt;30 Gy).</li>

11724<li>

11725Alkylating agents (growth hormone deficiency, LH/FSH deficiency).</li>

11726<li>

11727 Intrathecal chemotherapy (growth hormone deficiency).</li>

11728<li>

11729Hydrocephalus with shunt placement (growth hormone deficiency, LH/FSH deficiency).</li>

11730<li>

11731Seizures (TSH deficiency, ACTH deficiency).</li>

11732<li>

11733Stroke (growth hormone deficiency, TSH deficiency, LH/FSH deficiency, ACTH deficiency).</li>

11734</ul>

11735</div>

11736 </li>

11737<li>

11738Adverse outcomes associated with hypothalamic-pituitary disorders included the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

11739<ul id="_2734">

11740<li>

11741Short stature (growth hormone deficiency, TSH deficiency).</li>

11742<li>

11743Severe bone mineral deficit (growth hormone deficiency, LH/FSH deficiency).</li>

11744<li>

11745Obesity (LH/FSH deficiency).</li>

11746<li>

11747Frailty (growth hormone deficiency).</li>

11748<li>

11749Impaired physical health-related quality of life (TSH deficiency).</li>

11750<li>

11751Sexual dysfunction (LH/FSH deficiency).</li>

11752<li>

11753Impaired memory and processing speed (growth hormone deficiency, TSH deficiency).</li>

11754</ul>

11755</div>

11756</li>

11757</ol>

11758</div>

11759</li>

11760</ol>

11761</div>

11762<p id="_3012" tabindex="-1">

11763The International Late Effects of Childhood Cancer Guideline Harmonization Group (IGHG) consisting of 42 interdisciplinary international experts performed a systematic literature search on hypothalamic-pituitary axis surveillance in childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

1176437</a>

11765]</p>

11766<div class="pdq-content-list">

11767<ul id="_3013">

11768<li>

11769They noted that hypothalamic-pituitary axis radiation exposure increased the risk for hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction, with a dose dependent relationship. Doses of radiation therapy higher than 18 Gy are associated with a higher risk for growth hormone deficiency and central precocious puberty.</li>

11770<li>

11771Deficiencies in ACTH, TSH, and LH/FSH generally occur after doses higher than 30 Gy.</li>

11772<li>

11773The panel noted that childhood cancer survivors who have had local tissue injury to the hypothalamic-pituitary region are at risk of developing hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction from the time of diagnosis or surgery for a brain tumor located near or within the hypothalamic-pituitary region or from occurrence of hydrocephalus (specifically at risk for growth hormone deficiency and central precocious puberty).</li>

11774<li>

11775Individuals exposed to radiation are at risk of developing hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction one year from completion of radiation therapy.</li>

11776<li>

11777Childhood cancer survivors remain particularly at risk of growth hormone deficiency for at least 15 years after cancer diagnosis or treatment exposure. The risk beyond 15 years depends on individual patient factors. For central precocious puberty, patients remain at risk until age 8 years in girls and age 9 years for boys.</li>

11778</ul>

11779</div>

11780<p id="_1667" tabindex="-1">

11781The six anterior pituitary hormones and their major hypothalamic regulatory factors are outlined in <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_605">

11782Table 10</a>

11783.</p>

11784<table id="_605" class="table-default expandable-container">

11785<caption>

11786Table 10. Anterior Pituitary Hormones and Major Hypothalamic Regulatory Factors</caption>

11787<colgroup>

11788<col width="33.33%">

11789<col width="33.33%">

11790<col width="33.33%">

11791</colgroup>

11792<THead>

11793<tr>

11794<th>

11795Pituitary Hormone </th>

11796<th>

11797Hypothalamic Factor</th>

11798<th>

11799Hypothalamic Regulation of the Pituitary

11800Hormone</th>

11801</tr>

11802</THead>

11803<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

11804<tr>

11805<td colspan="3">

11806 (&#8211;) = inhibitory; (+) = stimulatory.</td>

11807</tr>

11808</TFoot>

11809<tbody>

11810<tr>

11811<td rowspan="2">

11812Growth hormone (GH)</td>

11813<td>

11814GH-releasing hormone

11815</td>

11816<td align="Center" scope="col">

11817+</td>

11818</tr>

11819<tr>

11844Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) </td>

11845<td>

11848+</td>

11855</td>

11856<td align="Center" scope="col">

11857+</td>

11858</tr>

11862</td>

11863<td align="Center" scope="col">

11864&#8211;</td>

11865</tr>

11868Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)</td>

11869<td>

11871

11872</td>

11874+</td>
