11880+</td>

11881</tr>

11882</tbody>

11883</table>

11884</section>

11885<section id="_607">

11886<h4 id="_607_toc">

11887Growth hormone deficiency</h4>

11888<p id="_663" tabindex="-1">

11889Growth hormone deficiency is the most common and often the first anterior pituitary deficit to occur after cranial radiation therapy. In childhood survivors of CNS tumors, the overall prevalence of growth hormone deficiency is 12.5%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

118903</a>

11891]</p>

11892<div class="pdq-content-list">

11893<ul id="_2210">

11894<li>

11895The risk increases with radiation dose and time since treatment. </li>

11896<li>

11897Growth hormone deficiency can result from relatively low doses of cranial radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

1189848</a>

11899]</li>

11900<li>

11901 Growth hormone deficiency can develop after 18 Gy to 24 Gy of cranial radiation, which is used to treat patients with ALL and lymphoma. The higher the radiation dose, the earlier that growth hormone deficiency will occur after treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.49">

1190249</a>

11903]</li>

11904<li>

11905Approximately 60% to 80% of pediatric patients with brain tumors who received radiation therapy doses higher than 30 Gy will have impaired serum growth hormone response to provocative stimulation, usually within 5 years of treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

1190650</a>

11907,<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

1190851</a>

11909] </li>

11910</ul>

11911</div>

11912<p id="_1668" tabindex="-1">

11913Evidence (radiation-dose response relationship of growth hormone deficiency in childhood brain tumor survivors):</p>

11914<div class="pdq-content-list">

11915<ol id="_1669">

11916<li>

11917A study of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=270731&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000270731&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=NotSet'); return(false);">

11918conformal radiation therapy</a>

11919 (CRT) in children with CNS tumors indicates that growth hormone insufficiency can usually be demonstrated within 12 months of radiation therapy, depending on hypothalamic dose-volume effects.[<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

1192052</a>

11921]</li>

11922<li>

11923In a report featuring data from 118 patients with localized brain tumors who were treated with radiation therapy, peak growth hormone was modeled as an exponential function of time after CRT and mean radiation dose to the hypothalamus.[<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

1192451</a>

11925]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11926<ul id="_1670">

11927<li>

11928The average patient was predicted to develop growth hormone deficiency with the following combinations of time after CRT and mean dose to the hypothalamus: 12 months and more than 60 Gy; 36 months and 25 Gy to 30 Gy; and 60 months and 15 Gy to 20 Gy.</li>

11929<li>

11930A cumulative dose of 16.1 Gy to the hypothalamus would be considered the mean radiation dose causing a 50% risk of growth hormone deficiency at 5 years (TD50/5) (see <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_710">

11931Figure 9</a>

11932).</li>

11933</ul>

11934</div>

11935</li>

11936</ol>

11937</div>

11938<p id="_710" tabindex="-1">

11939<figure id="figure_711" class="image-center">

11940<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/727434.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

11941Enlarge</a>

11942<img id="_711" alt="Graph shows peak growth hormone (in ng/mL) according to hypothalamic mean dose and time (in months) after start of irradiation." title="Graph shows peak growth hormone (in ng/mL) according to hypothalamic mean dose and time (in months) after start of irradiation." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/727434-750.jpg">

11943<figcaption class="caption-container">

11944Figure 9. Peak growth hormone (GH) according to hypothalamic mean dose and time after start of radiation. According to equation 2, peak GH = exp{2.5947 + time &#215; [0.0019 &#8722; (0.00079 &#215; mean dose)]}. Thomas E. Merchant, Susan R. Rose, Christina Bosley, Shengjie Wu, Xiaoping Xiong, and Robert H. Lustig, Growth Hormone Secretion After Conformal Radiation Therapy in Pediatric Patients With Localized Brain Tumors, Journal of Clinical Oncology, volume 29, issue 36, pages 4776-4780. Reprinted with permission. &#169; (2011) American Society of Clinical Oncology. All rights reserved.</figcaption>

11945</figure>

11946</p>

11947<p id="_1671" tabindex="-1">

11948Evidence (risk of growth deficits in childhood cancer survivors):</p>

11949<div class="pdq-content-list">

11950<ol id="_1672">

11951<li>

11952One study evaluated 127 patients with ALL treated with 24 Gy, 18 Gy, or no cranial radiation therapy (treatment era, 1980s&#8211;1990s).[<a href="#cit/section_6.53">

1195353</a>

11954]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11955<ul id="_1673">

11956<li>

11957 The change in height, compared with population norms expressed as the SDS, was significant for all three groups. The dose response was -0.49 &#177; 0.14 for the group that did not receive radiation therapy, -0.65 &#177; 0.15 for the group that received 18 Gy of radiation therapy, and -1.38 &#177; 0.16 for the group that received 24 Gy of radiation therapy.</li>

11958</ul>

11959</div>

11960</li>

11961<li>

11962Survivors of childhood ALL who are treated with chemotherapy alone are also at increased risk for adult short stature, although the risk is highest for those treated with cranial and craniospinal radiation therapy at a young age.[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

1196354</a>

11964] In a cross-sectional study, attained adult height was determined for 2,434 ALL survivors participating in the CCSS.<div class="pdq-content-list">

11965<ul id="_1674">

11966<li>

11967All survivor treatment exposure groups (chemotherapy alone and chemotherapy with cranial or craniospinal radiation therapy) had decreased adult height and an increased risk of adult short stature (height SDS &lt; -2), compared with siblings (<em>

11968P</em>

11969 &lt; .001).</li>

11970<li>

11971Compared with siblings, the risk of short stature for survivors treated with chemotherapy alone was elevated (OR, 3.4; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;6.0).</li>

11972<li>

11973Among survivors, significant risk factors for short stature included diagnosis of ALL before puberty, higher-dose cranial radiation therapy (&#8805;20 Gy vs. &lt;20 Gy), any radiation therapy to the spine (which effects vertebral bodies), and female sex.</li>

11974</ul>

11975</div>

11976</li>

11977<li>

11978The impact of chemotherapy alone on growth in 67 survivors treated with contemporary regimens for ALL was statistically significant at -0.59 SD. The loss of growth potential did not correlate with growth hormone status in this study, further highlighting the participation of other factors in the growth impairments observed in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_6.55">

1197955</a>

11980]</li>

11981<li>

11982In a longitudinal study of 372 survivors of ALL who were treated on a single-institution chemotherapy-only trial, the following were observed:[<a href="#cit/section_6.56">

1198356</a>

11984]<div class="pdq-content-list">

11985<ul id="_2078">

11986<li>

11987Height z-scores declined during treatment and improved after therapy.</li>

11988<li>

11989Younger age at diagnosis (2 to &lt;10 years), low-risk ALL status, white blood cell count below 50 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

119909</span>

11991/L at diagnosis, or CNS-negative status were associated with significant improvements in z-scores for height during the off-therapy period compared with those older at diagnosis (age &#8805;10 years), those with standard-risk/high-risk ALL status, those with a white blood cell count of 50 &#215; 10<span class="sup">

119929</span>

11993/L or higher, or CNS-positive status.</li>

11994<li>

11995The loss in height potential in older patients was attributed to attenuation of the growth spurt during treatment without improvement after therapy and to chemotherapy intensity in patients with standard- or high-risk disease features. </li>

11996</ul>

11997</div>

11998</li>

11999<li>

12000A French CCSS study evaluated risk factors for short adult height and growth hormone deficiency in 2,965 childhood cancer survivors using clinical and treatment data available in medical records. Patients treated with growth hormones (6.4%) were excluded.[<a href="#cit/section_6.57">

1200157</a>

12002]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12003<ul id="_2422">

12004<li>

12005Independent risk factors for short adult height included being young at the time of cancer treatment (RR, 0.9 per year of age), having a short height at diagnosis (&#8804;2 SDS: RR, 6.7), and having received treatment with pituitary radiation (5&#8211;20 Gy: RR, 4.2; 20&#8211;40 Gy: RR, 10.2; &#8805;40 Gy: RR, 19.5), busulfan (RR, 4.5), or more than 300 mg/m<span class="sup">

120062</span>

12007 of lomustine (300&#8211;600 mg/m<span class="sup">

120082</span>

12009: RR, 4.2 and &#8805;600 mg/m<span class="sup">

120102</span>

12011: RR, 9.1). </li>

12012<li>

12013Children who were treated with 15 Gy or higher of radiation to 90% or more volume of seven or more vertebrae without pituitary irradiation had an increased risk of short adult stature (RR, 4.6). This risk increased by 1.3-fold to 2.4-fold if they also received pituitary radiation therapy. </li>

12014</ul>

12015</div>

12016</li>

12017<li>

12018A St. Jude Children's Research Hospital investigation evaluated long-term (median follow-up, 10.2 years) height outcomes among 212 pediatric patients with CNS embryonal tumors who were treated with CSI at 23.4 Gy (n = 147) or 36 Gy or higher (n = 65).[<a href="#cit/section_6.58">

1201958</a>

12020]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12021<ul id="_2726">

12022<li>

12023Compared with U.S. standards, mean final height z-scores at age 18 years were -1.3 for female and -1.5 for male survivors. </li>

12024<li>

12025Factors associated with risk of height impairment included younger age at the time of CSI, higher CSI dose, and female sex.</li>

12026<li>

12027Factors associated with higher growth rates before the age of 15 years included older age at CSI, male sex, CSI dose lower than 36 Gy, replacement therapy for growth hormone and central adrenal insufficiency, and White race. </li>

12028</ul>

12029</div>

12030</li>

12031</ol>

12032</div>

12033<section id="_2213">

12034<h5 id="_2213_toc">

12035Growth after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</h5>

12036<div class="pdq-content-list">

12037<ul id="_2214">

12038<li>

12039Children who undergo HSCT with TBI have a significant risk of both growth hormone deficiency and the direct effects of radiation on skeletal development.[<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

1204059</a>

12041-<a href="#cit/section_6.61">

1204261</a>

12043]</li>

12044<li>

12045 The risk of growth hormone deficiency is increased with single-dose TBI as opposed to fractionated TBI, pretransplant cranial irradiation, female sex, and posttreatment complications such as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).[<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

1204659</a>

12047-<a href="#cit/section_6.61">

1204861</a>

12049] </li>

12050<li>

12051 Hyperfractionation of the TBI dose markedly reduces risk in patients who have not undergone cranial irradiation for CNS leukemia prophylaxis or therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.62">

1205262</a>

12053] </li>

12054<li>

12055Regimens containing busulfan and cyclophosphamide appear to increase risk in some studies,[<a href="#cit/section_6.61">

1205661</a>

12057,<a href="#cit/section_6.63">

1205863</a>

12059] but not others.[<a href="#cit/section_6.64">

1206064</a>

12061]</li>

12062</ul>

12063</div>

12064<p id="_1675" tabindex="-1">

12065Evidence (growth hormone deficiency in childhood HSCT survivors):</p>

12066<div class="pdq-content-list">

12067<ol id="_1676">

12068<li>

12069The late effects that occur after HSCT have been studied by the Late Effects Working Party of the European Group for Blood and Marrow Transplantation. Among 181 patients with aplastic anemia, leukemias, and lymphomas who underwent HSCT before puberty, the following results were observed:[<a href="#cit/section_6.65">

1207065</a>

12071,<a href="#cit/section_6.66">

1207266</a>

12073]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12074<ul id="_1677">

12075<li>

12076An overall decrease in final height&#8211;SDS value was found, compared with height at transplant and genetic height. The mean loss of height is estimated to be approximately 1 height&#8211;SDS (6 cm), compared with the mean height at time of HSCT and mean genetic height.</li>

12077<li>

12078The type of transplantation, GVHD, and growth hormone or steroid treatment did not influence final height.</li>

12079<li>

12080TBI (single-dose more than fractionated-dose radiation therapy), male sex, and young age at transplant were found to be major factors for long-term height loss. </li>

12081<li>

12082Most patients (140 of 181) reached adult height within the normal range of the general population.</li>

12083</ul>

12084</div>

12085</li>

12086<li>

12087Growth hormone deficiency has been reported after lower doses with a single fraction of 10 Gy and fractionated doses of 12 to 18 Gy of TBI.[<a href="#cit/section_6.67">

1208867</a>

12089]</li>

12090</ol>

12091</div>

12092</section>

12093<section id="_1678">

12094<h5 id="_1678_toc">

12095Growth hormone replacement therapy</h5>

12096<div class="pdq-content-list">

12097<ul id="_2243">

12098<li>

12099Growth hormone replacement therapy provides the benefit of optimizing height outcomes among children who have not reached skeletal maturity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1210040</a>

12101] The diagnosis requires specialized dynamic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1210240</a>

12103,<a href="#cit/section_6.68">

1210468</a>

12105]</li>

12106<li>

12107 Treatment with recombinant growth hormone (rGH) replacement therapy is generally delayed until 12 months after successful completion of cancer or brain tumor treatments and after a multidisciplinary discussion involving the prescribing pediatric endocrinologist, the primary oncologist, and other providers selected by the patient or family.[<a href="#cit/section_6.69">

1210869</a>

12109]</li>

12110<li>

12111Safety concerns pertaining to the use of rGH in childhood cancer survivors have primarily been related to the mitogenic potential of the growth hormone stimulating tumor growth in a population with an increased risk of second neoplasms.[<a href="#cit/section_6.70">

1211270</a>

12113] Most studies that report these outcomes, however, are limited by selection bias and small sample size.</li>

12114</ul>

12115</div>

12116<p id="_1681" tabindex="-1">

12117Evidence (subsequent neoplasm risk after growth hormone deficiency replacement therapy):</p>

12118<div class="pdq-content-list">

12119<ol id="_1682">

12120<li>

12121One study evaluated 361 growth hormone&#8211;treated cancer survivors enrolled in the CCSS and compared risk of recurrence, risk of subsequent neoplasm, and risk of death among survivors who did and did not receive treatment with growth hormone.[<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

1212271</a>

12123]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12124<ul id="_1683">

12125<li>

12126The RR of disease recurrence was 0.83 (95% CI, 0.37&#8211;1.86) for growth hormone&#8211;treated survivors. </li>

12127<li>

12128Growth hormone&#8211;treated participants were diagnosed with 15 subsequent neoplasms, all solid tumors, for an overall RR of 3.21 (95% CI, 1.88&#8211;5.46). This was mainly due to a small excess number of subsequent neoplasms observed in survivors of acute leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

1212971</a>

12130] </li>

12131<li>

12132With prolonged follow-up, the elevation of subsequent cancer risk resulting from growth hormone diminished.[<a href="#cit/section_6.72">

1213372</a>

12134]</li>

12135<li>

12136Compared with survivors not treated with growth hormone, those who were treated had a twofold excess risk of developing a subsequent neoplasm (RR, 2.15; 95% CI, 1.33&#8211;3.47; <em>

12137P</em>

12138 &lt; .002). Meningiomas were the most commonly observed neoplasms (9 of 20 tumors).[<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

1213971</a>

12140]</li>

12141</ul>

12142</div>

12143</li>

12144<li>

12145A study from the CCSS reported on the risk of subsequent CNS neoplasms after a longer period of follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_6.73">

1214673</a>

12147]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12148<ul id="_1684">

12149<li>

12150The adjusted rate ratio of meningioma and gliomas in growth hormone&#8211;treated survivors of CNS tumors was 1.0 (95% CI, 0.6&#8211;1.8; <em>

12151P</em>

12152 = .94), when compared with CNS tumor survivors who were not treated with growth hormone. This finding indicates negligible differences between

12153the two groups for this particular risk.</li>

12154</ul>

12155</div>

12156</li>

12157<li>

12158A review of existing data suggests that treatment with growth hormone is not associated with an increased risk of CNS tumor progression or recurrence, or new or recurrent leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_6.74">

1215974</a>

12160]</li>

12161</ol>

12162</div>

12163</section>

12164<p id="_1095" tabindex="-1">

12165In general, the data addressing subsequent malignancies among childhood cancer survivors treated with growth hormone therapy should be interpreted with caution given the small number of events.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1216640</a>

12167,<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

1216852</a>

12169,<a href="#cit/section_6.69">

1217069</a>

12171-<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

1217271</a>

12173,<a href="#cit/section_6.75">

1217475</a>

12175,<a href="#cit/section_6.76">

1217676</a>

12177]</p>

12178<p id="_2982" tabindex="-1">

12179As outlined in a consensus statement by the Growth Hormone Research Society, areas of uncertainty include the safety of growth hormone in children with cancer-predisposing conditions, its use in growth hormone&#8211;deficient children who are receiving maintenance therapy, and the overall benefit-risk ratio in adult survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.77">

1218077</a>

12181]</p>

12182</section>

12183<section id="_613">

12184<h4 id="_613_toc">

12185Disorders of LH and FSH</h4>

12186<div class="pdq-content-list">

12187<ul id="_2215">

12188<li>

12189Pubertal development can be adversely affected by cranial radiation therapy. </li>

12190<li>

12191Doses higher than 18 Gy can result in central precocious puberty, while doses higher than 30 Gy to 40 Gy may result in LH/FSH deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

1219247</a>

12193] </li>

12194</ul>

12195</div>

12196<section id="_1097">

12197<h5 id="_1097_toc">

12198Central precocious puberty</h5>

12199<section id="_2358">

12200<h6 id="_2358_toc">

12201Prevalence and risk factors </h6>

12202<div class="pdq-content-list">

12203<ul id="_2359">

12204<li>

12205Central precocious puberty is among the most common hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunctions. The prevalence varies across studies because of study cohort composition and method of ascertainment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

122063</a>

12207,<a href="#cit/section_6.78">

1220878</a>

12209,<a href="#cit/section_6.79">

1221079</a>

12211]</li>

12212<li>

12213Children with CNS tumors within or near the hypothalamic-pituitary axis (including those with neurofibromatosis type 1) or those treated with cranial radiation are most vulnerable.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

122143</a>

12215]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12216<ul id="_2360">

12217<li>

12218 In a study of 178 childhood brain tumor survivors (median follow-up, 6.6 years), precocious puberty developed in 12.2% of survivors, with a 5-year cumulative incidence of 4.0%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

122193</a>

12220]</li>

12221<li>

12222Central precocious puberty has been reported in children receiving cranial irradiation in doses of 18 Gy or higher.[<a href="#cit/section_6.78">

1222378</a>

12224,<a href="#cit/section_6.80">

1222580</a>

12226,<a href="#cit/section_6.81">

1222781</a>

12228]</li>

12229</ul>

12230</div>

12231</li>

12232<li>

12233Hydrocephalus also increases the risk of central precocious puberty.[<a href="#cit/section_6.82">

1223482</a>

12235]</li>

12236</ul>

12237</div>

12238</section>

12239<section id="_2356">

12240<h6 id="_2356_toc">

12241Diagnosis</h6>

12242<div class="pdq-content-list">

12243<ul id="_2357">

12244<li>

12245Central precocious puberty is defined by the onset of pubertal development before age 8 years in girls and 9 years in boys as a result of the premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. </li>

12246<li>

12247Assessment of puberty cannot be performed using testicular volume measurements in boys exposed to chemotherapy or direct radiation to the testes, given the toxic effect of these treatments on germ cells and repercussions on gonadal size.[<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

1224883</a>

12249]</li>

12250<li>

12251The staging of puberty in males within this population relies on the presence of other signs of virilization, such as the presence of pubic hair and the measurement of morning plasma testosterone and LH levels.[<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

1225283</a>

12253]</li>

12254</ul>

12255</div>

12256</section>

12257<section id="_2361">

12258<h6 id="_2361_toc">

12259Treatment and outcomes associated with central precocious puberty</h6>

12260<div class="pdq-content-list">

12261<ul id="_2362">

12262<li>

12263Aside from the adjustment and psychosocial challenges associated with early pubertal development, precocious puberty can lead to the rapid closure of the skeletal growth plates and short stature. This deleterious effect can be further potentiated by growth hormone deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_6.78">

1226478</a>

12265,<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

1226683</a>

12267] </li>

12268<li>

12269The increased growth velocity induced by pubertal development can mask concurrent growth hormone deficiency with seemingly normal growth velocity; this occurrence may mislead care providers.[<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

1227083</a>

12271]</li>

12272<li>

12273The impact of central precocious puberty on linear growth can be ascertained by assessing the degree of skeletal maturation (or bone age) using an x-ray of the left hand.[<a href="#cit/section_6.84">

1227484</a>

12275]</li>

12276<li>

12277Delaying the progression of puberty relies on the use of various gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist preparations. This approach has been shown to improve growth prospects, especially when other pituitary abnormalities, including growth hormone deficiency, are concurrently treated.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1227840</a>

12279,<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

1228085</a>

12281]</li>

12282</ul>

12283</div>

12284</section>

12285</section>

12286<section id="_1099">

12287<h5 id="_1099_toc">

12288LH/FSH deficiency</h5>

12289<div class="pdq-content-list">

12290<ul id="_2364">

12291<li>

12292LH/FSH deficiency (also referred to as hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) can manifest through pubertal delay (after age 13 years in girls and 14 years in boys), arrested puberty, or symptoms of decreased sex hormone production, depending on age and pubertal status at the time of diagnosis. </li>

12293<li>

12294The risk of LH/FSH deficiency is highest among patients treated with cranial radiation at doses greater than or equal to 30 Gy. LH/FSH deficiency following the exposure to lower doses can occur at delayed time points.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

122954</a>

12296] </li>

12297<li>

12298With higher doses of cranial radiation therapy (&gt;35 Gy), deficiencies in LH/FSH can be seen, with a cumulative incidence of 10% to 20% at 5 to 10 years posttreatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

122994</a>

12300,<a href="#cit/section_6.82">

1230182</a>

12302]</li>

12303<li>

12304The treatment of LH/FSH deficiency relies on sex-hormone replacement therapy adjusted to age and pubertal status.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1230540</a>

12306]</li>

12307</ul>

12308</div>

12309</section>

12310</section>

12311<section id="_615">

12312<h4 id="_615_toc">

12313TSH deficiency</h4>

12314<p id="_616" tabindex="-1">

12315TSH deficiency (also referred to as central hypothyroidism) in survivors of childhood cancer can have profound clinical consequences and be underappreciated. </p>

12316<section id="_2367">

12317<h5 id="_2367_toc">

12318Prevalence and risk factors</h5>

12319<div class="pdq-content-list">

12320<ul id="_2368">

12321<li>

12322The risk of TSH deficiency is highest among patients treated with cranial radiation at doses of 30 Gy or higher. TSH deficiency following the exposure to lower doses can occur at delayed time points.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

123234</a>

12324]</li>

12325<li>

12326The cumulative incidence of TSH deficiency was 23% (&#177; 8%) among embryonal brain tumor survivors treated with risk-adapted CSI, conformal primary site irradiation, and high-dose chemotherapy. Radiation dose to the hypothalamus in excess of 42 Gy is associated with an increased risk of developing TSH deficiency (44% &#177; 19% for a dose of &#8805;42 Gy and 11% &#177; 8% for a dose of &lt;42 Gy).[<a href="#cit/section_6.86">

1232786</a>

12328]</li>

12329<li>

12330Among medulloblastoma survivors treated with photon (median follow-up, 9.6 years) or proton (median follow-up, 3.8 years) radiation therapy, primary hypothyroidism developed in 12 of 54 patients (22%) after photon radiation therapy and 3 of 41 patients (7%) after proton radiation therapy (HR, 2.1; <em>

12331P</em>

12332 = .27). Central hypothyroidism (TSH deficiency) developed in 13 of 54 patients (24%) after photon radiation therapy and 4 of 41 patients (10%) after proton radiation therapy (HR, 2.16, <em>

12333P</em>

12334 = .18).[<a href="#cit/section_6.87">

1233587</a>

12336]</li>

12337<li>

12338In a study of 189 children and young adults (aged &lt;26 years) with brain tumors who were treated with proton radiation therapy, the 4-year actuarial rate of hypothyroidism was 20.1%. Ninety percent of the cases were related to central TSH deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

1233916</a>

12340]</li>

12341</ul>

12342</div>

12343</section>

12344<section id="_2365">

12345<h5 id="_2365_toc">

12346Clinical presentation and diagnosis</h5>

12347<div class="pdq-content-list">

12348<ul id="_2366">

12349<li>

12350Symptoms of central hypothyroidism (e.g., asthenia, edema, drowsiness, and skin dryness) may have a gradual onset and go unrecognized until thyroid replacement therapy is initiated. </li>

12351<li>

12352In addition to delayed puberty and slow growth, hypothyroidism may cause fatigue, dry skin, constipation, increased sleep requirement, and cold intolerance. </li>

12353<li>

12354Individuals with TSH deficiency usually have low plasma free T<sub>

123554</sub>

12356 levels and either low or inappropriately normal TSH levels. Declining free T4 levels within the normal range may also be predictive of TSH deficiency. Clinicians should not hesitate to reassess survivors with this pattern of thyroid function, especially in the presence of symptoms of hypothyroidism.[<a href="#cit/section_6.88">

1235788</a>

12358]</li>

12359<li>

12360Mixed primary and central hypothyroidism can also occur because of separate injuries to the thyroid gland and the hypothalamus (e.g., radiation injury to both structures), leading to mildly elevated TSH values despite the contribution of hypothalamic-pituitary deficits to hypothyroidism in affected individuals.</li>

12361</ul>

12362</div>

12363</section>

12364<section id="_2369">

12365<h5 id="_2369_toc">

12366 Management of TSH deficiency</h5>

12367<div class="pdq-content-list">

12368<ul id="_2370">

12369<li>

12370Thyroid hormone replacement therapy using levothyroxine represents the mainstay of treatment of TSH deficiency.</li>

12371<li>

12372 The dose of levothyroxine needs to be adjusted solely using plasma free T<sub>

123734</sub>

12374 levels. The levels of TSH are expected to remain low during therapy, given the central nature of this deficiency. </li>

12375<li>

12376Central hypothyroidism should not be treated before assessment of the functioning of other hypothalamic-pituitary deficiencies, because it could precipitate an adrenal crisis in patients with ACTH deficiency.</li>

12377</ul>

12378</div>

12379</section>

12380</section>

12381<section id="_618">

12382<h4 id="_618_toc">

12383ACTH deficiency</h4>

12384<section id="_2372">

12385<h5 id="_2372_toc">

12386Prevalence and risk factors</h5>

12387<div class="pdq-content-list">

12388<ul id="_2373">

12389<li>

12390ACTH deficiency is less common than other neuroendocrine deficits but should be suspected in patients who have a history of brain tumors (regardless of therapy modality), cranial radiation therapy, growth hormone deficiency, or central hypothyroidism.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1239140</a>

12392,<a href="#cit/section_6.86">

1239386</a>

12394,<a href="#cit/section_6.89">

1239589</a>

12396,<a href="#cit/section_6.90">

1239790</a>

12398]</li>

12399<li>

12400ACTH deficiency develops almost exclusively in survivors previously exposed to hypothalamic-pituitary doses of 30 Gy or greater.<div class="pdq-content-list">

12401<ul id="_2374">

12402<li>

12403The cumulative incidence of ACTH deficiency was 38% (&#177; 6%) among embryonal brain tumor survivors treated with risk-adapted CSI, conformal primary site irradiation, and high-dose chemotherapy. ACTH status was not affected by the dose of radiation therapy administered to the hypothalamus (median, 42.2 Gy for no ACTH deficiency vs. 41.3 Gy for ACTH deficiency).[<a href="#cit/section_6.86">

1240486</a>

12405] </li>

12406<li>

12407In a study of 189 children and young adults (aged &lt;26 years) with brain tumors who were treated with proton radiation therapy, the 5-year actuarial rate of ACTH deficiency was 8%, occurring almost exclusively after &#8805;40 Gy to the hypothalamus and pituitary.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

1240816</a>

12409]</li>

12410</ul>

12411</div>

12412</li>

12413<li>

12414Although uncommon, ACTH deficiency can occur in patients treated with intracranial radiation doses of less than 24 Gy and in patients with non-CNS tumors or hematological malignancies distant from the hypothalamic-pituitary region. The use of glucocorticoid therapy in treatment protocols may also be associated with steroid-induced adrenal insufficiency, which in some cases may be prolonged.[<a href="#cit/section_6.91">

1241591</a>

12416-<a href="#cit/section_6.93">

1241793</a>

12418] </li>

12419</ul>

12420</div>

12421</section>

12422<section id="_2375">

12423<h5 id="_2375_toc">

12424Diagnosis and management</h5>

12425<div class="pdq-content-list">

12426<ul id="_2225">

12427<li>

12428 The diagnosis of ACTH deficiency should be suspected when low plasma levels of morning cortisol are measured (a screening cortisol level collected at 8 AM that is 10 &#181;g/dL or more is reassuring for ACTH sufficiency, whereas a value of 5 &#181;g/dL or lower is suspicious for insufficiency).</li>

12429<li>

12430Confirmation is necessary using dynamic testing such as the low-dose ACTH stimulation test.[<a href="#cit/section_6.89">

1243189</a>

12432] </li>

12433<li>

12434Because of the substantial risk of central adrenal insufficiency among survivors treated with cranial radiation doses exceeding 30 Gy to the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, endocrine monitoring with periodic dynamic testing as clinically indicated is recommended for this high-risk group.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1243540</a>

12436]</li>

12437<li>

12438Patients with partial ACTH deficiency may have only subtle symptoms unless they become ill.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1243940</a>

12440]</li>

12441<li>

12442 Illness can disrupt these patients&#8217; usual homeostasis and cause a more severe, prolonged, or complicated course than expected. As in complete ACTH deficiency, incomplete or unrecognized ACTH deficiency can be life-threatening during concurrent illness.</li>

12443<li>

12444The treatment of ACTH deficiency relies on replacement with hydrocortisone, including stress dosing in situations of illness to adjust to the body&#8217;s physiologically increased need for glucocorticoids.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

1244540</a>

12446]</li>

12447</ul>

12448</div>

12449</section>

12450</section>

12451<section id="_620">

12452<h4 id="_620_toc">

12453Hyperprolactinemia</h4>

12454<div class="pdq-content-list">

12455<ul id="_2376">

12456<li>

12457Hyperprolactinemia has been described in patients who received radiation therapy to the hypothalamus in doses higher than 50 Gy or who underwent surgery that disrupted the integrity of the pituitary stalk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.94">

1245894</a>

12459]</li>

12460<li>

12461 Primary hypothyroidism may lead to hyperprolactinemia as a result of hyperplasia of thyrotrophs and lactotrophs, presumably caused by thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) hypersecretion. </li>

12462<li>

12463The prolactin response to TRH is usually exaggerated in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

1246448</a>

12465,<a href="#cit/section_6.95">

1246695</a>

12467]</li>

12468<li>

12469Hyperprolactinemia may result in delayed puberty, galactorrhea, menstrual irregularities, loss of libido, hot flashes, infertility, and osteopenia. Hyperprolactinemia resulting from cranial radiation therapy is rarely symptomatic and is frequently associated with hypogonadism (both central and primary).</li>

12470<li>

12471Hyperprolactinemia rarely requires treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.96">

1247296</a>

12473]</li>

12474</ul>

12475</div>

12476</section>

12477<p id="_1724" tabindex="-1">

12478<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_622">

12479Table 11</a>

12480 summarizes pituitary gland late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

12481<table id="_622" class="table-default expandable-container">

12647</table>

12648</section>

12649<section id="_629">

12650<h3 id="_629_toc">

12651Testis and Ovary</h3>

12652<p id="_630" tabindex="-1">

12653Testicular and ovarian hormonal functions are discussed in the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_98">

12654Late Effects of the Reproductive System</a>

12655 section of this summary.</p>

12656</section>

12657<section id="_623">

12658<h3 id="_623_toc">

12659Metabolic Syndrome</h3>

12660<p id="_624" tabindex="-1">

12661An increased risk of metabolic syndrome or its components has been observed among survivors of childhood cancer. The evidence for this outcome ranges from clinically manifested conditions that are self-reported by survivors to retrospectively assessed data in medical records and hospital registries to systematic clinical evaluations of clinically well-characterized cohorts. Studies have been limited by cohort selection and participation bias, heterogeneity in treatment approach, time since treatment, and method of ascertainment. Despite these limitations, compelling evidence indicates that metabolic syndrome is highly associated with cardiovascular events and mortality.</p>

12662<p id="_1688" tabindex="-1">

12663Definitions of metabolic syndrome are evolving but generally include a combination of central (abdominal) obesity with at least two of the following features:[<a href="#cit/section_6.97">

1266497</a>

12665]</p>

12666<div class="pdq-content-list">

12667<ul id="_626">

12668<li>

12669Hypertension.</li>

12670<li>

12671Atherogenic dyslipidemia (elevated triglycerides, reduced high-density lipoprotein [HDL] cholesterol).</li>

12672<li>

12673Abnormal glucose metabolism (fasting hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinism, insulin resistance, diabetes mellitus type 2).</li>

12674</ul>

12675</div>

12676<p id="_1689" tabindex="-1">

12677Evidence (prevalence of and risk factors for metabolic syndrome in childhood cancer survivors):</p>

12678<div class="pdq-content-list">

12679<ol id="_1690">

12680<li>

12681French investigators evaluated the overall and age-specific prevalence of and risk factors for metabolic syndrome and its components among 650 adult survivors of childhood leukemia treated without HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.98">

1268298</a>

12683] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12684<ul id="_2377">

12685<li>

12686The overall prevalence of the condition was 6.9%, with the following age-specific cumulative prevalence:<div class="pdq-content-list">

12687<ul id="_2378">

12688<li>

1268920 years&#8212;1.3%.</li>

12690<li>

1269125 years&#8212;6.1%.</li>

12692<li>

1269330 years&#8212;10.8%.</li>

12694<li>

1269535 years&#8212;22.4%.</li>

12696</ul>

12697</div>

12698</li>

12699<li>

12700The prevalence of individual components of the metabolic syndrome was as follows:<div class="pdq-content-list">

12701<ul id="_2379">

12702<li>

12703Increased fasting glucose&#8212;5.8%.</li>

12704<li>

12705Increased triglycerides&#8212;11.7%.</li>

12706<li>

12707Increased abdominal circumference&#8212;16.7%.</li>

12708<li>

12709Decreased HDL cholesterol&#8212;26.8%.</li>

12710<li>

12711Increased blood pressure&#8212;36.7%.</li>

12712</ul>

12713</div>

12714</li>

12715<li>

12716Clinical factors significantly predicting the risk of metabolic syndrome included male sex (OR, 2.64; 95% CI, 1.32&#8211;5.29), age at last evaluation (OR, 1.10; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;1.17) and body mass index (BMI) at diagnosis (OR, 1.15; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.32), but not cumulative steroid dose. Irradiated and nonirradiated patients exhibited different patterns of metabolic abnormalities, with more frequent abdominal obesity in irradiated patients and more frequent hypertension in nonirradiated patients.</li>

12717</ul>

12718</div>

12719</li>

12720<li>

12721A study monitored 784 long-term childhood ALL survivors (median age, 31.7 years) for a median follow-up of 26.1 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.99">

1272299</a>

12723]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12724<ul id="_1691">

12725<li>

12726 The prevalence of metabolic syndrome was 33.6%, which was significantly higher than that in a cohort of age-, sex-, and race-matched controls (n = 777) from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (RR, 1.43; 95% CI, 1.22&#8211;1.69).</li>

12727<li>

12728Risk factors associated with metabolic syndrome in this study included older age and past exposures to cranial radiation therapy.</li>

12729<li>

12730Components of the metabolic syndrome that were significantly more prevalent in ALL survivors than in controls included obesity, insulin resistance, hypertension, and decreased HDL levels.</li>

12731</ul>

12732</div>

12733</li>

12734<li>

12735The French childhood leukemia survivors&#8217; cohort showed that the prevalence of metabolic syndrome was increased among childhood leukemia survivors (n = 1,025), relative to controls (n = 3,202).[<a href="#cit/section_6.100">

12736100</a>

12737]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12738<ul id="_3015">

12739<li>

12740Metabolic syndrome was found in 10.3% of patients (mean follow-up, 16.3 years) and 4.5% of controls (OR, 2.49; <em>

12741P</em>

12742 &lt; .001). Transplant patients treated with TBI had the highest risk (OR, 6.26; <em>

12743P</em>

12744 &lt; .001). Other treatment groups that also showed a higher risk than controls included patients treated with chemotherapy only. ORs were 1.68 (<em>

12745P</em>

12746 = .005) after chemotherapy only, 2.32 (<em>

12747P</em>

12748 = .002) after chemotherapy and cranial irradiation, and 2.18 (<em>

12749P</em>

12750 = .057) after transplantation without irradiation.</li>

12751<li>

12752Compared with controls, unique profiles were seen in survivors according to treatment. Patients who received TBI and developed metabolic syndrome had a smaller waist circumference than controls. In contrast, patients who were treated with cranial irradiation and developed metabolic syndrome had a larger waist circumference than controls. Additionally, TBI recipients had increased triglyceride levels, fasting glucose levels, and systolic blood pressure. </li>

12753</ul>

12754</div>

12755</li>

12756<li>

12757In a prospective study of 164 long-term survivors of embryonal tumors treated with abdominal radiation therapy (median follow-up, 26 years), nephroblastoma (OR, 5.2) and neuroblastoma (OR, 6.5) survivors had more components of metabolic syndrome than did controls.[<a href="#cit/section_6.101">

12758101</a>

12759]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12760<ul id="_2380">

12761<li>

12762Compared with survivors who did not receive radiation therapy, survivors treated with abdominal irradiation had higher blood pressure, triglycerides, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and total fat percentage, which were assessed by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry.</li>

12763</ul>

12764</div>

12765</li>

12766</ol>

12767</div>

12768<section id="_2381">

12769<h4 id="_2381_toc">

12770 Lifestyle impact on modifiable risk factors</h4>

12771<div class="pdq-content-list">

12772<ul id="_2228">

12773<li>

12774Modifiable risk factors (such as diet, physical activity, and smoking habits) may impact the risk of developing metabolic syndrome in childhood cancer survivors.</li>

12775<li>

12776Several studies have provided support for the potential benefits of lifestyle modifications in reducing cardiovascular disease risk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.102">

12777102</a>

12778-<a href="#cit/section_6.104">

12779104</a>

12780]</li>

12781</ul>

12782</div>

12783<p id="_1694" tabindex="-1">

12784Evidence (lifestyle modifications to reduce cardiovascular risk in childhood cancer survivors):</p>

12785<div class="pdq-content-list">

12786<ol id="_1695">

12787<li>

12788Survivors participating in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study who were adherent to a heart-healthy lifestyle had a lower risk of metabolic syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_6.102">

12789102</a>

12790]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12791<ul id="_2229">

12792<li>

12793Females (RR, 2.4; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;3.3) and males (RR, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;3.0) in the cohort who did not follow recommended dietary and physical activity guidelines had a more than twofold excess risk of having clinical features of the metabolic syndrome.</li>

12794</ul>

12795</div>

12796</li>

12797<li>

12798A CCSS investigation evaluated the impact of exercise on cardiovascular disease risk among survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma.[<a href="#cit/section_6.103">

12799103</a>

12800]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12801<ul id="_2039">

12802<li>

12803Vigorous exercise was associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular events in a dose-dependent manner, independent of cardiovascular risk profile and treatment.</li>

12804<li>

12805Survivors who were adherent to national vigorous-intensity exercise guidelines had a 51% reduction in the risk of any cardiovascular event compared with those not meeting the guidelines.</li>

12806</ul>

12807</div>

12808</li>

12809<li>

12810Another CCSS investigation evaluated the association of exercise with mortality in adult survivors of childhood cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.104">

12811104</a>

12812]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12813<ul id="_2040">

12814<li>

12815After adjusting for chronic health conditions and treatment exposures, all-cause mortality was inversely associated with survivor-reported exercise quartiles (0, 3&#8211;6, 9&#8211;12, and 15&#8211;21 metabolic equivalent task [MET] hours/week).</li>

12816<li>

12817Survivors who endorsed recommended levels of vigorous exercise (&#8805;9 MET hours/week) in early adulthood and those who increased exercise over 8 years had a lower risk of mortality.</li>

12818</ul>

12819</div>

12820</li>

12821</ol>

12822</div>

12823</section>

12824<section id="_1355">

12825<h4 id="_1355_toc">

12826Abnormal glucose metabolism</h4>

12827<p id="_1356" tabindex="-1">

12828For individuals treated at a young age (age &lt;11 years), abdominal radiation therapy and TBI are increasingly recognized as independent risk factors for diabetes mellitus in childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

128292</a>

12830,<a href="#cit/section_6.105">

12831105</a>

12832-<a href="#cit/section_6.109">

12833109</a>

12834]</p>

12835<p id="_1696" tabindex="-1">

12836Evidence (risk factors for diabetes mellitus in childhood cancer survivors):</p>

12837<div class="pdq-content-list">

12838<ol id="_1697">

12839<li>

12840A single-center cohort study of 532 long-term adult survivors (median follow-up, 17.9 years; median age, 25.6 years) observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_6.106">

12841106</a>

12842]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12843<ul id="_1698">

12844<li>

12845Treatment, but not genetic variation, was strongly associated with the occurrence of the components of metabolic syndrome.</li>

12846<li>

12847Metabolic syndrome was more frequent in survivors who received cranial (23.3%, <em>

12848P</em>

12849 = .002) or abdominal (23.4%, <em>

12850P</em>

12851 = .009) radiation therapy than in survivors who did not receive radiation therapy (10.0%).</li>

12852</ul>

12853</div>

12854</li>

12855<li>

12856A cross-sectional study evaluated cardiovascular risk factors and insulin resistance in a clinically heterogeneous cohort of 319 childhood cancer survivors 5 or more years since diagnosis and 208 sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_6.110">

12857110</a>

12858] <div class="pdq-content-list">

12859<ul id="_1699">

12860<li>

12861Insulin resistance was significantly higher in survivors treated with cisplatin plus cranial irradiation (92% brain tumors) and in those who received steroids but no cisplatin (most leukemia survivors), compared with siblings.</li>

12862<li>

12863Insulin resistance did not differ between survivors treated with surgery alone and siblings. </li>

12864<li>

12865Among survivors, analysis of individual chemotherapy agents failed to find associations with cardiovascular risk factors or insulin resistance. </li>

12866<li>

12867Compared with siblings, nearly all chemotherapeutic agents, when examined individually, seemed to be associated with a high cardiovascular risk profile, characterized by lower total lean body mass, higher percentage fat mass, and insulin resistance.</li>

12868</ul>

12869</div>

12870</li>

12871<li>

12872In a European multicenter cohort of 2,520 childhood cancer survivors (median follow-up, 28 years), significant

12873associations were found between diabetes mellitus and increasing doses of radiation therapy to the tail of the pancreas. This finding supports the contribution of radiation-induced islet cell injury to impairments of glucose homeostasis in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_6.107">

12874107</a>

12875]</li>

12876<li>

12877A report from the CCSS compared 8,599 childhood cancer survivors with 2,936 randomly selected sibling controls, and adjusted for age, BMI, and several demographic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.111">

12878111</a>

12879]<div class="pdq-content-list">

12880<ul id="_1700">

12881<li>

12882The risk of diabetes mellitus was 1.8 times higher in survivors (95% CI, 1.3&#8211;2.5; <em>

12883P</em>

12884 &lt; .001).</li>

12885<li>

12886Significant associations were found between diabetes mellitus and young age at diagnosis (0&#8211;4 years), the use of alkylating agents, and abdominal radiation therapy or TBI. </li>

12887<li>

12888Survivors exposed to abdominal radiation had a 3.4-fold higher increased risk of diabetes (95% CI, 2.3&#8211;5.0; <em>

12889P</em>

12890 &lt; .001) when compared with siblings and after adjusting for BMI. Compared with siblings, survivors of neuroblastoma and Wilms tumor who were treated with abdominal radiation therapy had a 6.9-fold and 2.1-fold increased risk of diabetes, respectively. Individuals in these groups who had not been exposed to abdominal radiation therapy were not at increased risk.</li>

12891<li>

12892Survivors were significantly more likely to be receiving medication for hypertension, dyslipidemia, and/or diabetes mellitus than were sibling controls.</li>

12893</ul>

12894</div>

12895</li>

12896</ol>

12897</div>

12898</section>

12899<p id="_1725" tabindex="-1">

12900<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_628">

12901Table 12</a>

12902 summarizes metabolic syndrome late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

12903<table id="_628" class="table-default expandable-container">

12904<caption>

12905Table 12. Metabolic Syndrome Late Effects<span class="sup">

12906a</span>

12907</caption>

12908<colgroup>

12909<col width="33.33%">

12910<col width="33.33%">

12911<col width="33.33%">

12912</colgroup>

12913<THead>

12914<tr>

12915<th>

12916Predisposing Therapy</th>

12917<th>

12918Potential Late Effects</th>

12919<th>

12920Health Screening</th>

12921</tr>

12922</THead>

12923<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

12924<tr>

12925<td colspan="3">

12926BMI = body mass index.</td>

12927</tr>

12928<tr>

12929<td colspan="3">

12930<span class="sup">

12931a</span>

12932Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

12933Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

12934.</td>

12935</tr>

12936</TFoot>

12937<tbody>

12938<tr>

12939<td rowspan="2">

12940Abdominal irradiation; total-body irradiation.</td>

12941<td rowspan="2">

12942Components of metabolic syndrome (abdominal obesity,

12943 hypertension, dyslipidemia, impaired glucose

12944 metabolism)

12945</td>

12946<td>

12947Height, weight, BMI, blood pressure test</td>

12948</tr>

12949<tr>

12950<td>

12951Laboratory tests: Fasting glucose and lipids</td>

12952</tr>

12953</tbody>

12954</table>

12955</section>

12956<section id="_640">

12957<h3 id="_640_toc">

12958Body Composition: Underweight, Overweight, and Obesity</h3>

12959<div class="pdq-content-list">

12960<ul id="_2382">

12961<li>

12962Childhood cancer survivors are at risk of experiencing abnormal body composition, which includes becoming underweight (BMI, &lt;18.5), becoming overweight (BMI, &gt;25.0 to BMI, &lt;30.0), or being affected by obesity (BMI, &#8805;30.0).</li>

12963<li>

12964BMI at diagnosis has been identified as a significant predictor of being underweight or overweight at follow-up. This finding suggests that genetic or environmental factors contribute to the development or persistence of abnormal body composition.[<a href="#cit/section_6.112">

12965112</a>

12966,<a href="#cit/section_6.113">

12967113</a>

12968]</li>

12969</ul>

12970</div>

12971<section id="_2383">

12972<h4 id="_2383_toc">

12973Underweight</h4>

12974<div class="pdq-content-list">

12975<ul id="_2384">

12976<li>

12977CCSS investigators identified treatment-related risk factors for being underweight, including TBI (females) or abdominal irradiation (males), use of alkylating agents, and use of anthracyclines.[<a href="#cit/section_6.113">

12978113</a>

12979] </li>

12980<li>

12981Among a cohort of 893 Dutch childhood cancer survivors monitored for a median of almost 15 years, being underweight was linked to a high prevalence of moderate to extreme adverse health statuses and reports of a major medical condition.[<a href="#cit/section_6.112">

12982112</a>

12983]</li>

12984</ul>

12985</div>

12986</section>

12987<section id="_2385">

12988<h4 id="_2385_toc">

12989Overweight/obesity</h4>

12990<div class="pdq-content-list">

12991<ul id="_2386">

12992<li>

12993To date, patients with cancer who have an increased incidence of being affected by overweight and obesity are primarily ALL [<a href="#cit/section_6.112">

12994112</a>

12995,<a href="#cit/section_6.114">

12996114</a>

12997-<a href="#cit/section_6.118">

12998118</a>

12999]

13000 and CNS tumor [<a href="#cit/section_6.38">

1300138</a>

13002,<a href="#cit/section_6.94">

1300394</a>

13004] survivors who were treated with cranial radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.113">

13005113</a>

13006,<a href="#cit/section_6.119">

13007119</a>

13008]</li>

13009<li>

13010The development of overweight/obesity after cranial radiation therapy is multifactorial and includes the following:[<a href="#cit/section_6.116">

13011116</a>

13012,<a href="#cit/section_6.120">

13013120</a>

13014,<a href="#cit/section_6.121">

13015121</a>

13016]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13017<ul id="_2387">

13018<li>

13019Growth hormone deficiency.</li>

13020<li>

13021Leptin sensitivity.</li>

13022<li>

13023Reduced levels of physical activity and energy expenditure. </li>

13024</ul>

13025</div>

13026</li>

13027</ul>

13028</div>

13029</section>

13030<p id="_2388" tabindex="-1">

13031Evidence (risk factors for overweight/obesity):</p>

13032<div class="pdq-content-list">

13033<ol id="_2389">

13034<li>

13035CCSS investigators reported the following independent risk factors for obesity in childhood cancer survivors including treatment, lifestyle, and medication use:[<a href="#cit/section_6.122">

13036122</a>

13037]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13038<ul id="_2390">

13039<li>

13040Cancer diagnosed at ages 5 to 9 years (RR, 1.12; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.24).</li>

13041<li>

13042Abnormal physical functioning (RR, 1.19; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;1.33).</li>

13043<li>

13044Hypothalamic-pituitary radiation dose of 20 Gy to 30 Gy (RR, 1.17; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.3; <em>

13045P</em>

13046 = .01).</li>

13047<li>

13048Specific antidepressant use of paroxetine (RR, 1.29; 95% CI, 1.08&#8211;1.54).</li>

13049<li>

13050Survivors who adhered to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidelines for vigorous physical activity (RR, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.97; <em>

13051P</em>

13052 = .01) and who had a medium amount of anxiety (RR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.75&#8211;0.99; <em>

13053P</em>

13054 = .04) had a lower risk of obesity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.122">

13055122</a>

13056]</li>

13057</ul>

13058</div>

13059</li>

13060</ol>

13061</div>

13062<section id="_1298">

13063<h4 id="_1298_toc">

13064Body composition alterations after childhood ALL</h4>

13065<p id="_2780" tabindex="-1">

13066Evidence (risk factors for body composition alterations):</p>

13067<div class="pdq-content-list">

13068<ol id="_2391">

13069<li>

13070Moderate-dose cranial radiation therapy (18&#8211;24 Gy) among ALL survivors is associated with obesity, particularly in females treated at a young age.[<a href="#cit/section_6.114">

13071114</a>

13072,<a href="#cit/section_6.116">

13073116</a>

13074,<a href="#cit/section_6.123">

13075123</a>

13076]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13077<ul id="_2234">

13078<li>

13079Female adult survivors of childhood ALL who were treated with cranial radiation therapy of 24 Gy before age 5 years are four times more likely to be affected by obesity than are women who have not been treated for a cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.114">

13080114</a>

13081]</li>

13082<li>

13083Women treated with 18 Gy to 24 Gy cranial radiation therapy before age 10 years have a substantially greater rate of increase in their BMI through their young adult years than do women who were treated for ALL with only chemotherapy or women in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_6.116">

13084116</a>

13085] </li>

13086<li>

13087These women also have a significantly increased visceral adiposity and associated insulin resistance.[<a href="#cit/section_6.124">

13088124</a>

13089,<a href="#cit/section_6.125">

13090125</a>

13091]</li>

13092</ul>

13093</div>

13094</li>

13095<li>

13096Body composition alterations appear to be attenuated in males.<div class="pdq-content-list">

13097<ul id="_2392">

13098<li>

13099A study of long-term male survivors of ALL (mean age, 29 years) observed significantly higher body adiposity than in age-matched controls, despite normal weight and BMI.[<a href="#cit/section_6.126">

13100126</a>

13101]</li>

13102<li>

13103Potential indicators of increased adiposity included high leptin and low sex hormone&#8211;binding globulin levels.[<a href="#cit/section_6.126">

13104126</a>

13105]</li>

13106<li>

13107Serum testicular endocrine markers (testosterone, FSH, or inhibin B) did not correlate with body adiposity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.126">

13108126</a>

13109]</li>

13110</ul>

13111</div>

13112</li>

13113<li>

13114ALL therapy regimens are associated with increases in BMI shortly after completion of therapy, and possibly with a higher risk of obesity in the long term.[<a href="#cit/section_6.117">

13115117</a>

13116,<a href="#cit/section_6.118">

13117118</a>

13118,<a href="#cit/section_6.127">

13119127</a>

13120-<a href="#cit/section_6.129">

13121129</a>

13122]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13123<ul id="_2237">

13124<li>

13125 Several studies have reported that survivors of childhood ALL treated with chemotherapy alone also exhibit long-term changes in body composition, with relative increases in body fat [<a href="#cit/section_6.125">

13126125</a>

13127,<a href="#cit/section_6.130">

13128130</a>

13129-<a href="#cit/section_6.132">

13130132</a>

13131] and visceral adiposity in comparison to lean mass.[<a href="#cit/section_6.124">

13132124</a>

13133] </li>

13134<li>

13135These changes cannot be detected if BMI alone is used in the assessment of metabolic risk in this population.</li>

13136</ul>

13137</div>

13138</li>

13139<li>

13140A genetic predisposition to excess adiposity may be enhanced when a child with ALL is treated with cranial irradiation. Genetic determinants of BMI identified in the general population were investigated in two large cohorts of childhood cancer survivors (n = 1,458) (CCSS and St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study).[<a href="#cit/section_6.133">

13141133</a>

13142] <div class="pdq-content-list">

13143<ul id="_2728">

13144<li>

13145 Among ALL survivors who were treated with cranial radiation therapy in childhood, investigators identified statistical interactions of cranial radiation therapy treatment in survivors with germline genetic variants known to affect the baseline genetic risk of adiposity. This suggests that a genetic predisposition to excess adiposity may be enhanced when an individual is treated with cranial radiation therapy for childhood ALL. </li>

13146</ul>

13147</div>

13148</li>

13149</ol>

13150</div>

13151<p id="_1705" tabindex="-1">

13152 Evidence (body composition changes in adult survivors of childhood ALL):</p>

13153<div class="pdq-content-list">

13154<ol id="_1706">

13155<li>

13156 A cohort study of 365 adult survivors of ALL (149 treated with cranial radiation therapy and 216 treated without cranial radiation therapy) compared body composition, energy balance, and fitness with age-, sex-, and race-matched peers.[<a href="#cit/section_6.134">

13157134</a>

13158]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13159<ul id="_1707">

13160<li>

13161Female survivors who were not exposed to cranial irradiation had comparable body composition values to that of peers. </li>

13162<li>

13163Waist circumference, waist-to-height ratio, total fat mass, and percent fat mass were higher among male survivors and cranial radiation&#8211;exposed female survivors than among comparison group members.</li>

13164<li>

13165Survivors of both sexes exposed to cranial radiation therapy had higher BMI and percent body fat than did survivors not exposed to cranial radiation therapy.</li>

13166<li>

13167Although survivors who did not receive cranial radiation therapy had energy balances similar to the matched peer group, they had significantly higher measures of impaired fitness (impaired flexibility, peripheral sensorimotor deficits, proximal muscle weakness, and poor exercise tolerance).</li>

13168</ul>

13169</div>

13170</li>

13171<li>

13172In a CCSS study that was based on self-reported height and weight measurements, the following was observed:<div class="pdq-content-list">

13173<ul id="_3021">

13174<li>

13175Adult survivors of childhood ALL treated with chemotherapy alone did not have significantly higher rates of obesity than sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_6.114">

13176114</a>

13177] </li>

13178<li>

13179There were also no differences in BMI changes between these groups after a subsequent period of follow-up that averaged 7.8 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.116">

13180116</a>

13181]</li>

13182</ul>

13183</div>

13184</li>

13185<li>

13186Swiss investigators evaluated self-reported weight in 1,936 adult survivors of childhood ALL, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and Hodgkin lymphoma (median age, 24 years; median time from diagnosis, 17 years) and compared them with siblings and the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_6.135">

13187135</a>

13188]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13189<ul id="_2393">

13190<li>

13191The proportion of survivors who reported being overweight (26%) was comparable to that of siblings (24%) and the general Swiss population (25%). </li>

13192<li>

13193There was no evidence of a relationship between cumulative glucocorticoid dose and being overweight. </li>

13194<li>

13195There was also no evidence that the use of cranial radiation therapy modified the effect of the cumulative glucocorticoid dose on being overweight.</li>

13196</ul>

13197</div>

13198 </li>

13199</ol>

13200</div>

13201<p id="_2400" tabindex="-1">

13202Variable outcomes across studies likely relate to the use of BMI as the metric for abnormal body composition, which does not adequately assess visceral adiposity that can contribute to metabolic risk in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_6.136">

13203136</a>

13204]</p>

13205</section>

13206<section id="_1301">

13207<h4 id="_1301_toc">

13208Body composition alterations after treatment for CNS tumors</h4>

13209<p id="_1302" tabindex="-1">

13210Among brain tumor survivors treated with higher doses of cranial radiation therapy, the highest risk of developing obesity has been observed in females treated at a younger age.[<a href="#cit/section_6.137">

13211137</a>

13212]</p>

13213<p id="_2394" tabindex="-1">

13214Survivors of craniopharyngioma have a substantially increased risk of developing extreme obesity because of the tumor location and the hypothalamic damage resulting from surgical resection.[<a href="#cit/section_6.138">

13215138</a>

13216-<a href="#cit/section_6.141">

13217141</a>

13218]</p>

13219<p id="_2888" tabindex="-1">

13220A cohort of 661 childhood survivors of brain tumors (mean follow-up time, 7.3 years) was evaluated for weight gain associated with hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction. This cohort excluded survivors who had craniopharyngiomas or pituitary tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.142">

13221142</a>

13222]</p>

13223<div class="pdq-content-list">

13224<ul id="_2889">

13225<li>

13226Among survivors between the ages of 4 and 20 years at follow-up, 20.3% were classified as overweight and 8.5% had obesity, compared with 10.5% and 2.7%, respectively, in the general Dutch population of comparable age.</li>

13227<li>

13228Hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction was more prevalent in survivors who are overweight or have obesity than in survivors of normal weight. </li>

13229<li>

13230BMI SDS at diagnosis, diagnosis of low-grade glioma, and history of diabetes insipidus and central precocious puberty were associated with weight gain, being overweight, or having obesity.</li>

13231</ul>

13232</div>

13233</section>

13234<section id="_1303">

13235<h4 id="_1303_toc">

13236Body composition alterations after HSCT</h4>

13237<div class="pdq-content-list">

13238<ul id="_2395">

13239<li>

13240Survivors of childhood cancer treated with TBI in preparation for an allogeneic HSCT have increased measures of body fatness (percent fat) while often having a normal BMI.[<a href="#cit/section_6.108">

13241108</a>

13242,<a href="#cit/section_6.143">

13243143</a>

13244-<a href="#cit/section_6.145">

13245145</a>

13246]</li>

13247<li>

13248Longitudinal decline in BMI related to substantial decrease in lean mass has been observed among survivors of hematological malignancies treated with allogeneic HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.146">

13249146</a>

13250]</li>

13251<li>

13252This finding was largely attributable to TBI conditioning and severity of chronic GVHD.[<a href="#cit/section_6.146">

13253146</a>

13254]</li>

13255</ul>

13256</div>

13257</section>

13258<section id="_2900">

13259<h4 id="_2900_toc">

13260Body composition alterations after solid malignancies</h4>

13261<div class="pdq-content-list">

13262<ul id="_2901">

13263<li>

13264Survivors of abdominal and pelvic solid tumors treated with radiation therapy are at risk of alterations in body composition and metabolic health that can adversely affect functional performance.</li>

13265<li>

13266Among 431 survivors of childhood abdominal or pelvic tumors (median attained age, 29.9 years), higher cumulative doses of abdominal and pelvic radiation therapy were associated with lower lean muscle mass in both males and females.[<a href="#cit/section_6.147">

13267147</a>

13268]</li>

13269<li>

13270Compared with survivors who have normal (high) lean mass and normal (low) fat mass, survivors with normal lean mass and high fat mass had a significantly higher risk of insulin resistance, low HDL cholesterol, reduced quadriceps strength, and reduced distance covered in a 6-minute walk.[<a href="#cit/section_6.147">

13271147</a>

13272]</li>

13273</ul>

13274</div>

13275</section>

13276<section id="_1305">

13277<h4 id="_1305_toc">

13278Body composition and frailty</h4>

13279<p id="_1306" tabindex="-1">

13280Young adult survivors of childhood cancer have a higher-than-expected prevalence of frailty, a phenotype characterized by low muscle mass, self-reported exhaustion, low energy expenditure, slow walking speed, and weakness.[<a href="#cit/section_6.148">

13281148</a>

13282] </p>

13283<div class="pdq-content-list">

13284<ul id="_2241">

13285<li>

13286Individuals are considered <strong>

13287prefrail</strong>

13288 if they have two of these five characteristics and <strong>

13289frail</strong>

13290 if they have three or more of these characteristics.[<a href="#cit/section_6.148">

13291148</a>

13292] </li>

13293<li>

13294The frailty phenotype increases in prevalence with aging, and has been associated with excess risk of mortality and onset of chronic conditions.[<a href="#cit/section_6.148">

13295148</a>

13296] </li>

13297<li>

13298In CCSS participants, the overall prevalence of frailty among survivors (6.4%) was three times higher than that of sibling controls (2.2%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.149">

13299149</a>

13300]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13301<ul id="_2244">

13302<li>

13303The highest prevalence of frailty was reported in survivors of CNS tumors (9.5%) and bone tumors (8.1%).</li>

13304<li>

13305Cranial radiation, pelvic radiation (&#8805;34 Gy), and lung surgery were independent risk factors for frailty in the CCSS cohort.</li>

13306</ul>

13307</div>

13308 </li>

13309<li>

13310In St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study participants (median age at study entry, 30 years), frailty prevalence increased from 6.2% to 13.6% during the 5 years of follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_6.150">

13311150</a>

13312]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13313<ul id="_2790">

13314<li>

13315Risk factors for frailty at follow-up included treatment with chest radiation therapy of 20 Gy or higher (OR, 1.98), cardiac (OR, 1.58) and neurological (OR, 2.58) conditions, lack of strength training (OR, 1.74), sedentary lifestyle (OR, 1.75), and frailty at study entry (OR, 11.12). </li>

13316<li>

13317Prior history of frailty was the strongest risk factor for death during follow-up (OR, 3.52).</li>

13318</ul>

13319</div>

13320</li>

13321<li>

13322In a St. Jude Lifetime Cohort study (follow-up interval, 5 years), young-adult survivors of childhood cancer who are considered prefrail and frail (n = 205) experienced significant declines in neurocognitive domains commonly associated with dementia and Alzheimer disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.151">

13323151</a>

13324]<div class="pdq-content-list">

13325<ul id="_2881">

13326<li>

13327Survivors considered frail declined more on tests of short-term verbal recall and executive function than did survivors not considered frail.</li>

13328<li>

13329Survivors considered frail and prefrail experienced greater declines in focused attention than did survivors not considered frail.</li>

13330</ul>

13331</div>

13332</li>

13333<li>

13334Ongoing research aims to elucidate the pathophysiology of frailty and develop/test interventions to prevent or reverse this condition.</li>

13335</ul>

13336</div>

13337<p id="_1726" tabindex="-1">

13338<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_644">

13339Table 13</a>

13340 summarizes body composition late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

13372.</td>

13373</tr>

13376<tr>

13377<td rowspan="2">

13378Cranial radiation therapy</td>

13379<td rowspan="2">

13380Overweight/obesity</td>

13381<td>

13382Height, weight, BMI, blood pressure

13383test</td>

13384</tr>

13387Laboratory tests: Fasting glucose and lipids

13388</td>

13391</table>

13392<p id="_437" tabindex="-1">

13393For endocrine and metabolic syndrome late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

13394Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

13395.</p>
