14005

14006 </section>

14007

14008

14009

14010 <section id="_184">

14011

14012 <h2>

14013Late Effects of the Immune System</h2>

14014

14015 <div id="_section_184" class="pdq-sections">

14016<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

14017<h6>

14018In This Section</h6>

14019<ul>

14020<li>

14021<a href="#_185_toc">

14022Asplenia<ul>

14023<li>

14024<a href="#_1210_toc">

14025Posttherapy management</a>

14026</li>

14027</ul>

14028</a>

14029</li>

14030<li>

14031<a href="#_422_toc">

14032Humoral Immunity</a>

14033</li>

14034<li>

14035<a href="#_2977_toc">

14036Infection Risks</a>

14037</li>

14038</ul>

14039</nav>

14040<p id="_1358" tabindex="-1">

14041Late effects of the immune system have not been well studied, especially in survivors treated with contemporary therapies. Reports published about long-term immune system outcomes are limited by retrospective data collection, small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, heterogeneity in treatment approach, time since treatment, and method of ascertainment.</p>

14042<section id="_185">

14043<h3 id="_185_toc">

14044Asplenia</h3>

14045<p id="_42" tabindex="-1">

14046Surgical or functional splenectomy increases the risk of life-threatening invasive bacterial infection:[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

140471</a>

14048] </p>

14049<div class="pdq-content-list">

14050<ul id="_1206">

14051<li>

14052Although staging laparotomy is no longer standard practice for pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma, patients from earlier treatment periods have ongoing risks.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

140532</a>

14054,<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

140553</a>

14056]</li>

14057<li>

14058Children may be rendered asplenic by radiation therapy to the spleen in doses greater than 30 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

140594</a>

14060,<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

140615</a>

14062] Low-dose involved-field radiation therapy (21 Gy) combined with multiagent chemotherapy did not appear to adversely affect splenic function, as measured by pitted red blood cell assays.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

140635</a>

14064] No other studies of immune status after radiation therapy are available.</li>

14065<li>

14066Functional asplenia (with Howell-Jolly bodies, reduced splenic size and blood flow) after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) has been attributed to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).</li>

14067<li>

14068Childhood Cancer Survivor Study investigators observed a significantly increased risk of late infection-related mortality among survivors who were treated with splenectomy (relative risk [RR], 7.7; 95% confidence interval [CI], 3.1&#8211;19.1).[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

140696</a>

14070]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14071<ul id="_2593" class="list-dash">

14072<li>

14073Splenic radiation was also associated with a dose-related risk of late infection-related mortality (0.1&#8211;9.9 Gy: RR, 2.0; 95% CI, 0.9&#8211;4.5; 10.0&#8211;19.9 Gy: RR, 5.5; 95% CI, 1.9&#8211;15.4; &gt;20.0 Gy: RR, 6.0; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;20.2).</li>

14074<li>

14075 The low cumulative incidence of infection-related late mortality of 1.5% at 35 years after splenectomy and 0.6% after splenic radiation indicates that these are rare events.</li>

14076</ul>

14077</div>

14078</li>

14079</ul>

14080</div>

14081<p id="_885" tabindex="-1">

14082Individuals with asplenia, regardless of the reason for the asplenic state, have an increased risk of fulminant bacteremia, especially associated with encapsulated bacteria, which is associated with a high mortality rate.</p>

14083<p id="_2594" tabindex="-1">

14084The risk of bacteremia is higher in younger children than in older children, and this risk may be higher during the years immediately after splenectomy. Fulminant septicemia, however, has been reported in adults up to 25 years after splenectomy.</p>

14085<p id="_1207" tabindex="-1">

14086Bacteremia may be caused by the following organisms in asplenic survivors:</p>

14087<div class="pdq-content-list">

14088<ul id="_1208">

14089<li>

14090<em>

14091Streptococcus pneumoniae</em>

14092. The most common pathogen that causes bacteremia in children with asplenia.</li>

14093<li>

14094Other <em>

14095streptococci</em>

14096.</li>

14097<li>

14098<em>

14099Haemophilus influenzae</em>

14100 type b (Hib).</li>

14101<li>

14102<em>

14103Neisseria meningitidis</em>

14104.</li>

14105<li>

14106<em>

14107Escherichia coli</em>

14108; <em>

14109Staphylococcus aureus</em>

14110.</li>

14111<li>

14112Gram-negative bacilli, such as the <em>

14113Salmonella</em>

14114 species, the <em>

14115Klebsiella</em>

14116 species, and <em>

14117Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em>

14118. </li>

14119</ul>

14120</div>

14121<p id="_1209" tabindex="-1">

14122Individuals with functional or surgical asplenia are also at increased risk of fatal malaria and severe babesiosis.</p>

14123<section id="_1210">

14124<h4 id="_1210_toc">

14125Posttherapy management</h4>

14126<div class="pdq-content-list">

14127<ul id="_2595">

14128<li>

14129Clinicians should consider and encourage the administration of inactivated vaccines (e.g., influenza) and vaccines made of purified antigens (e.g., pneumococcus), bacterial components (e.g., diphtheria-tetanus-pertussis), or genetically engineered recombinant antigens (e.g., hepatitis B) in all cancer and transplant survivors according to recommended doses and schedules.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

141307</a>

14131-<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

141329</a>

14133]</li>

14134<li>

14135Two primary doses of quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine should be administered 2 months apart to children with asplenia, from age 2 years through adolescence, and a booster dose should be administered every 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

1413610</a>

14137] For more information, see the <a href="https://redbook.solutions.aap.org/SS/Immunization_Schedules.aspx" title="https://redbook.solutions.aap.org/SS/Immunization_Schedules.aspx">

14138Immunization Schedules for 2023</a>

14139 section of the Red Book.<div class="pdq-content-list">

14140<ul id="_2596" class="list-dash">

14141<li>

14142The efficacy of meningococcal vaccines in children with asplenia has not been established.</li>

14143<li>

14144 No known contraindication exists to giving these vaccines at the same time as other required vaccines, in separate syringes, and at different sites.</li>

14145</ul>

14146</div>

14147</li>

14148<li>

14149Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) and pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV) are indicated at the recommended age for all children with asplenia.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

1415011</a>

14151,<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

1415212</a>

14153]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14154<ul id="_2597" class="list-dash">

14155<li>

14156 Following the administration of the appropriate number of doses of PCV13, PPSV23 should be administered starting at age 24 months.</li>

14157<li>

14158 A second dose should be administered 5 years later.</li>

14159<li>

14160 For children aged 2 to 5 years with a complete PCV7 series who have not received PCV13, a supplemental dose of PCV13 should be administered.</li>

14161<li>

14162 For asplenic individuals aged 6 to 18 years who have not received a dose of PCV13, a supplemental dose of PCV13 should be considered.</li>

14163</ul>

14164</div>

14165</li>

14166<li>

14167 Hib immunization should be initiated at age 2 months, as recommended for otherwise healthy young children and for previously unimmunized children with asplenia.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

1416811</a>

14169] For more information, see the <a href="https://redbook.solutions.aap.org/SS/Immunization_Schedules.aspx" title="https://redbook.solutions.aap.org/SS/Immunization_Schedules.aspx">

14170Immunization Schedules for 2023</a>

14171 section of the Red Book. </li>

14172</ul>

14173</div>

14174<p id="_888" tabindex="-1">

14175Daily antimicrobial prophylaxis against pneumococcal infections is recommended for young children with asplenia, regardless of their immunization status.</p>

14176<div class="pdq-content-list">

14177<ul id="_2598">

14178<li>

14179 Although the efficacy of daily antimicrobial prophylaxis has been proven only in patients with sickle cell anemia, this experience has been extended to other high-risk children, including asplenic children with a history of malignant neoplasms or thalassemia.</li>

14180<li>

14181 In general, antimicrobial prophylaxis (in addition to immunization) should be considered for all children with asplenia younger than 5 years and for at least 1 year after splenectomy.</li>

14182<li>

14183The age at which antimicrobial prophylaxis is discontinued is an empiric decision.<div class="pdq-content-list">

14184<ul id="_2599" class="list-dash">

14185<li>

14186 On the basis of a multicenter study in sickle cell disease, prophylactic penicillin can be discontinued at age 5 years among those who are receiving regular medical attention and who have not had a severe pneumococcal infection or surgical splenectomy. </li>

14187<li>

14188The appropriate duration of prophylaxis is unknown for children with asplenia attributable to other causes.</li>

14189<li>

14190 Some experts continue prophylaxis throughout childhood and into adulthood for particularly high-risk patients with asplenia.</li>

14191</ul>

14192</div>

14193</li>

14194</ul>

14195</div>

14196</section>

14197<p id="_1727" tabindex="-1">

14198<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_424">

14199Table 14</a>

14200 summarizes spleen late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

14201<table id="_424" class="table-default expandable-container">

14202<caption>

14203Table 14. Spleen Late Effects<span class="sup">

14204a</span>

14205</caption>

14206<colgroup>

14207<col width="33.33%">

14208<col width="33.33%">

14209<col width="33.33%">

14210</colgroup>

14211<THead>

14212<tr>

14213<th>

14214Predisposing Therapy</th>

14215<th>

14216Immunologic Effects</th>

14217<th>

14218Health Screening/Interventions</th>

14219</tr>

14220</THead>

14221<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

14222<tr>

14223<td colspan="3">

14224GVHD = graft-versus-host disease; HSCT = hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; IgA = immunoglobulin A; T = temperature.</td>

14225</tr>

14226<tr>

14227<td colspan="3">

14228<span class="sup">

14229a</span>

14230Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

14231Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

14232.</td>

14233</tr>

14234</TFoot>

14235<tbody>

14236<tr>

14237<td rowspan="2">

14238Radiation exposing spleen;

14239splenectomy;

14240HSCT with currently active GVHD

14241</td>

14242<td rowspan="2">

14243Asplenia/hyposplenia;

14244overwhelming post-splenectomy sepsis</td>

14245<td>

14246Blood cultures during febrile episodes (T &gt;38.5&#176;C); empiric antibiotics</td>

14247</tr>

14248<tr>

14249<td>

14250Immunization for encapsulated organisms (pneumococcal, <em>

14251Haemophilus influenzae</em>

14252 type b, and meningococcal vaccines)</td>

14253</tr>

14254<tr>

14255<td rowspan="2">

14256HSCT with any history of chronic GVHD</td>

14257<td rowspan="2">

14258 Immunologic complications (secretory IgA deficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia, decreased B cells, T cell dysfunction, chronic infections [e.g., conjunctivitis, sinusitis, and bronchitis associated with chronic GVHD])</td>

14259<td>

14260History: chronic conjunctivitis, chronic sinusitis, chronic bronchitis, recurrent or unusual infections, sepsis

14261</td>

14262</tr>

14263<tr>

14264<td>

14265Exam: attention to eyes, nose/sinuses, and lungs

14266</td>

14267</tr>

14268</tbody>

14269</table>

14270<p id="_438" tabindex="-1">

14271For more information about posttransplant immunization, see the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) <em>

14272<a href="https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr4910a1.htm" title="https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr4910a1.htm">

14273Guidelines for Preventing Opportunistic Infections Among Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant Recipients</a>

14274</em>

14275.</p>

14276</section>

14277<section id="_422">

14278<h3 id="_422_toc">

14279Humoral Immunity</h3>

14280<p id="_423" tabindex="-1">

14281Although the immune system appears to recover from the effects of active chemotherapy and radiation therapy, there is some evidence that lymphoid subsets do not normalize in all survivors. Innate immunity, thymopoiesis, and DNA damage responses to radiation were shown to be abnormal in survivors of childhood leukemia.[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

1428213</a>

14283]</p>

14284<div class="pdq-content-list">

14285<ul id="_2600">

14286<li>

14287 Defects in immune recovery characterized by B-cell depletion have been observed in 2-year survivors of standard-risk and intermediate-risk acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

1428814</a>

14289]</li>

14290<li>

14291 Antibody levels to previous vaccinations are also reduced in patients off therapy for ALL for at least 1 year,[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

1429215</a>

14293,<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

1429416</a>

14295] suggesting abnormal humoral immunity [<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

1429617</a>

14297] and a need for revaccination in such children.</li>

14298<li>

14299 Survivors of childhood cancer may remain susceptible to vaccine-preventable infections. Treatment intensity, age at diagnosis, and time from treatment are associated with the risk of losing preexisting immunity.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

1430018</a>

14301,<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

1430219</a>

14303]</li>

14304</ul>

14305</div>

14306<p id="_1254" tabindex="-1">

14307While there is a paucity of data regarding the benefits of administering active immunizations in this population, reimmunization is necessary to provide protective antibodies.</p>

14308<div class="pdq-content-list">

14309<ul id="_2601">

14310<li>

14311 The recommended reimmunization schedule will depend on previously received vaccinations and on the intensity of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1431220</a>

14313,<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1431421</a>

14315]</li>

14316<li>

14317 In some children who received intensive treatment, consideration may be given to evaluating the antibodies against common vaccination antigens to determine the need for revaccination. For more information, see the <a href="https://redbook.solutions.aap.org/SS/Immunization_Schedules.aspx" title="https://redbook.solutions.aap.org/SS/Immunization_Schedules.aspx">

14318Immunization Schedules for 2022</a>

14319 section of the Red Book. </li>

14320</ul>

14321</div>

14322<p id="_1211" tabindex="-1">

14323Immune status is also compromised after HSCT, particularly in association with GVHD.[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

1432422</a>

14325]</p>

14326<div class="pdq-content-list">

14327<ul id="_2602">

14328<li>

14329 In a prospective longitudinal study of 210 survivors treated with allogeneic HSCT, antibody responses lasting for more than 5 years after immunization were observed in most patients for tetanus (95.7%), rubella (92.3%), poliovirus (97.9%), and, in diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) recipients, diphtheria (100%).[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1433023</a>

14331]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14332<ul id="_2603" class="list-dash">

14333<li>

14334Responses to pertussis (25.0%), measles (66.7%), mumps (61.5%), hepatitis B (72.9%), and diphtheria in tetanus-diphtheria (Td) recipients (48.6%) were less favorable.</li>

14335<li>

14336 Factors associated with vaccine failure include older age at immunization; lower CD3, CD4, or CD19 count; higher immunoglobulin M concentration; positive recipient cytomegalovirus serology; negative titer before immunization; history of acute or chronic GVHD; and radiation conditioning.</li>

14337</ul>

14338</div>

14339</li>

14340</ul>

14341</div>

14342<p id="_736" tabindex="-1">

14343Follow-up recommendations for transplant recipients have been published by the major North American and European transplant groups, the CDC, and the Infectious Diseases Society of America.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1434424</a>

14345,<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

1434625</a>

14347]</p>

14348</section>

14349<section id="_2977">

14350<h3 id="_2977_toc">

14351Infection Risks</h3>

14352<p id="_2978" tabindex="-1">

14353Infectious complications resulting in hospitalization occur in excess rates among long-term childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

1435426</a>

14355]</p>

14356<div class="pdq-content-list">

14357<ul id="_2979">

14358<li>

14359In a retrospective population-based observational study, the incidence rate was 12.6 per 1,000 person-years for infection associated with hospitalization among 5-year childhood cancer survivors, compared with 2.4 for individuals without cancer who were matched for birth year and sex. This represented an incidence rate ratio of 5.1. </li>

14360<li>

14361Incident rates remained elevated more than twofold during the 5- to 10-year and longer than 10-year postdiagnosis periods. </li>

14362<li>

14363Survivors had a greater risk of infection (incident rate ratio, 13.1) relative to comparators when potentially vaccine-preventable infections were evaluated.</li>

14364</ul>

14365</div>

14366</section>

14367<p id="_439" tabindex="-1">

14368For immune system late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

14369Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

14370.</p>

14432[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14433</li>

14435Brodtman DH, Rosenthal DW, Redner A, et al.: Immunodeficiency in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia after completion of modern aggressive chemotherapeutic regimens. J Pediatr 146 (5): 654-61, 2005.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15870670&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15870670&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14436[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14437</li>

14438<li id="section_7.18">

14439Fayea NY, Fouda AE, Kandil SM: Immunization status in childhood cancer survivors: A hidden risk which could be prevented. Pediatr Neonatol 58 (6): 541-545, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27543381&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27543381&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14440[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14441</li>

14442<li id="section_7.19">

14443Bochennek K, Allwinn R, Langer R, et al.: Differential loss of humoral immunity against measles, mumps, rubella and varicella-zoster virus in children treated for cancer. Vaccine 32 (27): 3357-61, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24793952&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24793952&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14444[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14445</li>

14446<li id="section_7.20">

14447Ruggiero A, Battista A, Coccia P, et al.: How to manage vaccinations in children with cancer. Pediatr Blood Cancer 57 (7): 1104-8, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21953691&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21953691&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14448[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14449</li>

14450<li id="section_7.21">

14451Patel SR, Chisholm JC, Heath PT: Vaccinations in children treated with standard-dose cancer therapy or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Pediatr Clin North Am 55 (1): 169-86, xi, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18242320&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18242320&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14452[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14453</li>

14454<li id="section_7.22">

14455Olkinuora HA, Taskinen MH, Saarinen-Pihkala UM, et al.: Multiple viral infections post-hematopoietic stem cell transplantation are linked to the appearance of chronic GVHD among pediatric recipients of allogeneic grafts. Pediatr Transplant 14 (2): 242-8, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19691523&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19691523&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14456[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14457</li>

14458<li id="section_7.23">

14459Inaba H, Hartford CM, Pei D, et al.: Longitudinal analysis of antibody response to immunization in paediatric survivors after allogeneic haematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Br J Haematol 156 (1): 109-17, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22017512&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22017512&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14460[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14461</li>

14462<li id="section_7.24">

14463Rizzo JD, Wingard JR, Tichelli A, et al.: Recommended screening and preventive practices for long-term survivors after hematopoietic cell transplantation: joint recommendations of the European Group for Blood and Marrow Transplantation, Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research, and the American Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation (EBMT/CIBMTR/ASBMT). Bone Marrow Transplant 37 (3): 249-61, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16435004&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16435004&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14464[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14465</li>

14466<li id="section_7.25">

14467Tomblyn M, Chiller T, Einsele H, et al.: Guidelines for preventing infectious complications among hematopoietic cell transplantation recipients: a global perspective. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 15 (10): 1143-238, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19747629&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19747629&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14468[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14469</li>

14470<li id="section_7.26">

14471Chehab L, Doody DR, Esbenshade AJ, et al.: A Population-Based Study of the Long-Term Risk of Infections Associated With Hospitalization in Childhood Cancer Survivors. J Clin Oncol 41 (2): 364-372, 2023.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35878085&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35878085&amp;dopt=Abstract">

14472[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

14473</li>

14474</ol>

14475</div>

14476

14477 </section>

14478

14479

14480

14481 <section id="_92">

14482

14483 <h2>

14484Late Effects of the Musculoskeletal System</h2>

14485

14486 <div id="_section_92" class="pdq-sections">

14487<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

14488<h6>

14489In This Section</h6>

14490<ul>

14491<li>

14492<a href="#_351_toc">

14493Abnormal Bone Growth<ul>

14494<li>

14495<a href="#_1266_toc">

14496Radiation to the head and brain</a>

14497</li>

14498<li>

14499<a href="#_1267_toc">

14500Radiation to the spine and long bones</a>

14501</li>

14502</ul>

14503</a>

14504</li>

14505<li>

14506<a href="#_359_toc">

14507Osteoporosis and Fractures<ul>

14508<li>

14509<a href="#_2608_toc">

14510Fracture risk in childhood cancer survivors</a>

14511</li>

14512<li>

14513<a href="#_2612_toc">

14514Risk prediction model for bone mineral density deficits</a>

14515</li>

14516</ul>

14517</a>

14518</li>

14519<li>

14520<a href="#_363_toc">

14521Osteonecrosis<ul>

14522<li>

14523<a href="#_2616_toc">

14524Exposure to corticosteroids and, possibly, methotrexate and concurrent asparaginase</a>

14525</li>

14526<li>

14527<a href="#_2618_toc">

14528Development of thromboembolism during antileukemic therapy</a>

14529</li>

14530<li>

14531<a href="#_2620_toc">

14532HSCT conditioning and course</a>

14533</li>

14534<li>

14535<a href="#_2622_toc">

14536Age at time of diagnosis or transplant</a>

14537</li>

14538<li>

14539<a href="#_2624_toc">

14540Race</a>

14541</li>

14542<li>

14543<a href="#_2626_toc">

14544Genetic factors</a>

14545</li>

14546<li>

14547<a href="#_2628_toc">

14548Sex</a>

14549</li>

14550</ul>

14551</a>

14552</li>

14553<li>

14554<a href="#_371_toc">

14555Osteochondroma</a>

14556</li>

14557<li>

14558<a href="#_355_toc">

14559Amputation and Limb-Sparing Surgery</a>

14560</li>

14561<li>

14562<a href="#_357_toc">

14563Joint Contractures</a>

14564</li>

14565</ul>

14566</nav>

14567<p id="_349" tabindex="-1">

14568The musculoskeletal system of growing children and adolescents is vulnerable to the cytotoxic effects of cancer therapies, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Documented late effects include the following: </p>

14569<div class="pdq-content-list">

14570<ul id="_1311">

14571<li>

14572Bone and joint (abnormal bone and/or muscle growth) problems. </li>

14573<li>

14574Deformity and functional loss associated with amputation/limb-sparing surgery, joint contracture, osteoporosis/fractures, and osteonecrosis.</li>

14575<li>

14576Changes in body composition (obesity and loss of lean muscle mass). </li>

14577</ul>

14578</div>

14579<p id="_1263" tabindex="-1">

14580While these late effects are discussed individually, it is important to remember that the components of the musculoskeletal system are interrelated. For example, hypoplasia of a muscle group can negatively affect the function of the long bones and the resultant dysfunction can subsequently lead to disuse and osteoporosis.</p>

14581<p id="_1265" tabindex="-1">

14582The major strength of the published literature documenting musculoskeletal late effects among children and adolescents treated for cancer is that most studies have clearly defined outcomes and exposures. However, many studies are observational and cross-sectional or retrospective in design. Single-institution studies are common, and for some outcomes, only small convenience cohorts have been described. Thus, it is possible that studies either excluded patients with the most severe musculoskeletal effects because of death or inability to participate in follow-up testing, or they oversampled those with the most severe musculoskeletal late effects because these patients were accessible as they returned for complication-related follow-up. Additionally, some of the results reported in adult survivors of childhood cancer may not be relevant to patients currently being treated because the delivery of anticancer modalities, particularly radiation therapy, has changed over the years in response to documented toxicities.</p>

14583<section id="_351">

14584<h3 id="_351_toc">

14585Abnormal Bone Growth</h3>

14586<p id="_1908" tabindex="-1">

14587The effect of radiation on bone growth depends on the sites irradiated, as follows:</p>

14588<div class="pdq-content-list">

14589<ul id="_1909">

14590<li>

14591<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1266">

14592Head and brain</a>

14593.</li>

14594<li>

14595<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1267">

14596Spine and long bones</a>

14597.</li>

14598</ul>

14599</div>

14600<section id="_1266">

14601<h4 id="_1266_toc">

14602Radiation to the head and brain</h4>

14603<p id="_352" tabindex="-1">

14604In an age- and dose-dependent fashion, radiation can inhibit normal bone and muscle maturation and development.</p>

14605<div class="pdq-content-list">

14606<ul id="_2604">

14607<li>

14608 Radiation to the head (e.g., cranial, orbital, infratemporal, or nasopharyngeal radiation therapy) can cause craniofacial abnormalities, particularly in children treated before age 5 years who received radiation doses of 20 Gy or higher [<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

146091</a>

14610-<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

146114</a>

14612] or who were treated with concomitant chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

146135</a>

14614] </li>

14615<li>

14616Soft tissue sarcomas such as orbital rhabdomyosarcoma and retinoblastoma are two of the more common cancer types treated with these radiation fields. Often, in addition to the cosmetic impact of the craniofacial abnormalities, there can be related dental and sinus problems.</li>

14617</ul>

14618</div>

14619<p id="_354" tabindex="-1">

14620Cranial radiation therapy damages the hypothalamic-pituitary axis in an age- and dose-response fashion and can result in growth hormone deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

146216</a>

14622,<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

146237</a>

14624] If the growth hormone deficiency is not treated during the growing years and, sometimes, even with appropriate treatment, it leads to a substantially lower final height. Patients with a central nervous system (CNS) tumor [<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

146258</a>

14626,<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

146279</a>

14628] or acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) [<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

1462910</a>

14630,<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

1463111</a>

14632] treated with 18 Gy or higher of cranial radiation therapy are at highest risk. Patients treated with single-fraction total-body irradiation (TBI),[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

1463312</a>

14634-<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1463514</a>

14636] and those treated with cranial radiation for non-CNS solid tumors [<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

1463715</a>

14638] are also at risk of growth hormone deficiency. If the spine is also irradiated (e.g., craniospinal radiation therapy for medulloblastoma or early ALL therapies in the 1960s), growth can be affected by two separate mechanisms&#8212;growth hormone deficiency and direct damage to the spine.</p>

14639</section>

14640<section id="_1267">

14641<h4 id="_1267_toc">

14642Radiation to the spine and long bones</h4>

14643<p id="_353" tabindex="-1">

14644Radiation therapy can also directly affect the growth of the spine and long bones (and associated muscle groups) and can cause premature closure of the epiphyses, leading to the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1464516</a>

14646-<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

1464723</a>

14648] </p>

14649<div class="pdq-content-list">

14650<ul id="_1268">

14651<li>

14652Short stature.</li>

14653<li>

14654Asymmetric growth (scoliosis/kyphosis).</li>

14655<li>

14656Limb-length discrepancy.</li>

14657</ul>

14658</div>

14659<p id="_1312" tabindex="-1">

14660Orthovoltage radiation therapy, commonly used before 1970, delivered high doses of radiation to bone and was commonly associated with subsequent abnormalities in bone growth.</p>

14661<p id="_2605" tabindex="-1">

14662 However, even with contemporary radiation therapy, if a solid tumor is located near an epiphysis or the spine, alterations in normal bone development can be difficult to avoid.</p>

14663<p id="_505" tabindex="-1">

14664The effects of radiation therapy administered to the spine on stature in survivors of Wilms tumor have been assessed.</p>

14665<p id="_1910" tabindex="-1">

14666Evidence (effect of radiation therapy on the spine and long bones):</p>

14667<div class="pdq-content-list">

14668<ol id="_1911">

14669<li>

14670A cross-sectional study evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for vitamin D deficiency (&lt;20 ng/mL) and its association with bone mineral density in 446 long-term childhood cancer survivors (median age, 27.5 years; median time from completion of therapy, 14.2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_8.24">

1467124</a>

14672]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14673<ul id="_2794">

14674<li>

14675Vitamin D deficiency was present in 24% of survivors.</li>

14676<li>

14677Independent predictors of vitamin D deficiency included high body mass index (BMI) (OR, 1.78 for patients who are overweight; OR, 2.4 for patients with obesity) and Hispanic or Black race and ethnicity (OR, 2.4). </li>

14678<li>

14679Survivors with vitamin D deficiency had a more-than-threefold risk (OR, 3.58) of reduced bone mineral density.</li>

14680</ul>

14681</div>

14682</li>

14683<li>

14684In the National Wilms Tumor Study (studies 1 through 4), stature loss in 2,778 children was evaluated.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

1468516</a>

14686]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14687<ul id="_1912">

14688<li>

14689 Repeated height measurements were collected during long-term follow-up.</li>

14690<li>

14691 The effects of radiation dosage, age at treatment, and chemotherapy on stature were analyzed using statistical models that accounted for the normal variation in height with sex and advancing age.</li>

14692<li>

14693 Predictions from the model were validated by descriptive analysis of heights measured at ages 17 to 18 years for 205 patients.</li>

14694<li>

14695 For those younger than 12 months at diagnosis who received more than 10 Gy of radiation therapy, the estimated adult-height deficit was 7.7 cm when compared with the nonradiation therapy group.</li>

14696<li>

14697For those who received 10 Gy, the estimated trunk shortening was 2.8 cm or less.</li>

14698<li>

14699Among those whose height measurements in the teenage years were available, patients who received more than 15 Gy of radiation therapy were 4 to 7 cm shorter on average than their nonirradiated counterparts, with an evident dose-response relationship.</li>

14700<li>

14701Chemotherapy did not confer additional risk.</li>

14702</ul>

14703</div>

14704</li>

14705<li>

14706The effect of radiation therapy on the development of scoliosis has also been re-evaluated. In a group of 42 children treated for Wilms tumor from 1968 to 1994, scoliosis was seen in 18 patients, with only one patient needing orthopedic intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

1470725</a>

14708]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14709<ul id="_1913">

14710<li>

14711Median time to development of scoliosis was 102 months (range, 16&#8211;146 months).</li>

14712<li>

14713A clear dose-response relationship was seen; children treated with lower doses (&lt;24 Gy) of radiation had a significantly lower incidence of scoliosis than those who received more than 24 Gy of radiation.</li>

14714<li>

14715There was also a suggestion that the incidence was lower in patients who received 10 to 12 Gy, the dosages currently used for Wilms tumor, although the sample size was small.</li>

14716</ul>

14717</div>

14718</li>

14719<li>

14720The effect of craniospinal irradiation (CSI) on bone growth was assessed in 220 pediatric patients with brain tumors who were treated with CSI.[<a href="#cit/section_8.26">

1472126</a>

14722]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14723<ul id="_2729">

14724<li>

14725 Vertebral growth was significantly correlated with radiation dose (&gt;39 Gy) and growth hormone deficiency.</li>

14726<li>

14727 83% of patients had fatty marrow changes, 31% had disc degenerative changes (signal change, bulging, and height loss), 13% had degenerative changes of spinal bones, 17% had wedging or spinal height loss, and 27% had scoliosis.</li>

14728<li>

14729 Even with symmetrical irradiation to the vertebral bodies, the risk of scoliosis was high after CSI.</li>

14730<li>

14731 Age at irradiation was a significant risk factor for scoliosis (<em>

14732P</em>

14733 = .0067), but there was no correlation with radiation dose. </li>

14734<li>

14735Adequate growth hormone replacement was important for bone growth.</li>

14736</ul>

14737</div>

14738</li>

14739</ol>

14740</div>

14741</section>

14742</section>

14743<section id="_359">

14744<h3 id="_359_toc">

14745Osteoporosis and Fractures</h3>

14746<p id="_360" tabindex="-1">

14747Although increased rates of fracture are not reported among long-term survivors of childhood cancer,[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1474827</a>

14749] maximal peak bone mass is an important factor influencing the risk of osteoporosis and fracture among older patients. Treatment-related factors that affect bone mineral loss include the following:</p>

14750<div class="pdq-content-list">

14751<ul id="_1314">

14752<li>

14753<strong>

14754Chemotherapy.</strong>

14755 Methotrexate has a cytotoxic effect on osteoblasts, resulting in a reduction of bone volume and formation of new bone.[<a href="#cit/section_8.28">

1475628</a>

14757,<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

1475829</a>

14759] This effect may be exacerbated by the chronic use of corticosteroids, another class of agents routinely used in the treatment of hematological malignancies and in supportive care for a variety of pediatric cancers.</li>

14760<li>

14761<strong>

14762Radiation therapy.</strong>

14763 Radiation-related endocrinopathies, such as growth hormone deficiency or hypogonadism, may contribute to ongoing bone mineral loss.[<a href="#cit/section_8.30">

1476430</a>

14765-<a href="#cit/section_8.33">

1476633</a>

14767]</li>

14768<li>

14769<strong>

14770Nutrition and activity.</strong>

14771 Suboptimal nutrition and physical inactivity may further predispose to deficits in bone mineral accretion.</li>

14772</ul>

14773</div>

14774<p id="_361" tabindex="-1">

14775Most of our knowledge about cancer and treatment effects on bone mineralization has been derived from studies of children with ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_8.34">

1477634</a>

14777]</p>

14778<div class="pdq-content-list">

14779<ul id="_2606">

14780<li>

14781In children with ALL, the leukemic process, and possibly vitamin D deficiency, may play a role in the alterations in bone metabolism and bone mass observed at diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.35">

1478235</a>

14783]</li>

14784<li>

14785Antileukemic therapy causes additional bone mineral density loss,[<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

1478636</a>

14787] which has been reported to normalize over time [<a href="#cit/section_8.37">

1478837</a>

14789] or to persist for many years after completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

1479038</a>

14791]</li>

14792<li>

14793 Clinical factors predicting higher risk of low bone mineral density include treatment with the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

1479432</a>

14795,<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

1479639</a>

14797-<a href="#cit/section_8.41">

1479841</a>

14799]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14800<ul id="_1914" class="list-dash">

14801<li>

14802High cumulative doses of methotrexate (&gt;40 g/m<span class="sup">

148032</span>

14804).</li>

14805<li>

14806High cumulative doses of corticosteroids (&gt;9 g/m<span class="sup">

148072</span>

14808).</li>

14809<li>

14810Cranial radiation therapy or craniospinal radiation therapy.</li>

14811<li>

14812More potent glucocorticoids such as dexamethasone.</li>

14813<li>

14814The development of osteonecrosis during treatment for ALL.[<a href="#cit/section_8.42">

1481542</a>

14816]</li>

14817</ul>

14818</div>

14819</li>

14820</ul>

14821</div>

14822<p id="_1315" tabindex="-1">

14823Clinical assessment of bone mineral density in adults treated for childhood ALL indicates that most bone mineral deficits normalize over time after discontinuing osteotoxic therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

1482432</a>

14825]</p>

14826<p id="_1916" tabindex="-1">

14827Evidence (low bone mineral density):</p>

14828<div class="pdq-content-list">

14829<ol id="_1917">

14830<li>

14831A cohort of 845 adult survivors of childhood ALL were evaluated at a median age of 31 years.[<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

1483232</a>

14833]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14834<ul id="_1918">

14835<li>

14836Very low bone mineral density was relatively uncommon, with only 5.7% of patients with bone mineral density z-scores consistent with osteoporosis and 23.8% of patients with bone mineral density z-scores consistent with osteopenia.</li>

14837<li>

14838 Cranial radiation dose of 24 Gy or higher, but not cumulative methotrexate or prednisone equivalent doses, was associated with a twofold elevated risk of bone mineral density z-scores of -1 or lower.</li>

14839<li>

14840In a subset of 400 survivors with longitudinal bone mineral density evaluations, bone mineral density z-scores tended to improve from adolescence to young adulthood.</li>

14841</ul>

14842</div>

14843</li>

14844<li>

14845 Among 862 ALL survivors (median age, 31.3 years) evaluated by quantitative computed tomography of L1 through L2 vertebrae, the following was reported:[<a href="#cit/section_8.43">

1484643</a>

14847]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14848<ul id="_2607">

14849<li>

1485030% of survivors had low bone mineral density (z-score below -1), and 18.6% of survivors met criteria for frailty or prefrailty.</li>

14851<li>

14852The prefrail phenotype is characterized by having two of five characteristics (low muscle mass, self-reported exhaustion, low energy expenditure, slow walking speed, and weakness), and the frail phenotype is characterized by having three or more of these characteristics.</li>

14853<li>

14854 Modifiable factors such as growth hormone deficiency, smoking, and alcohol consumption were significant predictors for these outcomes, with varying impact on the basis of sex.</li>

14855<li>

14856 These data underscore the importance of lifestyle counseling and screening for hormonal deficits during long-term survivors' follow-up evaluations.</li>

14857</ul>

14858</div>

14859</li>

14860<li>

14861Bone mineral density deficits that are likely multifactorial in etiology have been reported in allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) recipients conditioned with TBI.[<a href="#cit/section_8.44">

1486244</a>

14863,<a href="#cit/section_8.45">

1486445</a>

14865]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14866<ul id="_2693">

14867<li>

14868 French investigators observed a significant risk of lower femoral bone mineral density among adult survivors of childhood leukemia treated with HSCT who had gonadal deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_8.46">

1486946</a>

14870]</li>

14871<li>

14872 Hormonal therapy has been shown to enhance the bone mineral density of adolescent girls diagnosed with hypogonadism after HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.47">

1487347</a>

14874]</li>

14875</ul>

14876</div>

14877</li>

14878<li>

14879Bone mineral density deficits have been reported in long-term survivors of childhood brain tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_8.48">

1488048</a>

14881]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14882<ul id="_2980">

14883<li>

14884Among 50 survivors of medulloblastoma or CNS supratentorial primitive neuroectodermal tumors (median follow-up, 19.5 years), decreased bone marrow density z-scores were detected in 48% of the lumbar spine and 34% of the total body measurements. </li>

14885<li>

14886Modifiable risk factors for bone marrow density deficits included low serum calcium (62%) and vitamin D (26%), low vitamin D intake (69%), and inactive lifestyle (62%). </li>

14887<li>

14888Male sex, older age at diagnosis, and lower lean BMI were associated with increased risk of decreased bone marrow density z-scores.</li>

14889</ul>

14890</div>

14891</li>

14892<li>

14893DCOG-LATER investigators evaluated the risk factors for low and very low bone mineral density, any fractures, and vertebral fractures with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry in 3,996 5-year survivors of childhood cancer (mean age, 33 years at participation). Self-reported fractures were assessed among all participants, and vertebral fractures were assessed among a subset of participants.[<a href="#cit/section_8.49">

1489449</a>

14895]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14896<ul id="_2998">

14897<li>

14898The standardized incidence ratio of any first fracture was 3.53 (95% confidence interval [CI], 3.06&#8211;4.06) for male participants and 5.35 (4.46&#8211;6.52) for female participants. Thirty-three of 249 (13.3%) participants had vertebral fractures.</li>

14899<li>

14900Risk factors for low bone mineral density at any site included male sex, being underweight, exposure to high-dose carboplatin, exposure to any dose of cranial radiation therapy, hypogonadism, hyperthyroidism, low physical activity, and severe vitamin D deficiency.</li>

14901<li>

14902Risk factors for very low bone marrow density at any site included male sex, being underweight, exposure to cranial radiation therapy, growth hormone deficiency, and severe vitamin D deficiency. </li>

14903<li>

14904Risk factors for any fracture included male sex, former and current smoking status, and very low lumbar spine bone mineral density. </li>

14905<li>

14906Risk factors for vertebral fractures included older age at follow-up, previous treatment with platinum compounds, growth hormone deficiency, and low physical activity.</li>

14907</ul>

14908</div>

14909</li>

14910</ol>

14911</div>

14912<section id="_2608">

14913<h4 id="_2608_toc">

14914Fracture risk in childhood cancer survivors</h4>

14915<div class="pdq-content-list">

14916<ul id="_2609">

14917<li>

14918Despite disease-related and treatment-related risks of bone mineral density deficits, the prevalence of self-reported fractures among Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) participants was lower than that reported by sibling controls. Predictors of increased prevalence of fracture by multivariable analyses included the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

1491927</a>

14920]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14921<ul id="_2610" class="list-dash">

14922<li>

14923Among female survivors, increasing age at follow-up, White race, methotrexate treatment, and balance difficulties.</li>

14924<li>

14925Among male survivors, smoking history and White race. </li>

14926</ul>

14927</div>

14928</li>

14929<li>

14930In a cohort of 245 long-term survivors of ALL (median follow-up time, 15.1 years), the prevalence of and risk factors for vertebral deformities were assessed by spine radiographs and dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry scans.[<a href="#cit/section_8.50">

1493150</a>

14932]<div class="pdq-content-list">

14933<ul id="_2885">

14934<li>

14935Vertebral deformities were prevalent in 23% of patients, with 88% of them categorized as Genant grade 1 (&gt;20%&#8211;25% reduction in percentage of anterior, middle, or posterior vertebral height ratios).</li>

14936<li>

14937Independent predictors of prevalent vertebral deformity included male sex (RR, 1.94; 95% CI, 1.16&#8211;3.24), higher cumulative glucocorticoid dose (RR, 1.05; 95% CI, 1.00&#8211;1.10), and back pain (RR, 2.44; 95% CI, 1.56&#8211;3.84).</li>

14938<li>

14939Lumbar spine bone mineral density Z-score and age at and time from diagnosis were not significant predictors of vertebral deformity. However, sex-stratified analyses indicated that lumbar spine Z-score was significantly predictive of vertebral deformity in males.</li>

14940</ul>

14941</div>

14942</li>

14943<li>

14944Radiation-induced fractures can occur with doses of radiation of 50 Gy or higher, which are often used to treat Ewing sarcoma of the extremity.[<a href="#cit/section_8.51">

1494551</a>

14946,<a href="#cit/section_8.52">

1494752</a>

14948]</li>

14949</ul>

14950</div>

14951</section>

14952<section id="_2612">

14953<h4 id="_2612_toc">

14954Risk prediction model for bone mineral density deficits</h4>

14955<p id="_2613" tabindex="-1">

14956Data from the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort (development) and Erasmus Medical Center (validation) in the Netherlands were used to develop and validate prediction models for low and very low bone mineral density on the basis of clinical and treatment characteristics that identify adult survivors of childhood cancer who require screening by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry.[<a href="#cit/section_8.53">

1495753</a>

14958]</p>

14959<div class="pdq-content-list">

14960<ul id="_2614">

14961<li>

14962 Low bone mineral density was defined as lumbar spine bone mineral density and/or total-body bone mineral density z-score of -1 or lower; very low bone mineral density was defined as a z-score of -2 or lower.</li>

14963<li>

14964 Low bone mineral density was present in 51% of St. Jude Lifetime participants and 45% of Dutch participants, represented by survivors of both hematologic and solid malignancies. Very low bone mineral density was present in 20% of St. Jude Lifetime participants and 10% of Dutch participants.</li>

14965<li>

14966 The model, which included male sex, height, weight, attained age, current smoking status, and cranial irradiation, showed good performance for predicting risk of low bone mineral density (areas under the curve of 0.72 in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort and 0.69 in the Dutch cohort).</li>

14967<li>

14968 The model, which included male sex, height, weight, attained age, cranial irradiation, and abdominal irradiation, showed good performance for predicting risk of very low bone mineral density (areas under the curve of 0.76 in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort and 0.75 in the Dutch cohort).</li>

14969<li>

14970 These models correctly identified bone mineral density status in most White adult survivors through age 40 years using easily measured patient and treatment characteristics.</li>

14971</ul>

14972</div>

14973</section>

14974</section>

14975<section id="_363">

14976<h3 id="_363_toc">

14977Osteonecrosis</h3>

14978<p id="_909" tabindex="-1">

14979Osteonecrosis (also known as aseptic or avascular necrosis) is a rare, but well-recognized skeletal complication observed predominantly in survivors of pediatric hematological malignancies treated with corticosteroids.[<a href="#cit/section_8.54">

1498054</a>

14981-<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

1498256</a>

14983] The condition is characterized by death of one or more segments of bone that most often affects weight-bearing joints, especially the hips and knees. </p>

14984<div class="pdq-content-list">

14985<ul id="_2615">

14986<li>

14987The prevalence of osteonecrosis has varied from 1% to 22% based on the study population, treatment protocol, method of evaluation, and time from treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

1498856</a>

14989-<a href="#cit/section_8.63">

1499063</a>

14991]</li>

14992<li>

14993 Longitudinal cohort studies have identified a spectrum of clinical manifestations of osteonecrosis, ranging from asymptomatic, spontaneously resolving imaging changes to painful progressive articular collapse requiring joint replacement.[<a href="#cit/section_8.64">

1499464</a>

14995,<a href="#cit/section_8.65">

1499665</a>

14997]</li>

14998<li>

14999 Symptomatic osteonecrosis characterized by pain, joint swelling, and reduced mobility typically presents during the first 2 years of therapy, particularly in patients with ALL.</li>

15000<li>

15001 These symptoms may improve over time, persist, or progress in the years after completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.66">

1500266</a>

15003]</li>

15004<li>

15005 In one series, 60% of patients continued to have symptoms at a median follow-up of 4.9 years after diagnosis of osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.67">

1500667</a>

15007]</li>

15008<li>

15009Impaired physical performance and reduced quality of life have been observed in long-term survivors of childhood leukemia and lymphoma (mean age, 28 years) with osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.68">

1501068</a>

15011]</li>

15012<li>

15013 Surgical procedures, including core decompression, osteotomy, and joint replacements, are sometimes performed in patients with persistently severe symptoms.[<a href="#cit/section_8.67">

1501467</a>

15015]</li>

15016</ul>

15017</div>

15018<p id="_1318" tabindex="-1">

15019Factors that increase the risk of osteonecrosis include the following:</p>

15020<section id="_2616">

15021<h4 id="_2616_toc">

15022Exposure to corticosteroids and, possibly, methotrexate and concurrent asparaginase</h4>

15023<div class="pdq-content-list">

15024<ul id="_2617">

15025<li>

15026The most important treatment factor associated with the development of osteonecrosis is prolonged exposure to corticosteroids, which is typical in treatment regimens used for ALL, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.59">

1502759</a>

15028,<a href="#cit/section_8.62">

1502962</a>

15030,<a href="#cit/section_8.63">

1503163</a>

15032,<a href="#cit/section_8.69">

1503369</a>

15034,<a href="#cit/section_8.70">

1503570</a>

15036]</li>

15037<li>

15038Osteonecrosis risk may be related to type of corticosteroid, with some studies in patients with ALL indicating increased risk with the use of dexamethasone compared with prednisone.[<a href="#cit/section_8.71">

1503971</a>

15040,<a href="#cit/section_8.72">

1504172</a>

15042]</li>

15043<li>

15044Corticosteroid dosing schedule also appears to impact the risk of developing osteonecrosis. In the Children&#8217;s Oncology Group (COG)-1961 trial for newly diagnosed high-risk ALL, patients were randomly assigned to receive either continuous (daily) dexamethasone or an alternate-week schedule of dexamethasone during the delayed intensification phase; the alternate-week schedule was

15045associated with a

15046lower incidence of osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

1504756</a>

15048]</li>

15049<li>

15050In addition to corticosteroids, exposure to methotrexate and concurrent asparaginase may contribute to the development of osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.73">

1505173</a>

15052,<a href="#cit/section_8.74">

1505374</a>

15054]</li>

15055</ul>

15056</div>

15057</section>

15058<section id="_2618">

15059<h4 id="_2618_toc">

15060Development of thromboembolism during antileukemic therapy</h4>

15061<div class="pdq-content-list">

15062<ul id="_2619">

15063<li>

15064In a retrospective review of 208 children treated for ALL, investigators at McMaster University reported a 5.21-fold (95% CI, 1.82&#8211;14.91) increased odds of osteonecrosis among children who experienced thromboembolism during antileukemic therapy than among those who did not have a thromboembolism, even after accounting for age and asparaginase exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_8.74">

1506574</a>

15066]</li>

15067</ul>

15068</div>

15069</section>

15070<section id="_2620">

15071<h4 id="_2620_toc">

15072HSCT conditioning and course</h4>

15073<div class="pdq-content-list">

15074<ul id="_2621">

15075<li>

15076In a large case-control study that evaluated risk factors for osteonecrosis using data from the Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research, lower risks of osteonecrosis were seen in patients with nonmalignant diseases and in those who had received reduced-intensity conditioning regimens for malignant diseases than were seen in patients receiving myeloablative regimens for malignant diseases.[<a href="#cit/section_8.75">

1507775</a>

15078] </li>

15079<li>

15080Several studies have reported an increased risk of osteonecrosis in association with chronic graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).[<a href="#cit/section_8.60">

1508160</a>

15082,<a href="#cit/section_8.69">

1508369</a>

15084,<a href="#cit/section_8.75">

1508575</a>

15086]</li>

15087</ul>

15088</div>

15089</section>

15090<section id="_2622">

15091<h4 id="_2622_toc">

15092Age at time of diagnosis or transplant</h4>

15093<div class="pdq-content-list">

15094<ul id="_2623">

15095<li>

15096Several studies have demonstrated that age at diagnosis (or at time of transplant) is a significant independent predictor of osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

1509756</a>

15098,<a href="#cit/section_8.57">

1509957</a>

15100,<a href="#cit/section_8.62">

1510162</a>

15102,<a href="#cit/section_8.67">

1510367</a>

15104,<a href="#cit/section_8.69">

1510569</a>

15106,<a href="#cit/section_8.71">

1510771</a>

15108,<a href="#cit/section_8.75">

1510975</a>

15110]</li>

15111<li>

15112 Osteonecrosis is significantly more common in older children and adolescents than in younger children. In the COG-1961 trial for high-risk ALL, the 5-year cumulative incidence of symptomatic osteonecrosis was 1.0% for patients aged 1 to 9 years, 9.9% for patients aged 10 to 15 years, and 20% for patients aged 16 to 21 years (<em>

15113P</em>

15114 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

1511556</a>

15116]</li>

15117</ul>

15118</div>

15119</section>

15120<section id="_2624">

15121<h4 id="_2624_toc">

15122Race</h4>

15123<div class="pdq-content-list">

15124<ul id="_2625">

15125<li>

15126Osteonecrosis occurs more frequently in White patients than in Black patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.70">

1512770</a>

15128,<a href="#cit/section_8.76">

1512976</a>

15130]</li>

15131</ul>

15132</div>

15133</section>

15134<section id="_2626">

15135<h4 id="_2626_toc">

15136Genetic factors</h4>

15137<div class="pdq-content-list">

15138<ul id="_2627">

15139<li>

15140Genetic factors influencing folate metabolism, glucocorticoid metabolism, and adipogenesis have been linked to excess risk of osteonecrosis among survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_8.70">

1514170</a>

15142,<a href="#cit/section_8.77">

1514377</a>

15144,<a href="#cit/section_8.78">

1514578</a>

15146]</li>

15147<li>

15148Two candidate gene studies indicate that children homozygous for a 28&#8211;base pair repeat within the 5&#8217; untranslated region of the <em class="gene-name">

15149TYMS </em>

15150 gene are at increased risk of osteonecrosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.70">

1515170</a>

15152,<a href="#cit/section_8.78">

1515378</a>

15154] This gene is associated with folate production and replacement and is inhibited by methotrexate.</li>

15155<li>

15156 St. Jude Children's Research Hospital investigators observed an almost sixfold (odds ratio, 5.6; 95% CI, 2.7&#8211;11.3) risk of osteonecrosis among survivors with polymorphism of the <em class="gene-name">

15157ACP1</em>

15158 gene, which regulates lipid levels and osteoblast differentiation.[<a href="#cit/section_8.61">

1515961</a>

15160]</li>

15161<li>

15162Genome-wide association studies have identified potential risk variants in <em class="gene-name">

15163BMP7</em>

15164, <em class="gene-name">

15165PROX1</em>

15166::<em class="gene-name">

15167AS1</em>

15168, <em class="gene-name">

15169GRID2</em>

15170 (children younger than 10 years), and <em class="gene-name">

15171GRIN3A</em>

15172, which are all associated with glucocorticoid receptor activity.[<a href="#cit/section_8.77">

1517377</a>

15174,<a href="#cit/section_8.79">

1517579</a>

15176]</li>

15177</ul>

15178</div>

15179</section>

15180<section id="_2628">

15181<h4 id="_2628_toc">

15182Sex</h4>

15183<div class="pdq-content-list">

15184<ul id="_2629">

15185<li>

15186Studies evaluating the influence of sex on the risk of osteonecrosis have yielded conflicting results, with some suggesting a higher incidence in females [<a href="#cit/section_8.64">

1518764</a>

15188,<a href="#cit/section_8.67">

1518967</a>

15190,<a href="#cit/section_8.76">

1519176</a>

15192] that has not been confirmed by others.[<a href="#cit/section_8.55">

1519355</a>

15194]</li>

15195</ul>

15196</div>

15197</section>

15198</section>

15199<section id="_371">

15200<h3 id="_371_toc">

15201Osteochondroma</h3>

15202<div class="pdq-content-list">

15203<ul id="_2630">

15204<li>

15205Osteochondromas are benign boney protrusions that can be spontaneous or associated with radiation therapy. They generally occur as a single lesion; however, multiple lesions may develop in the context of hereditary multiple osteochondromatosis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.80">

1520680</a>

15207]</li>

15208<li>

15209Growth hormone therapy may influence the onset and pace of growth of osteochondromas.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

1521014</a>

15211,<a href="#cit/section_8.81">

1521281</a>

15213]</li>

15214<li>

15215Because malignant degeneration of these lesions is exceptionally rare, clinical rather than radiological follow-up is most appropriate.[<a href="#cit/section_8.82">

1521682</a>

15217]</li>

15218<li>

15219 Surgical resection is only necessary when the lesion interferes with joint alignment and movement.[<a href="#cit/section_8.83">

1522083</a>

15221]</li>

15222</ul>

15223</div>

15224<p id="_1924" tabindex="-1">

15225Evidence (risk of osteochondroma):</p>

15226<div class="pdq-content-list">

15227<ol id="_1925">

15228<li>

15229 Approximately 5% of children undergoing myeloablative HSCT will develop osteochondroma, which most commonly presents in the metaphyseal regions of long bones.[<a href="#cit/section_8.80">

1523080</a>

15231,<a href="#cit/section_8.84">

1523284</a>

15233]</li>

15234<li>

15235 A large Italian study reported a 6.1% cumulative risk of developing osteochondroma at 15 years posttransplant, with increased risk associated with younger age at transplant (&#8804;3 years) and use of TBI.[<a href="#cit/section_8.85">

1523685</a>

15237]</li>

15238<li>

15239Osteochondromas have been reported in patients with neuroblastoma who received local radiation therapy, anti-GD2 monoclonal antibody therapy, and isotretinoin.[<a href="#cit/section_8.86">

1524086</a>

15241]<div class="pdq-content-list">

15242<ul id="_1926">

15243<li>

15244Osteochondromas occurred at a median of 8.2 years from diagnosis, and the cumulative incidence rate was 4.9% at 10 years from diagnosis among 362 patients younger than 10 years.</li>

15245<li>

15246In this series, most of the osteochondromas were unrelated to radiation and had features characteristic of benign developmental osteochondroma.</li>

15247<li>

15248The pathogenic role for chemotherapy, anti-GD2 monoclonal antibody therapy, or isotretinoin in the development of osteochondroma remains speculative.</li>

15249</ul>

15250</div>

15251</li>

15252</ol>

15253</div>

15254</section>

15255<section id="_355">

15256<h3 id="_355_toc">

15257Amputation and Limb-Sparing Surgery</h3>

15258<p id="_356" tabindex="-1">

15259Amputation and limb-sparing surgery prevent local recurrence of bone tumors by removal of all gross and microscopic disease. If optimally executed, both procedures accomplish an <em>

15260en bloc</em>

15261 excision of tumor with a margin of normal uninvolved tissue.</p>

15262<div class="pdq-content-list">

15263<ul id="_2631">

15264<li>

15265The type of surgical procedure, the primary tumor site, and the age of the patient affect the risk of postsurgical complications.[<a href="#cit/section_8.87">

1526687</a>

15267]</li>

15268<li>

15269 Complications in survivors treated with amputation include prosthetic fit problems, chronic pain in the residual limb, phantom limb pain, and bone overgrowth.[<a href="#cit/section_8.87">

1527087</a>

15271,<a href="#cit/section_8.88">

1527288</a>

15273]</li>

15274<li>

15275 While limb-sparing surgeries may offer a more aesthetically pleasing outcome, complications have been reported more frequently in survivors who underwent these procedures than in those treated with amputation.</li>

15276<li>

15277 Complications after limb-sparing surgery include nonunion, pathologic fracture, aseptic loosening, limb-length discrepancy, endoprosthetic fracture, and limited joint range of motion.[<a href="#cit/section_8.87">

1527887</a>

15279,<a href="#cit/section_8.89">

1528089</a>

15281]</li>

15282<li>

15283 Occasionally, refractory complications develop after limb-sparing surgery and require amputation.[<a href="#cit/section_8.90">

1528490</a>

15285,<a href="#cit/section_8.91">

1528691</a>

15287] </li>

15288</ul>

15289</div>

15290<p id="_1321" tabindex="-1">

15291A number of studies have compared functional outcomes after amputation and limb-sparing surgery, but results have been limited by inconsistent methods of functional assessment and small cohort sizes.</p>

15292<div class="pdq-content-list">

15293<ul id="_2632">

15294<li>

15295 Overall, data suggest that limb-sparing surgery results in better function than amputation, but differences are relatively modest.[<a href="#cit/section_8.87">

1529687</a>

15297,<a href="#cit/section_8.91">

1529891</a>

15299,<a href="#cit/section_8.92">

1530092</a>

15301]</li>

15302<li>

15303 Similarly, long-term quality-of-life outcomes among survivors undergoing amputation and limb sparing procedures have not differed substantially.[<a href="#cit/section_8.90">

1530490</a>

15305]</li>

15306<li>

15307 A longitudinal analysis of health status among extremity sarcoma survivors in the CCSS indicates an association between lower extremity amputation and increasing activity limitations with age, and an association between upper extremity amputation and lower educational attainment.[<a href="#cit/section_8.93">

1530893</a>

15309]</li>

15310</ul>

15311</div>

15312<p id="_3033" tabindex="-1">

15313CCSS investigators evaluated risk factors for and outcomes of late amputation in survivors treated for lower extremity sarcomas.[<a href="#cit/section_8.94">

1531494</a>

15315]</p>

15316<div class="pdq-content-list">

15317<ul id="_3034">

15318<li>

15319The cumulative incidence of amputation at 25 years after cancer diagnosis and primary limb-sparing surgery was 18% and did not differ significantly among survivors diagnosed in the 1970s (27%) versus the 1980s (19%) and 1990s (15%).</li>

15320<li>

15321Factors associated with an increased risk of late amputation included male sex (hazard ratio [HR], 2.2; 95% CI, 1.07&#8211;3.82) and history of prosthetic joint reconstruction (HR, 2.58; 95% CI, 1.37&#8211;4.84).</li>

15322<li>

15323Survivors treated with primary amputation and those experiencing late amputation after limb-sparing surgery were more likely to report impaired physical functioning (relative risk [RR], 1.31; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;1.72 and RR, 2.46; 95% CI, 1.66&#8211;3.63, respectively) and worse bodily pain scores (RR, 1.50; 95% CI, 1.10&#8211;2.06 and RR, 2.33; 95% CI, 1.27&#8211;4.26, respectively) than those without amputation after limb-sparing surgery.</li>

15324</ul>

15325</div>

15326</section>

15327<section id="_357">

15328<h3 id="_357_toc">

15329Joint Contractures</h3>

15330<p id="_358" tabindex="-1">

15331HSCT with any history of chronic GVHD is associated with joint contractures.[<a href="#cit/section_8.95">

1533295</a>

15333-<a href="#cit/section_8.97">

1533497</a>

15335]</p>

15336</section>

15337<p id="_1728" tabindex="-1">

15338<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_377">

15339Table 15</a>

15340 summarizes bone and joint late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

15341<table id="_377" class="table-default expandable-container">

15342<caption>

15343Table 15. Bone and Joint Late Effects<span class="sup">

15344a</span>

15345</caption>

15346<colgroup>

15347<col width="33.33%">

15348<col width="33.33%">

15349<col width="33.33%">

15350</colgroup>

15351<THead>

15352<tr>

15353<th>

15354Predisposing Therapy</th>

15355<th>

15356Musculoskeletal Effects</th>

15357<th>

15358Health Screening</th>

15359</tr>

15360</THead>

15361<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

15362<tr>

15363<td colspan="3">

15364CT = computed tomography; DXA = dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry; GVHD = graft-versus-host disease; HSCT = hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.</td>

15365</tr>

15366<tr>

15367<td colspan="3">

15368<span class="sup">

15369a</span>

15370Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

15371Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

15372.</td>

15373</tr>

15374</TFoot>

15375<tbody>

15376<tr>

15377<td>

15378Radiation exposing musculoskeletal system </td>

15379<td>

15380Hypoplasia;

15381fibrosis;

15382reduced/uneven growth (scoliosis, kyphosis);

15383limb length discrepancy</td>

15384<td>

15385Exam: bones and soft tissues in radiation fields

15386</td>

15387</tr>

15388<tr>

15389<td rowspan="2">

15390Radiation exposing head and neck

15391</td>

15392<td rowspan="2">

15393Craniofacial abnormalities</td>

15394<td>

15395History: psychosocial assessment, with attention to

15396educational and/or vocational progress, depression, anxiety, posttraumatic stress, social withdrawal

15397</td>

15398</tr>

15399<tr>

15400<td>

15401Head and neck exam</td>

15402</tr>

15403<tr>

15404<td>

15405Radiation exposing musculoskeletal system </td>

15406<td>

15407Radiation-induced fracture</td>

15408<td>

15409Exam of affected bone</td>

15410</tr>

15411<tr>

15412<td>

15413Methotrexate;

15414corticosteroids (dexamethasone, prednisone);

15415radiation exposing skeletal structures;

15416HSCT</td>

15417<td>

15418Reduced bone mineral density</td>

15419<td>

15420Bone mineral density test

15421(DXA or quantitative CT)

15422</td>

15423</tr>

15424<tr>

15425<td rowspan="2">

15426Corticosteroids (dexamethasone, prednisone) </td>

15427<td rowspan="2">

15428Osteonecrosis</td>

15429<td>

15430History: joint pain, swelling, immobility, limited range of motion

15431

15432</td>

15433</tr>

15434<tr>

15435<td>

15436Musculoskeletal exam</td>

15437</tr>

15438<tr>

15439<td>

15440Radiation with exposure to oral cavity </td>

15441<td>

15442Osteoradionecrosis</td>

15443<td>

15444History/oral exam: impaired or delayed healing after dental work, persistent jaw pain or swelling, trismus</td>

15445</tr>

15446<tr>

15447<td rowspan="3">

15448Amputation </td>

15449<td rowspan="3">

15450Amputation-related complications (impaired cosmesis, functional/activity limitations, residual limb integrity, chronic pain, increased energy expenditure)</td>

15451<td>

15452History: pain, functional/activity limitations</td>

15453</tr>

15454<tr>

15455<td>

15456

15457Exam: residual limb integrity

15458

15459</td>

15460</tr>

15461<tr>

15462<td>

15463Prosthetic evaluation</td>

15464</tr>

15465<tr>

15466<td rowspan="4">

15467Limb-sparing surgery </td>

15468<td rowspan="4">

15469Limb-sparing surgical complications (functional/activity

15470limitations, fibrosis, contractures, chronic infection, chronic pain, limb length discrepancy, increased energy expenditure, prosthetic malfunction [loosening, non-union, fracture]) </td>

15471<td>

15472History: pain, functional/activity limitations

15473

15474

15475</td>

15476</tr>

15477<tr>

15478<td>

15479Exam: residual limb integrity</td>

15480</tr>

15481<tr>

15482<td>

15483Radiograph of affected limb</td>

15484</tr>

15485<tr>

15486<td>

15487Orthopedic evaluation

15488</td>

15489</tr>

15490<tr>

15491<td>

15492HSCT with any history of chronic GVHD </td>

15493<td>

15494Joint contracture</td>

15495<td>

15496Musculoskeletal exam</td>

15497</tr>

15498</tbody>

15499</table>

15500<p id="_440" tabindex="-1">

15501For musculoskeletal system late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

15502Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

15503.</p>

J Clin Oncol 18 (18): 3262-72, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10986059&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10986059&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15809[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15810</li>

15811<li id="section_8.77">

15812Karol SE, Mattano LA, Yang W, et al.: Genetic risk factors for the development of osteonecrosis in children under age 10 treated for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Blood 127 (5): 558-64, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26590194&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26590194&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15813[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15814</li>

15815<li id="section_8.78">

15816Finkelstein Y, Blonquist TM, Vijayanathan V, et al.: A thymidylate synthase polymorphism is associated with increased risk for bone toxicity among children treated for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Pediatr Blood Cancer 64 (7): , 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27957785&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27957785&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15817[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15818</li>

15819<li id="section_8.79">

Blood 126 (15): 1770-6, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26265699&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26265699&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15821[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15822</li>

15823<li id="section_8.80">

15824Bov&#233;e JV: Multiple osteochondromas. Orphanet J Rare Dis 3: 3, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18271966&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18271966&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15825[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15826</li>

15827<li id="section_8.81">

15828Bordigoni P, Turello R, Clement L, et al.: Osteochondroma after pediatric hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: report of eight cases. Bone Marrow Transplant 29 (7): 611-4, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11979312&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11979312&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15829[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15830</li>

15831<li id="section_8.82">

15832Taitz J, Cohn RJ, White L, et al.: Osteochondroma after total body irradiation: an age-related complication. 15834</li>

J Surg Oncol 73 (4): 198-205, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10797332&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10797332&amp;dopt=Abstract">

J Cancer Surviv 11 (1): 1-12, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27262580&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27262580&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15873[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15874</li>

15875<li id="section_8.93">

15876Marina N, Hudson MM, Jones KE, et al.: Changes in health status among aging survivors of pediatric upper and lower extremity sarcoma: a report from the childhood cancer survivor study. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 94 (6): 1062-73, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23380347&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23380347&amp;dopt=Abstract">

15886</li>
