15893[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

15894</li>

15895</ol>

15896</div>

15897

15898 </section>

15899

15900

15901

15902 <section id="_98">

15903

15904 <h2>

15905Late Effects of the Reproductive System</h2>

15906

15907 <div id="_section_98" class="pdq-sections">

15908<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

15909<h6>

15910In This Section</h6>

15911<ul>

15912<li>

15913<a href="#_380_toc">

15914Testis<ul>

15915<li>

15916<a href="#_1145_toc">

15917Surgery affecting testicular function</a>

15918</li>

15919<li>

15920<a href="#_1146_toc">

15921Radiation affecting testicular function</a>

15922</li>

15923<li>

15924<a href="#_1148_toc">

15925Chemotherapy affecting testicular function</a>

15926</li>

15927<li>

15928<a href="#_1149_toc">

15929Testicular function after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</a>

15930</li>

15931<li>

15932<a href="#_1159_toc">

15933Recovery of germ cell function</a>

15934</li>

15935<li>

15936<a href="#_2187_toc">

15937Leydig cell function in long-term survivors of childhood cancer</a>

15938</li>

15939</ul>

15940</a>

15941</li>

15942<li>

15943<a href="#_387_toc">

15944Ovary<ul>

15945<li>

15946<a href="#_1151_toc">

15947Surgery affecting ovarian function</a>

15948</li>

15949<li>

15950<a href="#_1153_toc">

15951Radiation affecting ovarian function</a>

15952</li>

15953<li>

15954<a href="#_1155_toc">

15955Chemotherapy affecting ovarian function</a>

15956</li>

15957<li>

15958<a href="#_1134_toc">

15959Premature ovarian failure</a>

15960</li>

15961<li>

15962<a href="#_1157_toc">

15963Ovarian function after HSCT</a>

15964</li>

15965<li>

15966<a href="#_2408_toc">

15967Predicting premature ovarian failure</a>

15968</li>

15969</ul>

15970</a>

15971</li>

15972<li>

15973<a href="#_395_toc">

15974Fertility</a>

15975</li>

15976<li>

15977<a href="#_2786_toc">

15978Sexual Function</a>

15979</li>

15980<li>

15981<a href="#_399_toc">

15982Reproduction<ul>

15983<li>

15984<a href="#_1233_toc">

15985Fertility preservation</a>

15986</li>

15987<li>

15988<a href="#_2781_toc">

15989Risk of pregnancy complications</a>

15990</li>

15991<li>

15992<a href="#_725_toc">

15993Offspring of childhood cancer survivors</a>

15994</li>

15995</ul>

15996</a>

15997</li>

15998</ul>

15999</nav>

16000<p id="_1142" tabindex="-1">

16001Reproductive outcomes in childhood cancer survivors may be compromised by surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy that negatively affects any component of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis or gonads. Evidence for this outcome in childhood cancer survivors is limited by studies characterized by small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, cross-sectional assessment, heterogeneity in treatment approach, time since treatment, and method of ascertainment. In particular, the literature is deficient regarding hard outcomes of reproductive potential (e.g., semen analysis in men, primordial follicle count in women) and outcomes after contemporary risk-adapted treatment approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

160021</a>

16003,<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

160042</a>

16005]</p>

16006<p id="_1359" tabindex="-1">

16007The risk of infertility is generally related to the tissues or organs involved by the cancer and the specific type, dose, and combination of cytotoxic therapy.</p>

16008<div class="pdq-content-list">

16009<ul id="_1143">

16010<li>

16011In pediatric patients with germ cell tumors, orchiectomy or oophorectomy may reduce germ cell numbers. </li>

16012<li>

16013Alkylating agents and similar DNA interstrand cross-linking agents are used in the treatment of pediatric cancers. They are the primary chemotherapeutic agents associated with a high risk of infertility. Factors influencing the risk of gonadal injury in children treated with alkylating agent chemotherapy include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

16014<ul id="_1158" class="list-dash">

16015<li>

16016Cumulative dose.<p id="_2117" tabindex="-1">

16017Earlier studies used the alkylating agent dose to define dose levels associated with the risk of gonadal toxicity within a specific study cohort. Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) investigators developed the cyclophosphamide equivalent dose, which is a metric for normalization of the cumulative doses of various alkylating agents that is independent of the study population. The alkylating agent dose and cyclophosphamide equivalent dose perform similarly when used in several models for different survivor outcomes that include treatment exposures, but only the cyclophosphamide equivalent dose permits comparison across variably treated cohorts. Investigations that evaluate risk factors for gonadal toxicity vary in the use of cumulative doses based on individual alkylating agents, the alkylating agent dose, and the cyclophosphamide equivalent dose.[<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

160183</a>

16019]</p>

16020</li>

16021<li>

16022The specific alkylating agent.</li>

16023<li>

16024The length of treatment.</li>

16025<li>

16026Age at treatment.</li>

16027<li>

16028Sex.</li>

16029</ul>

16030</div>

16031</li>

16032<li>

16033The risk of radiation injury to the hypothalamic-pituitary axis or gonads is related to the treatment volume, total dose, fractionation schedule, and age at treatment.</li>

16034</ul>

16035</div>

16036<p id="_1144" tabindex="-1">

16037In addition to anticancer therapy, age at treatment, and sex, it is likely that genetic factors influence the risk of permanent infertility. Pediatric cancer treatment protocols often prescribe combined-modality therapy; thus, the additive effects of gonadotoxic exposures may need to be considered in assessing reproductive potential. Detailed information about the specific cancer treatment modalities, including specific surgical procedures, the type and cumulative doses of chemotherapeutic agents, and radiation treatment volumes and doses, are needed to estimate risks for gonadal dysfunction and infertility.</p>

16038<p id="_2414" tabindex="-1">

16039The treatment-indicated risk of infertility does not simply translate into adult fertility status. This is particularly important for patients who were unable to participate in sperm/oocyte preservation because of their young age when diagnosed and treated for cancer. </p>

16040<div class="pdq-content-list">

16041<ul id="_2415">

16042<li>

16043In a study of survivors from a St. Jude Lifetime cohort (N = 1,067), most adult survivors of childhood cancer (61.9%) considered themselves at risk of infertility, which was significantly associated with sociodemographic factors (older age, White ethnicity, being married/partnered, higher education), gonadotoxic treatment, fertility concerns, previous unsuccessful attempts to conceive, and sexual dysfunction (all <em>

16044P</em>

16045 &lt; .05).[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

160464</a>

16047]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16048<ul id="_2416">

16049<li>

16050Risk perceptions were often discordant from laboratory-evaluated gonadal functioning. Laboratory-evaluated impaired gonadal function was found in 24% of female survivors and 56% of male survivors, but concordance with survivors&#8217; risk perceptions was low. Most survivors with discordant perceptions overestimated risk (20% of male and 44% of female survivors).</li>

16051<li>

16052Survivors who are at risk&#8212;such as those who show initial signs of fertility problems and/or those who are experiencing fertility-related uncertainties, worries, or distress&#8212;should be offered fertility testing.</li>

16053</ul>

16054</div>

16055</li>

16056</ul>

16057</div>

16058<section id="_380">

16059<h3 id="_380_toc">

16060Testis</h3>

16061<p id="_1119" tabindex="-1">

16062Cancer treatments that may impair testicular and reproductive function include the following:</p>

16063<div class="pdq-content-list">

16064<ul id="_1120">

16065<li>

16066<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1145">

16067Surgery</a>

16068 (orchiectomy, retroperitoneal lymph node dissection, extensive pelvic dissection).</li>

16069<li>

16070<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1146">

16071Radiation therapy</a>

16072 (exposing the hypothalamic-pituitary axis or testes).</li>

16073<li>

16074<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1148">

16075Chemotherapy</a>

16076 (alkylating agents and similar DNA interstrand cross-linking agents such as procarbazine).</li>

16077<li>

16078<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1149">

16079Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</a>

16080.</li>

16081</ul>

16082</div>

16083<section id="_1145">

16084<h4 id="_1145_toc">

16085Surgery affecting testicular function</h4>

16086<div class="pdq-content-list">

16087<ul id="_2436">

16088<li>

16089Patients who undergo unilateral orchiectomy for testicular torsion may have subnormal sperm counts at long-term follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

160905</a>

16091,<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

160926</a>

16093]</li>

16094<li>

16095 Retrograde ejaculation is a frequent complication of bilateral retroperitoneal lymph node dissection performed on males with testicular neoplasms.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

160967</a>

16097,<a href="#cit/section_9.8">

160988</a>

16099] Long-term outcomes after minimally invasive retroperitoneal lymph node dissection are not available.[<a href="#cit/section_9.9">

161009</a>

16101]</li>

16102<li>

16103Erectile dysfunction may occur after extensive pelvic dissections to remove a rhabdomyosarcoma of the prostate.[<a href="#cit/section_9.10">

1610410</a>

16105,<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

1610611</a>

16107]</li>

16108</ul>

16109</div>

16110</section>

16111<section id="_1146">

16112<h4 id="_1146_toc">

16113Radiation affecting testicular function</h4>

16114<p id="_1122" tabindex="-1">

16115Among men who were treated for childhood cancer, gonadal injury may have occurred if radiation treatment fields included the pelvis, gonads, or total body. </p>

16116<div class="pdq-content-list">

16117<ul id="_2437">

16118<li>

16119The germinal epithelium is more sensitive to radiation injury than the androgen-producing Leydig cells.</li>

16120<li>

16121 A decrease in sperm counts can be seen 3 to 6 weeks after such irradiation. Depending on the dosage, recovery may take 1 to more than 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

1612212</a>

16123]</li>

16124<li>

16125 The germinal epithelium is damaged by much lower dosages (&lt;1 Gy) of radiation than are Leydig cells (20&#8211;30 Gy).[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

1612612</a>

16127]</li>

16128<li>

16129 Irreversible germ cell failure may occur with fractionated radiation doses of greater than 2 Gy to 4 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

1613012</a>

16131]</li>

16132<li>

16133 Administration of higher radiation doses, such as 24 Gy, which was used for the treatment of testicular relapse of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), results in both germ cell failure and Leydig cell dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

1613413</a>

16135]</li>

16136</ul>

16137</div>

16138<p id="_1147" tabindex="-1">

16139Radiation injury to Leydig cells is related to the dose delivered and age at treatment. </p>

16140<div class="pdq-content-list">

16141<ul id="_2438">

16142<li>

16143Testosterone production may be normal in prepubertal boys treated with less than 12 Gy fractionated testicular irradiation, but elevated plasma concentrations of luteinizing hormone observed in this group suggest subclinical injury.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

1614414</a>

16145] </li>

16146<li>

16147Leydig cell failure typically results when prepubertal boys are treated with more than 20 Gy of radiation to the testes. Androgen therapy is required for masculinization.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

1614814</a>

16149] </li>

16150<li>

16151Leydig cell function is usually preserved in sexually mature male patients if radiation doses do not exceed 30 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

1615214</a>

16153] </li>

16154<li>

16155Although available data suggest that Leydig cells are more vulnerable when exposed to radiation before puberty, confounding factors, such as the age at testing and the effects of both orchiectomy and chemotherapy, limit the reliability of this observation.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

1615614</a>

16157]</li>

16158</ul>

16159</div>

16160</section>

16161<section id="_1148">

16162<h4 id="_1148_toc">

16163Chemotherapy affecting testicular function</h4>

16164<p id="_384" tabindex="-1">

16165Cumulative alkylating agent (e.g., cyclophosphamide, mechlorethamine, dacarbazine) dose is an important factor in estimating the risk of testicular germ cell injury. However, limited data are available that correlate results of semen analyses in clinically well-characterized cohorts.[<a href="#cit/section_9.15">

1616615</a>

16167]</p>

16168<div class="pdq-content-list">

16169<ul id="_2439">

16170<li>

16171 In general, Leydig cell function is preserved, but germ cell failure is common in men treated with high cumulative doses of cyclophosphamide (7,500 mg/m<span class="sup">

161722</span>

16173 or more) and more than 3 months of combination alkylating agent therapy.</li>

16174<li>

16175 Most studies suggest that prepubertal males are not at lower risk of chemotherapy-induced testicular damage than are postpubertal patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.16">

1617616</a>

16177-<a href="#cit/section_9.19">

1617819</a>

16179]</li>

16180</ul>

16181</div>

16182<p id="_1123" tabindex="-1">

16183Studies of testicular germ cell injury, as evidenced by oligospermia or azoospermia, after alkylating agent administration with or without radiation therapy have reported the following:</p>

16184<div class="pdq-content-list">

16185<ul id="_1124">

16186<li>

16187<strong>

16188Cyclophosphamide:</strong>

16189<div class="pdq-content-list">

16190<ul id="_1125" class="list-dash">

16191<li>

16192Male survivors of non-Hodgkin lymphoma who received a cumulative cyclophosphamide dose of greater than 9.5 g/m<span class="sup">

161932</span>

16194 and underwent pelvic radiation therapy were at increased risk of failure to recover spermatogenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

1619520</a>

16196]</li>

16197<li>

16198In survivors of Ewing sarcoma and soft tissue sarcoma, treatment with a cumulative cyclophosphamide dose of greater than 7.5 g/m<span class="sup">

161992</span>

16200 was correlated with persistent oligospermia or azoospermia.[<a href="#cit/section_9.21">

1620121</a>

16202]</li>

16203<li>

16204Cyclophosphamide doses exceeding 7.5 g/m<span class="sup">

162052</span>

16206 and ifosfamide doses exceeding 60 g/m<span class="sup">

162072</span>

16208 produced oligospermia or azoospermia in most exposed individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

1620922</a>

16210-<a href="#cit/section_9.24">

1621124</a>

16212]</li>

16213<li>

16214A small cohort study reported normal semen quality in adult long-term survivors of childhood ALL treated with 0 to 10 g/m<span class="sup">

162152</span>

16216 of cyclophosphamide and cranial irradiation, whereas no spermatozoa were detected in semen samples from survivors treated with more than 20 g/m<span class="sup">

162172</span>

16218 of cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

1621925</a>

16220] </li>

16221<li>

16222Treatment with a cyclophosphamide equivalent dose of less than 4 g/m<span class="sup">

162232</span>

16224 results in infrequent azoospermia or oligospermia. Approximately 89% of 31 men treated were normospermic.[<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

1622526</a>

16226]</li>

16227<li>

16228Spermatogenesis was present in 67% of 15 men who received 200 mg/kg of cyclophosphamide before undergoing HSCT for aplastic anemia.[<a href="#cit/section_9.27">

1622927</a>

16230]</li>

16231</ul>

16232</div>

16233 </li>

16234<li>

16235<strong>

16236Dacarbazine:</strong>

16237 <div class="pdq-content-list">

16238<ul id="_1126" class="list-dash">

16239<li>

16240The combination of doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine (ABVD) frequently produced oligospermia or azoospermia in adults during the course of treatment. However, recovery of spermatogenesis occurred after treatment was completed, which is in contrast to the experience reported after treatment with mechlorethamine, vincristine, procarbazine, and prednisone (MOPP).[<a href="#cit/section_9.28">

1624128</a>

16242]</li>

16243</ul>

16244</div>

16245 </li>

16246<li>

16247<strong>

16248Alkylating agent plus procarbazine:</strong>

16249 <div class="pdq-content-list">

16250<ul id="_1127" class="list-dash">

16251<li>

16252Most studies suggest that combination chemotherapy with an alkylating agent and procarbazine causes severe damage to the testicular germinal epithelium that is irreversible at high cumulative doses.[<a href="#cit/section_9.16">

1625316</a>

16254,<a href="#cit/section_9.29">

1625529</a>

16256-<a href="#cit/section_9.32">

1625732</a>

16258]</li>

16259<li>

16260Azoospermia occurred less frequently in adults after treatment with two, rather than six, cycles of MOPP.[<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

1626133</a>

16262]</li>

16263<li>

16264Elevation of the basal follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) level, which may reflect impaired spermatogenesis, was less frequent among patients who received two courses of vincristine, procarbazine, prednisone, and doxorubicin (OPPA) than among those who received two courses of OPPA in combination with two or more courses of cyclophosphamide, vincristine, procarbazine and prednisone (COPP).[<a href="#cit/section_9.34">

1626534</a>

16266]</li>

16267</ul>

16268</div>

16269</li>

16270<li>

16271<strong>

16272Alkylating agents plus low-dose cranial radiation:</strong>

16273<div class="pdq-content-list">

16274<ul id="_1999" class="list-dash">

16275<li>

16276In a cross-sectional study that included male adult survivors of pediatric ALL who had received alkylating agent chemotherapy with or without cranial radiation, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital investigators demonstrated that cranial radiation at doses lower than 26 Gy has no demonstrable independent effect on spermatogenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.35">

1627735</a>

16278]</li>

16279</ul>

16280</div>

16281</li>

16282</ul>

16283</div>

16284</section>

16285<section id="_1149">

16286<h4 id="_1149_toc">

16287Testicular function after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT)</h4>

16288<p id="_1150" tabindex="-1">

16289The risk of gonadal dysfunction and infertility related to conditioning with total-body irradiation (TBI), high-dose alkylating agent chemotherapy, or both is substantial.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

1629036</a>

16291] Because patients with relapsed or refractory cancer often undergo HSCT, previous treatment with alkylating agent chemotherapy or hypothalamic-pituitary axis or gonadal radiation therapy may confer additional risks.</p>

16292<div class="pdq-content-list">

16293<ul id="_2440">

16294<li>

16295A French L.E.A. long-term follow-up study evaluated testosterone deficiency in male childhood leukemia survivors after treatment with HSCT or testicular irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

1629636</a>

16297]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16298<ul id="_2886">

16299<li>

16300Among 178 patients treated with myeloablative TBI, 55.6% had total testosterone deficiency, 15.7% had partial deficiency, and 28.7% were normal. A testicular boost of 4 to 6 Gy of radiation therapy and a younger age at HSCT significantly increased the risk. </li>

16301<li>

16302Among 53 patients who received a busulfan-containing myeloablative conditioning regimen, 28.3% had total deficiency, 15.1% had partial deficiency, 56.6% were normal. For patients who received this regimen and additional testicular radiation, 0% were normal, compared with 62.5% of patients who did not receive additional testicular radiation. </li>

16303<li>

16304Treatment with 24 Gy of testicular radiation without HSCT induced total or partial deficiency in 71.4% and 28.6% of patients, respectively (n = 21).</li>

16305</ul>

16306</div>

16307</li>

16308<li>

16309 Age at treatment also influences the risk of gonadal injury. Young boys and adolescents treated with high-dose cyclophosphamide (200 mg/kg) will generally maintain Leydig cell function and testosterone production, but germ cell failure is common.[<a href="#cit/section_9.37">

1631037</a>

16311] </li>

16312<li>

16313After TBI conditioning, most male patients retain their ability to produce testosterone but will experience germ cell failure.[<a href="#cit/section_9.37">

1631437</a>

16315]</li>

16316<li>

16317Limited data suggest that a greater proportion of boys will retain germinal function or recovery of spermatogenesis (based on pubertal progress and gonadotropin levels) after reduced-intensity conditioning with fludarabine/melphalan than will those treated with myeloablative conditioning with busulfan/cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

1631838</a>

16319]</li>

16320</ul>

16321</div>

16322</section>

16323<section id="_1159">

16324<h4 id="_1159_toc">

16325Recovery of germ cell function</h4>

16326<p id="_1161" tabindex="-1">

16327Recovery of germ cell function after cytotoxic chemotherapy and radiation therapy is possible. However, evidence based on hard outcomes like sperm count is limited. Most studies use hormonal biomarkers like inhibin B and FSH levels to estimate the presence of spermatogenesis. However, limitations in the specificity and positive predictive value of these tests have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_9.39">

1632839</a>

16329,<a href="#cit/section_9.40">

1633040</a>

16331] Male survivors should be advised that semen analysis is the most accurate assessment of adequacy of spermatogenesis.</p>

16332</section>

16333<section id="_2187">

16334<h4 id="_2187_toc">

16335Leydig cell function in long-term survivors of childhood cancer</h4>

16336<p id="_2188" tabindex="-1">

16337Leydig cell function in childhood cancer survivors has not been well studied. St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for Leydig cell failure and Leydig cell dysfunction in 1,516 men (median age, 30.8 years; median time from diagnosis, 22 years).[<a href="#cit/section_9.41">

1633841</a>

16339]</p>

16340<div class="pdq-content-list">

16341<ul id="_2189">

16342<li>

16343The prevalence of Leydig cell failure (defined as testosterone &lt;250 ng/dL and luteinizing hormone &gt;9.85 IU/L) was 6.9%.</li>

16344<li>

16345The prevalence of Leydig cell dysfunction (defined as testosterone &#8805;250 ng/dL and luteinizing hormone &gt;9.85 IU/L) was 14.7%.</li>

16346<li>

16347Independent risk factors for Leydig cell failure included attained age of 26 years or older at assessment, testicular radiation therapy at any dose, and alkylating agents at cyclophosphamide equivalent doses of 4,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

163482</span>

16349 or higher.</li>

16350<li>

16351Unilateral orchiectomy and similar risk factors for Leydig cell failure were associated with Leydig cell dysfunction.</li>

16352<li>

16353The risk of Leydig cell failure and dysfunction increased with older age, higher radiation doses, and increased alkylating agent exposure.</li>

16354<li>

16355Adverse outcomes significantly associated with Leydig cell failure (but not Leydig cell dysfunction) included abdominal obesity, diabetes mellitus, erectile dysfunction, muscle weakness, and all-cause mortality.</li>

16356</ul>

16357</div>

16358</section>

16359</section>

16360<section id="_387">

16361<h3 id="_387_toc">

16362Ovary</h3>

16363<p id="_1132" tabindex="-1">

16364Cancer treatments that may impair ovarian function/reserve include the following:</p>

16365<div class="pdq-content-list">

16366<ul id="_1133">

16367<li>

16368<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1151">

16369Surgery</a>

16370 (oophorectomy).</li>

16371<li>

16372<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1153">

16373Radiation therapy</a>

16374 (exposing the hypothalamic-pituitary axis or ovaries).</li>

16375<li>

16376<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1155">

16377Chemotherapy</a>

16378 (alkylating agents, similar DNA interstrand cross-linking agents like procarbazine).</li>

16379<li>

16380<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1157">

16381HSCT</a>

16382.</li>

16383</ul>

16384</div>

16385<section id="_1151">

16386<h4 id="_1151_toc">

16387Surgery affecting ovarian function</h4>

16388<p id="_1152" tabindex="-1">

16389The main challenge for the pediatric surgeon in the management of ovarian tumors is finding the right balance between optimal tumor resection and maximal fertility preservation. Oophorectomy performed for the management of germ cell tumors may reduce ovarian reserve. Contemporary treatments use fertility-sparing surgical procedures combined with systemic chemotherapy to reduce this risk.[<a href="#cit/section_9.42">

1639042</a>

16391]</p>

16392</section>

16393<section id="_1153">

16394<h4 id="_1153_toc">

16395Radiation affecting ovarian function</h4>

16396<p id="_389" tabindex="-1">

16397In women treated for childhood cancer, primary gonadal injury may have occurred if treatment fields involved the lumbosacral spine, abdomen, pelvis, or total body. The frequency of ovarian failure after abdominal radiation therapy is related to both the age of the patient at the time of irradiation and the radiation therapy dose received by the ovaries. The ovaries of younger individuals are more resistant to radiation damage than those of older women because of their greater complement of primordial follicles. </p>

16398<p id="_1154" tabindex="-1">

16399Whole-abdomen irradiation at doses of 20 Gy or higher is associated with the greatest risk of ovarian dysfunction. Seventy-one percent of patients in one series failed to enter puberty, and 26% of women experienced premature menopause after receiving whole-abdominal radiation therapy doses of 20 Gy to 30 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.43">

1640043</a>

16401] Other studies reported similar results in women treated with whole-abdomen irradiation [<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

1640244</a>

16403] or craniospinal irradiation [<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

1640445</a>

16405,<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

1640646</a>

16407] during childhood.</p>

16408</section>

16409<section id="_1155">

16410<h4 id="_1155_toc">

16411Chemotherapy affecting ovarian function</h4>

16412<p id="_390" tabindex="-1">

16413Ovarian function may be impaired after treatment with combination chemotherapy that includes an alkylating agent and procarbazine. In general, girls maintain gonadal function at higher cumulative alkylating agent doses than do boys. Most female childhood cancer survivors who are treated with risk-adapted combination chemotherapy retain or recover ovarian function. However, the risk of acute ovarian failure and premature menopause is substantial if treatment includes combined-modality therapy with alkylating agent chemotherapy and abdominal or pelvic radiation therapy or dose-intensive alkylating agents for myeloablative conditioning before HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_9.47">

1641447</a>

16415-<a href="#cit/section_9.52">

1641652</a>

16417]</p>

16418</section>

16419<section id="_1134">

16420<h4 id="_1134_toc">

16421Premature ovarian failure</h4>

16422<p id="_1135" tabindex="-1">

16423Premature ovarian failure is well documented in childhood cancer survivors, especially in women treated with both an alkylating agent and abdominal radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.47">

1642447</a>

16425,<a href="#cit/section_9.51">

1642651</a>

16427-<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

1642854</a>

16429]</p>

16430<p id="_2041" tabindex="-1">

16431Studies have associated the following factors with an increased rate of premature ovarian insufficiency (acute ovarian failure and premature menopause):</p>

16432<div class="pdq-content-list">

16433<ul id="_1136">

16434<li>

16435Age at the time of treatment and attained age.</li>

16436<li>

16437Increasing doses of abdominal-pelvic radiation therapy.</li>

16438<li>

16439Exposure to alkylating agents and/or procarbazine. </li>

16440<li>

16441Oophorectomy.</li>

16442</ul>

16443</div>

16444<p id="_1156" tabindex="-1">

16445The presence of apparently normal ovarian function at the completion of chemotherapy should not be interpreted as evidence that no ovarian injury has occurred.</p>

16446<p id="_1765" tabindex="-1">

16447Evidence (excess risk of premature ovarian insufficiency after chemotherapy and radiation):</p>

16448<div class="pdq-content-list">

16449<ol id="_1766">

16450<li>

16451A CCSS study of 2,008 survivors of unilateral nonsyndromic Wilms tumor found the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.55">

1645255</a>

16453]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16454<ul id="_2993">

16455<li>

16456The 35-year cumulative incidence of premature ovarian insufficiency was 7.3% (95% confidence interval [CI], 5.0&#8211;9.7).</li>

16457<li>

16458Survivors of Wilms tumor who were treated with more intense therapy (including radiation therapy) experienced greater rates of premature ovarian insufficiency, compared with survivors who were treated with vincristine and dactinomycin alone. </li>

16459</ul>

16460</div>

16461</li>

16462<li>

16463The menopausal status of 2,930 survivors (median age, 35 years) participating in the CCSS was compared with that of 1,399 siblings. Nonsurgical premature menopause was defined as sustained menses cessation occurring for more than 6 months, beginning 5 years after the cancer diagnosis but before age 40 years, that was not caused by pregnancy, surgery, or medications.[<a href="#cit/section_9.51">

1646451</a>

16465]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16466<ul id="_1996">

16467<li>

16468The prevalence of nonsurgical premature menopause was 9.1% at age 40 years in these survivors.</li>

16469<li>

16470In multivariable analyses, significant independent risk factors for the development of nonsurgical premature menopause were the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

16471<ul id="_3059">

16472<li>

16473 Exposure to a dose of procarbazine greater than 4,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

164742</span>

16475 (odds ratio [OR], 8.96; 95% CI, 5.02&#8211;16.00; <em>

16476P</em>

16477 &lt; .0001).</li>

16478<li>

16479Exposure to any dose of radiation therapy to the ovaries (OR, 2.73 [95% CI, 1.33&#8211;5.61; <em>

16480P</em>

16481 = .0062] for a dose of less than 5 Gy and OR, 8.02 [95% CI, 2.81&#8211;22.85; <em>

16482P</em>

16483 &lt; .0001] for a dose of greater than 5 Gy).</li>

16484<li>

16485Receipt of an HSCT (OR, 6.35; 95% CI, 1.19&#8211;33.93; <em>

16486P</em>

16487 = .0307).</li>

16488</ul>

16489</div>

16490</li>

16491<li>

16492 A cyclophosphamide equivalent dose of 6,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

164932</span>

16494 or higher that included procarbazine was significant in the univariate analysis, but it did not achieve significance in the multivariable analysis.</li>

16495<li>

16496For survivors who received more than 4,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

164972</span>

16498 of procarbazine, the prevalence of nonsurgical premature menopause at age 40 years was 39.7%, compared with 4.2% among those who did not receive any procarbazine (<em>

16499P</em>

16500 &lt; .0001). </li>

16501<li>

16502Radiation exposure to the ovaries of greater than 5 Gy resulted in a prevalence of nonsurgical premature menopause at age 40 years of 24.1%, compared with a prevalence of 3.0% in those who did not receive radiation (<em>

16503P</em>

16504 &lt; .0001).</li>

16505<li>

16506 Cyclophosphamide exposure (at any dose), unilateral oophorectomy, smoking status, and body mass index (BMI) were not found to be significant for the risk of nonsurgical premature menopause.</li>

16507<li>

16508Compared with survivors who did not develop nonsurgical premature menopause, those who developed nonsurgical premature menopause were less likely to ever be pregnant or to have a live birth between the ages of 31 and 40 years. There was no difference in the pregnancy and live birth rates before the age of 30 years for survivors who ultimately developed nonsurgical premature menopause and those who do not.</li>

16509</ul>

16510</div>

16511</li>

16512<li>

16513A French cohort study of 1,109 female survivors of childhood solid cancer identified the risk factors for nonsurgical menopause, which included treatment with alkylating agents, radiation exposing the ovaries, and oophorectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

1651454</a>

16515]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16516<ul id="_1770">

16517<li>

16518Women treated with alkylating agents after the onset of puberty, either alone (relative risk [RR], 9.0; 95% CI, 2.7&#8211;28.0; <em>

16519P</em>

16520 = .0003) or associated with a low dose of radiation to the ovaries (RR, 29; 95% CI, 8&#8211;108; <em>

16521P</em>

16522 &lt; .0001), had the highest risk ratio for nonsurgical menopause.</li>

16523<li>

16524The overall rate of nonsurgical menopause by age 40 years was only 2.1% and substantially lower than the CCSS and European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer cohort studies that include survivors of hematological malignancies.</li>

16525<li>

16526Unilateral oophorectomy was associated with a 7-year-earlier age at menopause. </li>

16527</ul>

16528</div>

16529</li>

16530<li>

16531European survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma treated between the ages 15 years and 40 years and who were not receiving hormonal contraceptives were surveyed for the occurrence of premature ovarian failure.[<a href="#cit/section_9.53">

1653253</a>

16533]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16534<ul id="_1771">

16535<li>

16536In 460 women, premature ovarian failure was mainly influenced by alkylating chemotherapy use with a linear dose relationship between alkylating chemotherapy and premature ovarian failure occurrence.</li>

16537<li>

16538 Premature ovarian failure risk increased by 23% per year of age at treatment. In women treated without alkylating chemotherapy before age 32 years, cumulative premature ovarian failure risks were 3%, and at age 32 years or older, the same risks were 9%.</li>

16539<li>

16540If menstruation returned after treatment, cumulative premature ovarian failure risk was independent of age at treatment.</li>

16541<li>

16542Among women who ultimately developed premature ovarian failure, 22% had one or more children after treatment, compared with 41% of women without premature ovarian failure who had one or more children after treatment. </li>

16543<li>

16544This report indicates that women with proven fertility after treatment can still face infertility problems at a later stage.</li>

16545</ul>

16546</div>

16547</li>

16548<li>

16549St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for premature ovarian insufficiency in 921 female childhood cancer survivor participants. Premature ovarian insufficiency was clinically assessed and defined by persistent amenorrhea combined with an FSH level of 30 IU/L or higher before age 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

1655056</a>

16551] <div class="pdq-content-list">

16552<ul id="_1994">

16553<li>

16554The prevalence of premature ovarian insufficiency was 10.9% among women who were a median age of 31.7 years at study assessment and a median 24 years from cancer diagnosis. </li>

16555<li>

16556Independent risk factors for premature ovarian insufficiency included ovarian radiation therapy at any dose and cyclophosphamide equivalent dose of 8,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

165572</span>

16558 or higher.</li>

16559<li>

16560Obesity (BMI of 30 kg/m<span class="sup">

165612</span>

16562 or higher) at assessment was associated with a lower risk of premature ovarian insufficiency (HR, 0.36). </li>

16563<li>

16564Survivors with premature ovarian insufficiency had increased odds of low bone mineral density (OR, 5.07) and frailty (OR, 3.5) than did those without premature ovarian insufficiency.</li>

16565</ul>

16566</div>

16567</li>

16568</ol>

16569</div>

16570</section>

16571<section id="_1157">

16572<h4 id="_1157_toc">

16573Ovarian function after HSCT</h4>

16574<p id="_944" tabindex="-1">

16575The preservation of ovarian function among women treated with HSCT is related to age at treatment, receipt of pretransplant alkylating agent chemotherapy and abdominal-pelvic radiation therapy, and transplant conditioning regimen.[<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

1657649</a>

16577,<a href="#cit/section_9.57">

1657857</a>

16579]</p>

16580<p id="_1772" tabindex="-1">

16581Evidence (excess risk of premature ovarian insufficiency after HSCT):</p>

16582<div class="pdq-content-list">

16583<ol id="_1773">

16584<li>

16585Girls and young women conditioned with TBI or busulfan-based regimens appear to be at equally high risk of declining ovarian function and premature menopause compared with patients conditioned with cyclophosphamide only.[<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

1658649</a>

16587] All women who received high-dose (50 mg/kg/day &#215; 4 days) cyclophosphamide before HSCT for aplastic anemia developed amenorrhea after transplantation. </li>

16588<li>

16589In another series, 36 of 43 women with aplastic anemia conditioned with cyclophosphamide (200 mg/kg) had recovery of normal ovarian function 3 to 42 months after transplantation, including all of the 27 patients who were between ages 13 and 25 years at the time of HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_9.50">

1659050</a>

16591]</li>

16592<li>

16593TBI is especially damaging when given in a single fraction.[<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

1659449</a>

16595] Most postpubertal women who receive TBI before HSCT develop amenorrhea. </li>

16596<li>

16597In one series, recovery of normal ovarian function occurred in only 9 of 144 patients and was highly correlated with age at time of radiation therapy in patients younger than 25 years.[<a href="#cit/section_9.50">

1659850</a>

16599]</li>

16600<li>

16601Among women with leukemia, cranial irradiation before transplantation further decreased the possibility of retaining ovarian function.[<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

1660249</a>

16603]</li>

16604<li>

16605Ovarian function may be better preserved (based on pubertal progress and gonadotropin levels) in females undergoing HSCT with reduced-intensity conditioning using fludarabine/melphalan than in those undergoing conditioning with myeloablative busulfan/cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

1660638</a>

16607] </li>

16608</ol>

16609</div>

16610</section>

16611<section id="_2408">

16612<h4 id="_2408_toc">

16613Predicting premature ovarian failure</h4>

16614<div class="pdq-content-list">

16615<ol id="_2757">

16616<li>

16617Data from 5,886 (median follow-up, 23.9 years) CCSS and 875 (median follow-up, 23.9 years) St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study (SJLIFE) participants were used to develop and validate risk prediction tools for acute ovarian failure.[<a href="#cit/section_9.58">

1661858</a>

16619]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16620<ul id="_2441">

16621<li>

16622 Acute ovarian failure, defined as permanent loss of ovarian function within 5 years of cancer diagnosis, occurred in 6.0% of CCSS female participants and 5.7% of SJLIFE female participants.</li>

16623<li>

16624 Models were developed using either protocol-prescribed abdominal and pelvic radiation doses or ovarian dose based on ovarian radiation dosimetry from the CCSS cohort and validated in the SJLIFE cohort with good performance characteristics.</li>

16625<li>

16626 Common predictors in both models were history of HSCT, cumulative alkylating drug dose, and an interaction between age at cancer diagnosis and HSCT.</li>

16627<li>

16628 The online calculator is available on the <a href="https://ccss.stjude.org/tools-documents/calculators-other-tools/ccss-ovarian-risk-calculator.html" title="https://ccss.stjude.org/tools-documents/calculators-other-tools/ccss-ovarian-risk-calculator.html">

16629CCSS website</a>

16630.</li>

16631</ul>

16632</div>

16633</li>

16634<li>

16635A multicenter Dutch study evaluated treatment-related factors associated with abnormal hormonal and ultrasound markers of ovarian reserve in 5-year female childhood cancer survivors (diagnosed between 1963 and 2002) and in controls. There were 564 survivors and 390 controls who underwent clinical assessments of ovarian reserve, including antim&#252;llerian hormone (AMH), FSH, inhibin B levels, and antral follicle counts (AFC).[<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

1663659</a>

16637]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16638<ul id="_2758">

16639<li>

16640Of the childhood cancer survivors, 7.0% to 17.7% had abnormal ovarian reserve markers, compared with 2.4% to 13.6% of controls. </li>

16641<li>

16642Significantly more childhood cancer survivors older than 35 years had abnormal ovarian reserve markers than did controls (AMH: 26% vs. 4%; AFC: 20% vs. 3%; inhibin B: 42% vs. 16%). AMH and FSH were also significantly different in survivors younger than 35 years.</li>

16643<li>

16644Treatments independently associated with at least one abnormal ovarian reserve marker included cyclophosphamide, procarbazine, a group of other alkylating agents, dactinomycin, doxorubicin, mitoxantrone, spinal radiation therapy, abdominal/pelvic radiation therapy, and TBI.</li>

16645<li>

16646Dose-effect relationships could only be established for procarbazine and abdominal/pelvic radiation therapy.</li>

16647</ul>

16648</div>

16649</li>

16650</ol>

16651</div>

16652</section>

16653</section>

16654<section id="_395">

16655<h3 id="_395_toc">

16656Fertility</h3>

16657<p id="_396" tabindex="-1">

16658Infertility remains one of the most common life-altering treatment effects experienced by long-term survivors of childhood cancer. Pediatric cancer cohort studies have demonstrated the impact of cytotoxic therapy on reproductive outcomes. CCSS investigations have elucidated factors contributing to subfertility among childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

1665960</a>

16660,<a href="#cit/section_9.61">

1666161</a>

16662]</p>

16663<p id="_2894" tabindex="-1">

16664No abnormalities in fertility (reproductive characteristics and AMH levels as compared with controls) were identified in a series of 56 long-term female survivors of childhood differentiated thyroid cancer who received iodine I 131 (131I) for treatment. The median follow-up was 15.4 years (range, 8.3&#8211;24.7 years), and the median cumulative dose of 131I was 7.4 GBq/200.0 mCi. None of the survivors reported premature menopause.[<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

1666562</a>

16666]</p>

16667<p id="_2442" tabindex="-1">

16668Evidence (excess risk of impaired fertility):</p>

16669<div class="pdq-content-list">

16670<ol id="_2443">

16671<li>

16672Fertility was evaluated in 10,938 CCSS participants (5,640 males, 5,298 females) and 3,949 siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

1667360</a>

16674]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16675<ul id="_2444">

16676<li>

16677At a median follow-up of 8 years from cohort entry, 38% of survivors reported having or siring a pregnancy, resulting in at least one live birth in 83% of those survivors. </li>

16678<li>

16679Among siblings monitored for a median of 10 years, 62% reported having or siring a pregnancy, resulting in at least one live birth in 90% of those siblings. </li>

16680<li>

16681Multivariable analysis confirmed that survivors had significantly decreased likelihood of siring or having a pregnancy (hazard ratio [HR], 0.63 in males and 0.87 in females) or of having a live birth (HR, 0.63 in males and 0.82 in females) than did siblings.</li>

16682<li>

16683Greater doses of alkylating drugs (HR, 0.82 per 5,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

166842</span>

16685 increments) and cisplatin reduced the likelihood of siring pregnancy among male survivors, but only busulfan and higher doses (&gt;411 mg/m<span class="sup">

166862</span>

16687) of lomustine significantly reduced pregnancy among females. </li>

16688<li>

16689The risk of reduced likelihood of pregnancy in women was observed only at the highest cyclophosphamide equivalent dose (HR, 0.85 for upper quartile [&#8805;11,295 mg/m<span class="sup">

166902</span>

16691] vs. no exposure).</li>

16692<li>

16693HRs (95% CIs) for the likelihood of reporting first pregnancy by cyclophosphamide equivalent dose for male and female survivors are summarized in <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1614">

16694Table 16</a>

16695:<table id="_1614" class="table-default expandable-container">

16696<caption>

16697Table 16. Cyclophosphamide Equivalent Dose by Tertile and Sex</caption>

16698<colgroup>

16699<col width="17.66%">

16700<col width="17.66%">

16701<col width="23.49%">

16702<col width="17.66%">

16703<col width="23.49%">

16704</colgroup>

16705<THead>

16706<tr>

16707<th>

16708Cyclophosphamide Equivalent Dose by Tertile</th>

16709<th colspan="2">

16710Male</th>

16711<th colspan="2">

16712Female</th>

16713</tr>

16714<tr>

16715<th>

16716&#160;</th>

16717<th>

16718HR (95% CI)</th>

16719<th>

16720<em>

16721P</em>

16722 Value</th>

16723<th>

16724HR (95% CI)</th>

16725<th>

16726<em>

16727P</em>

16728 Value</th>

16729</tr>

16730</THead>

16731<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

16732<tr>

16733<td colspan="5">

16734CI = confidence interval; HR = hazard ratio.</td>

16735</tr>

16736</TFoot>

16737<tbody>

16738<tr>

16739<td>

16740Lower

16741(&lt;4,897 mg/m<span class="sup">

167422</span>

16743)

16744</td>

16745<td>

167461.14 (1.00&#8211;1.30)</td>

16747<td>

16748.045</td>

16749<td>

167500.97 (0.86&#8211;1.08)</td>

16751<td>

16752.55</td>

16753</tr>

16754<tr>

16755<td>

16756Middle

16757(4,897&#8211;9,638 mg/m<span class="sup">

167582</span>

16759)

16760</td>

16761<td>

167620.79 (0.68&#8211;0.91)</td>

16763<td>

16764.0010</td>

16765<td>

167660.98 (0.87&#8211;1.11)</td>

16767<td>

16768.76</td>

16769</tr>

16770<tr>

16771<td>

16772Upper

16773(&#8805;9,639 mg/m<span class="sup">

167742</span>

16775)

16776</td>

16777<td>

167780.55 (0.47&#8211;0.64)</td>

16779<td>

16780&lt;.0001</td>

16781<td>

167820.90 (0.79&#8211;1.01)</td>

16783<td>

16784.07</td>

16785</tr>

16786</tbody>

16787</table>

16788</li>

16789<li>

16790Similar relationships were observed for live birth outcomes.</li>

16791</ul>

16792</div>

16793</li>

16794<li>

16795Fertility may be impaired by factors other than the absence of sperm and ova. Conception requires delivery of sperm to the uterine cervix, patency of the fallopian tubes for fertilization to occur, and appropriate conditions in the uterus for implantation.<div class="pdq-content-list">

16796<ul id="_1139">

16797<li>

16798Retrograde ejaculation occurs with a significant frequency in men who undergo bilateral retroperitoneal lymph node dissection.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

167997</a>

16800,<a href="#cit/section_9.8">

168018</a>

16802]</li>

16803<li>

16804Uterine structure may be affected by abdominal irradiation. A study demonstrated that uterine length was significantly shorter in ten women with ovarian failure who had been treated with whole-abdomen irradiation. Endometrial thickness did not increase in response to hormone replacement therapy in three women who underwent weekly ultrasonography examinations. Using Doppler ultrasonography, no blood flow was detectable through either uterine artery in five women, and through one uterine artery in three additional women.[<a href="#cit/section_9.63">

1680563</a>

16806]</li>

16807</ul>

16808</div>

16809</li>

16810<li>

16811In a study of menopausal status on reproductive outcomes in 2,930 survivors from the CCSS, investigators found that for those who ultimately developed nonsurgical premature menopause, rates of pregnancy and live birth were substantially reduced before nonsurgical premature menopause between the ages of 31 and 40 years. However, pregnancy and live birth rates did not differ for those aged 21 to 30 years on the basis of ultimate menopausal status.[<a href="#cit/section_9.51">

1681251</a>

16813]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16814<ul id="_2445">

16815<li>

16816 Treatment variables significant for developing nonsurgical premature menopause by multivariable analyses included exposure to procarbazine doses higher than 4,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

168172</span>

16818, any ovarian irradiation, and HSCT.</li>

16819<li>

16820 A cyclophosphamide equivalent dose of 6,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

168212</span>

16822 or higher that included procarbazine was significant in the univariate analysis, but it did not achieve significance in the multivariable analysis.</li>

16823</ul>

16824</div>

16825</li>

16826</ol>

16827</div>

16828</section>

16829<section id="_2786">

16830<h3 id="_2786_toc">

16831Sexual Function</h3>

16832<p id="_2787" tabindex="-1">

16833The psychosexual health of adults who were treated for cancer during childhood, adolescence, and young adulthood has not been well studied. </p>

16834<p id="_2788" tabindex="-1">

16835A St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study estimated the prevalence of and risk factors for sexual dysfunction among 936 adult female survivors of childhood cancer. The study also evaluated associations between sexual dysfunction and psychological symptoms/quality of life.[<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

1683664</a>

16837]</p>

16838<div class="pdq-content-list">

16839<ul id="_2789">

16840<li>

16841Sexual dysfunction was prevalent in almost 20% of survivors. Survivors of germ cell tumors (OR, 8.8), renal tumors, (OR, 4.5) or leukemia (OR, 3.1) were at greater risk than controls. </li>

16842<li>

16843Older age at follow-up (45&#8211;54 vs. 18&#8211;24 years; OR, 5.7) and history of pelvic surgery (OR, 2.0), depression (OR, 2.0), and hypogonadism receiving hormone replacement (OR, 3.3) were associated with sexual dysfunction.</li>

16844<li>

16845Only 2.9% of survivors with sexual dysfunction reported receiving intervention.</li>

16846</ul>

16847</div>

16848</section>

16849<section id="_399">

16850<h3 id="_399_toc">

16851Reproduction</h3>

16852<section id="_1233">

16853<h4 id="_1233_toc">

16854Fertility preservation</h4>

16855<p id="_463" tabindex="-1">

16856Progress in reproductive endocrinology has resulted in the availability of several options for preserving or permitting fertility in patients about to receive potentially toxic chemotherapy or radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.65">

1685765</a>

16858-<a href="#cit/section_9.68">

1685968</a>

16860] </p>

16861<div class="pdq-content-list">

16862<ul id="_2446">

16863<li>

16864For males, cryopreservation of spermatozoa before treatment is an effective method to circumvent the sterilizing effect of therapy for all peripubertal and postpubertal males. Although pretreatment semen quality in patients with cancer has been shown to be less than that noted in healthy donors, the percentage decline in semen quality and the effect of cryodamage to spermatozoa from patients with cancer is similar to that of normal donors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

1686569</a>

16866,<a href="#cit/section_9.70">

1686770</a>

16868] </li>

16869<li>

16870For males unable to bank sperm, newer technologies such as testicular sperm extraction may be an option. Further micromanipulative technological advances such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection and similar techniques may be able to render sperm extracted surgically, or even poor-quality cryopreserved spermatozoa from cancer patients, capable of successful fertilization.[<a href="#cit/section_9.71">

1687171</a>

16872,<a href="#cit/section_9.72">

1687372</a>

16874]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16875<ul id="_3048">

16876<li>

16877Based on Norway national registries (Cancer Registry of Norway and Medical Birth Registry), young male cancer survivors were reported to be at a threefold increased risk of using assisted reproduction technology for offspring conception.[<a href="#cit/section_9.73">

1687873</a>

16879]</li>

16880<li>

16881In a population-based nationwide study using the Swedish Medical Birth Registry, childhood cancer survivors and teenage and young adult cancer survivors were more likely to achieve paternity through intracytoplasmic sperm injection rather than <em>

16882in vitro</em>

16883 fertilization.[<a href="#cit/section_9.74">

1688474</a>

16885]</li>

16886</ul>

16887</div>

16888</li>

16889<li>

16890For females, the most successful assisted-reproductive techniques depend on harvesting and banking the postpubertal patient&#8217;s oocytes and cryopreserving unfertilized oocytes or embryos before gonadotoxic therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

1689175</a>

16892] </li>

16893<li>

16894Established options for females include ovarian transposition, shielding from radiation, and oocyte/embryo cryopreservation. Ovarian tissue cryopreservation is currently considered experimental in the United States, but it is performed as an established fertility preservation procedure in parts of Europe and Israel.[<a href="#cit/section_9.76">

1689576</a>

16896,<a href="#cit/section_9.77">

1689777</a>

16898] Options for prepubertal female patients are limited to investigational ovarian tissue cryopreservation for later autotransplantation, which may be offered to girls with nonovarian, nonhematologic cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_9.78">

1689978</a>

16900] </li>

16901<li>

16902Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists are used for ovarian suppression but are considered experimental, and their effectiveness is unproven.[<a href="#cit/section_9.79">

1690379</a>

16904] Several randomized trials and meta-analyses have explored the benefits of gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues during chemotherapy. However, the use of such analogues for ovarian protection during chemotherapy remains controversial. Two randomized controlled trials demonstrated that menstrual function, ovulation, and pregnancy were more likely to occur in patients with breast cancer after treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists during chemotherapy, compared with those who did not receive this therapy. However, benefits for fertility outcomes are lacking. Studies have been limited by inadequate follow-up and the assessment of surrogate measures of fertility rather than pregnancy rates. While gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues are not currently approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for fertility preservation, these medications may be used off label.[<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

1690580</a>

16906]</li>

16907</ul>

16908</div>

16909</section>

16910<section id="_2781">

16911<h4 id="_2781_toc">

16912Risk of pregnancy complications</h4>

16913<p id="_2824" tabindex="-1">

16914For survivors who maintain fertility, numerous investigations have evaluated the prevalence of and risk factors for pregnancy complications in adults treated for cancer during childhood. Pregnancy complications such as hypertension, fetal malposition, fetal loss/spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and low birth weight have been observed in association with specific diagnostic and treatment groups.[<a href="#cit/section_9.81">

1691581</a>

16916-<a href="#cit/section_9.85">

1691785</a>

16918] </p>

16919<p id="_2825" tabindex="-1">

16920Evidence (excess risk of pregnancy complications):</p>

16921<div class="pdq-content-list">

16922<ol id="_2826">

16923<li>

16924In a study of 4,029 pregnancies among 1,915 women followed in the CCSS, there were 63% live births, 1% stillbirths, 15% miscarriages, 17% abortions, and 3% unknown or in gestation.[<a href="#cit/section_9.81">

1692581</a>

16926] <div class="pdq-content-list">

16927<ul id="_2827">

16928<li>

16929Risk of miscarriage was 3.6-fold higher in women treated with craniospinal irradiation and 1.7-fold higher in those treated with pelvic irradiation. Chemotherapy exposure alone did not increase risk of miscarriage.</li>

16930<li>

16931Survivors were less likely to have live births, more likely to have medical abortions, and more likely to have low-birth-weight babies than were siblings.</li>

16932</ul>

16933</div>

16934</li>

16935<li>

16936Disruption of normal uterine function after radiation therapy or other treatment that results in reduced uterine volume and impaired uterine blood flow appears to be the underlying pathophysiology for many of these adverse obstetrical events.[<a href="#cit/section_9.86">

1693786</a>

16938,<a href="#cit/section_9.87">

1693987</a>

16940]</li>

16941<li>

16942In the National Wilms Tumor Study, records were obtained for 1,021 pregnancies of more than 20 weeks duration. In this group, there were 955 single live births.[<a href="#cit/section_9.88">

1694388</a>

16944]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16945<ul id="_2828">

16946<li>

16947Hypertension complicating pregnancy, early or threatened labor, malposition of the fetus, lower birth weight (&lt;2,500 g), and premature delivery (&lt;36 weeks) were more frequent among women who had received flank irradiation, in a dose-dependent manner.</li>

16948</ul>

16949</div>

16950</li>

16951<li>

16952Another CCSS study evaluated pregnancy outcomes of partners of male survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.82">

1695382</a>

16954]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16955<ul id="_2829">

16956<li>

16957Among 4,106 sexually active males, 1,227 reported they sired 2,323 pregnancies, which resulted in 69% live births, 13% miscarriages, 13% abortions, and 5% unknown or in gestation at the time of analysis. </li>

16958<li>

16959Compared with partners of male siblings, there was a decreased incidence of live births (RR, 0.77), but no significant differences of pregnancy outcome by treatment.</li>

16960</ul>

16961</div>

16962</li>

16963<li>

16964Results from a Danish study confirm the association of uterine irradiation with spontaneous abortion, but not other types of abortion. In the Danish Cancer Registry, more than 34,000 pregnancies were evaluated, including 1,479 pregnancies in 1,688 female survivors of childhood cancer. The pregnancy outcomes of survivors, 2,737 sisters, and 16,700 comparison women in the population were identified.[<a href="#cit/section_9.83">

1696583</a>

16966]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16967<ul id="_2830">

16968<li>

16969No significant differences were seen between survivors and comparison women in the proportions of live births, stillbirths, or all types of abortions combined.</li>

16970<li>

16971Survivors with a history of neuroendocrine or abdominal radiation therapy had an increased risk of spontaneous abortion.</li>

16972<li>

16973The pregnancy outcomes of survivors were similar to those of comparison women, with the exception of spontaneous abortion.</li>

16974</ul>

16975</div>

16976</li>

16977<li>

16978In a retrospective cohort analysis from the CCSS of 1,148 men and 1,657 women who had survived cancer, there were 4,946 pregnancies.[<a href="#cit/section_9.84">

1697984</a>

16980]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16981<ul id="_2831">

16982<li>

16983Irradiation of the testes in men and pituitary gland in women and chemotherapy with alkylating drugs were not associated with an increased risk of stillbirth or neonatal death.</li>

16984<li>

16985Uterine and ovarian irradiation at doses higher than 10 Gy significantly increased the risk of stillbirth and neonatal death.</li>

16986<li>

16987For girls treated before menarche, irradiation of the uterus and ovaries at doses as low as 1 to 2.49 Gy significantly increased the risk of stillbirth or neonatal death.</li>

16988</ul>

16989</div>

16990</li>

16991<li>

16992Most pregnancies reported by survivors who underwent HSCT and their partners result in live births.[<a href="#cit/section_9.85">

1699385</a>

16994]<div class="pdq-content-list">

16995<ul id="_2832">

16996<li>

16997In female HSCT survivors who were exposed to TBI, there appears to be an increased risk of preterm delivery of low-birth-weight infants.</li>

16998<li>

16999Female HSCT survivors are at higher risk of needing cesarean delivery than are the normal population (42% vs. 16%).</li>

17000</ul>

17001</div>

17002</li>

17003<li>

17004Preservation of fertility and successful pregnancies may occur after HSCT, although the conditioning regimens that include TBI, cyclophosphamide, and busulfan are highly gonadotoxic. One study evaluated pregnancy outcomes in a group of females treated with HSCT.[<a href="#cit/section_9.89">

1700589</a>

17006]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17007<ul id="_2833">

17008<li>

17009 Among 708 women who were postpubertal at the time of transplant, 116 regained normal ovarian function and 32 became pregnant.</li>

17010<li>

17011Among 82 women who were prepubertal at the time of transplant, 23 had normal ovarian function and nine became pregnant.</li>

17012<li>

17013Of the 72 pregnancies in these 41 women, 16 occurred in those treated with TBI and 50% resulted in early termination.</li>

17014<li>

17015Among the 56 pregnancies in women treated with cyclophosphamide without either TBI or busulfan, 21% resulted in early termination.</li>

17016<li>

17017There were no pregnancies among the 73 women treated with busulfan and cyclophosphamide, and only one woman retained ovarian function.</li>

17018</ul>

17019</div>

17020</li>

17021<li>

17022A German Pediatric Oncology Group study demonstrated that the rate of childbearing for female survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma was similar to that of the general population. However, the rate of childbearing was lower for survivors who received pelvic radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.90">

1702390</a>

17024]</li>

17025<li>

17026British CCSS investigators evaluated pregnancy and labor complications among female survivors of childhood cancer treated with abdominal radiation. The study linked British CCSS cohort data to a national hospital registry.[<a href="#cit/section_9.91">

1702791</a>

17028] <div class="pdq-content-list">

17029<ul id="_2834">

17030<li>

17031Survivors treated with abdominal radiation had a significantly higher risk (RR, 2.1) of pregnancy complications than did survivors who did not receive abdominal radiation.</li>

17032<li>

17033Risks were elevated for hypertension complicating pregnancy among Wilms tumor survivors (RR, 3.29) treated with abdominal radiation. Risks were also elevated for gestational diabetes mellitus (RR, 3.35) and anemia (RR, 2.10) among all survivors treated with abdominal radiation.</li>

17034</ul>

17035</div>

17036</li>

17037<li>

17038A systematic review compared the data from published pregnancy and child health outcomes for pediatric and young adult leukemia and lymphoma survivors with the data from controls who did not have a history of cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.92">

1703992</a>

17040]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17041<ul id="_2835">

17042<li>

17043Compared with controls, survivors did not experience higher risks of spontaneous abortions, maternal diabetes and anemia, stillbirth, birth defects, or childhood cancer in offspring.</li>

17044<li>

17045Compared with controls, survivors had lower live birth rates and modestly higher risks of preterm birth and low birth weight.</li>

17046</ul>

17047</div>

17048</li>

17049</ol>

17050</div>

17051</section>

17052<section id="_725">

17053<h4 id="_725_toc">

17054Offspring of childhood cancer survivors</h4>

17055<p id="_726" tabindex="-1">

17056For childhood cancer survivors who have offspring, there is concern about congenital anomalies, genetic disease, or risk of cancer in the offspring. Children of cancer survivors are not at significantly increased risk of congenital anomalies stemming from their parents' exposure to mutagenic cancer treatments.</p>

17057<p id="_1785" tabindex="-1">

17058Evidence (children of cancer survivors not at significantly increased risk of congenital anomalies):</p>

17059<div class="pdq-content-list">

17060<ol id="_1786">

17061<li>

17062A retrospective cohort analysis of validated cases of congenital anomalies among 4,699 children of 1,128 male and 1,627 female participants of the CCSS observed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_9.93">

1706393</a>

17064]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17065<ul id="_1787">

17066<li>

17067No significant associations between gonadal radiation therapy or cumulative exposure to alkylating agents and congenital anomalies in offspring.</li>

17068</ul>

17069</div>

17070</li>

17071<li>

17072A study compared 2,198 offspring of adult survivors treated for childhood cancer between 1945 and 1975 with 4,544 offspring of sibling controls.[<a href="#cit/section_9.94">

1707394</a>

17074]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17075<ul id="_1788">

17076<li>

17077There were no differences in the proportion of offspring with cytogenetic syndromes, single-gene defects, or simple malformations.</li>

17078<li>

17079There was similarly no effect of type of childhood cancer treatment on the occurrence of genetic disease in the offspring.</li>

17080</ul>

17081</div>

17082</li>

17083<li>

17084A population-based study compared 2,630 live-born offspring of childhood cancer survivors with 5,504 live-born offspring of the survivors' siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_9.95">

1708595</a>

17086]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17087<ul id="_3060">

17088<li>

17089 The study found no differences in proportion of abnormal karyotypes or incidence of Down syndrome or Turner syndrome between survivor and sibling offspring.</li>

17090<li>

17091In the same population-based cohort, survivors treated with abdominal radiation therapy and/or alkylating agents did not have an increased risk of offspring with genetic disease, compared with survivors not exposed to these agents.</li>

17092</ul>

17093</div>

17094</li>

17095<li>

17096One study evaluated 5,847 offspring of survivors of childhood cancers treated in five Scandinavian countries.[<a href="#cit/section_9.96">

1709796</a>

17098]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17099<ul id="_2463">

17100<li>

17101In the absence of a hereditary cancer syndrome (such as hereditary retinoblastoma), there was no increased risk of cancer in offspring.</li>

17102<li>

17103 Compared with the offspring of siblings, there was no excess risk of single-gene disorders, congenital malformations, or chromosomal syndromes among the offspring of former patients.[<a href="#cit/section_9.97">

1710497</a>

17105]</li>

17106</ul>

17107</div>

17108</li>

17109<li>

17110A European Group for Blood and Marrow Transplantation study evaluated pregnancy outcomes in 19,412 patients who underwent allogeneic transplant and 17,950 patients who underwent autologous transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_9.85">

1711185</a>

17112]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17113<ul id="_3061">

17114<li>

17115Investigators did not observe an increased risk of birth defects, developmental delay, or cancer among offspring of male and female HSCT recipients.</li>

17116</ul>

17117</div>

17118</li>

17119<li>

17120A nationwide Finnish population-based registry study compared the risk of congenital anomalies in the offspring of 6,862 long-term survivors of childhood, adolescent, and young adult cancer treated between 1953 and 2004 with the risk of congenital anomalies in the offspring of 35,690 siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_9.98">

1712198</a>

17122] <div class="pdq-content-list">

17123<ul id="_1828">

17124<li>

17125Compared with siblings, childhood and adolescent survivors (prevalence ratio [PR], 1.17; 95% CI, 0.92&#8211;1.49) and young adult survivors (PR, 1.17; 95% CI, 0.83&#8211;1.23) were not at significant excess risk of congenital anomalies. </li>

17126<li>

17127There was an association between parent cancer and congenital anomalies in the offspring of survivors who were diagnosed in the earlier decades (1955&#8211;1964: PR, 2.77; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;6.11; and 1965&#8211;1974: PR, 1.55; 95% CI, 0.94&#8211;2.56).</li>

17128</ul>

17129</div>

17130</li>

17131</ol>

17132</div>

17133</section>

17134</section>

17135<p id="_1729" tabindex="-1">

17136<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1718">

17137Table 17</a>

17138 summarizes reproductive late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

17139<table id="_1718" class="table-default expandable-container">

17140<caption>

17141Table 17. Reproductive Late Effects<span class="sup">

17142a</span>

17143</caption>

17144<colgroup>

17145<col width="33.33%">

17146<col width="33.33%">

17147<col width="33.33%">

17148</colgroup>

17149<THead>

17150<tr>

17151<th>

17152Predisposing Therapy </th>

17153<th>

17154Reproductive Late Effects</th>

17155<th>

17156Health Screening</th>

17157</tr>

17158</THead>

17159<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

17160<tr>

17161<td colspan="3">

17162AMH = antim&#252;llerian hormone; FSH = follicle-stimulating hormone; LH = luteinizing hormone.</td>

17163</tr>

17164<tr>

17165<td colspan="3">

17166<span class="sup">

17167a</span>

17168Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

17169Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

17170.</td>

17171</tr>

17172</TFoot>

17173<tbody>

17174<tr>

17175<td rowspan="13">

17176Alkylating agents;

17177radiation exposing the gonads

17178</td>

17179<td rowspan="3">

17180Testicular hormonal dysfunction:

17181Testosterone deficiency/insufficiency;

17182delayed/arrested puberty

17183</td>

17184<td>

17185Tanner stage

17186

17187</td>

17200Reduced fertility;

17201oligospermia;

17202azoospermia;

17203infertility

17207</td>

17216</td>

17219<td rowspan="7">

17220Ovarian hormone deficiencies:

17221Delayed/arrested puberty;

17222premature ovarian insufficiency/premature menopause.

17223Reduced ovarian follicular pool:

17224Diminished ovarian reserve; infertility.

17225</td>

17227Tanner stage</td>

17254</table>

17255<p id="_442" tabindex="-1">

17256For reproductive late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

17257Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

17258.</p>

Med Pediatr Oncol 34 (3): 191-4, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10696125&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10696125&amp;dopt=Abstract">

17541</li>
