17655</div>

17656

17657 </section>

17658

17659

17660

17661 <section id="_52">

17662

17663 <h2>

17664Late Effects of the Respiratory System</h2>

17665

17666 <div id="_section_52" class="pdq-sections">

17667<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

17668<h6>

17669In This Section</h6>

17670<ul>

17671<li>

17672<a href="#_1214_toc">

17673Respiratory complications after radiation therapy</a>

17674</li>

17675<li>

17676<a href="#_1216_toc">

17677Respiratory complications after chemotherapy</a>

17678</li>

17679<li>

17680<a href="#_1218_toc">

17681Respiratory complications associated with HSCT</a>

17682</li>

17683<li>

17684<a href="#_1221_toc">

17685Other factors associated with respiratory late effects</a>

17686</li>

17687</ul>

17688</nav>

17689<p id="_1255" tabindex="-1">

17690Respiratory function may be compromised in long-term survivors of childhood cancer who were treated with the following therapies:</p>

17691<div class="pdq-content-list">

17692<ul id="_1927">

17693<li>

17694Specific chemotherapeutic agents.</li>

17695<li>

17696Thoracic radiation therapy.</li>

17697<li>

17698Pulmonary/chest wall surgery.</li>

17699<li>

17700Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).</li>

17701</ul>

17702</div>

17703<p id="_1928" tabindex="-1">

17704The effects of early lung injury from cancer treatment may be exacerbated by the decline in lung function associated with normal aging, other comorbid chronic health conditions, or smoking. The quality of current evidence regarding this outcome is limited by retrospective data collection, small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, description of outcomes following antiquated treatment approaches, and variability in time since treatment and method of ascertainment. No large cohort studies have been performed that include clinical evaluations coupled with functional and quality-of-life assessments.</p>

17705<p id="_57" tabindex="-1">

17706The true prevalence or incidence of pulmonary dysfunction in childhood cancer survivors is not clear. For children treated with HSCT, significant clinical disease has been observed. Population-based studies have demonstrated that survivors experience excess morbidity and mortality related to respiratory conditions.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

177071</a>

17708,<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

177092</a>

17710]</p>

17711<div class="pdq-content-list">

17712<ol id="_2759">

17713<li>

17714A study that linked population-based cancer registrations and inpatient admissions of 4,235 five-year childhood cancer survivors (aged 0&#8211;29 years) diagnosed between 1990 and 2011 compared admission rates of survivors with those of age- and sex-matched population controls.[<a href="#cit/section_10.1">

177151</a>

17716]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17717<ul id="_2760">

17718<li>

17719The cumulative incidence for any type of respiratory conditions was 49% by age 40 years among survivors, which was 1.86 (95% CI, 1.73&#8211;2.01) times higher than for controls. </li>

17720<li>

17721Treatment with pulmonary toxic chemotherapy increased the risk of admission for all respiratory conditions (subdistribution hazard ratio (sHR), 1.26; 95% CI, 1.03&#8211;1.53) and pneumonia (sHR, 1.48; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;2.17). </li>

17722<li>

17723Subsequent mortality was highest in patients admitted for pneumonia compared with other respiratory conditions (28% vs. 15%, respectively). </li>

17724</ul>

17725</div>

17726</li>

17727<li>

17728Another population-based study investigated long-term respiratory mortality before age 40 years among 5-year cancer survivors participating in the British Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (BCCSS) and the Teenage and Young Adult Cancer Survivor Study (TYACSS).[<a href="#cit/section_10.2">

177292</a>

17730]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17731<ul id="_2761">

17732<li>

17733Excess respiratory deaths were observed among survivors in the BCCSS (SMR, 6.8; 95% CI, 5.8&#8211;7.9) and TYACSS (SMR, 1.7; 95% CI, 1.6&#8211;1.8), with risks varying by type of respiratory death (e.g., pneumonia, pneumonitis, fibrosis, and chronic lower respiratory disease).</li>

17734<li>

17735Survivors of CNS tumors in the BCCSS and survivors of lung cancer, leukemia, and head and neck cancers in the TYACSS experienced the greatest number of excess respiratory deaths.</li>

17736<li>

17737An increase in excess number of respiratory deaths was noted with increasing age, but reassuringly, a decline in excess deaths was observed among more recently diagnosed survivors in both cohorts. </li>

17738</ul>

17739</div>

17740</li>

17741</ol>

17742</div>

17743<p id="_1256" tabindex="-1">

17744Evidence (selected cohort studies describing long-term pulmonary function outcomes):</p>

17745<div class="pdq-content-list">

17746<ol id="_1929">

17747<li>

17748The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) described the incidence of self-reported pulmonary dysfunction among adult survivors of central nervous system malignancies who were treated with craniospinal irradiation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.3">

177493</a>

17750]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17751<ul id="_2701">

17752<li>

17753The incidence of emphysema/obliterative bronchiolitis was 9.1 (95% confidence interval, 7.8&#8211;10.6) (per 1,000 person-years).</li>

17754<li>

17755The incidence of asthma, chronic cough, and the need for extra oxygen was more than 3.0 (per 1,000 person-years).</li>

17756<li>

17757High rates of late-onset pulmonary dysfunction occurring more than 5 years after diagnosis were also observed.</li>

17758</ul>

17759</div>

17760</li>

17761<li>

17762Dutch investigators reported outcomes of 193 childhood cancer survivors evaluated by pulmonary function testing at a median follow-up of 18 years after diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

177634</a>

17764]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17765<ul id="_1930">

17766<li>

17767 Pulmonary function impairment (Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events grade 2 or higher) was identified in 85 patients (44.0%) and included obstructive deficits (2.1%), restrictive deficits (17.6%), and decreased carbon monoxide diffusion capacity (39.9%).</li>

17768<li>

17769Multivariate logistic regression models showed that treatment with radiation therapy, radiation therapy combined with bleomycin, and radiation therapy combined with surgery were associated with the highest risk of pulmonary function impairment when compared with bleomycin treatment only.</li>

17770</ul>

17771</div>

17772</li>

17773<li>

17774In a longitudinal study evaluating the magnitude and trajectory of pulmonary dysfunction among 121 childhood cancer survivors (median time from diagnosis to last evaluation, 17.1 years) treated with potentially pulmonary-toxic therapy (e.g., bleomycin, busulfan, pulmonary radiation therapy), survivors were significantly more likely to have restrictive and diffusion defects than were healthy controls.[<a href="#cit/section_10.5">

177755</a>

17776]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17777<ul id="_1931">

17778<li>

17779 Age younger than 16 years at diagnosis and exposure to more than 20 Gy of chest radiation were associated with increased odds of restrictive defects, whereas female sex and chest radiation dose were associated with diffusion abnormalities.</li>

17780<li>

17781Decline in pulmonary function over time was largely related to changes in diffusion capacity. The odds of decline in diffusion function over time showed a fourfold increase among females and 24-fold increase among survivors treated with more than 20 Gy of chest radiation. Compared with survivors with normal diffusion, those with diffusion defects were significantly more likely to be symptomatic and have poorer health-related quality-of-life scores, with decreases in the domains of physical functioning, role limitation because of physical health, and low energy/increased fatigue.</li>

17782</ul>

17783</div>

17784</li>

17785<li>

17786CCSS investigators compared self-reported pulmonary outcomes and their impact on daily activities among 5-year cancer survivors (median, 25 years from diagnosis) and a sibling cohort.[<a href="#cit/section_10.6">

177876</a>

17788]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17789<ul id="_1932">

17790<li>

17791 Survivors were more likely to report chronic cough, the need for oxygen, lung fibrosis, and recurrent pneumonia than were siblings despite lower rates of smoking.</li>

17792<li>

17793By age 45 years, the cumulative incidence of any pulmonary condition was 29.6% for survivors. Survivors with chronic pulmonary conditions (e.g., chronic cough) were more likely to report activity limitations than were those without these conditions.</li>

17794<li>

17795Pulmonary complications contributed to an almost sixfold excess risk of death among survivors and demonstrated significant associations with exposure to platinum and lung radiation.</li>

17796</ul>

17797</div>

17798</li>

17799<li>

17800St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study investigators evaluated risk factors for clinically ascertained pulmonary function deficits and the functional impact of pulmonary impairment in 606 adult survivors of childhood cancer (median age, 34 years at evaluation; median time from cancer diagnosis, 21.9 years).[<a href="#cit/section_10.7">

178017</a>

17802]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17803<ul id="_2633">

17804<li>

17805Pulmonary function deficits were identified in the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

17806<ul id="_2702" class="list-dash">

17807<li>

17808Forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV<sub>

178091</sub>

17810) less than 80% predicted (50.7% of patients).</li>

17811<li>

17812Forced vital capacity (FVC) less than 80% predicted (47.2% of patients).</li>

17813<li>

17814Single-breath diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO)corrected for hemoglobin less than 75% predicted (44.6% of patients).</li>

17815</ul>

17816</div>

17817</li>

17818<li>

17819Obstructive lung defects (FEV<sub>

178201</sub>

17821/FVC, &lt;0.7) were found in 0.8% of patients and restrictive defects (total lung capacity [TLC] &lt;75%) in 31.2% of patients. </li>

17822<li>

17823Risk factors for abnormal pulmonary function included the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

17824<ul id="_2703" class="list-dash">

17825<li>

17826Estimated percentage of lung tissue that received at least 10 Gy of radiation therapy (V10) and elapsed time from diagnosis for FEV<sub>

178271</sub>

17828.</li>

17829<li>

17830Age at diagnosis and V10 for TLC.</li>

17831<li>

17832Increased body mass index, V10, and elapsed time from diagnosis for DLCO corrected for hemoglobin.</li>

17833</ul>

17834</div>

17835</li>

17836<li>

17837 Abnormal pulmonary function tests were associated with a decreased 6-minute walk distance.</li>

17838</ul>

17839</div>

17840</li>

17841</ol>

17842</div>

17843<section id="_1214">

17844<h3 id="_1214_toc">

17845Respiratory complications after radiation therapy</h3>

17846<p id="_1257" tabindex="-1">

17847Radiation therapy that exposes the lung parenchyma can result in pulmonary dysfunction related to reduced lung volume, impaired dynamic compliance, and deformity of both the lung and chest wall. </p>

17848<div class="pdq-content-list">

17849<ul id="_2634">

17850<li>

17851The potential for chronic pulmonary sequelae is related to the radiation dose administered, the volume of lung irradiated, and the fractional radiation therapy doses.[<a href="#cit/section_10.8">

178528</a>

17853] </li>

17854<li>

17855Combined-modality therapy including radiation therapy and pulmonary toxic chemotherapy or thoracic/chest wall surgery increases the risk of pulmonary function impairment.[<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

178564</a>

17857,<a href="#cit/section_10.9">

178589</a>

17859]</li>

17860<li>

17861Chronic pulmonary complications reported after treatment for pediatric malignancies include restrictive or obstructive chronic pulmonary disease, pulmonary fibrosis, and spontaneous pneumothorax.[<a href="#cit/section_10.10">

1786210</a>

17863] </li>

17864<li>

17865These sequelae are uncommon after contemporary therapy, which most often results in subclinical injury that is detected only by imaging or formal pulmonary function testing. </li>

17866</ul>

17867</div>

17868<p id="_1259" tabindex="-1">

17869Evidence (selected cohort studies describing pulmonary outcomes):</p>

17870<div class="pdq-content-list">

17871<ol id="_1933">

17872<li>

17873For survivors of pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma, the prevalence of pulmonary symptoms using contemporary involved-field techniques is reported to be low. However, some patients exhibit substantial subclinical dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_10.11">

1787411</a>

17875]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17876<ol id="_2694" class="lower-alpha">

17877<li>

17878A study of 54 children who were treated with induction chemotherapy (usually doxorubicin, bleomycin, vincristine, etoposide, prednisone, and cyclophosphamide&#8211;based chemotherapy) and 21 Gy of radiation therapy from 2008 through 2016 confirmed these findings.[<a href="#cit/section_10.12">

1787912</a>

17880] <div class="pdq-content-list">

17881<ul id="_2695">

17882<li>

17883At a median follow-up of 39.5 months, 3 of 54 patients (5.6%) or 3 of 108 lungs (2.8%) developed radiation pneumonitis (RP); two lungs had grade 1 RP and one lung had grade 2 RP.</li>

17884<li>

17885RP was seen only in patients with a median lung dose of higher than 12.4 Gy or with an individual mean lung dose higher than 13.8 Gy.</li>

17886</ul>

17887</div>

17888 </li>

17889<li>

17890In a study of 109 patients (59% with Hodgkin lymphoma) who were irradiated at a median age of 13.8 years (range, 0.04&#8211;20.9 years; median follow-up, 3.4 years), patients were treated with a median prescribed radiation therapy dose of 21 Gy (range, 0.4&#8211;64.8 Gy); 58.7% of patients received bleomycin, and 83.5% of patients received cyclophosphamide.[<a href="#cit/section_10.13">

1789113</a>

17892]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17893<ul id="_2636">

17894<li>

17895The 5-year cumulative incidence after irradiation was: pneumonitis, 6%; chronic cough, 10%; pneumonia, 35%; dyspnea, 11%; supplemental oxygen requirement, 2%; radiographic interstitial lung disease, 40%; and chest wall deformity, 12%. </li>

17896<li>

17897One patient died of progressive respiratory failure.</li>

17898<li>

17899Postirradiation pulmonary function tests available from 44 patients showed evidence of obstructive lung disease (25%), restrictive disease (11%), hyperinflation (32%), and abnormal diffusion capacity (12%). </li>

17900<li>

17901Thoracic surgery, bleomycin, age, maximum lung irradiation dose V30 (volume of lung exposed to a radiation dose &gt;30 Gy), and volume of lung exposed to a radiation dose of greater than 25 Gy were significant risk factors for the development of adverse pulmonary outcomes on univariate analysis.</li>

17902<li>

17903Mean lung irradiation dose, maximum lung dose, and V<sub>

17904dose</sub>

17905 (percentage of volume of lung receiving the threshold dose or greater) were highly correlated. On multivariate analysis, mean lung irradiation dose was the sole significant predictor of adverse pulmonary outcome (<em>

17906P</em>

17907 = .01). </li>

17908</ul>

17909</div>

17910</li>

17911</ol>

17912</div>

17913</li>

17914<li>

17915Changes in lung function have been reported in children treated with whole-lung radiation therapy for metastatic Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

1791614</a>

17917,<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

1791815</a>

17919]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17920<ul id="_1990">

17921<li>

17922 A dose of 12 Gy to 14 Gy reduced total lung capacity and vital capacity to about 70% of predicted values, and even lower if the patient had undergone thoracotomy.</li>

17923</ul>

17924</div>

17925</li>

17926<li>

17927Administration of bleomycin alone can produce pulmonary toxicity and, when combined with radiation therapy, can heighten radiation reactions. Chemotherapeutic agents such as doxorubicin, dactinomycin, and busulfan are radiomimetic agents and can reactivate underlying radiation damage.[<a href="#cit/section_10.14">

1792814</a>

17929,<a href="#cit/section_10.15">

1793015</a>

17931]</li>

17932</ol>

17933</div>

17934</section>

17935<section id="_1216">

17936<h3 id="_1216_toc">

17937Respiratory complications after chemotherapy</h3>

17938<p id="_55" tabindex="-1">

17939Chemotherapy agents with potential pulmonary toxic effects commonly used in the treatment of pediatric malignancies include bleomycin, busulfan, and the nitrosoureas (carmustine and lomustine). These agents induce lung damage on their own or potentiate the damaging effects of radiation to the lung.</p>

17940<p id="_2637" tabindex="-1">

17941 Combined-modality therapy including pulmonary toxic chemotherapy and thoracic radiation therapy or thoracic/chest wall surgery increases the risk of pulmonary function impairment.[<a href="#cit/section_10.4">

179424</a>

17943]</p>

17944<p id="_1935" tabindex="-1">

17945Evidence (outcomes among cohorts treated with pulmonary toxic chemotherapy):</p>

17946<div class="pdq-content-list">

17947<ol id="_1936">

17948<li>

17949The development of bleomycin-associated pulmonary fibrosis with permanent restrictive disease is dose dependent, usually occurring at doses greater than 200 U/m<span class="sup">

179502</span>

17951 to 400 U/m<span class="sup">

179522</span>

17953, higher than those used in treatment protocols for pediatric malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_10.16">

1795416</a>

17955,<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1795617</a>

17957]</li>

17958<li>

17959More current pediatric regimens for Hodgkin lymphoma using radiation therapy and doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine (ABVD) have shown a significant incidence of asymptomatic pulmonary dysfunction after treatment, which appears to improve with time.[<a href="#cit/section_10.18">

1796018</a>

17961-<a href="#cit/section_10.20">

1796220</a>

17963] However, grades 3 and 4 pulmonary toxicity was reported in 9% of children receiving 12 cycles of ABVD followed by 21 Gy of extended-field radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_10.17">

1796417</a>

17965]</li>

17966<li>

17967ABVD-related pulmonary toxic effects may result from fibrosis induced by bleomycin or radiation recall pneumonitis related to administration of doxorubicin.</li>

17968<li>

17969Pulmonary veno-occlusive disease has been observed rarely and has been attributed to bleomycin chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_10.21">

1797021</a>

17971]</li>

17972</ol>

17973</div>

17974</section>

17975<section id="_1218">

17976<h3 id="_1218_toc">

17977Respiratory complications associated with HSCT</h3>

17978<div class="pdq-content-list">

17979<ul id="_2638">

17980<li>

17981Patients undergoing HSCT are at increased risk of pulmonary toxic effects related to the following:[<a href="#cit/section_10.22">

1798222</a>

17983-<a href="#cit/section_10.24">

1798424</a>

17985]<div class="pdq-content-list">

17986<ul id="_2639">

17987<li>

17988Preexisting pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., asthma, pretransplant therapy).</li>

17989<li>

17990Conditioning regimens, including cyclophosphamide, busulfan,

17991or carmustine.</li>

17992<li>

17993Total-body irradiation.</li>

17994<li>

17995Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).</li>

17996</ul>

17997</div>

17998</li>

17999<li>

18000Although most survivors of transplant are not clinically compromised, restrictive lung disease may occur and has been reported to increase in prevalence with increasing time from HSCT, based on limited data from longitudinally followed cohorts.[<a href="#cit/section_10.25">

1800125</a>

18002,<a href="#cit/section_10.26">

1800326</a>

18004]</li>

18005<li>

18006 Obstructive disease is less common, as is late-onset pulmonary syndrome, which includes the spectrum of restrictive and obstructive disease.</li>

18007<li>

18008 Bronchiolitis obliterans with or without organizing pneumonia, diffuse alveolar damage, and interstitial pneumonia may occur as a component of this syndrome, generally between 6 and 12 months posttransplant. Cough, dyspnea, or wheezing may occur with either normal chest x-ray or diffuse/patchy infiltrates; however, most patients are symptom free.[<a href="#cit/section_10.23">

1800923</a>

18010,<a href="#cit/section_10.27">

1801127</a>

18012,<a href="#cit/section_10.28">

1801328</a>

18014]</li>

18015</ul>

18016</div>

18017</section>

18018<section id="_1221">

18019<h3 id="_1221_toc">

18020Other factors associated with respiratory late effects</h3>

18021<div class="pdq-content-list">

18022<ul id="_2640">

18023<li>

18024Additional factors contributing to chronic pulmonary toxic effects include superimposed infection, underlying pneumonopathy (e.g., asthma), chest wall abnormalities, respiratory toxic effects, chronic GVHD, and the effects of chronic pulmonary involvement by tumor or reaction to tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_10.9">

180259</a>

18026]</li>

18027<li>

18028 Lung lobectomy during childhood appears to have no significant impact on long-term pulmonary function,[<a href="#cit/section_10.29">

1802929</a>

18030] but the long-term effect of lung surgery for children with cancer is not well defined.</li>

18031<li>

18032Pulmonary complications may also be exacerbated by smoking cigarettes or other substances. While smoking rates in survivors of childhood cancer tend to be lower than the general population, it is still important to prevent initiation of smoking and promote cessation in this distinct population.[<a href="#cit/section_10.30">

1803330</a>

18034]</li>

18035</ul>

18036</div>

18037<p id="_1937" tabindex="-1">

18038Evidence (pulmonary dysfunction in former or current smokers):</p>

18039<div class="pdq-content-list">

18040<ol id="_1938">

18041<li>

18042Pulmonary function evaluations of 433 adult childhood cancer survivors treated with pulmonary toxic modalities demonstrated significantly higher risk of pulmonary dysfunction in smokers than in nonsmokers.[<a href="#cit/section_10.31">

1804331</a>

18044]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18045<ul id="_1939">

18046<li>

18047 FEV<sub>

180481</sub>

18049/FVC median values among current and former smokers were lower than those who had never smoked.</li>

18050<li>

18051Median FEV<sub>

180521</sub>

18053/FVC values were lower among those who smoked less than 6 pack-years and those who smoked 6 pack-years or more compared with those who had never smoked. This suggests that survivors who are former or current smokers have an increased risk of future obstructive and restrictive lung disease.</li>

18054</ul>

18055</div>

18056</li>

18057</ol>

18058</div>

18059</section>

18060<p id="_1730" tabindex="-1">

18061<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_419">

18062Table 18</a>

18063 summarizes respiratory late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

18064<table id="_419" class="table-default expandable-container">

18065<caption>

18066Table 18. Respiratory Late Effects<span class="sup">

18067a</span>

18068</caption>

18069<colgroup>

18070<col width="33.33%">

18071<col width="33.33%">

18072<col width="33.33%">

18073</colgroup>

18074<THead>

18075<tr>

18076<th>

18077Predisposing Therapy</th>

18078<th>

18079Respiratory Effects</th>

18080<th>

18081Health Screening/Interventions</th>

18082</tr>

18083</THead>

18084<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

18085<tr>

18086<td colspan="3">

18087DLCO = diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide; GVHD = graft-versus-host disease.</td>

18088</tr>

18089<tr>

18090<td colspan="3">

18091<span class="sup">

18092a</span>

18093Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

18094Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

18095.</td>

18096</tr>

18097</TFoot>

18098<tbody>

18099<tr>

18100<td rowspan="8">

18101Busulfan;

18102carmustine (BCNU)/lomustine (CCNU);

18103bleomycin;

18104radiation exposing lungs;

18105surgery impacting pulmonary function (lobectomy, metastasectomy, wedge resection) </td>

18106<td rowspan="8">

18107Subclinical pulmonary dysfunction;

18108interstitial pneumonitis;

18109pulmonary fibrosis;

18110restrictive lung disease;

18111obstructive lung disease

18112</td>

18113<td>

18114History: cough, shortness of breath, dyspnea on exertion, wheezing</td>

18115</tr>

18116<tr>

18117<td>

18118Pulmonary exam</td>

18119</tr>

18120<tr>

18121<td>

18122Pulmonary function tests (including DLCO and spirometry)</td>

18123</tr>

18124<tr>

18125<td>

18126Chest x-ray</td>

18127</tr>

18128<tr>

18129<td>

18130Counsel regarding tobacco avoidance/smoking cessation</td>

18131</tr>

18132<tr>

18133<td>

18134In patients with abnormal pulmonary function tests and/or chest x-ray, consider repeat evaluation before general anesthesia</td>

18135</tr>

18136<tr>

18137<td>

18138Pulmonary consultation for patients with symptomatic pulmonary dysfunction</td>

18139</tr>

18140<tr>

18141<td>

18142Influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations</td>

18143</tr>

18144<tr>

18145<td rowspan="8">

18146Hematopoietic cell transplantation with any history of chronic GVHD </td>

18147<td rowspan="8">

18148Pulmonary toxicity (bronchiolitis obliterans, chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis)</td>

18149<td>

18150History: cough, shortness of breath, dyspnea on exertion, wheezing</td>

18151</tr>

18152<tr>

18153<td>

18154Pulmonary exam</td>

18155</tr>

18156<tr>

18157<td>

18158Pulmonary function tests (including DLCO and spirometry)</td>

18159</tr>

18160<tr>

18161<td>

18162Chest x-ray</td>

18163</tr>

18164<tr>

18165<td>

18166Counsel regarding tobacco avoidance/smoking cessation</td>

18167</tr>

18168<tr>

18169<td>

18170In patients with abnormal pulmonary function tests and/or chest x-ray, consider repeat evaluation before general anesthesia</td>

18171</tr>

18172<tr>

18173<td>

18174Pulmonary consultation for patients with symptomatic pulmonary dysfunction</td>

18175</tr>

18176<tr>

18177<td>

18178Influenza and pneumococcal vaccinations</td>

18179</tr>

18180</tbody>

18181</table>

18182<p id="_443" tabindex="-1">

18183For respiratory late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

18184Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

18185.[<a href="#cit/section_10.32">

1818632</a>

18187]</p>

18233[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18234</li>

18235<li id="section_10.12">

18236Lewis GD, Agrusa JE, Teh BS, et al.: Radiation pneumonitis in pediatric Hodgkin lymphoma patients receiving radiation therapy to the chest. Pract Radiat Oncol 8 (5): e364-e368, 2018 Sep - Oct.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29730281&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29730281&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18237[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18238</li>

18239<li id="section_10.13">

18240Venkatramani R, Kamath S, Wong K, et al.: Correlation of clinical and dosimetric factors with adverse pulmonary outcomes in children after lung irradiation. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 86 (5): 942-8, 2013.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23726005&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23726005&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18241[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18242</li>

18243<li id="section_10.14">

18244McDonald S, Rubin P, Maasilta P: Response of normal lung to irradiation. Tolerance doses/tolerance volumes in pulmonary radiation syndromes. Front Radiat Ther Oncol 23: 255-76; discussion 299-301, 1989.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2697658&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2697658&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18245[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18246</li>

18247<li id="section_10.15">

18248McDonald S, Rubin P, Phillips TL, et al.: Injury to the lung from cancer therapy: clinical syndromes, measurable endpoints, and potential scoring systems. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 31 (5): 1187-203, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7713782&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7713782&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18249[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18250</li>

18251<li id="section_10.16">

18252Bossi G, Cerveri I, Volpini E, et al.: Long-term pulmonary sequelae after treatment of childhood Hodgkin's disease. Ann Oncol 8 (Suppl 1): 19-24, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9187424&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9187424&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18253[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18254</li>

18255<li id="section_10.17">

18256Fryer CJ, Hutchinson RJ, Krailo M, et al.: Efficacy and toxicity of 12 courses of ABVD chemotherapy followed by low-dose regional radiation in advanced Hodgkin's disease in children: a report from the Children's Cancer Study Group. J Clin Oncol 8 (12): 1971-80, 1990.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1700080&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1700080&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18257[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18258</li>

18259<li id="section_10.18">

18260Hudson MM, Greenwald C, Thompson E, et al.: Efficacy and toxicity of multiagent chemotherapy and low-dose involved-field radiotherapy in children and adolescents with Hodgkin's disease. J Clin Oncol 11 (1): 100-8, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8418221&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8418221&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18261[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18262</li>

18263<li id="section_10.19">

18264Hunger SP, Link MP, Donaldson SS: ABVD/MOPP and low-dose involved-field radiotherapy in pediatric Hodgkin's disease: the Stanford experience. J Clin Oncol 12 (10): 2160-6, 1994.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7523608&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7523608&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18265[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18266</li>

18267<li id="section_10.20">

18268Marina NM, Greenwald CA, Fairclough DL, et al.: Serial pulmonary function studies in children treated for newly diagnosed Hodgkin's disease with mantle radiotherapy plus cycles of cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and procarbazine alternating with cycles of doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. Cancer 75 (7): 1706-11, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8826931&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8826931&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18269[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18270</li>

18271<li id="section_10.21">

18272Polliack A: Late therapy-induced cardiac and pulmonary complications in cured patients with Hodgkin's disease treated with conventional combination chemo-radiotherapy. Leuk Lymphoma 15 (Suppl 1): 7-10, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7767265&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7767265&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18273[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18274</li>

18275<li id="section_10.22">

18276Cerveri I, Fulgoni P, Giorgiani G, et al.: Lung function abnormalities after bone marrow transplantation in children: has the trend recently changed? Chest 120 (6): 1900-6, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11742920&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11742920&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18278</li>

18280Leiper AD: Non-endocrine late complications of bone marrow transplantation in childhood: part II. Br J Haematol 118 (1): 23-43, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12100126&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12100126&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18281[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18282</li>

Bone Marrow Transplant 33 (5): 509-17, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14716347&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14716347&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18285[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18286</li>

18287<li id="section_10.25">

18288Inaba H, Yang J, Pan J, et al.: Pulmonary dysfunction in survivors of childhood hematologic malignancies after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Cancer 116 (8): 2020-30, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20186702&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20186702&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18289[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18290</li>

18291<li id="section_10.26">

18292Frisk P, Arvidson J, Hedenstr&#246;m H: A longitudinal study of pulmonary function after stem cell transplantation, from childhood to young adulthood. Pediatr Blood Cancer 58 (5): 775-9, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21584939&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21584939&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18293[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18294</li>

18295<li id="section_10.27">

18296Uderzo C, Pillon M, Corti P, et al.: Impact of cumulative anthracycline dose, preparative regimen and chronic graft-versus-host disease on pulmonary and cardiac function in children 5 years after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: a prospective evaluation on behalf of the EBMT Pediatric Diseases and Late Effects Working Parties. Bone Marrow Transplant 39 (11): 667-75, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17401396&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17401396&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18297[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18298</li>

18299<li id="section_10.28">

18300Yoshihara S, Yanik G, Cooke KR, et al.: Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS), bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and other late-onset noninfectious pulmonary complications following allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Biol Blood Marrow Transplant 13 (7): 749-59, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17580252&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17580252&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18301[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18302</li>

18303<li id="section_10.29">

18304Kreisel D, Krupnick AS, Huddleston CB: Outcomes and late complications after pulmonary resections in the pediatric population. Semin Thorac Cardiovasc Surg 16 (3): 215-9, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15619188&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15619188&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18305[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18306</li>

18307<li id="section_10.30">

18308Gibson TM, Liu W, Armstrong GT, et al.: Longitudinal smoking patterns in survivors of childhood cancer: An update from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study. Cancer 121 (22): 4035-43, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26287647&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26287647&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18309[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18310</li>

18311<li id="section_10.31">

18312Oancea SC, Gurney JG, Ness KK, et al.: Cigarette smoking and pulmonary function in adult survivors of childhood cancer exposed to pulmonary-toxic therapy: results from the St. Jude lifetime cohort study. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev 23 (9): 1938-43, 2014.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24939744&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24939744&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18313[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18314</li>

18315<li id="section_10.32">

18316Liles A, Blatt J, Morris D, et al.: Monitoring pulmonary complications in long-term childhood cancer survivors: guidelines for the primary care physician. Cleve Clin J Med 75 (7): 531-9, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18646589&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18646589&amp;dopt=Abstract">

18317[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

18318</li>

18319</ol>

18320</div>

18321

18322 </section>

18323

18325

18326 <section id="_20">

18327

18328 <h2>

18329Late Effects of the Special Senses</h2>

18330

18331 <div id="_section_20" class="pdq-sections">

18332<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

18333<h6>

18334In This Section</h6>

18335<ul>

18336<li>

18337<a href="#_21_toc">

18338Hearing<ul>

18339<li>

18340<a href="#_1061_toc">

18341Hearing loss and platinum-based therapy</a>

18342</li>

18343<li>

18344<a href="#_1064_toc">

18345Hearing loss and cranial radiation therapy</a>

18346</li>

18347<li>

18351</ul>

18352</a>

18353</li>

18354<li>

18355<a href="#_24_toc">

18356Orbital and Optic<ul>

18357<li>

18358<a href="#_1066_toc">

18359Retinoblastoma</a>

18360</li>

18361<li>

18363Rhabdomyosarcoma</a>

18364</li>

18367Low-grade optic pathway glioma</a>

18368</li>

18369<li>

18374</a>

18375</li>

18376</ul>

18377</nav>

18378<section id="_21">

18379<h3 id="_21_toc">

18380Hearing</h3>

18381<p id="_1585" tabindex="-1">

18382Hearing loss as a late effect of therapy can occur after exposure to platinum compounds (cisplatin and carboplatin), cranial radiation therapy, or both. These therapeutic exposures are most common in the treatment of central nervous system (CNS) and non-CNS solid tumors. Children are more susceptible to otologic toxic effects from platinum agents than are adults.[<a href="#cit/section_11.1">

183831</a>

18384,<a href="#cit/section_11.2">

183852</a>

18386]</p>

18387<p id="_2641" tabindex="-1">

18388Evidence (hearing loss):</p>

18389<div class="pdq-content-list">

18390<ol id="_2642">

18391<li>

18392A longitudinal study evaluated the incidence of and risk factors for hearing loss in 171 patients (340 ears) with CNS and head and neck tumors treated with multiple ototoxic exposures. The study reported associations with severe hearing loss, ototoxic chemotherapy, and cochlea dose.[<a href="#cit/section_11.3">

183933</a>

18394]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18395<ul id="_2887">

18396<li>

18397Mean cochlea dose (odds ratio [OR], 1.04 per Gy; <em>

18398P</em>

18399 &lt; .001), time since radiation therapy (OR, 1.21 per year; <em>

18400P</em>

18401 &lt; .001), cisplatin dose (OR, 1.48 per 100 mg/m<span class="sup">

184022</span>

18403; <em>

18404P</em>

18405 &lt; .001), and carboplatin dose (OR, 1.41 per 1,000 mg/m<span class="sup">

184062</span>

18407; <em>

18408P</em>

18409 = .002) were associated with increasing International Society of Pediatric Oncology-Boston grade of hearing loss. </li>

18410<li>

18411The cumulative incidence of high-frequency hearing loss (&gt;4 kHz) was 50% or greater at 5 years after radiation if mean cochlea dose was &gt;30 Gy.</li>

18412<li>

18413The incidence of hearing loss across all frequencies continued to increase beyond 5 years after radiation therapy.</li>

18414<li>

18415There was no synergistic effect of radiation therapy and cisplatin (interaction term, <em>

18416P</em>

18417 = .53) or radiation therapy and carboplatin (interaction term, <em>

18418P</em>

18419 = .85). </li>

18420</ul>

18421</div>

18422</li>

18423<li>

18424 A report from the Swiss Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (N = 2,061) estimated the prevalence of hearing loss in survivors at 10%, compared with 3% in siblings. Hearing loss was most common in survivors of CNS tumors (25%), neuroblastoma (23%), hepatic tumor (21%), germ cell tumor (20%), bone tumor (16%), and soft tissue sarcoma (16%).[<a href="#cit/section_11.4">

184254</a>

18426]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18427<ul id="_2932">

18428<li>

18429A follow-up study from this cohort was limited to 270 childhood cancer survivors treated with platinum-based chemotherapy. Varying doses of cisplatin were used. Of those who received cisplatin, the median cumulative dose was 400 mg/m<span class="sup">

184302</span>

18431 (interquartile range, 314&#8211;480 mg/m<span class="sup">

184322</span>

18433). Hearing loss, assessed using audiological evaluations, was characterized as mild (20%), moderate (29%), and severe (28%). More severe hearing loss was associated with younger age at diagnosis (OR, 5.4 for &lt;5 years), treatment in earlier years (OR, 4.8 for 1990&#8211;1995), higher cisplatin doses (OR, 13.5 for &gt;450 mg/m<span class="sup">

184342</span>

18435), concomitant cranial radiation therapy (OR, 4.4), and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (OR, 2.7).[<a href="#cit/section_11.5">

184365</a>

18437]</li>

18438</ul>

18439</div>

18440</li>

18441<li>

18442 Data from the North American Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) indicate that the relative rate of first occurrence of auditory complications (i.e., problems hearing sounds, tinnitus, hearing loss, deafness) is greatest in the time period from diagnosis to 5 years postdiagnosis; however, during the period of 5 or more years postdiagnosis, the risk of developing such conditions for survivors remained significantly higher than for siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

184436</a>

18444]</li>

18445<li>

18446A population-based study used health registry data to evaluate the long-term incidence and predictors of hearing loss requiring hearing amplification devices (HAD) among Canadian childhood cancer survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

184477</a>

18448]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18449<ol id="_2718" class="lower-alpha">

18450<li>

18451Among 11,842 cases and 59,210 controls identified, cases were at higher risk of needing an HAD (hazard ratio [HR], 12.8; 95% confidence interval [CI], 9.8&#8211;16.7). </li>

18452<li>

18453The cumulative incidence of HAD among survivors was 2.1% (95% CI, 1.7%&#8211;2.5%) at 20 years and increased to 6.4% (95% CI, 2.8%&#8211;12.1%) at 30 years postdiagnosis. </li>

18454<li>

18455The 30-year incidence was highest in survivors of neuroblastoma (10.7%; 95% CI, 3.8%&#8211;21.7%) and hepatoblastoma (16.2%; 95% CI, 8.6%&#8211;26.0%).</li>

18456<li>

18457In multivariable analyses, predictors of requiring an HAD included the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

18458<ul id="_2459" class="list-dash">

18459<li>

18460Age 0 to 4 years at diagnosis versus age 5 to 9 years (HR, 2.2; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;3.3).</li>

18461<li>

18462Treatment with 200 mg/m<span class="sup">

184632</span>

18464 or more of cisplatin versus no cisplatin (HR, 3.1; 1.8&#8211;5.5).</li>

18465<li>

18466 Treatment with cranial or facial radiation therapy of higher than 32 Gy versus radiation therapy of 32 Gy or lower (HR, 2.4; 1.6&#8211;3.7).</li>

18467</ul>

18468</div>

18469 </li>

18470</ol>

18471</div>

18472</li>

18473</ol>

18474</div>

18475<p id="_1060" tabindex="-1">

18476Risk factors associated with hearing loss include the following:</p>

18477<div class="pdq-content-list">

18478<ul id="_308">

18479<li>

18480Younger age at treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

184817</a>

18482,<a href="#cit/section_11.8">

184838</a>

18484]</li>

18485<li>

18486Higher cumulative dose of platinum-based chemotherapy (&#8805;200 mg/m<span class="sup">

184872</span>

18488).[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

184897</a>

18490,<a href="#cit/section_11.9">

184919</a>

18492] Based on the results of a multi-institutional North American cohort study (n = 1,481), significant risk factors for developing cisplatin-induced hearing loss included both the cumulative dose of cisplatin and how the cisplatin was administered. Higher fractionated doses were associated with risk of cisplatin-induced hearing loss (for each 10 mg/m<span class="sup">

184932</span>

18494 increase/day: adjusted odds ratio [OR], 1.15; for each 50 mg/m<span class="sup">

184952</span>

18496 increase per cycle: adjusted OR, 2.16).[<a href="#cit/section_11.8">

184978</a>

18498]</li>

18499<li>

18500Exposure to cisplatin combined with carboplatin.[<a href="#cit/section_11.9">

185019</a>

18502]</li>

18503<li>

18504CNS tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_11.8">

185058</a>

18506]</li>

18507<li>

18508Cranial radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.7">

185097</a>

18510,<a href="#cit/section_11.8">

185118</a>

18512]</li>

18513<li>

18514Neurosurgery.</li>

18515</ul>

18516</div>

18517<section id="_1061">

18518<h4 id="_1061_toc">

18519Hearing loss and platinum-based therapy</h4>

18520<div class="pdq-content-list">

18521<ul id="_2643">

18522<li>

18523Platinum-related sensorineural hearing loss develops as an acute toxicity that is generally irreversible and bilateral.[<a href="#cit/section_11.10">

1852410</a>

18525]</li>

18526<li>

18527 The prevalence of hearing loss has varied widely per series and is based on platinum treatment (e.g., platinum type, dose, infusion duration); host factors (e.g., age, genetic susceptibility, renal function); receipt of additional ototoxic therapy (cranial radiation therapy, aminoglycosides, loop diuretics), and the grading criteria used to report prevalence and severity of hearing loss.[<a href="#cit/section_11.9">

185289</a>

18529,<a href="#cit/section_11.10">

1853010</a>

18531]</li>

18532<li>

18533 Hearing loss manifests initially in the high frequencies and progresses to the speech frequencies with increasing cumulative exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_11.10">

1853410</a>

18535]</li>

18536<li>

18537Cisplatin-induced hearing loss involving the speech frequencies (500&#8211;2,000 Hz) usually occurs with cumulative doses that exceed 400 mg/m<span class="sup">

185382</span>

18539 in pediatric patients.[<a href="#cit/section_11.11">

1854011</a>

18541,<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

1854212</a>

18543]</li>

18544<li>

18545 Prolonging the duration of infusion or splitting the dose has been reported to reduce the risk of significant hearing loss.[<a href="#cit/section_11.13">

1854613</a>

18547]</li>

18548<li>

18549In a randomized trial that compared cisplatin alone with cisplatin plus delayed administration of sodium thiosulfate, the administration of sodium thiosulfate 6 hours after cisplatin chemotherapy resulted in a 48% lower incidence of cisplatin-induced hearing loss among children with standard-risk hepatoblastoma and did not jeopardize overall survival or event-free survival.[<a href="#cit/section_11.14">

1855014</a>

18551]</li>

18552<li>

18553 Otologic toxic effects after platinum chemotherapy have been reported to worsen years after completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.15">

1855415</a>

18555]</li>

18556<li>

18557Radiation therapy to the posterior fossa inclusive of the eighth cranial nerve (suggestive of damage to the cochlea at the end of therapy) increases the risk of late-onset hearing loss in survivors treated with cisplatin.[<a href="#cit/section_11.16">

1855816</a>

18559]</li>

18560<li>

18561Carboplatin used in conventional (nonmyeloablative) dosing is typically not ototoxic.[<a href="#cit/section_11.17">

1856217</a>

18563] However, delayed-onset hearing loss has been reported in the following populations:<div class="pdq-content-list">

18564<ul id="_2644" class="list-dash">

18565<li>

18566In a cross-sectional, multicenter analysis that included 451 Dutch childhood cancer survivors who received platinum agents but not cranial radiation therapy, the incidence of ototoxicity (defined as M&#252;nster grade &gt;2b [&gt;20 dB at &#8805;4&#8211;8kHz]) associated with the use of carboplatin alone (n = 112) was 17%.[<a href="#cit/section_11.9">

185679</a>

18568]</li>

18569<li>

18570A single study of otologic toxic effects after non&#8211;stem cell transplant dosing of carboplatin for retinoblastoma reported that 8 of 175 children developed hearing loss. For seven of the eight children, the onset of the otologic toxic effects was delayed a median of 3.7 years.[<a href="#cit/section_11.18">

1857118</a>

18572]</li>

18573<li>

18574Another study that evaluated audiological outcomes among 60 retinoblastoma survivors treated with nonmyeloablative systemic carboplatin and vincristine estimated a cumulative incidence of hearing loss of 20.3% at 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_11.19">

1857519</a>

18576]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18577<ul id="_2645">

18578<li>

18579 Among the ten patients (17%) who developed sustained grade 3 or grade 4 hearing loss, nine were younger than 6 months at the start of chemotherapy. </li>

18580<li>

18581Younger age at the start of treatment was the only significant predictor of hearing loss; the cumulative incidence of hearing loss was 39% for patients younger than 6 months versus only 8.3% for patients aged 6 months and older.</li>

18582</ul>

18583</div>

18584</li>

18585</ul>

18586</div>

18587</li>

18588<li>

18589The use of a carboplatin conditioning regimen for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, particularly in combination with previous carboplatin or cisplatin therapy, may cause significant otologic toxic effects.[<a href="#cit/section_11.11">

1859011</a>

18591,<a href="#cit/section_11.12">

1859212</a>

18593]</li>

18594</ul>

18595</div>

18596</section>

18597<section id="_1064">

18598<h4 id="_1064_toc">

18599Hearing loss and cranial radiation therapy</h4>

18600<div class="pdq-content-list">

18601<ul id="_2646">

18602<li>

18603Cranial radiation therapy, when used as a single modality, may result in otologic toxic effects that may be gradual in onset, manifesting months to years after exposure. The <em>

18604threshold dose</em>

18605 for auditory toxicity after radiation therapy alone is in the range of 35 Gy to 45 Gy for children.[<a href="#cit/section_11.20">

1860620</a>

18607]</li>

18608<li>

18609 High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss is uncommon at cumulative radiation doses below 35 Gy, and is rarely severe below doses of 45 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.21">

1861021</a>

18611] The exception is for patients with supratentorial tumors and ventriculoperitoneal shunts, in whom doses below 30 Gy may be associated with intermediate frequency (1,000&#8211;2,000 Hz) hearing loss.[<a href="#cit/section_11.20">

1861220</a>

18613,<a href="#cit/section_11.22">

1861422</a>

18615]</li>

18616<li>

18617 To reduce the risk of hearing loss, the average cochlear dose should not exceed 30 Gy to 35 Gy, delivered over 6 weeks.</li>

18618<li>

18619 Young patient age and presence of a brain tumor and/or hydrocephalus can increase susceptibility to hearing loss.</li>

18620<li>

18621Sensorineural hearing loss after cranial radiation therapy can progress over time.<div class="pdq-content-list">

18622<ul id="_2647" class="list-dash">

18623<li>

18624In a study of 235 pediatric brain tumor patients treated with conformal or intensity-modulated radiation therapy (without cisplatin or preexisting hearing loss) and monitored for a median of 9 years, sensorineural hearing loss was prevalent in 14% of patients, with a median time to onset of 3.6 years from radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.23">

1862523</a>

18626]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18627<ul id="_2648">

18628<li>

18629 Follow-up evaluations among 29 patients identified continued decline in hearing sensitivity.</li>

18630<li>

18631 Risk factors for cranial radiation&#8211;associated sensorineural hearing loss included younger age at initiation of radiation, higher cochlear radiation dose, and cerebrospinal fluid shunting.</li>

18632</ul>

18633</div>

18634</li>

18635</ul>

18636</div>

18637</li>

18638<li>

18639When used concomitantly with cisplatin, radiation therapy can substantially exacerbate the hearing loss associated with platinum chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.20">

1864020</a>

18641,<a href="#cit/section_11.24">

1864224</a>

18643-<a href="#cit/section_11.26">

1864426</a>

18645]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18646<ul id="_2649" class="list-dash">

18647<li>

18648 In a report from the CCSS, 5-year survivors were at increased risk of problems with hearing sounds (relative risk [RR], 2.3), tinnitus (RR, 1.7), hearing loss requiring an aid (RR, 4.4), and hearing loss in one or both ears not corrected by a hearing aid (RR, 5.2), compared with siblings. Temporal lobe irradiation (&gt;30 Gy) and posterior fossa irradiation (&gt;50 Gy but also 30&#8211;49.9 Gy) were associated with these adverse outcomes. Exposure to platinum was associated with an increased risk of problems with hearing sounds (RR, 2.1), tinnitus (RR, 2.8), and hearing loss requiring an aid (RR, 4.1).[<a href="#cit/section_11.6">

186496</a>

18650]</li>

18651</ul>

18652</div>

18653</li>

18654<li>

18655Another CCSS study evaluated clinical and genetic risk factors for hearing loss and tinnitus among adult survivors of pediatric cancer who were treated with cranial radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.27">

1865627</a>

18657]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18658<ul id="_2926">

18659<li>

18660Males were more likely than females to report cranial radiation therapy&#8211;related tinnitus (9.4% vs. 5.4%) and hearing loss (14.0% vs. 10.7%).</li>

18661<li>

18662Survivors with tinnitus or hearing loss were more likely than controls to experience persistent dizziness or vertigo, take antidepressants, and report poorer overall health.</li>

18663<li>

18664A genome-wide association study identified a single-nucleotide polymorphism on chromosome 6 as nearly genome-wide significant for association with cranial radiation therapy&#8211;related hearing loss. A replication analysis in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort Study supported its significant association with cranial radiation therapy&#8211;related and de novo hearing loss.</li>

18665</ul>

18666</div>

18667</li>

18668</ul>

18669</div>

18670</section>

18671<section id="_1793">

18672<h4 id="_1793_toc">

18673Hearing loss and quality of life</h4>

18674<p id="_1794" tabindex="-1">

18675Importantly, children treated for malignancies may be at risk of early- or delayed-onset hearing loss that can affect learning, communication, school performance, social interaction, and overall quality of life.</p>

18676<div class="pdq-content-list">

18677<ul id="_1795">

18678<li>

18679Among 137 child survivors of neuroblastoma (aged 8&#8211;17 years), hearing loss was associated with problems with reading and math skills, as well as higher risk of learning disability and/or special education needs. In addition, hearing loss was associated with poorer school-related quality of life.[<a href="#cit/section_11.28">

1868028</a>

18681]</li>

18682<li>

18683Serial neurocognitive and audiology evaluations were performed on 260 children and young adults with embryonal brain tumors who were enrolled on a treatment protocol that consisted of surgery, risk-adapted cranial spinal irradiation, and chemotherapy. The 64 children with severe sensorineural hearing loss exhibited greater reading difficulties over time compared with the group of children with normal or mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss. Specifically, these children with severe sensorineural hearing loss seemed to struggle most with phonological skills and processing speed, which affect higher level skills such as reading comprehension.[<a href="#cit/section_11.29">

1868429</a>

18685]</li>

18686<li>

18687In a study of adult survivors of pediatric CNS tumors (n = 180) and non-CNS solid tumors (n = 226) who were treated with potentially ototoxic cancer therapy, serious hearing loss (requiring aid or resulting in deafness) was associated with a twofold increased risk of dependent living and unemployment or not graduating from high school.[<a href="#cit/section_11.30">

1868830</a>

18689] </li>

18690</ul>

18691</div>

18692<p id="_1716" tabindex="-1">

18693The Children&#8217;s Oncology Group has published recommendations for the evaluation and management of hearing loss in survivors of childhood and adolescent cancers to promote early identification of at-risk survivors and timely referral for remedial services.[<a href="#cit/section_11.31">

1869431</a>

18695]</p>

18696</section>

18697<p id="_1731" tabindex="-1">

18698<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_314">

18699Table 19</a>

18700 summarizes auditory late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

18701<table id="_314" class="table-default expandable-container">

18702<caption>

18703Table 19. Auditory Late Effects<span class="sup">

18704a</span>

18705</caption>

18706<colgroup>

18707<col width="33.33%">

18708<col width="33.33%">

18709<col width="33.33%">

18710</colgroup>

18711<THead>

18712<tr>

18713<th>

18714Predisposing Therapy</th>

18715<th>

18716Potential Auditory Effects</th>

18717<th>

18718Health Screening/Interventions</th>

18719</tr>

18720</THead>

18721<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

18722<tr>

18723<td colspan="3">

18724FM = frequency modulated.</td>

18725</tr>

18726<tr>

18727<td colspan="3">

18728<span class="sup">

18729a</span>

18730Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

18731Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

18732.</td>

18733</tr>

18734</TFoot>

18735<tbody>

18736<tr>

18737<td rowspan="7">

18738Platinum agents (cisplatin, carboplatin); radiation exposing the ear</td>

18739<td rowspan="7">

18740Otologic toxic effects;

18741

18742sensorineural hearing loss; tinnitus;

18743vertigo; dehydrated ceruminosis; conductive hearing loss

18744</td>

18746History: hearing difficulties, tinnitus, vertigo</td>

18747</tr>

18748<tr>

18749<td>

18750Otoscopic exam </td>

18751</tr>

18752<tr>

18753<td>

18754Audiology evaluation </td>

18755</tr>

18756<tr>

18757<td>

18758Amplification in patients with progressive hearing loss</td>

18759</tr>

18760<tr>

18761<td>

18762Speech and language therapy for children with hearing loss</td>

18763</tr>

18764<tr>

18765<td>

18766Otolaryngology consultation in patients with chronic infection, cerumen impaction, or other anatomical problems exacerbating or contributing to hearing loss</td>

18767</tr>

18768<tr>

18769<td>

18770Educational accommodations (e.g., preferential classroom seating, FM amplification system, etc.)</td>

18771</tr>

18772</tbody>

18773</table>

18774</section>

18775<section id="_24">

18776<h3 id="_24_toc">

18777Orbital and Optic</h3>

18778<p id="_25" tabindex="-1">

18779Orbital complications are common after radiation therapy for retinoblastoma, head and neck sarcomas, CNS tumors, and after total-body irradiation (TBI).</p>

18780<section id="_1066">

18781<h4 id="_1066_toc">

18782Retinoblastoma</h4>

18783<div class="pdq-content-list">

18784<ul id="_2650">

18785<li>

18786For survivors of retinoblastoma, a small orbital volume may result from either enucleation or radiation therapy.</li>

18787<li>

18788 Age younger than 1 year may increase the risk of orbital complications, but this finding is not consistent across studies.[<a href="#cit/section_11.32">

1878932</a>

18790,<a href="#cit/section_11.33">

1879133</a>

18792]</li>

18793<li>

18794Progress has been made in the management of retinoblastoma, with better enucleation implants, intravenous chemoreduction, and intra-arterial chemotherapy in addition to thermotherapy, cryotherapy, and plaque radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.34">

1879534</a>

18796,<a href="#cit/section_11.35">

1879735</a>

18798]</li>

18799<li>

18800 Longer follow-up is needed to assess the impact on vision in patients undergoing these more contemporary treatment modalities.[<a href="#cit/section_11.32">

1880132</a>

18802,<a href="#cit/section_11.34">

1880334</a>

18804,<a href="#cit/section_11.35">

1880535</a>

18806]</li>

18807<li>

18808Previously, tumors located near the macula and fovea were associated with an increased risk of complications leading to vision loss, although treatment of these tumors with foveal laser ablation has shown promise in preserving vision.[<a href="#cit/section_11.36">

1880936</a>

18810,<a href="#cit/section_11.37">

1881137</a>

18812]</li>

18813<li>

18814In a study of 61 patients (94 eyes) with a mean follow-up of 51.8 months, a mean lens dose of 7 Gy was associated with a 5-year incidence of cataracts of 20% to 25%.[<a href="#cit/section_11.38">

1881538</a>

18816]</li>

18817<li>

18818In a study of 64 eyes from 42 patients (22 bilateral cases) with salvaged retinoblastoma, after a mean follow-up of 8 years, strabismus was found to be a very common adverse sequela, with 69% of patients having some type of deviation.

18819Exotropia (43%) was more common. Foveal tumor at presentation was found to be the only significant risk factor.[<a href="#cit/section_11.39">

1882039</a>

18821]</li>

18822<li>

18823A qualitative analysis of survey responses from 404 survivors of retinoblastoma (mean time since diagnosis, 42 years) who had undergone enucleation identified psychosocial effects related to physical and intrapersonal struggles with appearance and social and relational problems, particularly with teasing and bullying.[<a href="#cit/section_11.40">

1882440</a>

18825]</li>

18826</ul>

18827</div>

18828<p id="_1077" tabindex="-1">

18829For more information about the treatment of retinoblastoma, see <a href="/types/retinoblastoma/hp/retinoblastoma-treatment-pdq">

18830Retinoblastoma Treatment</a>

18831.</p>

18832</section>

18833<section id="_1067">

18834<h4 id="_1067_toc">

18835Rhabdomyosarcoma</h4>

18836<div class="pdq-content-list">

18837<ul id="_2651">

18838<li>

18839Survivors of orbital rhabdomyosarcoma are at risk of dry eye, cataract, orbital hypoplasia, ptosis, retinopathy, keratoconjunctivitis, optic neuropathy, lid epithelioma, and impairment of vision after radiation therapy doses of 30 Gy to 65 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.41">

1884041</a>

18841,<a href="#cit/section_11.42">

1884242</a>

18843]</li>

18844<li>

18845 The higher radiation therapy dose ranges (&gt;50 Gy) are associated with lid epitheliomas, keratoconjunctivitis, lacrimal duct atrophy, and severe dry eye.</li>

18846<li>

18847 Retinitis and optic neuropathy may also result from doses of 50 Gy to 65 Gy and even at lower total doses if the individual fraction size is higher than 2 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.43">

1884843</a>

18849]</li>

18850<li>

18851 Cataracts are reported after lower doses of 10 Gy to 18 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_11.41">

1885241</a>

18853,<a href="#cit/section_11.42">

1885442</a>

18855,<a href="#cit/section_11.44">

1885644</a>

18857]</li>

18858</ul>

18859</div>

18860<p id="_1068" tabindex="-1">

18861For more information about the treatment of rhabdomyosarcoma in children, see <a href="/types/soft-tissue-sarcoma/hp/rhabdomyosarcoma-treatment-pdq">

18862Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma Treatment</a>

18863.</p>

18864</section>

18865<section id="_1069">

18866<h4 id="_1069_toc">

18867Low-grade optic pathway glioma</h4>

18868<p id="_1070" tabindex="-1">

18869Survivors of optic pathway gliomas are also at risk of visual complications, resulting in part from tumor proximity to the optic nerve. </p>

18870<div class="pdq-content-list">

18871<ul id="_2652">

18872<li>

18873In a retrospective cohort study of 59 pediatric patients with sporadic optic pathway gliomas diagnosed between 1990 and 2014 (median follow-up, 5.2 years), there was a significant burden of long-term visual impairment.[<a href="#cit/section_11.45">

1887445</a>

18875]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18876<ul id="_2653" class="list-dash">

18877<li>

18878 More than two-thirds of the patients had evidence of long-term vision loss, more than one-half had severe vision loss in at least one eye, and one-quarter of the patients had severe bilateral vision loss.</li>

18879<li>

18880 Identified risk factors for poor visual outcome were postchiasmal involvement, younger age, and optic nerve pallor at presentation.</li>

18881</ul>

18882</div>

18883</li>

18884<li>

18885Longitudinal follow-up (mean, 9 years) of 21 patients with optic pathway gliomas indicated that before treatment, 81% of patients had reduced visual acuity, 81% had optic nerve pallor, and all had reduced visual evoked potentials in one or both eyes.[<a href="#cit/section_11.46">

1888646</a>

18887]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18888<ul id="_2654" class="list-dash">

18889<li>

18890 Treatment arrested acuity loss for 4 to 5 years.</li>

18891<li>

18892 Visual acuity was stable or improved in 33% of patients at last follow-up; however, it declined on average. Visual acuity at follow-up was related to tumor volume at initial presentation.</li>

18893</ul>

18894</div>

18895</li>

18896<li>

18897In a study of 51 children with low-grade gliomas and low-grade glioneural tumors diagnosed within the first year of life, visual acuity was decreased in 27 of 48 patients (56%), 13 (27%) of whom were legally blind. The tumor location (hypothalamic or optic pathway) was significantly associated with decreased visual acuity (<em>

18898P</em>

18899 = .002).[<a href="#cit/section_11.47">

1890047</a>

18901]</li>

18902<li>

18903CCSS investigators evaluated the impact of impaired vision on cognitive and psychosocial outcomes among 1,233 adult survivors of childhood low-grade gliomas.[<a href="#cit/section_11.48">

1890448</a>

18905]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18906<ul id="_2655" class="list-dash">

18907<li>

18908 Some degree of visual impairment was prevalent in 22.5% of patients, and 3.8% of patients were blind in both eyes. </li>

18909<li>

18910Survivors who were blind in both eyes were more likely to be unmarried, live dependently, and be unemployed than were survivors with unimpaired vision.</li>

18911<li>

18912Bilateral blindness did not impact self-reported cognitive or emotional outcomes. Impaired (with some remaining) vision was not associated with psychological or economic outcomes.</li>

18913</ul>

18914</div>

18915</li>

18916</ul>

18917</div>

18918</section>

18919<section id="_1073">

18920<h4 id="_1073_toc">

18921Treatment-specific effects</h4>

18922<p id="_311" tabindex="-1">

18923Survivors of childhood cancer are at increased risk of ocular late effects related to both glucocorticoid and radiation exposure to the eye.</p>

18924<p id="_1796" tabindex="-1">

18925Evidence (cataract development from radiation exposure):</p>

18926<div class="pdq-content-list">

18927<ol id="_1797">

18928<li>

18929The CCSS reported that survivors who were 5 or more years from diagnosis were at increased risk of developing cataracts (RR, 10.8), glaucoma (RR, 2.5), legal blindness (RR, 2.6), double vision (RR, 4.1), and dry eye (RR, 1.9), compared with siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_11.49">

1893049</a>

18931]</li>

18932<li>

18933The 15-year cumulative incidence of cataract was 4.5% among 517 survivors of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (median, 10.9 years from diagnosis), systematically evaluated by slit lamp examination. CNS radiation therapy was the only treatment-related risk factor identified for cataract development, which occurred in 11.1% of irradiated survivors, compared with 2.8% of those who were not irradiated.[<a href="#cit/section_11.50">

1893450</a>

18935]</li>

18936<li>

18937A report from the CCSS provides additional data on the interval from radiation therapy and the radiation dose associated with the development of cataracts.[<a href="#cit/section_11.51">

1893851</a>

18939]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18940<ul id="_1799">

18941<li>

18942 Among 13,902 study participants, 3.5% developed cataracts (41% within 5 years of radiation therapy), with a median time to onset of 9.6 years and a maximum time of 37 years. Lens radiation doses were associated with an increased prevalence: 1.3% if less than 0.5 Gy, 6.1% after 2.5 to 3.49 Gy, and 40.6% after 20 to 60 Gy.</li>

18943<li>

18944Higher doses were associated with a shorter time interval to diagnosis.</li>

18945<li>

18946Of the group with cataracts, 31% reported having cataract surgery, supporting the clinical consequences.</li>

18947<li>

18948Cytosine arabinoside (odds ratio [OR], 1.5) and doxorubicin (OR, 1.5) were independently associated with cataract development, methotrexate was inversely associated (OR, 0.6), and no positive interaction between the use of corticosteroids and radiation therapy was observed.</li>

18949</ul>

18950</div>

18951</li>

18952</ol>

18953</div>

18954<p id="_2875" tabindex="-1">

18955Visual acuity decline is rare after radiation therapy for intracranial malignancies in children.</p>

18956<p id="_2874" tabindex="-1">

18957Evidence (visual acuity decline from radiation exposure):</p>

18958<div class="pdq-content-list">

18959<ol id="_2876">

18960<li>

18961A retrospective study of 458 children (875 at-risk eyes) treated with proton therapy for intracranial malignancy assessed radiation therapy&#8211;related visual decline. Eyes were considered at risk if either the ipsilateral optic nerve or optic chiasm received 30 GyRBE or higher to 0.1 cm<span class="sup">

189623</span>

18963.[<a href="#cit/section_11.52">

1896452</a>

18965]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18966<ul id="_2877">

18967<li>

18968No patients experienced complete vision loss.</li>

18969<li>

18970The actuarial 5-year rate of visual acuity decline was 2.6%.</li>

18971<li>

18972Tumor location significantly correlated with risk. Investigators found that children with tumors of the suprasellar or the optic pathway region are at greatest risk. The reported risk was about 5% decline in visual acuity with a dose of 56 GyRBE to the optic nerve or optic pathway. </li>

18973<li>

18974For children with tumors arising elsewhere in the brain, no toxicity was observed.</li>

18975</ul>

18976</div>

18977</li>

18978</ol>

18979</div>

18980<p id="_28" tabindex="-1">

18981Ocular complications, such as cataracts and dry eye syndrome, are common after stem cell transplantation in childhood. </p>

18982<p id="_1800" tabindex="-1">

18983Evidence (ocular effects of stem cell transplantation):</p>

18984<div class="pdq-content-list">

18985<ol id="_1801">

18986<li>

18987A St. Jude Children's Research Hospital investigation evaluated ocular complications in school-aged children and adolescents who survived at least 1 year following allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation. Among 162 patients (mean age at transplantation, 13.4 years; mean follow-up, 4 years), the following was reported:[<a href="#cit/section_11.53">

1898853</a>

18989]<div class="pdq-content-list">

18990<ul id="_2727">

18991<li>

18992Cataract formation was noted in 57 patients (35%) and dry eye was noted in 51 patients (31%).</li>

18993<li>

18994Multivariate analysis of significant variables showed that TBI was a risk factor for cataract formation, and chronic GVHD was a significant risk factor for dry eye syndrome.</li>

18995</ul>

18996</div>

18997 </li>

18998<li>

18999Compared with patients treated with busulfan or other chemotherapy, patients treated with single-dose or fractionated TBI are at increased risk of cataracts. Risk ranges from approximately 10% to 60% at 10 years posttreatment, depending on the total dose and fractionation, with a shorter latency period and more severe cataracts noted after single fraction and higher dose or dose-rate TBI.[<a href="#cit/section_11.54">

1900054</a>

19001-<a href="#cit/section_11.57">

1900257</a>

19003]</li>

19004<li>

19005Patients receiving TBI doses of less than 40 Gy have a less than 10% chance of developing severe cataracts.[<a href="#cit/section_11.57">

1900657</a>

19007]</li>

19008<li>

19009Corticosteroids and graft-versus-host disease may further increase risk.[<a href="#cit/section_11.54">

1901054</a>

19011,<a href="#cit/section_11.58">

1901258</a>

19013]</li>

19014<li>

19015The prevalence of cataracts, evaluated by serial slit lamp testing, among 271 participants (mean follow-up, 10.3 years) in the Leuc&#233;mie de l'Enfant et de l'Adolescent (LEA) program was 41.7%, with 8.1% requiring surgical intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_11.59">

1901659</a>

19017]<div class="pdq-content-list">

19018<ul id="_2656">

19019<li>

19020The cumulative incidence of cataracts among those treated with TBI increased over time from 30% at 5 years to 70.8% at 15 years and 78% at 20 years.</li>

19021<li>

19022 The lack of a plateau in cataract incidence suggests that nearly all patients treated with TBI will develop cataracts as follow-up increases.</li>

19023<li>

19024 In contrast, the 15-year cumulative incidence of cataracts was 12.5% among those conditioned with busulfan.</li>

19025<li>

19026 Multivariable analysis identified high cumulative steroid dose as a potential cofactor with TBI for cataract risk.</li>

19027</ul>

19028</div>

19029</li>

19030<li>

19031Dry eye syndrome has been shown to be more common if the patient was exposed to repeated high trough levels of cyclosporine.[<a href="#cit/section_11.60">

1903260</a>

19033]</li>

19034</ol>

19035</div>

19036</section>

19037<p id="_1732" tabindex="-1">

19038<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_313">

19039Table 20</a>

19040 summarizes ocular late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

19041<table id="_313" class="table-default expandable-container">

19042<caption>

19043Table 20. Ocular Late Effects<span class="sup">

19044a</span>

19045</caption>

19046<colgroup>

19047<col width="33.33%">

19048<col width="33.33%">

19049<col width="33.33%">

19050</colgroup>

19051<THead>

19052<tr>

19053<th>

19054Predisposing Therapy</th>

19055<th>

19056Ocular/Vision Effects</th>

19057<th>

19058Health Screening/Interventions</th>

19059</tr>

19060</THead>

19061<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

19062<tr>

19063<td colspan="3">

19064GVHD = graft-versus-host disease; 131I = iodine I 131.</td>

19065</tr>

19066<tr>

19067<td colspan="3">

19068<span class="sup">

19069a</span>

19070Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

19071Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

19072.</td>

19073</tr>

19074</TFoot>

19075<tbody>

19076<tr>

19077<td rowspan="3">

19078Busulfan;

19079

19080corticosteroids; radiation exposing the eye

19081</td>

19082<td rowspan="3">

19083Cataracts</td>

19084<td>

19085History: decreased acuity, halos, diplopia</td>

19086</tr>

19087<tr>

19088<td>

19089Eye exam: visual acuity, funduscopy (yearly)</td>

19090</tr>

19091<tr>

19092<td>

19093Ophthalmology consultation</td>

19094</tr>

19095<tr>

19096<td rowspan="3">

19097Radiation exposing the eye,

19098including radioiodine (131I)

19099</td>

19100<td rowspan="3">

19101Ocular toxicity (orbital hypoplasia, lacrimal duct atrophy, xerophthalmia [keratoconjunctivitis sicca], keratitis, telangiectasias, retinopathy, optic chiasm neuropathy, enophthalmos, chronic painful eye, maculopathy, papillopathy, glaucoma)</td>

19102<td>

19103History: visual changes (decreased acuity, halos, diplopia), dry eye, persistent eye irritation, excessive tearing, light sensitivity, poor night vision, painful eye</td>

19104</tr>

19105<tr>

19106<td>

19107Eye exam: visual acuity, funduscopy (yearly)</td>

19108</tr>

19109<tr>

19110<td>

19111Ophthalmology consultation</td>

19112</tr>

19113<tr>

19114<td rowspan="2">

19115Hematopoietic cell transplantation with any history of chronic GVHD</td>

19116<td rowspan="2">

19117Xerophthalmia

19118(keratoconjunctivitis sicca)

19119</td>

19120<td>

19121History: dry eye (burning, itching, foreign body sensation, inflammation)</td>

19122</tr>

19123<tr>

19124<td>

19125Eye exam: visual acuity, funduscopy (yearly)</td>

19126</tr>

19127<tr>

19128<td rowspan="2">

19129Enucleation</td>

19130<td rowspan="2">

19131Impaired cosmesis;

19132poor prosthetic fit; orbital hypoplasia

19133</td>

19134<td>

19135Ocular prosthetic evaluation</td>

19136</tr>

19137<tr>

19138<td>

19139Ophthalmology</td>

19140</tr>

19141</tbody>

19142</table>

19143</section>

19144<p id="_444" tabindex="-1">

19145For information on the late effects of special senses, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

19146Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

19147.</p>

Ophthalmology 117 (8): 1623-9, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20381868&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20381868&amp;dopt=Abstract">

19289[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

19290</li>
