19390</li>

19391</ol>

19392</div>

19393

19394 </section>

19395

19396

19397

19398 <section id="_59">

19399

19400 <h2>

19401Late Effects of the Urinary System</h2>

19402

19403 <div id="_section_59" class="pdq-sections">

19404<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

19405<h6>

19406In This Section</h6>

19407<ul>

19408<li>

19409<a href="#_1225_toc">

19410Therapy-Related Factors Affecting the Kidney<ul>

19411<li>

19412<a href="#_2658_toc">

19413Nephrectomy</a>

19414</li>

19415<li>

19416<a href="#_2660_toc">

19417Chemotherapy</a>

19418</li>

19419<li>

19420<a href="#_2673_toc">

19421Radiation therapy</a>

19422</li>

19423</ul>

19424</a>

19425</li>

19426<li>

19427<a href="#_2681_toc">

19428Renal Function in Adults Treated for Nonsyndromic Wilms Tumor</a>

19429</li>

19430<li>

19431<a href="#_1229_toc">

19432Genetic Factors Predisposing to Renal Dysfunction</a>

19433</li>

19434<li>

19435<a href="#_1232_toc">

19436Therapy-Related Bladder Complications<ul>

19437<li>

19438<a href="#_2685_toc">

19439Chemotherapy</a>

19440</li>

19441<li>

19442<a href="#_2688_toc">

19443Radiation therapy</a>

19444</li>

19445<li>

19446<a href="#_2690_toc">

19447Surgery</a>

19448</li>

19449</ul>

19450</a>

19451</li>

19452<li>

19453<a href="#_2163_toc">

19454Kidney Transplant</a>

19455</li>

19456</ul>

19457</nav>

19458<p id="_1191" tabindex="-1">

19459Acute toxicity of the urinary system from cancer therapy is well known. Less is known about the genitourinary outcomes in long-term survivors.[<a href="#cit/section_12.1">

194601</a>

19461] The evidence for long-term renal injury in childhood cancer survivors is limited by studies characterized by small sample size, cohort selection and participation bias, cross-sectional assessment, heterogeneity in time since treatment, and method of ascertainment. In particular, the inaccuracies of diagnosing chronic kidney dysfunction by estimating equations of glomerular dysfunction should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_12.2">

194622</a>

19463]</p>

19464<p id="_2657" tabindex="-1">

19465 Cancer treatments predisposing to renal injury and/or high blood pressure later in life include the following:</p>

19466<div class="pdq-content-list">

19467<ul id="_1940">

19468<li>

19469Chemotherapeutic drugs (cisplatin, carboplatin, ifosfamide, methotrexate).</li>

19470<li>

19471Renal radiation therapy.</li>

19472<li>

19473Nephrectomy.</li>

19474</ul>

19475</div>

19476<p id="_1941" tabindex="-1">

19477The risk and degree of renal dysfunction depend on type and intensity of therapy, and the interpretation of the studies is compromised by variability in testing.</p>

19478<p id="_2902" tabindex="-1">

19479The incidence of and risk factors for late-onset kidney failure among long-term survivors of childhood cancer has not been well studied. </p>

19480<p id="_2933" tabindex="-1">

19481Among 25,530 CCSS participants (median follow-up, 22.3 years), the 35-year cumulative incidence of self-reported late-onset kidney failure&#8212;defined as dialysis, renal transplant, or death attributable to kidney disease&#8212;was 1.7% (compared with 0.2% in the sibling cohort).[<a href="#cit/section_12.3">

194823</a>

19483]</p>

19484<div class="pdq-content-list">

19485<ul id="_2903">

19486<li>

19487Independent treatment risk factors for late-onset kidney failure included high-dose (&gt;15 Gy) radiation exposing the kidney (RR, 4.0), high-dose (&gt;250 mg/m<span class="sup">

194882</span>

19489) anthracycline (RR, 1.6), any ifosfamide dose (RR, 2.6), and nephrectomy (RR, 1.9).</li>

19490<li>

19491Modifiable risk factors associated with late-onset kidney failure included hypertension (RR, 14.4 with history of nephrectomy; RR, 5.9 without history of nephrectomy) and diabetes (RR, 2.2). </li>

19492</ul>

19493</div>

19494<p id="_1223" tabindex="-1">

19495Few large-scale studies have evaluated late renal-health outcomes and risk factors for renal dysfunction among survivors treated with potentially nephrotoxic modalities. </p>

19496<p id="_1942" tabindex="-1">

19497Evidence (renal dysfunction in childhood cancer survivors):</p>

19498<div class="pdq-content-list">

19499<ol id="_1943">

19500<li>

19501In a large, cross-sectional study of 1,442 childhood cancer survivors (median attained age, 19.3 years; median time from diagnosis, 12.1 years), Dutch investigators assessed the presence of albuminuria, hypomagnesemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypertension, and they estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) among survivors treated with ifosfamide, cisplatin, carboplatin, high-dose cyclophosphamide (&gt;1 g/m<span class="sup">

195022</span>

19503 or more per course), or high-dose methotrexate (&gt;1 g/m<span class="sup">

195042</span>

19505 or more per course), radiation therapy to the kidney region, total-body irradiation (TBI), or nephrectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.4">

195064</a>

19507]<div class="pdq-content-list">

19508<ul id="_1944">

19509<li>

19510 At least one abnormality of renal function or hypertension was detected in 28.1% of survivors.</li>

19511<li>

19512History of nephrectomy (odds ratio [OR], 8.6; 95% confidence interval [CI], 3.4&#8211;21.4) had the strongest association with a GFR of less than 90 mL/min per 1.73 m<span class="sup">

195132</span>

19514.</li>

19515<li>

19516The prevalence of decreased GFR was highest among those treated with multimodality therapy including nephrectomy, nephrotoxic chemotherapy, and abdominal radiation therapy. Nearly 5% of these survivors had a GFR of less than 90 mL/min per 1.73 m<span class="sup">

195172</span>

19518.</li>

19519<li>

19520Abdominal irradiation was the only significant treatment-related risk factor for hypertension (OR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;4.5).</li>

19521</ul>

19522</div>

19523</li>

19524</ol>

19525</div>

19526<section id="_1225">

19527<h3 id="_1225_toc">

19528Therapy-Related Factors Affecting the Kidney</h3>

19529<p id="_1226" tabindex="-1">

19530Cancer treatments predisposing to late renal injury and hypertension include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_12.5">

195315</a>

19532-<a href="#cit/section_12.7">

195337</a>

19534]</p>

19535<section id="_2658">

19536<h4 id="_2658_toc">

19537Nephrectomy</h4>

19538<div class="pdq-content-list">

19539<ul id="_2659">

19540<li>

19541Survivors of childhood cancer who have undergone nephrectomy are at risk of hyperfiltration injury.</li>

19542<li>

19543Compensatory hypertrophy of the remaining kidney typically occurs after nephrectomy, but over time, renal injury may manifest as reduced glomerular filtration, microalbuminuria and proteinuria, hypertension, and, rarely, focal glomerulosclerosis leading to chronic renal failure.[<a href="#cit/section_12.4">

195444</a>

19545,<a href="#cit/section_12.6">

195466</a>

19547]</li>

19548<li>

19549 Patients with nonsyndromic unilateral Wilms tumor treated with unilateral radical nephrectomy without nephrotoxic chemotherapy or ionizing radiation therapy appear to be at low risk of developing significant long-term renal dysfunction.[<a href="#cit/section_12.8">

195508</a>

19551]</li>

19552<li>

19553A meta-analysis examined data from 23 studies of patients with Wilms tumor (293 unilateral cases and 386 bilateral cases). The study demonstrated significantly increased odds of developing abnormal kidney function (OR, 4.29; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;18.00) and having a lower estimated glomerular filtration rate (mean, -8.99) among patients treated with radical nephrectomy, compared with those treated with nephron-sparing surgery. Patients with bilateral Wilms tumor (mean follow-up, 7.7 years) treated with radical nephrectomy and contralateral nephron-sparing surgery had higher odds of developing abnormal kidney function (OR, 3.82; 95% CI, 1.76&#8211;8.33) and hypertension (OR, 5.81; 95% CI, 1.31&#8211;25.86), compared with those treated with bilateral nephron-sparing surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_12.9">

195549</a>

19555]</li>

19556</ul>

19557</div>

19558</section>

19559<section id="_2660">

19560<h4 id="_2660_toc">

19561Chemotherapy</h4>

19562<section id="_2661">

19563<h5 id="_2661_toc">

19564Cisplatin</h5>

19565<p id="_2662" tabindex="-1">

19566Cisplatin can cause glomerular and tubular damage, resulting in a diminished GFR and electrolyte wasting (particularly magnesium, calcium, and potassium).[<a href="#cit/section_12.10">

1956710</a>

19568-<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1956912</a>

19570]</p>

19571<div class="pdq-content-list">

19572<ul id="_2663">

19573<li>

19574Acute cisplatin-related nephrotoxicity has been reported in 30% to 100% of exposed children.[<a href="#cit/section_12.13">

1957513</a>

19576] However, the prevalence of persistent renal dysfunction in long-term survivors appears to be considerably lower. </li>

19577<li>

19578Among 63 children treated with platinum agents, GFR was less than 60 mL/min per 1.73 m<span class="sup">

195792</span>

19580 in 11% of children, and hypomagnesemia requiring oral supplements occurred in 7% of children at 10 years from completion of therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1958112</a>

19582]</li>

19583<li>

19584 Among 651 sarcoma patients evaluated after cessation of antineoplastic therapy (median follow-up, 2 years), hypomagnesemia occurred in 12.1% of patients after cisplatin therapy and in 15.6% after carboplatin therapy, compared with 4.5% who did not receive any platinum derivatives.[<a href="#cit/section_12.14">

1958514</a>

19586]</li>

19587<li>

19588 In all groups, the frequency of hypomagnesemia decreased with ongoing follow-up, but serum magnesium remained lower in platinum-treated patients throughout the study period.[<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1958912</a>

19590,<a href="#cit/section_12.14">

1959114</a>

19592]</li>

19593</ul>

19594</div>

19595</section>

19596<section id="_2664">

19597<h5 id="_2664_toc">

19598Carboplatin</h5>

19599<p id="_2665" tabindex="-1">

19600Carboplatin is a cisplatin analogue and is less nephrotoxic than cisplatin.</p>

19601<div class="pdq-content-list">

19602<ul id="_2666">

19603<li>

19604 In a prospective, longitudinal, single-center, cohort study of children monitored for more than 10 years after cisplatin or carboplatin therapy, older age at treatment was found to be the major risk factor for nephrotoxicity, especially for patients who received carboplatin, while cisplatin dose schedule and cumulative carboplatin dose were also important predictors of toxicity. Platinum nephrotoxicity did not change significantly over 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1960512</a>

19606]</li>

19607<li>

19608The combination of carboplatin and ifosfamide may be associated with more renal damage than the combination of cisplatin and ifosfamide.[<a href="#cit/section_12.10">

1960910</a>

19610-<a href="#cit/section_12.12">

1961112</a>

19612]</li>

19613<li>

19614 Additional follow-up in larger numbers of survivors treated with carboplatin (without other nephrotoxic agents and modalities) must be evaluated before potential renal toxicity can be better defined.</li>

19615</ul>

19616</div>

19617</section>

19618<section id="_2667">

19619<h5 id="_2667_toc">

19620Ifosfamide</h5>

19621<p id="_2668" tabindex="-1">

19622 Ifosfamide can also cause glomerular and tubular toxicity, with renal tubular acidosis and Fanconi syndrome, a proximal tubular defect characterized by impairment of resorption of glucose, amino acids, phosphate, and bicarbonate.</p>

19623<div class="pdq-content-list">

19624<ul id="_2669">

19625<li>

19626 Ifosfamide doses greater than 60 g/m<span class="sup">

196272</span>

19628, age younger than 5 years at treatment, and combination with cisplatin and carboplatin increase the risk of ifosfamide-associated renal tubular toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_12.15">

1962915</a>

19630-<a href="#cit/section_12.17">

1963117</a>

19632]</li>

19633<li>

19634 A French study that evaluated the prevalence of late renal toxicity after ifosfamide reported normal tubular function in 90% of pediatric cancer survivors (median follow-up, 10 years); 79% of the cancer survivors had normal GFR, and all survivors had normal serum bicarbonate and calcium.[<a href="#cit/section_12.17">

1963517</a>

19636]<div class="pdq-content-list">

19637<ul id="_2670" class="list-dash">

19638<li>

19639 Hypomagnesemia and hypophosphatemia were seen in 1% of cancer survivors. Glycosuria was detected in 37% of cancer survivors but was mild in 95% of cases.</li>

19640<li>

19641 Proteinuria was observed in 12% of cancer survivors. In multivariate analysis, ifosfamide dose and interval from therapy were predictors of tubulopathy, and older age at diagnosis and interval from therapy were predictors of abnormal GFR.</li>

19642</ul>

19643</div>

19644</li>

19645</ul>

19646</div>

19647</section>

19648<section id="_2671">

19649<h5 id="_2671_toc">

19650Methotrexate</h5>

19651<p id="_2672" tabindex="-1">

19652 High-dose methotrexate (1,000&#8211;33,000

19653mg/m<span class="sup">

196542</span>

19655) has been reported to cause acute renal dysfunction in up to 12.4% of patients. Long-term renal sequelae have not been described.[<a href="#cit/section_12.6">

196566</a>

19657,<a href="#cit/section_12.18">

1965818</a>

19659]</p>

19660</section>

19661</section>

19662<section id="_2673">

19663<h4 id="_2673_toc">

19664Radiation therapy</h4>

19665<p id="_2674" tabindex="-1">

19666Radiation therapy to the kidney can result in radiation nephritis or nephropathy after a latent period of 3 to 12 months. </p>

19667<div class="pdq-content-list">

19668<ul id="_2675">

19669<li>

19670The kidney is relatively radiosensitive, with a tolerance dose of 20 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.19">

1967119</a>

19672]</li>

19673<li>

19674 Doses of 18 Gy are considered unlikely to cause severe or chronic renal sequelae. In contrast, up to 50% of individuals treated with 20 Gy may develop glomerular dysfunction or hypertension within 20 years.[<a href="#cit/section_12.20">

1967520</a>

19676]</li>

19677<li>

19678 Specific quantitative data are sparse, but a study of 108 children treated for Wilms tumor who had undergone unilateral nephrectomy showed that 41% of children who received less than 12 Gy of radiation to the contralateral remaining kidney, 56% of children who received 12 Gy to 24 Gy, and 91% of children who received more than 24 Gy had a decreased creatinine clearance (GFR &lt;63 mL/min/m<span class="sup">

196792</span>

19680).[<a href="#cit/section_12.21">

1968121</a>

19682]</li>

19683<li>

19684 In a report from the German Registry for the Evaluation of Side Effects after Radiation in Childhood and Adolescence (RISK consortium), 126 patients who underwent radiation therapy to parts of the kidneys for various cancers were evaluated. All patients had also received potentially nephrotoxic chemotherapy. Whole-kidney volumes exposed to greater than 20 Gy (<em>

19685P</em>

19686 = .031) or 30 Gy (<em>

19687P</em>

19688 = .003) of radiation were associated with a greater risk of nephrotoxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_12.22">

1968922</a>

19690]</li>

19691<li>

19692Risk factors for radiation injury include the following:<div class="pdq-content-list">

19693<ul id="_2676" class="list-dash">

19694<li>

19695Age at time of radiation therapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

19696<ul id="_2677">

19697<li>

19698 Neonates appear to have an increased sensitivity to radiation therapy; doses of 12 Gy to 24 Gy at 1.25 Gy to 1.5 Gy per fraction to the entire kidney were associated with a decreased GFR.[<a href="#cit/section_12.23">

1969923</a>

19700]</li>

19701<li>

19702 However, for older children, there is no convincing evidence that age at the time of radiation therapy is related to renal injury.[<a href="#cit/section_12.23">

1970323</a>

19704]</li>

19705</ul>

19706</div>

19707</li>

19708<li>

19709Unilateral versus bilateral radiation therapy.<div class="pdq-content-list">

19710<ul id="_2678">

19711<li>

19712 In the National Wilms Tumor Study experience, renal failure was more common in children with bilateral tumors than in children with unilateral tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_12.24">

1971324</a>

19714]</li>

19715<li>

19716 The effects of radiation also depend on whether partial or whole-kidney radiation therapy is administered. Renal failure is rare after the administration of partial-volume radiation doses between 12 Gy and 27 Gy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.25">

1971725</a>

19718]</li>

19719<li>

19720 When certain agents such as cyclosporine and teniposide are not used, total-body irradiation doses of up to 13 Gy are associated with a less than 8% incidence of kidney toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_12.26">

1972126</a>

19722]</li>

19723</ul>

19724</div>

19725</li>

19726<li>

19727Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT).<div class="pdq-content-list">

19728<ul id="_2680">

19729<li>

19730Chronic kidney disease is a long-term complication of HSCT that has been variably associated with acute kidney injury, lower pretransplant renal function, TBI, conditioning regimens such as fludarabine, graft-versus-host disease, and use of calcineurin inhibitors.[<a href="#cit/section_12.27">

1973127</a>

19732-<a href="#cit/section_12.29">

1973329</a>

19734]</li>

19735<li>

19736Most reports of renal outcomes among long-term survivors of childhood cancer treated with HSCT are limited to descriptive outcomes of very small cohorts.</li>

19737<li>

19738For more information, see the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/hp-stem-cell-transplant/gvhd#_206">

19739Urinary System Late Effects</a>

19740 section in Complications, Graft-Versus-Host Disease, and Late Effects After Pediatric Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation.</li>

19741</ul>

19742</div>

19743</li>

19744</ul>

19745</div>

19746</li>

19747</ul>

19748</div>

19749</section>

19750</section>

19751<section id="_2681">

19752<h3 id="_2681_toc">

19753Renal Function in Adults Treated for Nonsyndromic Wilms Tumor</h3>

19754<div class="pdq-content-list">

19755<ul id="_2682">

19756<li>

19757St. Jude Lifetime Cohort investigators evaluated the impact of specific treatment modalities on long-term renal function and blood pressure among adult survivors of Wilms tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_12.30">

1975830</a>

19759]<div class="pdq-content-list">

19760<ul id="_2683" class="list-dash">

19761<li>

19762Among 40 survivors of unilateral nonsyndromic Wilms tumor, the prevalence of hypertension was significantly increased for unirradiated (25%) and irradiated (35%) survivors, compared with the prevalence in 35 noncancer controls (0%).</li>

19763<li>

19764No irradiated or unirradiated participant had an estimated GFR (creatinine + cystatin C) less than 60 mL/min/1.73 m<span class="sup">

197652</span>

19766. </li>

19767<li>

19768Chronic kidney disease was infrequent in long-term survivors of unilateral nonsyndromic Wilms tumor, regardless of whether they were treated with whole-abdominal radiation or no radiation.</li>

19769</ul>

19770</div>

19771</li>

19772</ul>

19773</div>

19774</section>

19775<section id="_1229">

19776<h3 id="_1229_toc">

19777Genetic Factors Predisposing to Renal Dysfunction</h3>

19778<div class="pdq-content-list">

19779<ul id="_2684">

19780<li>

19781Many childhood survivors of Wilms tumor who develop chronic renal failure have syndromes accompanying <em class="gene-name">

19782WT1</em>

19783 mutations or deletions that predispose to renal disease.</li>

19784<li>

19785 Data from the National Wilms Tumor Study Group and the U.S. Renal Data System indicate that the 20-year cumulative incidence of end-stage renal disease is 74% in children with unilateral Wilms tumor and Denys-Drash syndrome, 36% for those with WAGR (Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, and range of developmental delays) syndrome, 7% for male patients with genitourinary anomalies, and 0.6% for patients with none of these conditions.[<a href="#cit/section_12.31">

1978631</a>

19787]</li>

19788<li>

19789 For patients with bilateral Wilms tumors, the incidence of end-stage renal disease is 50% for Denys-Drash syndrome, 90% for WAGR syndrome, 25% for genitourinary anomaly, and 12% for others.[<a href="#cit/section_12.31">

1979031</a>

19791,<a href="#cit/section_12.32">

1979232</a>

19793]</li>

19794<li>

19795 End-stage renal disease in patients with WAGR syndrome and genitourinary anomalies tended to occur relatively late, and often during or after adolescence.[<a href="#cit/section_12.31">

1979631</a>

19797]</li>

19798</ul>

19799</div>

19800</section>

19801<section id="_1232">

19802<h3 id="_1232_toc">

19803Therapy-Related Bladder Complications</h3>

19804<p id="_269" tabindex="-1">

19805Pelvic or central nervous system surgery, alkylator-containing chemotherapy such as cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide, pelvic radiation therapy, and certain spinal and genitourinary surgical procedures have been associated with urinary bladder late effects, as follows:[<a href="#cit/section_12.33">

1980633</a>

19807]</p>

19808<section id="_2685">

19809<h4 id="_2685_toc">

19810Chemotherapy</h4>

19811<div class="pdq-content-list">

19812<ul id="_2686">

19813<li>

19814 The oxazaphosphorine alkylating agents (cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide) and radiation therapy exposing the bladder have been implicated in the development of hemorrhagic cystitis.</li>

19815<li>

19816 Chemotherapy-associated hemorrhagic cystitis presents as an acute toxicity and appears to be a rare persistent effect among clinically well characterized long-term survivor cohorts.[<a href="#cit/section_12.34">

1981734</a>

19818,<a href="#cit/section_12.35">

1981935</a>

19820]</li>

19821<li>

19822In a study of 6,119 children treated between 1986 and 2010 (mean age, 12.2 years &#177; 6.3 standard deviation), 1.6% of patients (n = 97) developed hemorrhagic cystitis (manifesting at mean 2.7 months after transplant induction therapy and mean 12.4 months after pelvic radiation), most of whom (75%) had severity scores of II or III (scale, I&#8211;IV).[<a href="#cit/section_12.36">

1982336</a>

19824]<div class="pdq-content-list">

19825<ul id="_2687" class="list-dash">

19826<li>

19827 Patients with radiological evidence of renal or bladder calculi or tumors that invaded the bladder wall were excluded from the study. </li>

19828<li>

19829Older age, previous bone marrow or peripheral stem cell transplantation, and BK virus in the urine were risk factors for hemorrhagic cystitis and were associated with a higher severity score.</li>

19830</ul>

19831</div>

19832</li>

19833<li>

19834Previous exposure to cyclophosphamide has been linked to risk of bladder carcinoma. An excess prevalence of bladder tumors has also been observed in survivors of specific diagnostic types (e.g., heritable retinoblastoma) supporting the contribution of genetic factors in the development of subsequent neoplasms.[<a href="#cit/section_12.37">

1983537</a>

19836,<a href="#cit/section_12.38">

1983738</a>

19838]</li>

19839</ul>

19840</div>

19841</section>

19842<section id="_2688">

19843<h4 id="_2688_toc">

19844Radiation therapy</h4>

19845<div class="pdq-content-list">

19846<ul id="_2689">

19847<li>

19848 Pelvic radiation therapy is also associated with an increased risk of hemorrhagic cystitis that may be either acute or chronic in presentation.</li>

19849<li>

19850 The risk of radiation-induced hemorrhagic cystitis is greatest among survivors treated with radiation doses of more than 30 Gy to the whole bladder or more than 60 Gy to a portion of the bladder.[<a href="#cit/section_12.33">

1985133</a>

19852]</li>

19853<li>

19854 Long-term bladder fibrosis and contracture may result as sequelae from hemorrhagic cystitis or radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_12.33">

1985533</a>

19856]</li>

19857</ul>

19858</div>

19859</section>

19860<section id="_2690">

19861<h4 id="_2690_toc">

19862Surgery</h4>

19863<div class="pdq-content-list">

19864<ul id="_2691">

19865<li>

19866 Surgical procedures involving the lower genitourinary tract have the potential to impair normal function of the bladder and normal voiding mechanisms.</li>

19867<li>

19868Any cancer therapy or tumor infiltration that disrupts innervation of the bladder can have deleterious effects on bladder function that may manifest as impaired bladder storage, inability to void, and/or incontinence.</li>

19869<li>

19870Children who have undergone ileal enterocystoplasty for bladder augmentation are at risk of developing a vitamin B<sub>

1987112</sub>

19872 deficiency. Serum B<sub>

1987312</sub>

19874 levels decrease over time after the procedure, with the greatest risk occurring 7 years postoperatively.[<a href="#cit/section_12.39">

1987539</a>

19876]</li>

19877</ul>

19878</div>

19879</section>

19880</section>

19881<section id="_2163">

19882<h3 id="_2163_toc">

19883Kidney Transplant</h3>

19884<p id="_2164" tabindex="-1">

19885In a study of solid organ transplants in 13,318 survivors in the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study, 71 survivors had end-stage kidney disease that warranted kidney transplants, 50 of whom received a kidney transplant.[<a href="#cit/section_12.40">

1988640</a>

19887]</p>

19888<div class="pdq-content-list">

19889<ul id="_2692">

19890<li>

19891 At 35 years after cancer diagnosis, the cumulative incidence of a kidney transplant was 0.39%, and the cumulative incidence of being placed on the waiting list or receiving a kidney was 0.54%.</li>

19892<li>

19893 Exposure to ifosfamide and receiving TBI were associated with the highest hazard ratio for being placed on the waiting list or receiving a kidney transplant.</li>

19894<li>

19895 The 5-year survival rate from the time of kidney transplant was 93.5%, which is similar to that of the general population in the same age range.</li>

19896</ul>

19897</div>

19898</section>

19899<p id="_1733" tabindex="-1">

19900<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_376">

19901Table 21</a>

19902 summarizes kidney and bladder late effects and the related health screenings.</p>

19903<table id="_376" class="table-default expandable-container">

19904<caption>

19905Table 21. Kidney and Bladder Late Effects<span class="sup">

19906a</span>

19907</caption>

19908<colgroup>

19909<col width="33.33%">

19910<col width="33.33%">

19911<col width="33.33%">

19912</colgroup>

19914<tr>

19915<th>

19916Predisposing Therapy</th>

19917<th>

19918Renal/Genitourinary Effects</th>

19919<th>

19920Health Screening</th>

19921</tr>

19922</THead>

19923<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

19924<tr>

19925<td colspan="3">

19926BUN = blood urea nitrogen; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; RBC/HFP = red blood cells per high-field power (microscopic exam).</td>

19927</tr>

19928<tr>

19929<td colspan="3">

19930<span class="sup">

19931a</span>

19932Adapted from the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

19933Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

19934.</td>

19935</tr>

19936</TFoot>

19937<tbody>

19938<tr>

19939<td rowspan="5">

19940Cisplatin/carboplatin;

19941ifosfamide; calcineurin inhibitors

19942 </td>

19943<td rowspan="5">

19944Renal toxicity (glomerular injury, tubular injury [renal tubular acidosis], Fanconi syndrome, hypophosphatemic rickets)

19945</td>

19946<td>

19947Blood pressure

19948

19949

19950</td>

19951</tr>

19952<tr>

19953<td>

19954BUN, Creatinine, Na, K, Cl, CO<sub>

199552</sub>

19956, Ca, Mg, PO<sub>

199574</sub>

19958 levels</td>

19959</tr>

19960<tr>

19961<td>

19962Urinalysis</td>

19963</tr>

19964<tr>

19965<td>

19966Electrolyte supplements for patients with persistent electrolyte wasting</td>

19967</tr>

19968<tr>

19969<td>

19970Nephrology consultation for patients with hypertension, proteinuria, or progressive renal insufficiency</td>

19971</tr>

19972<tr>

19973<td rowspan="4">

19974Methotrexate;

19975radiation exposing kidneys/urinary tract

19976</td>

19977<td rowspan="4">

19978Renal toxicity (renal insufficiency, hypertension)</td>

19979<td>

19980Blood pressure

19981

19982</td>

19983</tr>

19984<tr>

19985<td>

19986BUN, Creatinine, Na, K, Cl, CO<sub>

199872</sub>

19988, Ca, Mg, PO<sub>

199894</sub>

19990 levels</td>

19991</tr>

19992<tr>

19993<td>

19994Urinalysis

19995</td>

19996</tr>

19997<tr>

19998<td>

19999Nephrology consultation for patients with hypertension, proteinuria, or progressive renal insufficiency</td>

20000</tr>

20001<tr>

20002<td rowspan="6">

20003Nephrectomy </td>

20004<td rowspan="6">

20005Renal toxicity (proteinuria, hyperfiltration, renal insufficiency)</td>

20006<td>

20007Blood pressure

20008

20009

20010</td>

20011</tr>

20012<tr>

20013<td>

20014BUN, Creatinine, Na, K, Cl, CO<sub>

200152</sub>

20016, Ca, Mg, PO<sub>

200174</sub>

20018 levels</td>

20019</tr>

20020<tr>

20021<td>

20022Urinalysis</td>

20023</tr>

20024<tr>

20025<td>

20026Discuss contact sports, bicycle safety (e.g., avoiding handlebar injuries), and proper use of seatbelts (i.e., wearing lap belts around hips, not waist)</td>

20027</tr>

20028<tr>

20029<td>

20030Counsel to use NSAIDs with caution</td>

20031</tr>

20032<tr>

20033<td>

20034Nephrology consultation for patients with hypertension,

20035proteinuria, or progressive renal insufficiency</td>

20036</tr>

20037<tr>

20038<td>

20039Nephrectomy;

20040pelvic surgery;

20041cystectomy

20042</td>

20043<td>

20044Hydrocele </td>

20045<td>

20046Testicular exam</td>

20047</tr>

20048<tr>

20049<td rowspan="2">

20050Cystectomy </td>

20051<td rowspan="2">

20052Cystectomy-related complications (chronic urinary tract infections, renal dysfunction, vesicoureteral reflux, hydronephrosis, reservoir calculi, spontaneous neobladder perforation, vitamin B<sub>

2005312</sub>

20054/folate/carotene

20055deficiency [patients with ileal enterocystoplasty only])</td>

20056<td>

20057Urology evaluation

20058</td>

20059</tr>

20060<tr>

20061<td>

20062Vitamin B<sub>

2006312</sub>

20064 level

20065</td>

20066</tr>

20067<tr>

20068<td rowspan="3">

20069Pelvic surgery;

20070cystectomy </td>

20071<td rowspan="3">

20072Urinary incontinence;

20073urinary tract obstruction

20074</td>

20075<td>

20076History: hematuria, urinary urgency/frequency, urinary incontinence/retention, dysuria, nocturia, abnormal urinary stream</td>

20077</tr>

20078<tr>

20079<td>

20080Counsel regarding adequate fluid intake, regular voiding,

20081seeking medical attention for symptoms of voiding dysfunction or urinary tract infection, compliance with recommended bladder catheterization regimen</td>

20082</tr>

20083<tr>

20084<td>

20085Urologic consultation for patients with dysfunctional voiding or recurrent urinary tract infections</td>

20086</tr>

20087<tr>

20088<td rowspan="5">

20089Cyclophosphamide/Ifosfamide;

20090radiation exposing bladder/urinary tract

20091</td>

20092<td rowspan="5">

20093Bladder toxicity (hemorrhagic cystitis, bladder fibrosis, dysfunctional voiding, vesicoureteral reflux, hydronephrosis)</td>

20094<td>

20095History: hematuria, urinary urgency/frequency, urinary incontinence/retention, dysuria, nocturia, abnormal urinary stream

20096</td>

20097</tr>

20098<tr>

20099<td>

20100Urinalysis

20101</td>

20102</tr>

20103<tr>

20104<td>

20105Urine culture, spot urine calcium/creatinine ratio, and

20106ultrasound of kidneys and bladder for patients with microscopic

20107hematuria (defined as &#8805;5 RBC/HFP on at least 2 occasions)</td>

20108</tr>

20109<tr>

20110<td>

20111Nephrology or urology referral for patients with culture-negative

20112microscopic hematuria AND abnormal ultrasound and/or abnormal calcium/creatinine ratio</td>

20113</tr>

20114<tr>

20115<td>

20116Urology referral for patients with culture negative macroscopic hematuria</td>

20117</tr>

20118</tbody>

20119</table>

20120<p id="_445" tabindex="-1">

20121For urinary late effects information, including risk factors, evaluation, and health counseling, see the <a href="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/" title="http://www.survivorshipguidelines.org/">

20122Children's Oncology Group Long-Term Follow-Up Guidelines for Survivors of Childhood, Adolescent, and Young Adult Cancers</a>

20123.</p>

20124<h6 do-not-show="toc">

20125References</h6>

20126<ol>

20127<li id="section_12.1">

20128Shnorhavorian M, Friedman DL, Koyle MA: Genitourinary long-term outcomes for childhood cancer survivors. Curr Urol Rep 10 (2): 134-7, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19239818&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19239818&amp;dopt=Abstract">

20129[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

20130</li>

20131<li id="section_12.2">

20132Green DM: Evaluation of renal function after successful treatment for unilateral, non-syndromic Wilms tumor. 20289

20291

20292

20293

20294 <section id="_143">

20295

20296 <h2>

20297Changes to This Summary (09/11/2023)</h2>

20298

20299 <div id="_section_143" class="pdq-sections">

20300<p id="_144" tabindex="-1">

20301The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as new information becomes available. This section describes the latest changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

20302<p id="_3077" tabindex="-1">

20303<strong>

20304<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1360">

20305Late Effects of the Cardiovascular System</a>

20306</strong>

20307</p>

20308<p id="_3079" tabindex="-1">

20309Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2405">

20310text</a>

20311 to state that based on available evidence about peripartum cardiomyopathy, the International Guideline Harmonization Group assessed that cardiomyopathy surveillance is reasonable before pregnancy or in the first trimester for female survivors of childhood, adolescent, and young adult cancer who are at moderate and high risk because they were treated with anthracyclines or chest radiation therapy.</p>

20312<p id="_3078" tabindex="-1">

20313<strong>

20314<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_9">

20315Late Effects of the Central Nervous System (CNS)</a>

20316</strong>

20317</p>

20318<p id="_3080" tabindex="-1">

20319Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1750">

20320text</a>

20321 about the results of the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital TOTAL XVI trial that evaluated whether a higher dose of pegaspargase and early intensification of triple intrathecal therapy (ITT; methotrexate, hydrocortisone, and cytarabine) would improve systemic and CNS control in children with newly diagnosed acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and whether it affected neurocognitive function (cited Jacola et al. as reference 73).</p>

20322<p id="_3081" tabindex="-1">

20323Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1711">

20324neuroblastoma</a>

20325 as a cancer type that is associated with neurocognitive abnormalities in survivors. Also added text about the results of a Children's Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS) study that compared cognitive outcomes among 837 survivors of neuroblastoma and a sibling cohort using the CCSS Neurocognitive Questionnaire (cited Hesko et al. as reference 90).</p>

20326<p id="_3082" tabindex="-1">

20327Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1055">

20328text</a>

20329 about the results of a population-based, cross-sectional, survivorship study that found that 28% of adolescent and young adult survivors of sarcoma experienced impaired social functioning (cited Drabbe et al. as reference 120).</p>

20330<p id="_3083" tabindex="-1">

20331Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2995">

20332Major psychiatric disorders</a>

20333 as a new subsection.</p>

20334<p id="_3084" tabindex="-1">

20335Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1056">

20336text</a>

20337 to state that in a cohort of 5,121 childhood and adolescent cancer survivors, the incidence of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) was 0.59%. Compared with controls, survivors showed a 6.10-fold elevated risk of being diagnosed with PTSD. Brain cancer survivors had the highest risk of all cancer diagnoses for PTSD (cited Hsu et al. as reference 129).</p>

20338<p id="_3085" tabindex="-1">

20339<strong>

20340<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_30">

20341Late Effects of the Digestive System</a>

20342</strong>

20343</p>

20344<p id="_3095" tabindex="-1">

20345Added Patni et al. as <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1240">

20346reference 12</a>

20347.</p>

20348<p id="_3086" tabindex="-1">

20349Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2771">

20350text</a>

20351 to state that in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort, survivors who received radiation therapy that potentially exposed the oral cavity were more likely to report at least one dental health problem and at least one soft tissue abnormality after controlling for socioeconomic factors, age at last follow-up and diagnosis, other treatment exposures, and access to dental services.</p>

20352<p id="_3087" tabindex="-1">

20353Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2550">

20354text</a>

20355 to state that in the St. Jude Lifetime Cohort, survivors who received classic alkylating agents or anthracycline antibiotics were more likely to report at least one dental health problem after controlling for socioeconomic factors, age at last follow-up and diagnosis, other treatment exposures, and access to dental services.</p>

20356<p id="_3088" tabindex="-1">

20357Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2553">

20358text</a>

20359 about the results of a Pediatric Normal Tissue Effects in the Clinic initiative that reported on late effects for childhood cancer survivors who were treated with radiation therapy for head and neck cancers (cited Milgrom et al. as reference 23).</p>

20360<p id="_3089" tabindex="-1">

20361Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2568">

20362text</a>

20363 about the results of a CCSS study that evaluated the long-term morbidity among unilateral, nonsyndromic Wilms tumor survivors according to conventional treatment regimens (cited Weil et al. as reference 40).</p>

20364<p id="_3090" tabindex="-1">

20365Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2568">

20366text</a>

20367 about the results of a CCSS study that evaluated the prevalence of esophageal stricture and identified associated clinical and treatment risk factors among 17,121 5-year childhood cancer survivors and 3,400 siblings (cited Asdahl et al. as reference 43).</p>

20368<p id="_3073" tabindex="-1">

20369<strong>

20370<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_184">

20371Late Effects of the Immune System</a>

20372</strong>

20373</p>

20374<p id="_3074" tabindex="-1">

20375Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2977">

20376Infection Risks</a>

20377 as a new subsection.</p>

20378<p id="_3075" tabindex="-1">

20379<strong>

20380<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_92">

20381Late Effects of the Musculoskeletal System</a>

20382</strong>

20383</p>

20384<p id="_3091" tabindex="-1">

20385Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1917">

20386text</a>

20387 about the results of a study that reported bone mineral density deficits in long-term survivors of childhood brain tumors (cited Kvammen et al. as reference 48).</p>

20388<p id="_3092" tabindex="-1">

20389Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_1917">

20390text</a>

20391 about the results of a DCOG-LATER study that evaluated the risk factors for low and very low bone mineral density, any fractures, and vertebral fractures with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry in 3,996 5-year survivors of childhood cancer (cited van Atteveld et al. as reference 49).</p>

20392<p id="_3093" tabindex="-1">

20393Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_3033">

20394text</a>

20395 about the results of a CCSS investigation that evaluated risk factors for and outcomes of late amputation in survivors treated for lower extremity sarcomas (cited Geiger et al. as reference 94).</p>

20396<p id="_3076" tabindex="-1">

20397<strong>

20398<a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_20">

20399Late Effects of the Special Senses</a>

20400</strong>

20401</p>

20402<p id="_3094" tabindex="-1">

20403Added <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_2932">

20404text</a>

20405 to state that varying doses of cisplatin were used to treat childhood cancer survivors in a follow-up study. Of those who received cisplatin, the median cumulative dose was 400 mg/m<span class="sup">

204062</span>

20407.</p>

20408<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

20409This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

20410PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

20411, which is

20412editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

20413the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

20414information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

20415maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

20416About This PDQ Summary</a>

20417 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

20418PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

20419 pages.

20420</p>

20421</div>

20422

20423 </section>

20424

20425

20426

20427 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

20428

20429 <h2>

20430About This PDQ Summary</h2>

20431

20432 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

20433<section id="_AboutThis_2">

20434<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

20435Purpose of This Summary</h3>

20436<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

20437This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the late effects of treatment for childhood cancer. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

20438</section>

20439<section id="_AboutThis_4">

20440<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

20441Reviewers and Updates</h3>

20442<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

20443This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/pediatric-treatment">

20444PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board</a>

20445, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

20446<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

20447 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

20448<div class="pdq-content-list">

20449<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

20450<li>

20451be discussed at a meeting,</li>

20452<li>

20453be cited with text, or</li>

20454<li>

20455replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

20456</ul>

20457</div>

20458<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

20459Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

20460<p id="" tabindex="-1">

20461The lead reviewers for Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer are:</p>

20462<div class="pdq-content-list">

20463<ul id="">

20464<li>

20465Sally J. Cohen-Cutler, MD, MS (Children's Hospital of Philadelphia)</li>

20466<li>

20467Louis S. Constine, MD (James P. Wilmot Cancer Center at University of Rochester Medical Center)</li>

20468<li>

20469Melissa Maria Hudson, MD (St. Jude Children's Research Hospital)</li>

20470<li>

20471Nita Louise Seibel, MD (National Cancer Institute)</li>

20472<li>

20473Emily S. Tonorezos, MD, MPH (National Cancer Institute)</li>

20474</ul>

20475</div>

20476<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

20477Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

20478Email Us</a>

20479. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

20480</section>

20481<section id="_AboutThis_10">

20482<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

20483Levels of Evidence</h3>

20484<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

20485Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/treatment">

20486formal evidence ranking system</a>

20487 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

20488</section>

20489<section id="_AboutThis_12">

20490<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

20491Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

20492<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

20493PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

20494<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

20495The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

20496<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

20497PDQ&#174; Pediatric Treatment Editorial Board. PDQ Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq">

20498https://www.cancer.gov/types/childhood-cancers/late-effects-hp-pdq</a>

20499. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389273]</p>

20500<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

20501Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

20502Visuals Online</a>

20503, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

20504

20505</p>

20506</section>

20507<section id="_AboutThis_17">

20508<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

20509Disclaimer</h3>

20510<p id="_AboutThis_18" tabindex="-1">

20511Based on the strength of the available evidence, treatment options may be described as either &#8220;standard&#8221; or &#8220;under clinical evaluation.&#8221; These classifications should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

20512Managing Cancer Care</a>

20513 page.</p>

20514</section>

20515<section id="_AboutThis_20">

20516<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

20517Contact Us</h3>

20518<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

20519More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

20520Contact Us for Help</a>

20521 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

20522Email Us</a>

20523.</p>

20524</section>
